Also The middle of a house; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) meaning the saAHap [i. e. court] of the middle of a house [and of a mosque, &c.]: (TA:) [and also a hall: for] it is thus called whether without, or with, a roof. (Kull, voce bayotN.) And The saAHap [or spacious vacant part] of the middle of a desert; and of an elevated and plain, or hard and elevated, tract; and of a wide space of low, or depressed, ground: pl. SuHuwnN, the only pl. form. (TA.) A wide part of a desert: so in the saying, sironaA fiI SaHoni AlfalaApi [We journeyed in the wide part of the desert]. (Mṣb.) And A level, or plain, tract of ground. (TA.) And An acclivity (sanad) of a valley, in which is some elevation above [other] elevated ground, as though supported [by the latter]; and in like manner, of a mountain, and of a hill such as is termed Oakamap; the SuHuwn of the ground being the dufuwf [i. e. banks, or acclivities,] thereof: it is bare, and such as flows [with rain]; and is not thus called unless bare of everything, and even: and it means also an even tract of ground like the area of the place in which dates are put to dry. (TA.)
[Hence,] one says, jaraI Ald-amoEu EalaI SaHonaIo wajonatayohi ‡ [The tears ran upon the middle of each of his cheek-balls]. (TA.)
Also A gift. (TA. [See 1, first sentence.])
SaHonapN; pl. SaHanaAtN: see 1.
Also A bead (xarazapN) with which women fascinate men, and restrain them, or withhold them from other women. (Lḥ, TA.)

entry.sense: SuHonapN A clear space of a [stony tract such as is called] Har-ap. (Ḳ.)

SiHonaMCN, (Ṣ, and so accord. to some copies of the Ḳ,) and SaHonaMCN, (thus also accord. to some copies of the Ḳ,) and with the short alif, [app. SiHonFI and SaHonFI,] (Ṣ, and so accord. to some copies of the Ḳ,) or SiHonaApN and SaHonaApN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or thus also, (accord. to some copies of the Ḳ,) or thus, and also SiHonaMCapN and SaHonaMCapN, (accord. to other copies of the Ḳ,) or when with p having a more special signification, [being a n. of un., and, if so, accord. to a general rule, with tenween when without p, as is said to be the case in the TA, on the authority of Az, accord. to whom, as is also there stated, the word is pluralized by the elision of the p,] (Ṣ,) A certain condiment, or seasoning, made of fish, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of small fish, which has the properties of exciting appetence, and rectifying the state of the stomach: (Ḳ:) or i. q. SiyrN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) i. e. what is called in Pers. maAhiI MwahN [jelly of salted fish]: (Mgh:) AZ is related to have said that SHnAp is Pers., meaning what the Arabs call Siyr: IAth says that Syr and SHnAp are both of them Pers. words. (TA.)

SaHuwnN A she-camel that has a habit of kicking: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and a kicking mare or horse: and a she-ass that kicks the he-ass with her hind leg whenever he comes near to her: or, as some say, a she-ass in which are whiteness and redness [app. meaning a wild she-ass]. (TA.)
miSoHanapN A vessel like the [bowls called] SaHofap (Ḳ, TA) and qaSoEpa. (TA.)

1. SaHaA, said of a day, [aor. yaSoHuw,] inf. n. SaHowN, It was, or became, cloudless: (TA:) and so OaSoHaI↓: (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA, but not in the CK:) [it is said that] SaHowN signifies the departing of the clouds: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) [but] Es-Sijistánee says that the vulgar think it to have this meaning, whereas it only means the dispersing of the clouds with the departing of the cold. (Mṣb, TA.) And OaSoHati↓ Als-amaMCu The sky became cloudless. (Ks, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA, but not in the CK.)

SaHowN signifies also ‡ The relinquishing of youthful folly, and amorous dalliance, and of what is vain, or futile. (Ḳ, TA.) Hence the saying of a poet,
SaHaA Alqalobu Eano salomaI waOaqoSara baATiluho
‡ [The heart relinquished, or has relinquished, youthful folly and amorousness by becoming rid of Selmà, and its vain, or futile, occupation ceased, or has ceased]. (TA.)
And one says, SaHati AlEaAcilapu † The censuring female relinquished censuring. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. ASHI: see 1, in four places.
OaSoHayonaA We became in a case of cloudlessness [of the sky or day]; (Mṣb, TA;) the sky became cloudless to us. (Ṣ.)
OaSoHayotuhu mino sukorihi [I recovered him, or roused him, from his intoxication], and mino nawomihi [from his sleep]. (TA.)
And sometimes UiSoHaMCN is used as meaning The act of rousing, and recalling to mindfulness, from a state of heedlessness, or inadvertence. (TA.)

entry.sense: SaHowN [an inf. n. used as an epithet, and therefore applicable to a fem. as well as a masc. noun, and to a dual and a pl. as well as a sing.], applied to a day, Cloudless; (Ḳ, TA;) as also SaAHK↓; (Ṣ, TA;) and muSoHK↓: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and (Ḳ) in the same sense applied to a sky; (Ks, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also muSoHiyapN↓, or, accord. to Ks, this is not allowable, but only SaHowN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) though one says of the sky OaSoHat. (Mṣb.)

SaHowapN A state [of freedom from intoxication, or] of sensibility, or mental perception. (TA voce sakorapN.) yuriydu Oano yaOoxucahaA bayona AlS-aHowapi waAls-akorapi [He desires to take it being in a state between that of sensibility and that of insensibility, or mental perception and inability thereof,] is a prov., applied to him who seeks a thing feigning ignorance while possessing knowledge. (TA.) [See also another ex. voce sakorapN.]
SaAHK: see SaHowN.
It is also said of one intoxicated [as meaning Recovering, or becoming free, from his intoxication; or ceasing to be intoxicated: see 1]. (Ṣ, TA.)

maSoHaApN is like masolaApN in meaning as well as in measure, [signifying A cause of freedom,] except that the former is from the intoxication of grief and the latter is from distress of mind and anxiety. (TA.)

miSoHaApN A sort of vessel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) used for drinking; (TA;) a TaAs [q. v.], or a jaAm [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) Aṣ says, “I know not of what it is:” (Ṣ, TA:) it is said to be of silver. (TA.) El-Aạshà speaks of wine being poured into it. (Ṣ, TA.) And one says wajohN kamiSoHaApi All-ujayoni [A face like the mSHAp of silver.] (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Sax-a AlOucuna, aor. _u {yaSoxuxu}, (Ṣ, A,* TA,) inf. n. Sax-N; (Ṣ, TA;) in a copy of the T, ASx-↓, inf. n. UiSoxaAxN; (TA;) It (a sound) deafened the ear by its vehemence. (Ṣ, A, TA.)
And Sax-ahu, aor. as above, He struck him on the ear and rendered it deaf. (A.)
And Sax-aniI fulaAnN biEaZiymapK ‡ Such a one accused me of a great crime, and calumniated me. (A, TA.)
And ramaAhu faSax-ahu, inf. n. as above, He shot, or cast, at him, and caused him extreme pain: or, as some say, killed him. (JK.)

And Sax-a AlguraAbu The crow pierced with his beak into the gall on the back of a camel: (Ḳ,* TA:) or AlguraAbu yaSux-u biminoqaArihi fiI dabarapi AlbaEiyri the crow pierces with his beak into the gall on the back of the camel. (JK.)

Sax-N also signifies The striking with something hard, (L, Ḳ,) as a staff, (L,) upon something solid, (L, Ḳ,) and with iron upon iron. (L.) [Accord. to the TḲ, one says, Sax-a AlHadiyda EalaI AlS-axorapi, meaning Darabahu bihaA: but I think that the right reading is biAlHadiydi; and the meaning, He struck with the iron upon the mass of rock.]

Sax-a AlHajaru, (A,) and Sax-ati AlS-axorapu and the like, (L,) inf. n. SaxiyxN (A, L, Ḳ) and Sax-N, (L, Ḳ,) The stone, (A,) and the mass of rock, (L, Ḳ,) caused a sound to be heard (A, L, Ḳ) on its being struck (A, L) with a stone. (L.)
And Sax-a liHadiyvihi He listened to his narration, or discourse. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see above {1}, first sentence.
Sax-apN A sound produced by the striking of a mass of rock with a stone. (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ.)
SaAx-apN A cry that deafens by its vehemence. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also A calamity, or misfortune: (Ḳ:) or a severe calamity or misfortune: and hence the resurrection is called AlS-aAx-apu. (A, TA.)

1. Saxiba, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaSoxabu}, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. SaxabN, (Ṣ,* A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) of which saxabN is a syn., of the dial. of Rabee'ah, but [said to be] a bad word, (TA,) He clamoured; or raised a loud, or vehement, cry, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or a confusion, or mixture, of cries or shouts or noises; (Ṣ, A, TA;) accord. to some, in altercation, or contention: (TA:) or he raised much clamour, and confusion of cries or shouts or noises. (Mṣb.)

3. SAxbhu, (A, MA,) inf. n. muSaAxabapN, (A,) [He raised a clamour, or confused noise, with him;] he spoke with him with a loud voice or noise or clamour: he clamoured with, or at, or against, him, with anger. (MA.)
6: see the next paragraph {8}.

8. ASTxbwA (Ṣ,* A, TA) and tSAxbw↓ (A, Ḳ, TA) They clamoured; or raised loud, or vehement, cries, or clamours, [or confused noises,] and beat one another, or contended together in beating or in fight. (Ḳ, TA.) A poet says,
Uin-a AlD-afaAdiEa fiI AlgudoraAni taSoTaxibu
[Verily the frogs make a loud and confused croaking in the pools of water left by the torrents]. (Ṣ.) And one says, samiEotu QSoTixaAba AlT-ayori (A, Ḳ *) i. e. [I heard] the confused cries, or voices, of the birds. (Ḳ. [See also SaxabN.])
And [hence,] AiSoTaxabato OamowaAju AlwaAdiI ‡ [The waves of the valley, or torrent-bed, flowing with water, dashed together, making a loud and confused sound]. (A.)
SaxabN inf. n. of 1: (Mṣb, TA:) [used as a simple subst., its pl. is OaSoxaAbN:] one says, samiEotu OaSoxaAba AlT-ayori I heard the [confused] cries, or voices, of the birds. (Mṣb. [See also 8.])

SaxibN (A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Sax-aAbN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SaxobaAnu↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SaxuwbN↓ (Ḳ) and SaAxibN↓ (A, Mṣb) are epithets from Saxiba; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) all except the last signifying One who clamours, or raises confused cries or shouts or noises, vehemently, or much; (TA;) [the last having a similar, but not intensive, signification, i. e. clamouring,, &c.:] and the first, though masc., is applied by the poet Usámeh El-Hudhalee to a female singer considered as a person (XaxoS [and meaning in this instance loud of voice]); for an epithet of the measure faEilN applied to a woman (AimoraOapN) is not known in the language: (L, TA:) the [proper] fem. epithet is SaxibapN and Sax-aAbapN↓ (Ḳ) and SaxobaI↓ (Mṣb) and SaxuwbN↓ (Ḳ, TA, in the CK [erroneously] SaxuwbapN) and Suxub-apN↓: (Ḳ:) the pl. of SaxobaAnu is SuxobaAnN↓; (Kr, Ḳ;) [and the pl. of SaxuwbN is SuxubN↓, like SuburN pl. of SabuwrN:] the hypocrites are described in a trad. as SuxubN biAln-ahaAri xuXubN biAll-ayoli [expl. voce xaXabN], meaning clamorous and contentious. (TA.)
[Hence,] HimaArN Saxibu AlX-awaAribi An ass that makes his braying to reciprocate [loudly] in the ducts of his throat; (Ḳ;) that brays vehemently. (Ṣ in art. Xrb, q. v.)
And EuwdN Saxibu AlOawotaAri ‡ [A lute of which the chords send forth loud sounds]. (A, TA.)

And maMCN Saxibu AlMciI-i (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ) and muSoTaxibu↓ AlMciI-i (Ḳ) ‡ Water of which the waves send forth a [loud] sound, (Ṣ, TA,) or are agitated, (Ḳ,) or dash together. (TA.) See also what next follows.

hom.sense: EayonN SaxobapN, (Ḳ, TA,) with the x quiescent, (TA,) or SaxibapN↓, (so in a copy of the A,) ‡ A spring, or fountain, that is agitated [app. so as to make a confused sound] in estuating. (A, Ḳ, TA.)
And SaxobapN signifies also The [kind of bead (xarazap), used for captivating, or fascinating, called] EaTofap: (TA:) or a bead (xarazap) used [as a charm] in [cases of] love and hatred. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: Suxub-apN: see SaxibN.
Sax-aAbN, and its fem. Sax-aAbapN: see SaxibN.
SaAxibN: see SaxibN.
muSoTaxibN: see SaxibN.

hom.sense: 1. Saxida Aln-ahaAru, aor. _a {yaSoxadu}, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. SaxadN (Ṣ, L) and SaxadaAnN, (L,) The day was, or became, intensely hot. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) And Saxida AlHar-u, inf. n. SaxadaAnN, The heat was, or became, intense; as also ASxd↓, inf. n. UiSoxaAdN. (L.)

Saxadatohu AlX-amosu, aor. _a {yaSoxadu}, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. SaxodN, (Ṣ, L,) The sun smote him, (Ṣ, L,) and burned him: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or was, or became, hot upon him. (L.) And Saxadahu AlHar-u The heat pained his brain. (A.)
Saxada said of the [bird called] Surad, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaSoxadu}, inf. n. SaxodN and SaxiydN, (L,) It cried: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) and so Saxadat said of the haAmap [or owl]. (A, L.)
Saxada Uilayohi, (L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaSoxadu}, (L,) inf. n. SuxuwdN, He listened to him, (L, Ḳ,) and inclined to him. (L.)

entry.sense: 4. ASxd He (a man, TA) entered upon [a time of] heat. (Ḳ.)
Also, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and ASTxd↓, (A,) It (a chameleon) warmed itself with the heat of the sun; basked in the sun. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)
See also 1.
8: see 4. [And see also muSoTaxidN, below.]
SuxodN a dial. var. of suxodN: meaning Blood and water in the saAbiyaMC [or membrane enclosing the fœtus in the womb]:
and i. q. rahalN: [see suxodN:]
and Yellowness in the face. (L.)
SaxodaAnN: see what next follows.

yawomN SaxadaAnN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and SaxodaAnN↓ (Th, L, Ḳ) and SayoxuwdN↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ [written by Freytag, as from the Ṣ, SaxuwdN]) and SaAxidN↓ and SayoxadN↓ (L) A day intensely hot. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) And layolapN SaxadaAnapN A night intensely hot. (L.) And haAjirapN SayoxuwdN↓ A midday intensely hot. (A.)

[SaxadaAnN is originally an inf. n. Hence] one says, Oatayotuhu fiI SaxadaAni AlHar-i I came to him during the intenseness of the heat: (L:) and one says also, Atyth fiI maSaAxidi↓ AlHar-i I came to him in the midday-intensities of the heat; (TA;) for maSaAxidu is pl. of maSoxadapN↓ signifying the midday-intensity of heat; (Ḳ, TA;) as also SaAxidapN↓: (L, TA:) and Atyth fiI SayaAxiydi↓ AlHar-i [meaning the same; or I came to him during the intensities of the heat]: (TA:) and ramaAniI AlHar-u biSayaAxiydihi↓ waAlbarodu biSanaAdiydihi [The heat smote me with its intensities, and the cold with its vehemencies]. (A.)

hom.sense: SaAxidN Intense heat. (L.)
See also SaxadaAnN.
[Also Crying, as a Surad and as an owl.] One says haAmN SawaAxidu [in which the latter word is pl. of the fem. SaAxidapN] Owls hooting. (A.)
And Listening, and inclining, to one. (L.)

waAHidN qaAHidN SaAxidN [the second word here written in the TA and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ faAxidN, but it is said in the TA in art. qHd, on the authority of the Ḳ, to be correctly with q,] means SunobuwrN, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. Single, or solitary, and weak: or i. q. daAhiyapN [i. e. very cunning, or very intelligent or sagacious, and crafty: but this meaning I think improbable]. (TA. [See also art. qHd.])

entry.sense: SayoxadN: see SaxadaAnN.

Also AlS-ayoxadu, (L, Ḳ,) or Sayoxadu AlX-amosi, (A,) The rays (Eayon) of the sun: (A, L, Ḳ:) so called because of the heat thereof. (L.) One says, caAba Sayoxadu AlX-amosi [The rays of the sun became intensely hot], (A,) and AisotacaAba AlS-ayoxadu [which means the same]. (L.)
SaAxidapN: see SaxadaAnN.
SayoxaAdN: see the next paragraph, in two places.
SayoxuwdN; and its pl. SayaAxiydu: see SaxadaAnN, in four places.

SaxorapN SayoxuwdN A hard rock which becomes intensely hot when the sun shines fiercely upon it: (L:) or [simply] a hard rock; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also SayoxaAdN↓: (Ḳ:) or a solid, firm, and strong, rock; and so SayoxaAdN↓: (TA:) or a smooth and hard rock, that cannot be moved from its place, and upon which iron has not effect: and a great rock, which nothing can raise, and upon which neither a pickaxe nor any other thing has effect: (L:) or a rock upon which the pickaxe has no effect: (A:) pl. as above. (L.)
SayoxaduwnN Hardness (Ḳ, TA) and strength. (TA.)
muSoTaxidN A chameleon standing erect, towards the sun; [app. on a branch;] as also muSoTaximN. (L. [See also 4.])
2. taSoxiyrN [inf. n. of Sax-ara] i, q. tasoxiyrN. (Ḳ.)

SaxorN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and SaxarN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter on the authority of Yaạḳoob, (Ṣ,) thus sometimes pronounced, (Mṣb,) Rocks; or great masses of stone: (Ṣ:) or great masses of hard stone: (A, Ḳ:) and SaxorapN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and SaxarapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) [are the ns. un., signifying] one thereof, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or these have a more special signification [as meaning a rock and a mass of rock]: (Mṣb:) pl. SuxuwrN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SuxuwrapN (A, Ṣgh, L) and [of SaxorapN and SaxarapN] SaxaraAtN. (Mṣb, Ḳ. [In the latter, SaxorN and SaxarN, as well as SuxuwrN and SaxaraAtN, are improperly termed pls. of Sxrp.]) By Saxorap in the Ḳur xxxi. 15 is meant a Sxrp that is beneath the ground. (Zj, TA.) And by the Saxorap mentioned in a trad. as being of, or from, Paradise is meant the Sxrp [or rock] of Jerusalem [in the centre of the building now called “the Dome of the Rock”]. (TA.)
SaxarN; n. un. SaxarapN: see SaxorN.
SaxirN A place abounding in rocks, or great masses of hard stone; as also muSoxirN↓. (Ḳ.)
SaxiyrN A certain plant. (Ḳ.) [Golius explains this as meaning Great, applied to a rock, or mass of stone; and so maSoxarN; on the authority of J: but neither of these do I find in the Ṣ.]
SaxiyrapN: see SaHiyrapN.
SaAxirN The sound of iron [striking] upon iron. (Ḳ.)
SaAxirapN A kind of earthen vessel, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) out of which one drinks. (A.)
OaSoxaru Alwajohi ‡ A hard-faced man; one having little shame. (A.)
muSoxirN; see SaxirN.
1. Saxamatohu AlX-amosu The sun smote, or hurt, or burned, him, or his face. (Ḳ.)
8. ASTxm, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and ASTHm, (Ḳ,) He stood erect, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and El-ʼAbbás adds, silent, as though he were angry. (TA.) [See also the part. n., below.]
SaxomaMCu A [stony tract such as is termed] Har-ap in which the plain is intermixed with the rugged. (Ḳ.)
muSoTaximN part. n. of 8. (Ṣ.) Applied to a chameleon, Standing erect, towards the sun; [app. on a branch;] as also muSoTaxidN. (L in art. Sxd.)

hom.sense: 1. Sad-a Eanohu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yaSodudu} (Ṣ, M, A) and _i {yaSodidu}, (M,) the latter only agreeable with analogy, (MF,) [but the former, which is the more common, explainable on the ground that wajohahu or the like is understood,] inf. n. SuduwdN (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and Sad-N, (M,) He turned away from, avoided, shunned, and left, him, or it; he was averse from him, or it; (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) he turned away his face from him [or it]: (Ḥam p. 89:) and Sad-ahu also,, aor. _u {yaSodudu}, inf. n. Sad-N, he forsook him, and turned away his face from him. (L.) One says, OaraI fiyka SuduwdFA [I see in thee aversion]. (A.) And laA Sad-a Eano caAka [lit. There is no evading that], meaning truly thou didst that. (Lḥ, M.) Sad-a Als-abiylu ‡ [The road, or way, turned aside] is said when a difficult road up a mountain, (A, L,) or some other obstacle, (A,) presents itself before thee, and thou leavest it, and takest another way. (A, L.)

And Sad-ahu Eanohu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yaSodudu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. Sad-N; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and ASd-hu↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiSodaAdN; (TA;) and Sd-dhu↓; (M;) He averted him; turned him, or sent him, away, or back; or caused him to return, or go back, or revert; from it: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) prevented, or hindered, him from doing it: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or did so by gentle means: and so Dad-ahu. (L in art. Dd.)

Sad-a, aor. _i {yaSodidu}, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) agreeably with analogy, (MF,) and this is the more approved form, (T,) and _u, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. SadiydN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and Sad-N, (M,) He cried out, vociferated, or raised a clamour, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) mino kacaA [at, or by reason of, such a thing]. (A.)
And Sad-a, aor. _i {yaSodidu}, (Lth, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. Sad-N, (M,) He laughed, mino kacaA [at such a thing]: (Lth, Mṣb:) or he laughed violently, or immoderately. (M.)
2. Sd-dhu Eanohu: see 1.

And Sd-d, (T, TA,) inf. n. taSodiydN; for which one says Sd-d, inf. n. taSodiyapN, (T, M,* Ḳ,* TA,) changing one of the d s into I, (T, Ḳ, TA,) like as one says qaS-ayotu OaZofaAriI, which is originally qaS-aSotu; (T, TA;) and Sad-aI biyadayohi; (TA in art. SdI;) He clapped with his hands; (T, M, Ḳ;) because, in the action of clapping the hands together, the Sad-, i. e. “face,” of one hand fronts that of the other; or, accord. to Aboo-Jaạfar Er-Rustamee, Alt-aSodiyapu is from SadFI meaning “a sound” [or “an echo”]; but the former derivation is the more probable: (TA:) [see art. SdI:] also he raised his voice, or called out, or cried out. (M, TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [viii. 35], wamaA kaAna SalaAtuhumo Einado Qlobayoti Uil-aA mukaMCF wataSodiyapF And their prayer at the House [of God] is nought but whistling, and clapping with the hands: (M,* TA:) meaning, they do thus instead of praying as they have been commanded to do. (Jel.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 3. SaAd-ahu waDaAd-ahu [He treated him with aversion and opposition]. (A.)

hom.sense: 4. ASd-hu Eanohu: see 1.

ASd- said of a wound, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiSodaAdN; (TA;)
as also Sd-d↓; (M, TA;) It contained, or generated, matter, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) such as is termed Sadiyd: (M, Mṣb:) or ran with such matter. (A.)

entry.sense: 5. tSd-d lahu, for which one says taSad-aI lh, [changing the last d into I, as in the case of Sad-ada, q. v.,] from AlS-adadu, meaning “the place, or part, that is before, in front, facing, or opposite;” (Az, L;) He addressed, or applied, or directed, himself, or his regard, or attention, or mind, to him, or it; [as though he set himself over against the object to which the verb relates:] and he asked him, or petitioned him, for a thing that he wanted: syn. taEar-aDa lahu; (L and Ḳ * in the present art., and Ṣ and M and Ḳ in art. SdI;) and Oaqobala Ealayohi; (L;) and taDar-aEa lahu: (M in art. SdI:) he inclined to him, or it: (L:) he raised his head towards it: (M in art. SdI, in explanation of tSd-I:) he raised his head and breast towards it, looking towards it, or regarding it: (TA in art. SdI, in explanation of tSd-I:) the object is one at which you raise your eyes, looking at it: (Ṣ in art. SdI, in explanation of tSd-I:) he applied, or gave, his whole attention to it, (meaning an affair,) having his mind unoccupied by other things; syn. tafar-aga lahu watabat-ala. (Mṣb.) One says also, tSd-I lilr-ad-i EalaI AlmuSan-ifi [He addressed, or applied, himself to reply against the author]. (TA in art. Hzb, &c.) And tSd-I lilomaEoruwfi waTalabahu He addressed himself, or applied himself, to obtain favour, or bounty; and sought it; syn. taEar-aDa lahu [and tabar-aI lh]. (Mṣb in art. ErD.) And Oanota lahu taSad-aI, [in the Ḳur, lxxx., 6,] originally tataSad-adu, (L,) and accord. to one reading taS-ad-aI, (Jel,) means To him thou addressest thyself, or directest thine attention, and inclinest; syn. tataEar-aDu lahu, (L,) and tuqobilu Ealayohi, (Zj,) and tamiylu Uilayohi; (L;) or tataEar-aDu lahu biQloUiqobaAli Ealayohi: (Bḍ:) or addressest thyself,, &c., and humblest thyself: (M in art. SdI: [in which, however, this explanation is not given with express reference to the above-cited phrase in the Ḳur:]) or it may signify thou seekest to bring thyself near to him, or to advance thyself in his favour; from AlS-adadu as signifying Alqurobu. (T.) [See also art. SdI.]
8. ASTd-t She (a woman) covered herself with a SidaAd [q. v.],. e. sitor. (Nawádir el-Aaráb, O, Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1. SadoSadapN The beating of the sieve with one's hand. (TA.)
Sado a Pers. word [app. used by the Arabs] signifying A hundred. (TA.)
Sad-N: see Sud-N, in four places.
Also The face, or front, of the hand. (TA.)

Sud-N (M, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Sad-N↓ (Ḳ) The side of a valley, (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or of a XiEob [i. e. the kind of water-course so called, or a ravine], and of a mountain where it forms a ravine, (M, L,) and ‡ of a road: (A:) pl. [of pauc.] OaSodaAdN and [of mult.] SuduwdN. (TA.) And Sad-N↓ (L) and SadadN↓ (M, L) signify [in like manner] A side; a lateral, or an adjacent, part, quarter, tract, or the like; syn. of the former jaAnibN, (L,) and of the latter naAHiyapN. (M, L.) AinoDam-a Ealayohimu AlS-ud-aAni [lit. The two sides of the road confined them] means ‡ they occupied the middle of the road. (A.) And AlS-ud-aAni signifies also ‡ The two edges, or extremities, or cusps, of the notch of an arrow, between which is the place of the bow-string; syn. XaroxaA Alfuwqi. (O. [In the Ḳ, erroneously, XaroxaA Alfaroqi.])
Also Sud-N and Sad-N↓ A mountain: (AA, Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and so sud-N and sad-N: (AA, Ṣ, M:) pl. OaSodaAdN and SuduwdN. (M, L.)
And Sad-N↓ [or Sud-N] A cloud, or collection of clouds, rising high, and appearing like a mountain: and so sad-N [or sud-N (q. v.)], which is the more approved word. (M, L.)
SadadN: see Sud-N.

Also i. q. qurobN [used as a n. of place, meaning Vicinity, or a near place or sport; as in phrases here following]: (ISk, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and the place, or part, that is before, in front, facing, or opposite. (ISk,* T, Ṣ,* M, A,* L, Ḳ.*) One says, daAruhu biSadadi Almasojidi [His house is in the vicinity of, i. e. near to, the mosque; or his house is opposite to the mosque]. (Mṣb. [The former meaning is there indicated; but no meaning is expressed.]) And Oaxacotuhu mino SadadK i. e. mino qurobK [I took it from a near place or spot]. (A.) And daAriI Sadada daArihi, (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) in which Sdd is in the accus. case as an adv. n. of place, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and biSadadihi, (ISk, A,) and EalaI Sadadihi, (Lth, ISk,) My house is opposite to, i. e. in the place, or part, that is in front of, his house: (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and in the vicinity of, or near to, his house. (Ḳ.) And hecaA Sadada hecaA, and biSadadihi, This is in front of, or opposite to, this. (M.)
[Hence, app.,] laA Hadada liI duwnahu walaA Sadada There is no impediment to me in the way of it, nor any obstacle. (A.)
And huwa Sadadaka i. q. qaSodaka [i. e. He, or it, is tending, or looking, in the direction of thee; or is before thee, or before thy face: see art. qSd]. (Sb, M.)

And OanaA biSadadK mino hecaA AlOamori [I am directing myself, or my attention, to this affair]. (A.) [narojiEu UilaI maA naHonu biSadadihi, meaning We will return to that subject to which our attention is directed, is a phrase of frequent occurrence after a digression.]
SidaAdN A woman's sitor [app. meaning veil, or covering]. (Nawádir el-Aaráb, O, Ḳ.)
See also what next follows.
SaduwdN i. q. mijowalN [app. meaning A kind of garment for women or for young girls, which is thus called]; (O, Ḳ; in the CK miHowal;) as also SidaAdN↓; so says Th. (O.)

hom.sense: SadiydN an inf. n. of Sad-a [q. v.] in one of its senses. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

Also The ichor, i. e. thin water, [or watery humour,] of a wound, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) mixed [or tinged] with blood, (Ṣ, A, Mgh,) before the matter becomes thick: (Ṣ, A:) or matter, or pus, like water, in which is a mixture of red and white: (M:) or matter, or pus, like water in thinness and like blood in its having a mixture of red and white: (AZ, Mṣb:) and some add that when it has thickened, it is mid-ap: (Mṣb:) or matter, or pus, mixed with blood, (Lth, Mgh, Mṣb,) in a wound. (Lth.) In the Ḳur xiv. 19, it means What flows from the skins of the inmates of Hell: (M:) or what flows from their insides, and is mixed with matter and blood: (Jel:) or hot water (HamiymN) boiled until it thickens. (M, Ḳ.)
And hence, as being likened thereto, Sadiydu AlfiD-api i. e. cuwaAbatuhaA [app. meaning What is melted of silver]. (M.)

entry.sense: Sud-aI A species of fig, white without, black within, and very sweet. (AḤn, M, TA.)

hom.sense: Sud-aAdN A road to water. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And AlS-ud-aAdu The serpent: (Ḳ:) and (Ḳ, TA, in the CK “or”) a certain small animal (duwayob-ap, Ṣ, Ḳ) of the kind of the [field-rats called] jirocaAn: (Ṣ:) or [a species of lizard;] what is called saAm-u OaboraSa [q. v.]; (AZ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) used in this sense by Keys: (AZ, Ṣ:) or, accord. to Yaạḳoob, the [lizard called] wazaE: or, as some say, a species of the [field rats called] jirocaAn: (M:) pl. SadaAYidu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which is anomalous. (Ṣ, M.)

entry.sense: SaAd-N Turning away, avoiding, shunning, and leaving; or averse: fem. SaAd-apN: pl. of both Sud-aAdN; and of the fem. SawaAd-u also. (M.)
maSoduwdN [pass. part. n. of Sad-ahu, q. v.]. One says, fulaAnN maSoduwdN Eani Alxayori [Such a one is turned away from, or prevented from attaining, what is good, or prosperity]. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. SadiYa, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaSodaOu}, (L,) inf. n. SadaON, (Ṣ, M,) said of a horse, (Ḳ, TA,) and of a kid, (Ṣ, TA,) [or a goat,] He was of the colour termed SudoOap [i. e. sorrel inclining to blackness; or blackness intermixed, or tinged over, with redness; or a colour like that of the rust of iron; probably from the same verb in the sense next following]; (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ, TA;) as also SaduWa, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaSoduOu}; (TA; [and it is implied in the Ḳ that the latter verb is syn. with the former in all its senses;]) but the former verb is that which is commonly known, and that alone which is required by analogy as a verb denoting a colour, and the latter is not known to have been heard; (MF, TA;) and in the L it is said that the verb in this sense is SadiYa and AiS-adaOa↓, this latter [formed from AiSoTadaOa, originally AiSotadaOa,] of the measure AifotaEala. (TA.)

Also, (M, Ḳ,) SadiYa, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ, TA,) said of iron, It was, or became, rusty, or rusted; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) in which sense it is said also of the like of iron. (M.)
And SadiYa said of a man, He stood erect, and looked. (Ḳ.)

SadaOa AlmiroMpa, aor. _a {yaSodaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. SadoCN, (TḲ,) He polished the mirror, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e., removed from it the rust, (TA,) in order to use it as a collyrium; (Ḳ, TA;) as also Sad-aOahaA↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taSodiYapN. (TA.)
[Whether the mirrors of the Arabs were made of bronze, or of what other metal they were made, is not said. See also 1 in art. HlO.]
And, aor. as above, said of an owl, He uttered a cry or cries. (Sh, TA. [See also art. Sdw.])

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}.

5. tSd-O lahu, (Ḳ,) as also tSd-E lh, (TA,) i. q. tSd-I lh, (Ḳ, TA,) which is the original, meaning tEr-D lh [i. e. He addressed, or applied, or directed, himself, or his regard, or attention, or mind, to him, or it;, &c.]. (TA.)
8. AiS-adaOa: see 1, first sentence.

hom.sense: SadaON inf. n. of SadiYa [q. v.]. (Ṣ, M.)
Also [a subst.] signifying The rust of iron, (Ṣ, M,* TA,) and of copper and the like. (Ḥar p. 481. [But there erroneously written SdMC.])

entry.sense: SadiYN [part. n. of SadiYa, q. v.].
One says, yadiI mina AlHadiydi SadiYapN My hand is disagreeable in smell [from the rust of iron]. (Ṣ.)
And huwa SaAgirN SadiYN † He is one to whom disgrace, or shame, and baseness, or meanness, attach. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also OaSodaOu.

SudoOapN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in a horse, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and in a goat, or kid, (Ṣ,) A sorrel colour (XuqorapN) inclining to blackness, (M, Ḳ, TA,) the latter predominating: (TA:) or blackness intermixed, or tinged over, with redness [app. like the rust of iron]. (Ṣ.)

OaSodaOu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) applied to a horse, (Ḳ, TA,) or to a kid, (TA,) Of a sorrel colour (i. e. of the colour termed Xuqorap) inclining to blackness, (M, Ḳ, TA,) the latter predominating: (TA:) or, applied to a horse, and to a goat, or kid, (Ṣ,) or applied to a kid, (Ḳ,) of a black colour intermixed, or tinged over, with redness [app. like the rust of iron]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) fem. SadoMCu (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and SadiYapN↓. (M, L, TA.) And kumayotN OaSodaOu [A bay, or dark bay, or brown, horse,] tinged over with dinginess. (Ṣ.)
Also Rusty, or rusted; applied to iron and the like. (M.)

And [hence] katiybapN SadoMCu, (M, and so in copies of the Ḳ,) or SadoOFI, (Ḳ accord. to the TA,) and the former also, (TA,) [A body of troops having their arms or armour] overspread with the rust of iron. (M, Ḳ.)

And SadoMCu A land (OaroDN) of which the stones are of a red colour inclining to blackness, and rugged, not even with the ground, these stones having beneath them [other] rough stones, or, sometimes, soil and stones. (Sh, L.)

1. SadaHa, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _a {yaSodaHu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. SadoHN (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and SudaAHN, (Ḳ,) in a verse of Wejeehah Bint-Ows Ed-Dabbeeyeh Sud-aAH, (Ḥam p. 617,) He cried, or raised a loud cry; (Ṣ, A;) or raised his voice vehemently; (Lth, T;) said of a cock [i. e. he crowed, or crowed loudly or vehemently]; (Lth, T, Ṣ, A;) and of a crow [i. e. he croaked, or croaked loudly or vehemently]: (Lth, T, Ṣ:) said of an ass, he brayed loudly: (L:) said of a bird, and † of a man, he raised his voice in singing (L, Ḳ) or otherwise; cried out vehemently and sharply; or uttered a vehement and sharp voice. (L.)

SadoHapN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and SudoHapN↓ and SadaHapN↓ (L, Ḳ) A kind of bead (xarazapN, Lḥ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ) used for the purpose of captivating, or fascinating: (Ḳ:) or with which men are captivated, or fascinated: (Ṣ:) or with which women captivate, or fascinate, men: (Lḥ:) or with which men are conciliated. (L.)
SudoHapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
SadaHapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SaduwHN Having a loud cry or voice; as also Sad-aAHN↓; both applied to a cock [meaning loudcrowing]; (A;) [and to a crow as meaning loudcroaking]; and so the former applied to an ass [meaning loud-braying]; and so SayodaHN↓ applied to a horse [meaning loud-neighing]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [and app. also applied to a camel as meaning loudbraying, for] SayodaHu was the name of the she-camel of Dhu-r-Rummeh: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or SaduwHN (L, Ḳ) and Sad-aAHN↓ (L) and SayodaHN↓ and SayodaAHN↓ and miSodaHN↓ (L, Ḳ) signify that raises his voice much in singing or otherwise; (L;) [app. thus applied to a bird, and † to a man; (see 1;)] or that cries out vehemently, or much; or has a loud, or strong, voice; (L, Ḳ;) and so SayodaHiI-N↓. (Ḥam p. 558.) [Hence,] qayonapN SaAdiHapN↓ ‡ [A loud-voiced female singer]. (A, TA.) And HaAdK SayodaHN↓ ‡ [A loud-voiced man urging camels by his singing]. (A, TA.) And mizoharN Sad-aAHN↓ ‡ [A loud-sounding lute]. (Ṣ, A.)
Sad-aAHN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
SaAdiHapN: see SaduwHN.
SayodaHN: see SaduwHN, in three places.
SayodaHiI-N: see SaduwHN.
SayodaAHN see SaduwHN.
AlOaSodaHu The lion: (Ḳ:) so called because of his roaring. (TA.)
miSodaHN: see SaduwHN.

hom.sense: 1. Sadara, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaSoduru} (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _i {yaSodiru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. SadorN (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SuduwrN (A, TA) and maSodarN (M, Ḳ) and mazodarN because of the similarity [of the letters S and z], (M,) He returned, went back; (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and went, or turned, away; (Mṣb;) from (Eano) water, (Ṣ, M, A,) and a country, (Ṣ, M,) or a place, (Mṣb,) and † any affair. (Lth.)

Hence, Sadara Alqawolu, aor. _u {yaSoduru}, inf. n. SuduwrN, † [The saying issued, proceeded, or emanated, Eanohu from him.] (Mṣb.) [And Sadara Eanohu AlfiEolu, with the same aor. and inf. n., † The action proceeded from him.]
And Sadara Uilayohi He went to it; namely, a place: (TA:) he came to it. (Kull. p. 228.)
Sadarahu: see 4.
Also, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaSoduru}, inf. n. SadorN, (M,) He hit, struck, or hurt, his Sador [i. e. breast]. (M, Ḳ.) You say, Darabotuhu faSadarotuhu I struck him and hit his breast. (A.)
And Sadira He had a complaint of the Sador [or chest]. (M, Ḳ.) [See its part. n., below.]
2. Sd-rhu: see 4.

Sd-r baEiyrahu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taSodiyrN, (TA,) He tied a cord from the girth of his camel to the part behind [or beyond] the callous lump on his breast: (Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to Lth, (L,) one says, Sd-r Eano baEiyrihi, (M, L,) and the meaning is, he tied a cord from the taSodiyr [or breast-girth] to the part behind [or beyond] the callous lump on the breast of his camel, to keep the tSdyr in its place, when it had become loose in consequence of the animal's having become lank in the belly: the cord above mentioned is called sinaAfN [q. v.]. (Lth, L.)
And Sd-r EalaI AlbaEiyri [app. He put the breast-girth upon the camel]: from Alt-aSodiyru, i. e. “the girth” [thus called]. (MA.)
Sud-ira His (a horse's) breast became wetted with sweat. (Ṣ.) See 5.
Sd-rhu, (TA,) or Sd-rhu fiI Almajolisi, (Ṣ,) † He placed him, or seated him, in the upper, or highest, part in the sitting-room, or sitting-place. (TA.) And Sud-ira He was advanced, or promoted. (A.)

Sd-r kitaAbahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) ‡ He put to his book, or writing, a Sador, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) i. e. a title, or a commencement. (TA.) And Sd-r kitaAbahu bikacaA ‡ [He commenced his book, or writing, with such a thing]. (A.)
See also 5, where it is expl. as intrans., in two places.

3. muSaAdarapN signifies The returning, or going back, [app. with another, from water, &c.] (KL.) [The verb is probably trans., agreeably with general analogy, in all its senses; SAdrhu app. signifying primarily He returned, or went back, with him from water, &c.]
[IbrD thinks that it signifies also † He vied, or contended, with him for precedence, or priority.]

Also † The exacting a fine or the like [app. from another: or the suing, or prosecuting, another, for a debt, &c.]. (KL.) You say, SAdrhu EalaI kacaA mina AlmaAli (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA) † He desired, or sought, to obtain from him; or he demanded of him; or he sued, or prosecuted, him for; such a sum, or such an amount, of property. (Ḳ,* TA.)

And SaAdarotuhu EalaI kaca A wakacaA † I released him from my reckoning with him on such and such terms agreed upon by both. (TA in art. frq.) And Suwdira EalaI maAlK yuWad-iyhi † He (an agent) was released from being reckoned with (fuwriqa) on the condition of his paying certain property for which he became responsible: a phrase of the registrars of accounts. (TA in the present art.)

entry.sense: 4. ASdrhu, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Sadarahu↓, (M, Ḳ,) and Sd-rhu↓, (Ḳ,) He caused him to return; sent him, or brought him, back, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or away; (Mṣb;) from (Eano) water, and a country [or place], (Ṣ,) and † any affair. (Lth.) You say, OaSodaronaA rikaAbanaA We sent, or brought, back our riding-camels satisfied with drink so that it was not necessary for us to remain with them for the sake of the water. (TA.) And Oaworadahu waOaSodarahu He brought it and he took it away. (Ḥar p. 361.)

[Hence,] Oaworada waOaSodara ‡ He began and completed. (TA.) You say, UicaA Oaworada OamorFA OaSodarahu ‡ When he begins a thing, or an affair, he completes it. (A.) And fulaAnN yuwridu walaA yuSodiru ‡ Such a one begins and does not complete. (A.)
And ASdr Alqawola † [He issued forth the saying; made it to issue, proceed, or emanate, Eanohu from him]. (Mṣb. [See 1.]) [And ASdr Eanohu AlfiEola † He, or it, made the action to proceed from him.]
5. tSd-r He [a man, TA] erected his chest in sitting. (M, Ḳ.)

‡ He [a horse] outreached the other horses with his chest; (M, Ḳ,* TA;) as also Sd-r↓, (Ṣ,* M, MA, Ḳ,) inf. n. taSodiyrN: the latter verb is afterwards expl. in the Ḳ as meaning baraza biraOosihi; but this is a mistake. (TA.) Tufeyl says, describing a horse,
kaOan-ahu baEoda maA Sad-arona↓ mino EaraqK
siydN tamaT-ara jinoHa All-ayoli maboluwlu
As though he were, after they had outreached with their chests, from a row of [other] horses, [a wolf that had exposed himself to rain during a portion of the night, and had become wetted:] but accord. to one relation, it is Sud-irona↓, meaning their breasts were wetted [mino EaraqK] by reason of sweat: the former reading, however is the better. (Ṣ.)

Also † He sat, or became placed or seated, in the upper, or highest, part in the sitting-room, or sitting-place. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.) And He became advanced, or promoted. (A.) tSd-r liOumuwri Aln-aAsi † [He became advanced to the foremost place for the conducting of the affairs of the people]. (Ḥar p. 194.)
6. tSAdrwA [app. They returned together from water, &c.]. (A. [This meaning seems to be there indicated by the context.])
And one says, tSAdrwA EalaI maA XaAWuwA ‡ [app. meaning They released one another from being reckoned with, by mutual agreement, on such terms as they would: see 3]. (A.)
SadorN Anything that fronts, or faces, one. (M, Ḳ.)

And hence, (M,) The Sador [i. e. breast, or chest, or bosom,] of a man, [often meaning his mind,] (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of other than man: (Mṣb:) of the masc. gender: (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) pl. SuduwrN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) the only pl. form. (M.) [See also SudorapN.] As to the saying of the poet, (Ṣ, M,) El-Aạshà, (Ṣ,)
wataXoraqu biAlqawoli Al-aciI qado OacaEotuhu
kamaA Xariqato Sadoru AlqanaApi mina Ald-ami
[And thou becomest, or wilt become, red by reason of the saying that I have published, like as the fore part of the spear becomes red from blood], (Ṣ,* M,) he has made Sdr fem. because the Sdr of the qnAp is a part of the qnAp; for they [sometimes] make a noun fem. when it is prefixed to a fem. noun: (Ṣ:) or if you will, you may say that he has made Sdr fem. because he meant [thereby] the qnAp; and if you will, you may say that the Sdr of a qnAp is a qnAp. (M.) [Hence,] banaAtu AlS-adori ‡ The spaces between the bones of the breast. (M, TA.) [And also] † Anxieties. (T in art. bnI.) And caAtu AlS-uduwri † What is in the minds. (Ksh and Bḍ and Jel in iii. 115, &c.) And DaAqa Sadoruhu † His bosom, or mind, became strait, or contracted. (Mṣb in art. Dyq. [See the Ḳur xv. 97 and xxvi. 12.]) And XaraHa biAlkufori SadorFA † He opened and dilated his bosom, meaning, was pleased, with infidelity. (Jel in xvi. 108. [See also the similar phrases XaraHa Qll-ehu Sadorahu liloUisolaAmi and liqabuwli Alxayori expl. in art. XrH.]) And AinoXaraHa Sadoruhu † His bosom became dilated or enlarged [with joy]. (Ṣ in art. XrH.) And waAsiEu AlS-adori and raHiybu AlS-adori † Ample, or dilated, in the breast, or bosom; [meaning free-minded; free from distress of mind; without care: and free from narrowness of mind; liberal, munificent, or generous.] (Ṣ and TA in art. rHb.) [And Day-iqu AlS-adori † Having the bosom, or mind, strait, or contracted.] And rajulN baEiydu AlS-adori ‡ A man who is not to be turned, or bent, or inclined. (M.) In the saying halo yasotaTiyEu mano bihi SadorN Uil-aA Oano yanofiva [meaning Is he who has the disease of the chest (daMCu AlS-adori) able to do without spitting?], if it be correct, the prefixed noun [dMC] is suppressed. (Mgh.) [Sadoru Ald-ajaAjapi, as said by Freytag, is the name of † The star γ of Cygnus.]

Also † The upper, or uppermost, part of the front of anything. (M, Ḳ.) [Hence,] Suduwru AlwaAdiI † The higher, or upper, parts, and fronts, or fore parts, of the valley; (M, Ḳ;) as also SadaAYiruhu, which is pl. of SadaArapN↓, (Ḳ,) or SidaArapN↓, (as in a copy of the M,) or SaAdirapN↓, (as in the L,) or of SadiyrapN↓. (M, L, Ḳ.) And Sadoru Almajolisi † The upper, or highest, part [or end] of the sitting-room, or sitting-place: (TA:) the elevated part thereof. (Mṣb.)

[† The fore part of anything. † The prow, or fore part, of a ship.] † The fore part of the foot, between the toes and the [protuberant part called the] HimaArap. (M.) † The fore part of the sandal, before the [hole through which is put the thong called the XiraAk, i. e. the hole called the] xurot. (M.) ‡ The part of the arrow that is above the middle, as far as the mrAX: (so in a copy of the A: [an evident mistranscription for raOos, i. e. head:]) or the part of the arrow that is beyond the middle, as far as the slender part, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is next the head; (M;) so called because it is the fore part when it is shot: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and likewise of the spear [as in the verse cited above in this paragraph]. (M.) yawomN kaSadori Alr-umoHi [lit. † A day like the fore part of the spear] means † a day of straitness and distress: accord. to Th, it is a day by which war, or battle, is peculiarly distinguished. (M, L.)

† The first, first part, or commencement, of anything; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) even † of the day, (M, Mṣb,) and † of the night, and † of the winter, and † of the summer, and † the like, (M,) and ‡ of an affair. (A. [See an ex. voce EajuzN.]) ‡ The title of a book or writing: and the first part, or commencement, thereof. (TA.) [† The first foot of the first hemistich of a verse.] And The first hemistich (altogether) of a verse. (O voce EajuzN.) [And † The first verse of a qaSiydap.]
Sadoru AlT-ariyqi † The wide, or widening, part of the road. (Mṣb.)

Sadoru Alqawomi † The head, or chief, of the people, or party; as also AlmaSodaru↓. (TA.) And hence, Sadoru AlS-uduwri † [The chief of the chiefs; a title applied to the prime minister of the king; and also to the chief judge; app., in the earlier times, to the former;] he who performs the onerous duties of the king, or of the state. (TA.)
And † A part, or portion, of a thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: SadarN a subst. signifying Return, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from (Eano) water, (Ṣ, M,) and a country, (Ṣ,) or a place, (Mṣb,) and † any affair: (Lth:) as some say, from anything. (M.) Hence, TawaAfu AlS-adari, (Ḳ, TA, in the CK AlS-adori,) i. e. The compassing of the Kaabeh on the occasion of the return of the pilgrims from 'Arafát. (TA.) [Hence also,] AlS-adaru The fourth day of the days of the sacrifice [performed by the pilgrims]: (M, Ḳ:) so called because the people then return from Mekkeh to their abodes. (M.) [And hence the saying,] tarakotuhu EalaI mivoli layolapi AlS-adari I left him as in the night preceding the fourth day of the days of the sacrifice: (A:) or [as in the night preceding the day] when the people return from their pilgrimage; (Ṣ;) meaning, † possessing nothing. (M.)
Also quasi-pl. n. of SaAdirN, q. v. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: SudorapN The Sador [or breast] (M, Ḳ) of a man [or beast]: (TA:) or the prominent part of the upper portion thereof. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

Hence, (Ṣ,) A certain garment [which covers the breast], (Ṣ, M,) well known: (Ḳ:) a short shirt: a short diroE: and the dim., SudayorapN↓, is applied to a short shirt which is worn next the body. (TA.) [In the present day, SudayoriI, which is a corruption of the dim., is applied to A kind of waistcoat; a short vest without sleeves: and its pl. is SudayoriyaAt.] See also the next paragraph.

SidaArN A certain garment, of which the head, or upper part, is like the miqonaEap, [covering the head,] and the lower part of which covers the breast (M, Ḳ) and the shoulders: (M:) a woman in mourning for the death of her husband or relation used to wear a SdAr of wool: (Az:) or i. q. SudorapN↓ [q. v.] and mijowalN and OuSodapN: (IAạr:) or a certain garment with which the head and breast are covered, worn by a woman in mourning for her husband: (A:) or a small shirt worn next the body: (Ṣ:) or a diroE worn next the breast: (Aṣ:) or i. q. UitobN [q. v.]. (T in art. Atb.)
It is said in a prov., kul-u caAti SidaArK xaAlapN [Every female having a SdAr is as a maternal aunt]: i. e., it is incumbent on a man to be jealous for every woman like as he is jealous for his women under covert, or the females of his family whom he is under an obligation to respect and protect. (Ṣ. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 310.])
Also A certain mark made with a hot iron upon the breast of a camel. (Ṣ.)
SadaArapN † Precedence, or priority. (TA.)
See also SadorN, near the middle of the paragraph.
SidaArapN: see SadorN, near the middle of the paragraph.
SadiyrapN: see SadorN, near the middle of the paragraph.
SudayorapN dim. of SudorapN, q. v. (TA.)
SaAdirN Returning [from water, &c.]; going, or turning, back, or away: (TA:) quasi-pl. n. SadarN↓. (M, Ḳ.)
[Hence the saying,] maA lahu SaAdirN walaA waAridN ‡ He has not anything: (M, Ḳ:) or he has not a thing nor a people. (Lḥ, M.)
And TariyqN SaAdirN ‡ A road, or way, by which people return from water: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) opposed to TariyqN waAridN. (M, A.)
SaAdirapN: see SadorN, near the middle of the paragraph.

hom.sense: OaSodaru A man (M) having a large breast, or chest; (M, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. having the breast, or chest, or the upper part thereof, prominent; as also muSad-arN↓. (TA.)

AlOaSodaraAni Two veins (M, Ḳ) that beat, or pulse, (M,) beneath the temples: (M, Ḳ:) or the two sides of a man: or the two shoulder-joints: (TA:) the word has no singular. (M.) [Hence the saying,] jaMCa yaDoribu OaSodarayohi; (M, Meyd, Ḳ, TA;) and some say Oasodarayohi [q. v.], (Meyd, TA,) and this is the original; (Meyd;) and some, Oazodarayohi; (Meyd, TA;) a prov.; (M, Meyd, TA;) meaning He came beating [with his hand] his two sides, (TA,) or his two shoulderjoints: (Meyd, TA:) i. e. he came empty [-handed]; (M, Meyd, Ḳ,* TA;) not having accomplished the object of his desire: (Meyd:) or he came exulting, or behaving insolently, (Meyd, and Ḥar p. 603,) not knowing where were his OaSodaraAni: so accord. to Yoo: and some say, jaMCa baDoribu biOaSodarayohi. (Ḥar.)

entry.sense: taSodiyrN [a subst. like tacoriyEN and tanobiytN] The [fore-girth, i. e. breast-girth, or] girth that is upon the breast of the camel: (Ṣ, A:*) [the hind girth, or belly-girth,] that which is next the viyl, is called the Haqab: (Ṣ:) or the girth of the camel's saddle (Alr-aHol), and of the [camel-vehicle called] hawodaj. (M.)
maSodarN A place of returning or going back, (Ṣ, TA,) or of going, or turning, away [from water, and from a country or place, and † from an affair or thing]. (TA. [See 1, first sentence.])

[Hence, maSodaru OamorK ‡ The way of return from, or of completing, a thing or an affair: opposed to maworiduhu.] One says, huwa yaEorifu mawaArida AlOumuwri wamaSaAdirahaA ‡ [He knows the ways of betaking himself to things or affairs, and the ways of withdrawing himself from them; or of commencing them and of completing them]. (A.) [See also another ex. in art. rHb, conj. 6.]

And hence [also], the maSaAdir [pl. of maSodar] of verbs: (Ṣ, TA:) maSodarN signifies † The root of a word, from which proceed the derivatives of verbs: (Lth, TA:) [in this sense it is a conventional term of grammar and lexicology, not belonging to the classical language; but on account of the importance of understanding its true application in lexicology, it is necessary to give here a full explanation of it: it is, agreeably with its etymology, the source (lit. place) of derivation, accord. to the grammarians of El-Basrah; and is what I term an infinitive noun: it is defined as] a noun signifying, by its original application, an accident as subsisting in, or proceeding from, an agent (as AlfaraHu [“the being joyful”], AlD-arobu [“the act of beating”], and AlquEuwdu [“the act of sitting”]), or affecting an object of action, (as Aljunuwnu [“the being possessed by a jinnee”]), conformable to its verb, so as to comprise all the letters in that verb, either literally (as in the instances above) or virtually (as in AlqitaAlu [“the act of fighting”], which wants the A that is before the t in the verb, yet wants it as to the letter only, and not virtually, wherefore it is sometimes pronounced as if with the said letter, as in qaAtala qiytaAlFA, but the A is changed into I on account of the kesr of the letter before it), or substituting another letter for any of those letters that it wants (as in AlEidapu [“the act of promising”], which wants the w that is in its verb as to the letter and virtually, but has p substituted for it [by way of compensation]): (from a comparison of definitions, &c. in the Expos. of the “Kitab Hodood en-Nahw” by the author of the work thus entitled, arts. mSdr and Asm mSdr; the Expos. of the “Shudhoor edh-Dhahab” by the author of the work thus entitled, section on the nouns that govern as verbs; I’Aḳ;, &c.:) but the grammarians of El-Koofeh hold that the verb is the root, and that the mSdr is derived from it: (I’Aḳ p. 148:) some mSAdr, moreover, are derived from real (as opposed to ideal) substantives, as Alt-aHaj-uru [“the becoming stone”] from AlHajaru [“stone”]. (Kull p. 327.) The mSdr has the same government as its own verb: it is often, and may be at pleasure, used as an ideal subst. or abstract noun: and it is often employed in the place of an act. or a pass. part. n.: (Kull, &c.:) [when thus used as an epithet, it is employed alike as sing. and pl. and masc. and fem.:] accord. to Zj, every mSdr used as an epithet is for cuw [or caAt, &c.] followed by the mSdr, and therefore it has no dual nor pl. [nor fem.] form. (TA voce HaraDN.) [It has also other uses, which are expl. in the grammars. Used as a maSodar, it is sometimes made fem.; as it is also when used in the sense of a noun that is properly fem.: see SarofN, third sentence.]

Uisomu maSodarK, called by some AisomN lilomaSodari, is a term applied to [† A quasi-infinitive noun; i. e.] a noun which is not a mSdr, but which is occasionally used in the place of a mSdr; like as a mSdr is used in the place of an act. part. n., and in that of a pass. part. n.: such as AlwuDuwoCu for Alt-awaD-uWu [“the performing of the ablution preparatory to prayer”], and Algusolu for AlAigotisaAlu [“the washing of oneself”]; each of which wants somewhat that is in its verb without substituting anything for that which is wanting. (Expos. of the “Kitáb el- Hodood,” cited above.) This kind of noun the grammarians of El-Koofeh and Baghdád allow to govern as a mSdr; but the grammarians of El-Basrah hold that the noun governed in the accus. case in each of the exs. adduced by the former as confirmatory of their opinion is so governed by a verb understood. (Expos. of the “Shudhoor,” ubi suprà.) It is also applied to A proper name signifying an accident [or attribute]; as fajaAri and HamaAdi, proper names, by original application, for Alfajorapu and AlmaHomadapu [“vice” and “praise”] and the like: and this kind does not govern as a mSdr. (Expos. of the “Kitáb Hodood en-Nahw,” ubi suprà; and Expos. of the “Shudhoor,” ubi suprà.) It is also applied to [what is more properly termed AisomN lilomaEonaI AlHaASili biAlmaSodari, by some termed simply HaASilN biAlmaSodari, i. e. An ideal substantive, or abstract noun;] a noun applied to signify an accident [or attribute] considered abstractedly [such as SadarN signifying “return;” and this kind is commonly termed in the lexicons simply an Aisom as distinguished from a mSdr]. (Kull p. 327.) Some apply it also to what is [properly] termed maSodarN miymiI-N [i. e. A mSdr commencing with an augmentative m], if not of the measure mufaAEalapN: but such is really a maSodar. (Expos. of the “Shudhoor,” ubi suprà.) And some of the grammarians [and of the lexicographers likewise] apply it to A noun that signifies the instrument [or means] with [or by] which the action signified by a mSdr is performed: as AlOukolu [“food,” as being “that by means of which the act of eating (AlOakolu) is performed”]. (Kull, ubi suprà.)
See also SadorN, last sentence but two.

hom.sense: muSodirN [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.]
‡ A man who completes things or affairs. (A.)
And One of the names of the month jumaAdaI AlOuwlaI: (M, Ḳ:) [ISd says,] I think it to be of the dial. of [the tribe of] 'Ad. (M.)

entry.sense: maSodarapu Alqawomi ‡ Those who are made to have the precedence, or priority, of the people, or party. (A, TA.)
[maSodariI-N, as a grammatical term, Of, or relating to, the maSodar. See the particles Oano and kaIo, &c.]
muSad-arN A man (M) strong in the chest; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and in like manner a lion, (M, A,) and a wolf: (M:) and the lion; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and the wolf; (Ḳ;) because they are strong in the chest. (TA.)
See also OaSodaru.
A horse to whose breast the sweat has reached. (M, Ḳ.)
A horse, and a sheep or goat, white in the upper part (lab-ap) of the breast: (M, Ḳ:) or (with p, A) a ewe having a black breast, (M, A, Ḳ,) the rest of her being white. (M.)

‡ A horse that outreaches others (IAạr, M, A, Ḳ) with his breast: (TA:) IAạr does not mention the breast. (M, TA.) [Accord. to rule, this should be muSad-irN, as is shown by a verse cited above: see 5.]
‡ An arrow thick in the part called the Sador. (M, A, Ḳ.)

And AlmuSad-aru is a name applied to † The first of the arrows termed gufol, (M, Ḳ,) which have no notches, and to which is assigned no portion [and no fine, in the game called Almayosir]; these being added only to give additional weight to the collection of arrows from a dislike of suspicion [of foul play]. (Lḥ, M. [See Als-afiyHu and AlmaniyHu.])

maSoduwrN A man (A, &c.) having a complaint of the chest. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb.) ʼObeyd-Allah Ibn-ʼAbd-Allah Ibn-'Otbeh, on its being said to him, How long wilt thou utter this poetry? replied,
laA bud-a lilomaSoduwri mino Oano yasoEulaA
To him who has a complaint of the chest, there is no avoiding coughing. (TA. [See also nafava.])
It is also often used as meaning † Grieved, afflicted, or vexed. (TA in art. nfv.)

hom.sense: 1. SadaEahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaSodaEu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. SadoEN, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) He clave, split, slit, or cracked, it [i. e. a hard thing, such as a glass vessel, and a wall, and the like of these; (see SadoEN below;) or so generally]; syn. Xaq-ahu; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Sd-Ehu↓, [but app. in an intensive sense, or relating to a number of objects,] inf. n. taSodiyEN: (TA:) or so as to divide it in halves: or so that it did not separate. (Ḳ.)
[Hence,] one says, SadaEahu SadoEa Alr-idaMCi [He slit it, or rent it, as with the slitting, or rending, of the garment called rdAC]. (TA.)

And SadaEa AlfalaApa ‡ He traversed, or crossed, the desert; [as though he clave it;] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and in like manner, Aln-ahora the river. (TA.) And hecaA AlT-ariyqu yaSodaEu fiI OaroDi kacaA wakacaA † [This road extends through such and such a land]. (TA.) And SadaEa All-ayola, inf. n. as above, ‡ He journeyed during [or through] the night. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

SadoEN also signifies The act of separating, or dispersing, or scattering; (Mṣb;) and so taSodiyEN↓; (Ṣ, O;) syn. taforiyqN [with which each is probably syn. in other, but similar, senses]. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb.) One says, SadaEa AlX-aIoCa He, or it, separated, or dispersed, or scattered, the thing. (TA.) And SadaEotu Alqawoma, inf. n. SadoEN, † I separated, or dispersed, or scattered, the people, or party. (Mṣb.) And SadaEatohumu Aln-awaI means [in like manner] far-aqatohum [i. e. ‡ The place that was the object of the journey separated them from their homes, &c.]; and so Sad-aEatohum↓; whence Alt-aSodaAEu [as an inf. n., like Alt-aSodiyEu]. (TA.) And SadaEotu Alganama SidoEatayoni † I separated, or divided, the sheep, or the goats, into two flocks or herds. (Ṣ, TA.)

[And hence,] SadaEotu AlX-aIoCa † I made the thing distinct [as though separate from others], apparent, manifest, evident, clear, or plain: whence the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb in a verse cited in art. fyD, conj. 4. (Ṣ.)

And SadaEa biAlHaq-i ‡ He spoke the truth openly, or aloud, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) distinguishing, or discriminating, between it and falsehood: and thus Kh has expl. the verb as used in the verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb above referred to. (TA.) And SadaEa biAlOamori, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) † He made known the affair, or case, by speaking of it. (Ḳ, TA.)

faQSodaEo bimaA tuWomaru, in the Ḳur [xv. 94], means † Therefore cleave thou, or divide thou, their congregation, [app. by separating the believers from the unbelievers, with that wherewith thou art charged, (bihi being understood after tWmr,) i. e.,] with the declaration of the unity [of God]: (IAạr, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or † distinguish thou therewith between the truth and falsehood: (AO, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or † dispense thou among them in their collective state [that wherewith thou art charged, i. e.] the announcement [of the unity, &c.]: (TA:) or † reveal thou, or make manifest, (Fr, Zj, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) that with which thou art charged, (Zj, Mṣb, TA,) and fear not any one, (Zj, TA,) or the ordinance, i. e., (Fr, TA,) thy religion; (Fr, Ṣ, TA;) mA [with what follows it] being held by Fr, who thus explains the phrase, to occupy the place of an inf. n., namely, AlOamor: (TA:) or † utter thou openly, or aloud, (O, Ḳ, TA,) that with which thou art charged, meaning, accord. to Ibn-Mujáhid, (TA,) the Ḳur-án: (O, Ḳ, TA:) in the R it is said to be from AlS-adiyEu meaning “the daybreak;” ignorance being likened to the darkness of night, and the Ḳur-án to light that cleaves that darkness: (TA:) or † order thou, or ordain, or decree, [that with which thou art charged, i. e.,] the truth: and † decide thou according to the ordinance [prescribed to thee]: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or ‡ direct thy course by that [revelation] with [the preaching of] which thou art charged: (O, Ḳ, TA:) so says Th, on the authority of an Arab of the desert; accord. to whom, (O, TA,)
SadaEa fulaAnFA signifies ‡ He directed his course to such a one because of his generosity. (Th, O, Ḳ, TA.)
SadaEa biAlOamori, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) also signifies † He hit, or attained, with the affair, its proper place [or object]. (Ḳ, TA.)
And SadaEotu UilaI AlX-aIoCi, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (AZ, Ṣ,) inf. n. SuduwEN, † I inclined to the thing. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

And SadaEahu Eanohu † He, or it, turned him away from him, or it. (Ḳ.) One says, maA SadaEaka Eano hecaA AlOamori † What turned thee away from this affair? (Ṣ, O, TA:) and some say, mA Sadagaka, with the pointed g, which is better. (O, TA.)
See also the next paragraph {2}.
And see SaAdiEN, last sentence.
2: see 1, in three places.

[Freytag adds two other explanations of Sd-E: namely, “Immisit,” followed by an accus. and fI; taken by inference from the Ḥam p. 196, l. 12 from the bottom: and “Rupit, perdidit;” from Reiske's additions to Golius: but both of these require consideration.]

[Sd-Ehu also signifies † It affected him with headache; as though it made his head to split.] One says, Sad-aEaniI Oaziyzu Alr-aHaI † [The sounding of the mill-stone affected me with headache]. (A and TA in art. Az.) And Sud-iEa, inf. n. taSodiyEN, † He (a man, Ṣ) was, or became, affected with SudaAE [or headache]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ; [see the Ḳur lvi. 19;]) and SudiEa↓ [without teshdeed], pass. part. n. maSoduwEN↓, is allowable in poetry. (O, Ḳ.)
5. tSd-E, of which AiS-ad-aEa is a var.: (O, Ḳ:) see 7, in four places.

Also It became separated, or dispersed, or scattered. (Ḳ.) One says, tSd-E Alqawomu ‡ The people, or party, became separated, or dispersed, or scattered. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.) And tSd-EwA Ean-iI † They became separated,, &c., from me. (TA.) yawomaYicK yaS-ad-aEuwna, in the Ḳur [xxx. 42], means On that day they shall become separated into two parties, a party in Paradise and a party in Hell. (Zj, O, TA.) And one says, tSd-E Als-aHaAbu † The clouds became [scattered, or] dissundered. (TA.) And taSad-aEati AlOaroDu bifulaAnK † Such a one, fleeing, became concealed in the earth or land [as though it became cloven with him]. (O, Ḳ, and Ḥam pp. 136 and 418.)
tSd-E lahu: see tSd-O, in art. SdO.

entry.sense: 7. AnSdE [generally said of a hard thing, such as a glass vessel, and a wall, and the like of these, (see 1, first sentence,)] It became cloven, split, slit, or cracked; or, in an intrans. sense, it clave, split, slit, or cracked; syn. AinoXaq-a: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or so as to become divided in halves: or so that it did not separate: (see again 1, first sentence:)] as also tSd-E↓ [but app. in an intensive sense, meaning it became cloven, &c., or it clave, &c., much, or in several places]. (O, Ḳ.) One says, taSad-aEati↓ AlbayoDapu walamo tatafal-aqo [The egg cracked, or rather cracked in several places, but did not split apart]. (AZ, Ṣ in art. qyD.) And tSd-E↓ Alv-awobu The garment, or piece of cloth, became slit or rent, or much slit or rent; i. q. AinoSaAHa. (Mṣb in art. SyH.) And AnSdEt AlOaroDu biAln-abaAti The earth clave with, or became cloven by, the plants, or herbage; as also tSd-Et↓. (TA.) And AnSdE AlS-uboHu † The dawn broke; like Anfjr, and Anflq, and AnfTr. (TA.)

hom.sense:
SadoEN [originally an inf. n.] A cleft, split, slit, or crack, (Lth, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) [generally] in a hard thing, (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA,) such as a glass vessel, and a wall, and the like of these: pl. SuduwEN. (TA.) Hassán says, satirizing El-Hárith Ibn-'Owf El-Murree,
waOamaAnapu Almur-iI-i Hayovu laqiytahu
mivolu Alz-ujaAjapi SadoEuhaA lamo yujobari
[And the fidelity of the Murree, where (meaning wherever) thou meetest him, is like the glass vessel, of which the crack is not repaired]. (O, TA.)

And A part, or portion, separated, of a thing, (O, Ḳ, TA,) of sheep or goats, and the like: (TA:) an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly thus termed]: (O, Ḳ, TA:) like xaloqN in the sense of maxoluwqN, &c. (O, TA.)

And The plants of the earth; (Ḳ;) because they cleave it: (TA:) [i. e.] the plants from over which the earth cleaves: so in the phrase waQloOaroDi caAti QlS-adoEi, in the Ḳur lxxxvi. 12: (Bḍ:) or this phrase means And the earth which is cloven by the plants (Th, Bḍ, TA) and by the springs. (Bḍ.)

And i. q. UilobN: (TA:) you say, Aln-aAsu Ealayohimo SadoEN waAHid, (Ḳ, TA,) and UilobN waAHidN [or OalobN waAHidN], (TA,) The people are one company combined in hostility against them: (Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner waEolN wAHd and DilaEN wAHd: so says AZ. (TA.)
And A man light of flesh; and so SadaEN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) sometimes: (Ṣ:) or of middling stature, light of flesh: (Ks, TA:) like the mountain-goat thus termed. (TA.)
See also SadaEN.

entry.sense: SidoEN The half of a thing that is cloven, or split, or slit, in halves. (Ḳ,* TA. [See also SidoEapN.]) You say, SadaEa AlX-aIoCa SidoEayoni He clave, or split, or slit, the thing in halves. (TA.)
And † A company of men. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
And † A woman who makes a division in the state of a people and does not repair it. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA.)

hom.sense: SadaEN and SadoEN↓, (Ḳ,) or the former only, (Ṣ,) applied to a mountain-goat, and a gazelle, and an ass, [app. a wild ass,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a camel, (Ḳ,) Of a middling size, neither great nor small, but between the two: (Ṣ:) or youthful and strong: [see also SadiyEN:] or [in the CK “and”] the former word signifies a thing of any sort between two things; between tall and short, and youthful and advanced in age, and fat and lean, and great and small. (Ḳ.)
For the former word as applied to a man: see SadoEN.
Also, thus applied Penetrating, sharp, or effective, in his affair. (TA.)

[It is said that] SadaEN signifies also The SadaO [i. e. rust] of iron. (Ḳ.) [But this seems to be a mistake, which has arisen from what here follows.] It is said that [a certain person called] El-Uskuff [which generally means “the bishop”], being asked by ʼOmar respecting the Khaleefehs, designated [him who was afterwards] the fourth of them [ʼAlee] as SadaEN mino HadiydK, meaning [lit.] thereby A mountain-goat of iron; using it as a hyperbolical appellation to denote his might and courage and endurance and hardness: or the phrase, as some relate it, is SadaON HadydN [which may be rendered, “light or active in body” (a meaning assigned to SadaON and SadaEN, the latter of which is said to be in this sense the original), and “sharp”]; or SadaOu HadiydK [i. e. “rust of iron,” app. alluding to his frequent and long-continued wearing of mail and bearing of weapons]; which last is thought by Aṣ to be most probably correct. (O,* TA.)

entry.sense: And A [herd such as is termed] Siromap of camels; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so SadiyEN↓: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:*) or, accord. to AZ, a herd of camels amounting to sixty. (O, TA.) And A separate flock, or herd, of sheep or goats; as also SadiyEN↓: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or, as some say, of these also, amounting to sixty: and it is said to signify also a herd of gazelles: (TA:) and SadiyEN↓ signifies also a herd of oxen [probably meaning wild oxen]. (O, TA.)
One says also, Ealayohi SidoEapN mino maAlK i. e. [On him lies a debt of] a small amount of property. (TA.)

hom.sense: SadaEaAtN ‡ [Divisions in opinion, &c.]. One says, bayonahumo SadaEaAtN fiI Alr-aOoIi waAlhawaI ‡ Between them is division [in opinion and affection; or rather between them are divisions, &c.]. (O, Ḳ, TA.) And OaSoliHuwA maA fiykumo mina AlS-adaEaAti ‡ [Repair ye the divisions that are among you;] i. e. become ye in a state of unity. (O, TA.) And Uin-ahumo EalaI maA fiyhimo mina AlS-adaEaAti Oalib-aMCu kiraAmN ‡ [Verily they, notwithstanding the divisions that are among them, are intelligent and generous]. (TA.) [It is stated in the TA, among the additions to the Ḳ in this art., that one says also, Uin-ahumo EalaI maA taraI mino SadaAEatihimo↓ lakiraAmN app. as meaning † Verily they, notwithstanding what thou seest of their disunion, are generous: but I think it most probable that SadaAEatihimo is a mistranscription for SadaEaAtihimo.]
[Reiske, as stated by Freytag, explains it as signifying also Camels going swiftly.]

entry.sense: SudaAEN † Headache: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) Er-Rághib says that it is like a splitting in the head by reason of pain; and is a metaphorical term. (TA.)

hom.sense: SadiyEN Either half of a garment, or piece of cloth, (O, Ḳ,) that is slit in halves: (O:) and a thing [XaIoCN accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, but I think that the right reading is XaIoCK i. e. “of a thing,”] that is cloven, or split, or slit, in halves: pl. SuduEN. (Ḳ.) See also SidoEapN, first sentence. It is also said to signify A [garment of the kind called] ridaMC, that is slit in halves. (TA.) And A new patch in an old and worn-out garment. (O, Ḳ.) And A garment much rent. (TA.) And A black garment which a wailing woman wears with a white garment beneath it, and which she rends at her bosom so that the white one appears: so says Kásim Ibn-Thábit. (TA.) And A garment that is worn beneath the coat of mail. (O, Ḳ.) And A shirt [of a middling size] between two shirts, neither large nor small. (TA.)
See also SidoEapN, second and third sentences, in three places.

Accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, (O,) applied to a mountain-goat, it signifies Youthful: and (some say, O) of middling size; syn. marobuwEu Alxaloqi; (O, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. between two [in size]; like SadaEN [q. v.]. (TA.)
Also † Daybreak: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) because it cleaves the night. (O.)
And Fresh milk which is put in a place, and becomes cool, and overspread by a thin skin: (O, Ḳ:) so called because you skim off (taSodaEu, lit. “cleave,”) that thin skin from the clear milk. (O.)

entry.sense: SadaAEapN: see a saying mentioned above, voce SadaEaAtN.

[Hence,] applied to a valley, (O, Ḳ,) and a road, or way, (sabiylN, O, TA, in the Ḳ erroneously written sayolN [a torrent], TA, [or both may be correct,]) and a mountain, (Ḳ, TA, [in the O, HabolN is put for jabalN,]) † Extending far along the earth. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
And, applied to the daybreak, † Shining, or bright; syn. muXoriqN. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.)
Also † One who decides, or judges, between, or among, a people, or party. (TA.)

A poet (qys bn cryH) says,
falam-aA badaA minohaA AlfiraAqu kamaA badaA
biZahori AlS-afaA AlS-alodi AlX-uquwqu AlS-awaAdiEu [i. e. And when separation from her appeared, like as appear the cleaving cracks in the surface of the hard and smooth rock]: it may be that SadaEa↓ is syn. with taSad-aEa in some dial. [and that SawaAdiE is pl. of its part. n.]: or this may be an instance of a possessive epithet, meaning having a cleaving. (TA.)
huwa OaSodaEuhumo biAlS-awaAbi fiI OasoraEi jawaAbK † [app. He is the most effective of them in deciding rightly in a most quick answer]. (TA.)
maSodaEN ‡ A smooth, or plain, road, in a rugged tract of ground: pl. maSaAdiEu. (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA.)

miSodaEN A [sort of arrow-head, or arrow, such as is termed] miXoqaS [q. v.]: pl. maSaAdiEu. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.) Hence the quiver is called xaAbiYapu AlmaSaAdiEi [The concealer, or guarder, of the mSAdE]. (TA.)
daliylN miSodaEN † A guide going his way [app. with energy]. (TA.)
And xaTiybN miSodaEN † An orator, or a preacher, perspicuous, (O, Ḳ, TA,) eloquent, (Ḳ, TA,) and bold in speech. (TA.)
maSoduwEN: see 2, last sentence.

hom.sense: 1. Sadagotuhu, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,*) aor. _a {yaSodagu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. SadogN, (TḲ,) [may be rendered I walked, or went along, cheek by jole with him; lit.] I had my Sudog [or temple] over against his (another man's) in walking, or going along. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ *) [See also 3. Accord. to Golius, it means also I overtook him, and joined myself to him by his side: but for this explanation he names no authority.]
And Sadagahu, aor. as above [and probably _u also, like that of damagahu], and inf. n. as above, He struck his Sudog [or temple]. (TA.)
And Sudiga, like EuniIa, inf. n. as above, He had a complaint of his Sudog [or temple]. (TA.)

Sadagahu Eani AlOamori He turned him away, or back, from the affair. (Ḳ. [And so, accord. to Freytag, as from the Ṣ, on the authority of Aṣ, ASdgh: but he has app. taken this from a mistranscription in a copy of the Ṣ.]) One says, maA Sadagaka Eano hecaA AlOamori What turned thee away, or back, from this affair? (Aṣ, Ṣ, O:) and SadaEaka also: (Ṣ and O in art. SdE:) but the former is the better. (O in that art.)
And Ait-abaEa fulaAnN baEiyrahu famaA Sadagahu i. e. [Such a one followed his camel, and] he did not turn him aside: this is said when he has taken fright, or become refractory, and run away. (Aṣ, Ṣ, O.) And Selemeh is related to have said, AiXotarayotu sin-aworFA falamo yaSodagohun-a [I bought a cat, and he did not drive them away]; meaning the rats, or mice. (O.)
One says also, fulaAnN maA yaSodagu namolapF Such a one does not kill an ant; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) by reason of his weakness. (Ṣ.)
And Sadagahu, inf. n. as above, He straightened his, or its, Sadag, i. e. crookedness, and bending, or inclining. (TA.)
Sadaga UilaI AlX-aIoCi, inf. n. SuduwgN, He inclined to the thing. (TA.) And Sadaga Eano Tariyqihi He declined from his way, or road. (TA.)
Saduga, aor. _u {yaSodugu}, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. SadaAgapN, (Ṣ, O,) He (a man, Ṣ, O,) was, or became, weak. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) [See its part. n. SadiygN.]

entry.sense: 3. SAdghu i. q. daAraAhu [He treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him;, &c.]: or EaAraDahu fiI AlmaXoIi [he went along over against him]: (Ḳ:) Ibn-ʼAbbád says that SaAdagotu Alr-ajula means daArayotuhu: and he adds, wahiIa AlmuEaAraDapu fiI AlmaXoIi: (O: [but the right reading seems to be Oawo hiIa:]) accord. to the A, one says, SaAdagotuhu fiI AlmaXoIi SudogiI liSudogihi [I walked, or went along, with him, my temple towards his temple]. (TA.) [See also 1, first sentence.]

SudogN [The temple; i. e.] the part between the eye and the ear; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) the part between the outer angle of the eye and the root (OaSol) of the ear; (A, Mṣb;) the part of the head that slopes down to the place of attachment of the jaws; as expl. by AZ, it is [from] the place of juncture between the lHyp [app. a mistranscription for laHoI i. e. jaw, agreeably with the explanation next preceding,] and [the main portion of] the head, to the part beneath the qaron [which is the temporal ridge]; (TA;) each of what are termed the SudogaAni: (AZ, A, TA:) ISd mentions also Sudug↓, as occurring in poetry, and expresses a doubt whether it be, or be not, peculiar to poetry: (TA:) and sometimes they said sudogN, with s: Ḳṭr says that certain persons of the Benoo-Temeem, called Bel'ambar [a contraction of Benu-l-'Ambar], change s into S [or use these two letters indiscriminately] when followed by any of the letters T and q and g and x, whether the latter be second or third or fourth; saying siraATN and SiraATN, and basoTapN and baSoTapN, and sayoqalN and SayoqalN, &c.: (Ṣ, O:) the pl. is OaSodaAgN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA, [in all except the Mṣb mentioned after the signification expl. in the next sentence, and properly a pl. of pauc.,]) and also OaSodugN [which is probably used only as a pl. of pauc.]. (TA.)
And ‡ The hair that hangs down upon the place above-mentioned. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says SudogN muEaqorabN ‡ [A curled lock of hair hanging down upon the temple]. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
SadagN Crookedness, and bending, or inclining. (TA. [See 1, near the end.])
SudugN: see SudogN.
SadaAgN A mark made with a hot iron upon the Sudog [or temple, of a camel], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) or, as in the A, upon the even part of the Sudog, lengthwise. (TA.)

SadiygN an epithet applied to a child (Ṣ, Ḳ) In the stage extending to his completion of seven days: (Ṣ:) or that is seven days old: (Mgh, O, Ḳ:) because his temple becomes firm (yaXotad-u Sudoguhu) only to this period, (so in the O, [and the like is said in the Mgh,]) or because his temples are not bound (laA yuXad-u SudogaAhu) save for seven days: (so in the TA:) or it may be an instance of faEiylN in the sense of mafoEuwlN from Sadagahu Eani AlX-aIoCi meaning “he turned him away, or back, from the thing.” (O.)
And [hence, perhaps,] Weak. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

AlOaSodagaAni [The two temporal arteries;] two veins beneath the SudogaAni [or two temples], (O, Ḳ,) which, as is said by Aṣ, are always pulsing, in everyone in the world: a word having no sing., like as they say of AlmicorawaAni. (O.)
miSodagN: see what next follows.

miSodagapN A pillow, or cushion; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) because placed beneath the Sudog [or temple]; also pronounced misodagapN; and sometimes they said mizodagapN; (Ṣ, O;) and [miSodagN↓ and] misodagN and mizodagN signify the same. (TA in art. sdg.)
muSad-agN, and its fem. muSad-agapN: see what follows.

hom.sense: 1. Sadafa Ean-iI, (Ṣ, O,) or Eanohu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaSodifu}, (O, Ḳ,) He turned away from, avoided, shunned, and left, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) me, (Ṣ, O,) or him, or it; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) so the verb signifies in the Ḳur vi. 158 [and a similar instance occurs in verse 46 of the same chap.]; (O;) and so tSd-f↓ Eanohu: (O,* Ḳ:) and (so in the Ḳ [but more properly “or”]) Sadafa, (AʼObeyd, M, O, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaSodifu} (M, Ḳ) and _u {yaSodufu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. SadofN and SuduwfN, (M, O, Ḳ, TA, [SadafFA in the CK is a mistake,]) he turned away, (AʼObeyd, M, O, Ḳ, TA,) or became turned away, or back, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and declined, (Ḳ, TA,) Eanohu from it, (M, O,) namely, a thing; (O;) said of a man. (Ḳ.) And Sadafato, said of a woman, She turned away her face. (Mṣb.)
See also 4.

SadafN is an inf. n. (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb) of which the verb is Sadifa, (M, Mṣb,) and from which is derived the epithet OaSodafu↓ applied to a horse, or to a camel: (Ṣ, M, O:) it signifies, in relation to a horse, The having the thighs near together, and the hoofs far apart, with a twisting of the pasterns (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or a crookedness in the fore legs: (M:) or an inclining in the hoof towards the off side: (ISk, Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Ḳ:) or an inclining of the foot (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) of the fore leg or of the kind leg (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb) of the camel, towards the off side; (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) if towards the near side, the epithet applied to him is Oaqofadu, (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and the verb is qafida, inf. n. qafadN: (TA:) or an inclining in the qadam [or human foot]; Aṣ says, I know not whether from the right or from the left: or an approaching of one of the knees towards the other; thus, peculiarly, in the horse: or a nearness together of [the two tendons called] the EujaAyataAni, and a wideness apart of the hoofs, with a twisting of the pasterns; one of the natural faults of horses: (M:) [Mṭr says,] as meaning a twisting in the neck, I have not found it. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: 3. SAdfhu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. muSaAdafapN, (M, TA,) He found him; or lighted on him; syn. wajadahu; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) namely, another man; (Ṣ, O;) and laqiyahu [which may also be rendered he met with him; or encountered him]; (O, Ḳ, TA;) and waAfaqahu [which signifies the same]. (M,* TA, and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wfq.) One says, SaAdafotu fulaAnFA bimawoDiEi kacaA I found, or met with, such a one in such a place; syn. waAfaqotuhu. (TA in art. wfq.) And SaAdafota Oamoraka muwaAfiqFA liUiraAdatika [Thou foundest thine affair, or thy case, suitable to thy wish; i. e., foundest it to be so: thus, in this instance, and in many others, like its syns. wajadota and laqiyta, the verb has two objective complements]. (Ṣ * and Ḳ * and TA in art. wfq.)
And muSaAdafapN signifies also The being opposite, one to another; or the facing one another; or the matching one another; syn. muHaAcaApN. (TA.)

4. ASdfhu He, or it, turned him away, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) or back; or caused him to return, go back, or revert; (Ḳ, TA;) Eanohu from it; (M;) and Sadafahu↓, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. SadofN, (O,) signifies the same; (O, Ḳ;) the latter verb being trans. as well as intrans., but when trans. having only one inf. n., that mentioned above. (O.) One says, OaSodafaniI Eanohu kacaA wakacaA Such and such things turned me away from it. (Ṣ, O.)
5. tSd-f: see 1, first sentence.

Also I. q. taEar-aDa: (TA:) in the saying of Muleyh El-Hudhalee,
falam-aA Qsotawato OaHomaAluhaA wataSad-afatN
biXum-i AlmaraAqiI baAridaAti AlmadaAxili [app. describing a she-camel, or a number of camels, meaning And when her, or their, burdens were, or became, adjusted, or firm or steady, and she, or they, went alternately to the right and left, (see the phrase taEar-aDati AlUibilu AlmadaArija, in art. ErD,) in the high places of ascent, cold in the entrances thereof, because of their height], Skr says, taSad-afato means taEar-aDato. (M, TA.)
