6. taSaAdafaA, said of two sides of a mountain, They met together, and faced each other. (TA.)

hom.sense: SadafN inf. n. of Sadifa [q. v.]. (M, Mṣb.)

Also Anything high, or lofty, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) such as a wall and a mountain, (M,) or such as a wall and the like; (Ḳ;) like what is termed hadafN: (Aṣ, Ṣ, O:) and the side of a mountain: (M:) or SadafN and hadafN both signify any building or structure, that is high, or lofty, and great; (AʼObeyd, TA;) accord. to Az, likened to the Sadaf of a mountain, which is the side that faces one, thereof: (TA:) and SadafN and SudufN↓ (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) and SudafN↓ and SadufN↓, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to different readings of a passage in the Ḳur, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) [xviii. 95,] in which the dual occurs, (Ṣ, M, O,) signify the place of ending, or breaking off, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) of a mountain, (Ḳ,) or of a lofty mountain: (Ṣ, O:) or the side of a mountain: (Ḳ:) or the part between two mountains: (M:) or, as used in this instance, (Ḳ, TA,) in the verse of the Ḳur, (TA,) AlS-adafaAni, (M, Ḳ,) as also AlS-udufaAni↓, (M,) means two mountains (M, L, Ḳ) meeting together, (M, L, TA,) in the copies of the Ḳ, mutalaAziqaAni [i. e. cleaving together], but the correct reading is mutalaAqiyaAni, as in the L [and M], (TA,) between Ya-jooj and Ma-jooj: (M, L, Ḳ, TA:) and AlS-udufaAni↓, (M, Ḳ,) with damm to the d (M,) i. e. with two dammehs, especially, (Ḳ,) or this as well as AlS-adafaAni, (TA,) means the two sides of the XiEob [app. here meaning ravine, or gap, between two mountains], or of the valley: (M, Ḳ, TA:) so says IDrd: (M, TA:) both signify the two sides of the mountain when they [meet together, and] face each other, so called litaSaAdufihimaA, i. e. because of their meeting together, and facing each other, having between them a [road such as is termed] faj-, or a XiEob [expl. above], or a valley. (TA.)

Also [The mother-of-pearl shell; or oyster-shell; and any shell of a mollusk: and, by an extension of its primary application, the oyster itself; and any shell-fish, or testaceous mollusk of the water, and likewise of the land:] the cover of the pearl; (Ḳ;) or this is called Sadafu Ald-ur-api, (Ṣ, O,) or Sadafu Ald-ur-i; (Mṣb;) a kind of cover created in the sea, composed of [what are termed] SadafataAni [i. e. a pair of shell-valves], which are opened from [i. e. so as to disclose] a kind of flesh in which is life, called the maHaArap [i. e. oyster], and in the like thereof are found pearls; (Lth, TA;) i. q. maHaArN [which means oyster-shells, and also oysters themselves, and both of these may be here meant, as both are correct meanings of SadafN]: (M:) n. un. with p {SadafapN}: (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [in the Mṣb it is also said that AlS-adafapu signifies the maHaArap, which is the maHomil of the pilgrims; but I think that this is a mistake, caused by understanding maHaArap here in a wrong sense; for I find no other authority for assigning this meaning to AlS-adafapu:] pl. OaSodaAfN. (O, Ḳ.) [See an ex. of the pl. voce HalazuwnN.]
[Hence,] AlS-adafapu signifies also, (M, TA,) or Sadafapu AlOucuni, (O,) The maHaArap [or concha, i. e. the external, deep, and wide, cavity, around the hole,] of the ear. (M, O, TA.)

[And hence, also,] AlS-adafataAni signifies The two small hollows, or sockets, in each of which is set the head of one of the two thing-bones, and in each of which is a ligament (EaSabapN [app. that called ligamentum teres, forming a tie]) to that head. (M, TA.) [And in like manner, The two sockets in the scapula, in each of which turns the head of one of the two upper arm-bones: (see HaAriqapN:) or these, it seems, are called by some AlS-adafaAni; for it is said that] AlS-adafu signifies the part of the scapula which is the place of the waAbilap. (O, Ḳ.)
And SadafN also signifies ‡ Flesh, (O,) or a piece of flesh, (Ḳ, TA,) growing in a wound of the head, next the skull, resembling the cartilages. (O, Ḳ.)
And in the Tekmileh it is said that [the pl.] OaSodaAfN signifies Waves of the sea. (TA.)
See also SudafN.

entry.sense: SadufN: see SadafN, second sentence.

hom.sense: SudafN: see SadafN, second sentence.
Also, i. e. like SuradN, (O, Ḳ,) or SadafN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) A species of animal of prey: (M, O, Ḳ:*) or, as some say, a bird. (M, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: SudufN: see SadafN, in three places.

hom.sense: SadafiI-N A camel of a certain sort, (M, Ḳ,*) of excellent quality, (Ḳ,) [ISd says,] so called, (M, Ḳ,) I think, in relation to a tribe of Arabs of El-Yemen, (M,) or in relation to a sub-tribe (baTon) of Kindeh, (Ḳ,) called AlS-adifu. (M, Ḳ.) [See also SarafiI-N.]
[Also a rel. n. from SadafN; Testaceous.]

entry.sense: SaduwfN A woman who turns away her face (Lḥ, M, Mṣb) from her husband: (Lḥ, M:) or a woman who turns her face towards one and then turns away: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or a woman who desires not kisses: (M:) or having a stinking mouth, (Lḥ, Ibn-ʼAbbád, M, O, Ḳ,) as an epithet applied to a female, (Lḥ, M,) or to a male: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:) applied in this last sense to a man because he turns away his face whenever any one speaks to him. (TA.)
And A she-camel that will not come to the watering-trough until it is left to her unoccupied: like SaruwmN. (TA in art. Srm. [See also what next follows.])
SawaAdifu [pl. of SaAdifapN] Camels that come to others at the drinking-trough, and wait at their rumps until the drinkers have gone away, that they may go in. (Ṣ, O. [See also what next precedes.])
OaSodafu: see SadafN, in the first paragraph.
muSad-afN meaning One often attacked by diseases is a word used by the vulgar. (TA.)
maSoduwfN Veiled, or concealed; covered; or protected; syn. masotuwrN. (TA.)

1. Sadaqa, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaSoduqu}, (M, TA,) inf. n. SidoqN (Ṣ,* M, O,* Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and SadoqN, (M, Ḳ,) the former of which is the more chaste, (TA,) or the latter is an inf. n. and the former is a simple subst., (Ḳ,) and taSodaAqN (M) and maSoduwqapN, (O, Ḳ, TA,) which is one of the [few] inf. ns. of the measure mafoEuwlapN, (O, TA,) [or a fem. pass. part. n. used as an inf. n. like as is said of its contr. makocuwbapN,] he spoke, said, uttered, or told, truth, or truly, or veraciously; contr. of kacaba: (Mṣb: [and in like manner it is said in the Ṣ and M and O and Ḳ that SidoqN is the contr. of kacibN:]) Er-Rághib says that SidoqN and kacibN are primarily in what is said, whether relating to the past or to the future, and [in the latter case] whether it be a promise or other than a promise; and only in what is said in the way of information: but sometimes they are in other modes of speech, such as asking a question, and commanding, and supplicating; as when one says, “Is Zeyd in the house?” for this implies information of his being ignorant of the state of Zeyd; and when one says, “Make me to share with thee, or to be equal with thee,” for this implies his requiring to be made to share with the other, or to be made equal with him; and when one says, “Do not thou hurt me,” for this implies that the other is hurting him: SidoqN, he says, is [by implication] the agreeing of what is said with what is conceived in the mind and with the thing told of, together; otherwise it is not complete Sidoq, but may be described either as Sidoq or sometimes as Sidoq and sometimes as kacib according to two different points of view; as when one says without believing it, “Moḥammad is the Apostle of God,” for this may be termed Sidoq because what is told is such, and it may be termed kacib because it is at variance with what the speaker conceives in his mind. (TA.) One says, Sadaqa fiI AlHadiyvi [He spoke truth in the information, or narration]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And Sadaqahu i. e. He told him, or informed him, with truth, or veracity, (AHeyth,* M, Mṣb,*) fiI Alqawoli [in the saying]; for it is trans. as well as intrans. (Mṣb.) And Sadaqahu AlHadiyva (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, in the CK [erroneously] Sad-aqa fulAnFA AlHadiyva) He told him with truth, or veracity, the information, or narration; for it is sometimes doubly trans. (TA.) And SadaqaniI sin-a bakorihi [He hath told me truly the age, or as to the age, of his youthful camel; or SadaqaniI sin-u bakorihi the age of his youthful camel has spoken truly to me]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) a prov., (Ṣ, O,) expl. in art. bkr [q. v.]. (Ḳ.) And fulaAnN laA yaSoduqu Oavaruhu and Oavarahu, meaning Such a one, when asked, will not tell truly whence he comes. (M.) And Sadaqato yamiynuhu His oath was, or proved, true. (Mṣb in art. bt.) Sadaqotu Qll-eha HadiyvFA Uino lamo OafoEalo kacaA is an oath of the Arabs, meaning laA Sadaqotu Alx [May I not utter truly to God a saying, i. e. may I not speak truth to God, if I do not such a thing]. (AHeyth, O, Ḳ.) One says also, Sadaqahu Aln-aSiyHapa, and AlUixaMCa, He rendered to him truly, or sincerely, good advice, and brotherly affection. (M.)
And Sada quwhumu AlqitaAla (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,* TA) [They gave them battle earnestly, not with a false show of bravery; as is implied in the Ṣ, and M, and Ḳ; i. e.] they advanced against them boldly in fight: (M, TA:) and in like manner, SadaquwA fiI AlqitaAli they advanced boldly in fight: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the former means they gave them battle so as to fulfil their duty: and hence, in the Ḳur [xxxiii. 23], rijaAlN SadaquwA maA EaAhaduwA Qll-eha Ealayohi, Men who fulfilled the covenant that they had made with God. (TA.) And Sadaqa All-iqaMCa, inf. n. SidoqN, He was firm, or steady, in encounter, or conflict. (M, TA.) And Sadaqa Zan-iI My opinion was, or proved, true, or correct, like as one says [in the contrary case], kacaba: (Er-Rághib, TA:) whence, in the Ḳur [xxxiv. 19], walaqado Sadaqa Ealayohimo Uiboliysu Zan-ahu, meaning fiI Zan-ihi [i. e. And assuredly Iblees was, or proved to be, correct in his opinion that he had formed against them]: but some read Sad-aqa↓, meaning, as Fr says, Haq-aqa [i. e. Iblees proved, or found, to be true, his opinion, &c.]. (TA.) And Sadaqatohu nafosuhu His soul [told him truth; meaning,] diverted him, or hindered him, or held him back, from an undertaking, causing him to imagine himself unable to prosecute it. (TA in art. kcb.) And Sadaqa AlS-uboHu [The dawn shone clearly]. (Ṣ in art. sqT.) [And one says of a word or the like, yaSoduqu EalaI kacaA, meaning It applies correctly to such a thing.]
Sadaqa AlwaHoXiI-u: see 2, near the end.

hom.sense: 2. Sd-qhu, (Ṣ, M, O, &c.,) inf. n. taSodiyqN, contr. of kac-abahu. (O,* Ḳ.) [This explanation implies several meanings here following.] He attributed, or ascribed, to him truth, veracity, or the speaking truth. (Mṣb.) And He said to him, “Thou hast spoken truth.” (Mṣb.) He accepted, or admitted, [or assented to, or believed,] what he said: (M:) you say, Sd-qhu fiI Hadiyvihi [He accepted,, &c., what he said in his information, or narration]: (Ṣ:) and you say Sd-q bilisaAnihi [He assented to the truth of what was said with his tongue]; as well as biqalobihi [with his heart, or mind]. (T in art. Aamn.) He held him to be a speaker of truth. (MA.) [He found him to be a speaker of truth. He, or it, proved him to be a speaker of truth; verified him; or confirmed the truth of what he said: see an ex. in a verse cited voce bayonN.] He found it (an opinion) to be true, or veritable. (Ksh and Bḍ and Jel, in xxxiv. 19.) He verified it; confirmed its truth; or proved it to be true, or veritable; i. e. an opinion [&c.]; syn. Haq-aqahu: (Ksh and Bḍ, ibid.:) one says, Sad-aqa Alxabara Alxuboru [The trial, proof, or test, verified the information]. (Ṣ in art. xbr.) See 1, near the end. In the saying in the Ḳur [xxxix. 34], waQl-aciI jaMCa biAlS-idoqi waSad-aqa bihi, [which seems to be best rendered But he who hath brought the truth and he who hath accepted it as the truth, (see kac-aba biAlOamori,)] ʼAlee the son of Aboo-Tálib is related to have said that by AlcI jMC bAlSdq is meant Moḥammad; and by AlcI Sd-q bh, Aboo-Bekr: or, as some say, Gabriel and Moḥammad [are meant by the former and the latter respectively]: or by the former, Moḥammad; and by the latter, [every one of] the believers: (M:) accord. to Er-Rághib, by wSd-q bh is meant and hath found, or proved, to be true (Haq-aqa) that which he hath brought by word, by that which he hath aimed at (bimaA taHar-aAhu) by deed. (TA.)
Sd-q is also said to signify He said, “This thing is the truth;” like Haq-aqa. (TA in art. Hq.)

And this verb also denotes AlmubaAlagapu fiI AlS-idoqi: thus in the saying,
Sad-aqato fiyhimo ZunuwniI
[My opinions respecting them were, or proved to be, very true or correct]. (Ksh, in xxxiv. 19.)
Sd-q AlwaHoXiI-u, (O, Ḳ, TA,) or Sadaqa↓, (so in a copy of the M,) ‡ The wild animal ran without looking aside, when charged upon, or attacked: (M, O, Ḳ, TA:) mentioned by IDrd. (O, TA.)
Sad-aqahumo He exacted from them the poor-rate. (TA. [See SadaqapN.])
See also 5.

entry.sense: 3. SaAdaqotuhu, (M,) inf. n. muSaAdaqapN (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) and SidaAqN, (M, O, Ḳ,) the latter like kitaAbN, (TA, [in the CK erroneously written SadAq,]) I acted, or associated, with him as a friend, or as a true, or sincere, friend. (Ṣ,* M, O,* Ḳ.*) [See also 6.]

4. ASdq AlmaroOapa He named for the woman a SadaAq [or dowry]: (Ṣ, M,* O, Ḳ:) or he gave her her SadaAq: (M,* Mṣb:) or he appointed her, or assigned her, a SadaAq, on taking her as his wife: (TA:) and he married her, or took her as his wife, on the condition of his giving her a SadaAq. (Mṣb.) And sometimes this verb is doubly trans.; whence, in a trad., maA caA tuSodiquhaA faqaAla UizaAriI [It was said, “What is it that thou meanest for her, or givest her, as her dowry?” and he said, “My waist-wrapper”]. (Mgh.)

5. tSd-q Ealayohi He gave him (i. e. the poor, Mgh, Mṣb) what is termed Sadaqap, (M, Mgh, Mṣb,) meaning [an alms, or] what is given for the sake of God, (M,) or what is given with the desire of obtaining a recompense from God: (M,* Mgh:) and Sad-aqa↓ Elyh signifies the same; (M, TA;) and in this sense Sd-q is [said by some to be] used in the Ḳur lxxv. 31. (TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xii. 88], wataSad-aqo EalayonaA: (TA:) or this means † And do thou confer a favour upon us by giving that which is [not like the mean merchandise that we have brought, but of middling quality,] between good and bad. (M.) One says, taSad-aqotu bikacaA, meaning I gave such a thing as a Sadaqap. (Mṣb.) See an ex. voce Xiq-N. The saying, in a trad., Uin-a Qll-eha taSad-aqa Ealayokumo bivuluvi OamowaAlikumo, meaning ‡ [Verily God] hath conferred a favour [upon you by giving you a third of your possessions to bequeath to whom ye will], if correct, is tropical. (Mgh.)

It is said by Ibn-Es-Seed, on the authority of AZ and IJ, and mentioned by IAmb, that tSd-q signifies also He asked, or begged, for what is termed Sadaqap [or alms]: but Fr and Aṣ and others disallow the beggar's being called mutaSad-iq: (Az, TA:) IḲt says that the verb is improperly used in this sense by the vulgar: (Mṣb:) [and accord. to J and Ṣgh,] one says, mararotu birajulK yasoOalu, and one should not say yataSad-aqu. (Ṣ, O.)

6. taSaAduqN signifies The acting, or associating, as friends, or as true, or sincere, friends, one with another. (Ḳ. [See also 3.]) And I. q. SidoqN: (TA:) [or rather mutual Sidoq; contr. of takaAcubN:] one says, taSaAdaqaA fiI AlHadiyvi and fiI Almawad-api (Ṣ, O, TA) They were true, or sincere, each to the other, in information, or narration, and in love, or affection; contr. of takaAcabaA. (O, TA.)
SadoqN is an inf. n. of Sadaqa [q. v.]: (M, Ḳ:)

and is used as an epithet, applied to a man, &c.: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ, TA:) [and] SidoqN↓ [also, if not a mistranscription for SadoqN,] is an inf. n. used as an epithet, applied to a man and to a woman: (so in a copy of the M and in the TA:) [it is said that] the former signifies Hard, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb,) applied to a spear, (Ṣ, M, O,) and to other things: (M:) or even, or straight; (Ṣ, O;) or it signifies thus also, applied to a spear, and to a sword: (M:) or hard and even or straight, applied to a spear, (Ḳ, TA,) and to a man, (Ḳ,) or to the latter as meaning hard: or, as IB says, on the authority of IDrst, it is not from hardness, but means combining those qualities that are commended; and it is applied to a spear as meaning long and pliant and hard, and the like; and to a man, and to a woman likewise [without p, but see what follows], as meaning true in hardness and strength and goodness; for, IDrst says, if it meant hard, one would say HajarN SadoqN and HadiydN SadoqN, which one does not: (TA:) and, applied to anything, (O, Ḳ, TA,) it means complete, or perfect, (Kh, O, Ḳ, TA,) thus applied to a man, (TA,) such as is commended; (O;) fem. with p {SadoqapN}, (O, Ḳ, TA,) applied to a woman: (O:) the pl. is SudoqN, applied to a company of men, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and SuduqN (Ḳ) and Sadoquwna, so applied, and SadoqaAtN applied to women: (O, Ḳ:) and Ru-beh says, describing asses,
maqocuwcapu AlMcaAni SadoqaAtu AlHadaqo
meaning [Rounded, as though pared, in the ears,] penetrating in the eyes; (O, TA;) which is [said to be] tropical. (TA.) SadoqN signifies also Firm, or steady, in encounter, or conflict: (M:) or one says Sadoqu All-iqaMCi, applying this epithet to a man, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) meaning thus: (TA:) and Sadoqu Aln-aZari [firm, or steady, in look]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA. [Said in the TA to be tropical.])

SidoqN is an inf. n. of Sadaqa [q. v.]: (M, Ḳ, &c.:) or a simple subst., (Ḳ,) signifying [Truth; veracity; or] agreement of what is said with what is conceived in the mind and with the thing told of, together; otherwise it is not complete Sidoq, as expl. above in the first paragraph of this art. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

It is also syn. with Xid-apN [meaning Hardness; firmness, compactness, or soundness; strength, power, or force; vigour, robustness, sturdiness, or hardiness; and courage, bravery, or firmness of heart]: (Ḳ, TA: [in the latter of which it is said to be tropical; but this is evidently not the case accord. to the O, in which it is said that it radically denotes quw-apN (i. e. strength, force,, &c.,) in a saying, &c.: in the Ḳ it is implied by the context that it is syn. with Xid-ap when used as the complement of a prefixed n. in instances mentioned in what here follows: but Ṣgh says, more correctly,]) a noun signifying anything to which goodness is attributed is prefixed to Sidoq, governing it in the gen. case; so that one says (O) rajulu SidoqK (Sb, M, O, Ḳ) [A man of good nature or disposition or character, &c.], contr. of rajulu sawoCK; (Sb, M;) and Sadiyqu SidoqK [a friend of good nature, &c.]; (O, Ḳ;) and likewise AimoraOapu SidoqK [a woman of good nature, &c.]; (Ḳ;) and in like manner also HimaAru SidoqK [an ass of a good kind]; (Sb, M, Ḳ;) and vawobu SidoqK [a garment, or piece of cloth, of good quality]. (Sb, M.) The saying in the Ḳur [x. 93], (O,) walaqado baw-aOonaA baniI AisoraAYiyla mubaw-aOa SidoqK means And verily we assigned to the Children of Israel a good place of abode. (O, Ḳ.)
See also SadoqN.
SadoqapN: see SadaAqN; each in two places.
SudoqapN: see SadaAqN; each in two places.

SadaqapN [An alms; i. e.] a gift (Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) to the poor (Ṣ, O, Mṣb) for the sake of God, (M, Ḳ,) or to obtain a recompense from God; (M,* Mgh, Ḳ;*) a portion which a man gives forth from his property by way of propitiation, [to obtain the favour of God,] like zakaApN, except that the former is primarily applied to such as as is supererogatory, and the latter to such as is obligatory: but it is said to be applied to such as is obligatory [i. e. to the zakaAp, q. v., meaning the poor-rate, which is the portion, or amount, of property, that is given therefrom, as the due of God, by its possessor, to the poor, according to a fixed rate,] when the person who does so aims at conformity with the truth in his deed: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [in this latter sense, which is indicated in the Ṣ and O, &c., and more plainly in the M, it is very frequently used:] and thus it is used in the Ḳur ix. 104, and in like manner its pl. in ix. 60: (Er-Rághib, TA:) the pl. is SadaqaAtN. (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., laA Sadaqapa fiI AlUibili AljaAr-api [There is no poorrate in the case of working camels], because they are the riding-camels of the people; for the poorrate is in the case of pasturing camels, exclusively of the working. (Ṣ in art. jr.)
See also SadaAqN.
SaduqapN: see SadaAqN, in two places.
SuduqapN: see the next paragraph.

SadaAqN and SidaAqN↓, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former of which is the most common of the dial. vars. here mentioned, (Mṣb,) [but] the latter is [said to be] more chaste than the former, (Mgh,) and SaduqapN↓, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, (Mṣb,) and SudoqapN↓, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the dial. of Temeem, (Mṣb,) and SadoqapN↓ (M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SuduqapN↓ (M, O, Ḳ) and SadaqapN↓, (M, Ḳ,) The mahor (Ṣ, M, Mgh, O, Ḳ) of a woman; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [i. e. a dowry; nuptial gift; or gift that is given to, or for, a bride:] the pl. of SdAq is SuduqN, (M, Mgh, Mṣb,) a pl. of mult., (M,) or SudoqN, (O,) or both, (Ḳ,) and OaSodiqapN, a pl. of pauc., (M,) or this is accordant to analogy, but has not been heard; (Mgh;) the pl. of SaduqapN↓ is SaduqaAtN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the pl. of SudoqapN↓ is SudoqaAtN and SudaqaAtN and SuduqaAtN, (O,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) which last is the worst; (Ḳ;) and the pl. of SadoqapN↓ is SudaqN, (Mṣb,) or SadoqaAtN [by rule SadaqaAtN]. (O.)
SidaAqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SaduwqN Having the quality of speaking, saying, uttering, or telling, truth, or truly, or veraciously, in a high, or an eminent, degree; very, or eminently, true or veracious: (Mṣb:) pl. SuduqN and SudoqN. (Ḳ.) See also OaSodaqu.

SadiyqN A friend: (O, Ḳ:) or a true, or sincere, friend: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, TA:) applied likewise to a female, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as also SadiyqapN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former anomalous, the latter regular; (MF;) and to a pl. number, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) as in the Ḳur xxvi. 101 (M) [and in several other instances, of which see one in a verse cited voce rawiI-N]: its proper pl. is OaSodiqaMCu (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) and SudaqaMCu and SudoqaAnN, (M, Ḳ,) the last on the authority of Fr, (TA,) and OaSaAdiqu, (M, O, Ḳ,) which is a pl. pl., (Ḳ,) said by IDrd to be anomalous, unless it be a pl. pl.: (O:) and the dim. is Suday-iqN↓; one says, huwa Suday-iqiI, meaning He is the most special, or most distinguished, of my friends, or of my true, or sincere, friends. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

SadaAqapN Love, or affection: (Ḳ:) or truth, or sincerity, of love or affection: (TA:) or friendship, or friendliness; (Ṣ, M;) or true, or sincere, friendship or friendliness: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) or true firmness of heart in love or affection; an attribute of a human being only. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
Suday-iqN dim. of SadiyqN, q. v. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

Sid-iyqN One who speaks, says, utters, or tells, truth, or truly, or veraciously, much, or often: (Mgh, O, Ḳ:) [or rather having the quality of speaking, saying, uttering, or telling, truth, or truly, or veraciously, in a very high, or very eminent, degree; for] it has a more intensive signification than SaduwqN [q. v.]: (TA:) or i. q. muSad-iqN [which may have the latter of the two meanings expl. above, or may mean one who accepts, or admits, the truth of what is said, or who verifies,, &c.: or muSad-iq in a high, or an eminent, degree; for it is added that] the fem. as used in the Ḳur v. 79 means superlative in AlS-idoq and Alt-aSodiyq; as a possessive epithet, i. e. caAtu taSodiyqK: (M:) or it signifies daAYimu Alt-aSodiyqi [i. e. always muSad-iq in one or another or all of the senses assigned to this word above: it may be correctly rendered eminently, or always, veracious: and eminently, or always, accepting, or confirming, the truth]: and it may mean one who verifies his saying by deed, or act: (Ṣ:) it is said in the “Mufradát” [of Er-Rághib] that it has the first of the meanings expl. in this paragraph: or rather means, one who never lies: or rather, one by whom lying cannot be practised because of his habitual veracity: or rather, one who is true in his saying and his belief, and who confirms his truth by his deed, or acting. (TA.)
SaAdiqN Speaking, saying, uttering, or telling, truth, or truly, or veraciously; true in respect of speech, &c., or veracious. (Mṣb, TA.)
SidoqN SaAdiqN is a phrase like XiEorN XaAEirN, meaning Eminent, and exalted, veracity. (M, TA.*)

And HamolapN SaAdiqapN [A charge, or an assault, made with earnestness, not with a false show of bravery,] is like the saying [in the contr. case] HamolapN kaAcibapN. (M, TA:* said in the latter to be tropical.) See also maSodaq, in two places.
One says also tamorN SaAdiqu AlHalaAwapi, meaning Very sweet dates. (IDrd, O.)
And barodN SaAdiqN Vehement, or intense, cold. (TA voce baHotN, &c.)

AlS-ayodaqu The small star cleaving to the middle one of [those called] banaAtu naEoXK AlkuboraI [which compose the tail of Ursa Major]; (Kr, M, TA;) [i. e. the star called Als-uhaA, q. v.; for] it is said that the first of bnAt nEX AlkbrI, that is at the extremity thereof, is named AlqaAYidu; and the second is AlEanaAqu, and by the side of it is a small star named Als-uhaA and AlS-ayodaqu; and the third is AlHawaru: (O:) or, accord. to AA, (O, TA,) the pole-star (AlquTobu). (O, Ḳ, TA. [But this is strange; and the more so as it is added in the Ḳ that it is expl. in art. qwd; for the explanation in that art. (though not free from obvious mistakes) identifies AlS-ayodaqu with Als-uhaA.])

And, (Ḳ,) accord. to Sh, (O, TA,) it signifies AlOamiynu [The trusted, trusted in, or confided in,, &c.]. (O, Ḳ. [But it is added in the O that Sh cites a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abi- s-Salt in which AlOamiynu is applied as an epithet to the star called AlSaydq.])
And, (Ḳ,) accord. to some, as AA says, (O,) it signifies The king. (O, Ḳ.)
faEalahu fiI gib-i SaAdiqapK [in the CK faEalahu gib-a SAdiqapK] means He did it after the affair, or case, had become manifest to him. (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA.)
SunoduwqN, mentioned in this art. in the Ṣ and Mṣb: see art. Sndq.

OaSodaqu [More, and most, true or veracious]. One says OaSodaqu mino qaTaApK [More veracious than a katáh]; because the bird thus called cries qaTaA qaTaA; [thus telling where it is to be found;] its name being imitative of its cry: (Meyd, and TA in art. qTw:) hence it is called by the Arabs AlS-aduwqu↓: the saying is a prov. (Meyd.)

cuw maSodaqK, (JK, Ṣ, M, O,) with fet-ḥ, (Ṣ,) or cuw miSodaqK↓ like minobar, (Ḳ,) applied to a man, (JK, M,) [i. e.] applied to a courageous man, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) means SaAdiqu↓ AlHamolapi [Earnest, not making a false show of bravery, in the charge, or assault]; (JK, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ;) or courageous [in the charge, or assault]: (JK:)
maSaAdiqu, occurring in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, may be for cawuw maSaAdiqa; or it may be an anomalous pl. of SidoqN [used as an epithet], like malaAmiHu and maXaAbihu [pls. of lamoHapN and XabahN]. (M.) Also, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) applied to a horse, (M,) [i. e.] applied to a fleet and excellent horse, (Ṣ, O,) in like manner, (M,) meaning SaAdiqu↓ AljaroIi [Earnest in running]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as though fulfilling his promise of running: (Ṣ, O: [said in the TA to be tropical:]) Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh says,
UicaA maA QsotaHam-ato OaroDuhu mino samaAYihi
jaraI wahowa mawoduwEN wawaAEidu maSodaqi
meaning When his hoofs are wetted with the sweat of his upper parts, he runs, being left to himself, not beaten nor chidden, and a fulfiller of his promise to do his utmost. (Ṣ, O.) And sometimes it is applied to an opinion, in like manner [as meaning True, or sincere]. (M.)
maSodaqN also signifies Hardness. (Th, M.)

Also i. q. Had-N [as meaning The edge of a sword]: (TA:) [in a copy of the M written jid-, which I think an evident mistake; for it is added,] and it is said to have this meaning in a verse of Dureyd Ibn-Eṣ-Ṣimmeh [relating to a sword]. (M, TA.)
miSodaq: see the next preceding paragraph
muSad-aqN A man from whom the poor-rate (Sadaqap) of his cattle is exacted. (TA.)

hom.sense: muSad-iqN One who accepts, admits, assents to, or believes, another in his information, or narration. (Ṣ, TA.)

Also The exactor, or collector, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) of the SadaqaAt, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) i. e. (TA) of the Huquwq [or dues, meaning poor-rates], (M, TA,) of the cattle, (Mṣb,) or of the sheep or goats, (Ṣ, M, O, TA,) and of the camels, (M, O, TA,) for the persons to whom pertain the shares [thereof]. (TA.)

entry.sense: muS-ad-iqN: see mutaSad-iqN.

miSodaAqN A thing that confirms, or proves, the truth of a thing: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [and] a verbal evidence of the truth, or veracity, of a man. (Ḥar p. 106.) One says, hecaA miSodaAqu hecaA This is what confirms, or proves, the truth of this. (Ṣ.) And XaIoCN layosa lahu miSodaAqN [A thing having nothing to verify it]. (IAạr, TA in art. brq.)

maSoduwqapN [see 1, near the beginning]. One says layosa liHamolatihi maSoduwqapN [meaning There is no earnestness attributable to his charge, or assault]; like as one says [in the contr. case], lys lahaA makocuwbapN. (M.)

mutaSad-iqN One who gives what is termed Sadaqap [meaning alms]: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) accord. to Kh, it means thus, and also one who asks [alms]; (O, TA;) and IAmb says the like; but Az says that the skilful of the grammarians disallow this; and thus say Fr and Aṣ and others: (TA:) [J, also, and Ṣgh and Fei, say that] it has only the former meaning: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) it is also pronounced muS-ad-iqN↓, by substitution [of S for t] and incorporation [of one S into the other]; (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ;*) and this pronunciation of the pl. both masc. and fem. occurs in the Ḳur lvii. 17, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) where Ibn-Ketheer and Aboo-Bekr, differing from others, read without teshdeed to the S. (O.)

SayodalN Stones [i. e. pieces of ore] of silver: mentioned by IB on the authority of IDrst: and he says that HijaArapu AlEaqaAqiyri [meaning drugs resembling pieces of stone, such as pieces of gum, &c.,] are likened thereto. (TA.)
SayodalapN [The trade of the SayodalaAniI-;] the sale of EiTaArap [i. e. drugs and perfumes]. (Ḳ,* TA.)

SayodalaAniI-N (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) a word of wellknown meaning: (M:) A seller of medicines (Mgh, Mṣb, TA) and of drugs (TA) and of perfumes: (Ḳ, TA:) a rel. n. from SayodalaAnu, the name of a town or place, (Ḳ,) or from SayodalN meaning as expl. above; (IB, TA;) or a Pers. word arabicized: (M:) and SayodanaAniI-N signifies the same, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, SanodanaAniI-N,]) and so SanodalaAniI-N: (Ḳ in this art., and O and Ḳ in art. Sndl:) the pl. of the first is SayaAdilapN. (M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Also A king: and so SayodanaAniI-N. (M in art. Sdn.)

1. Sadamahu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaSodimu}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. SadomN, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) He dashed himself, i. e. his body, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA,) against him, (Ṣ, TA,) or against it, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA,) i. e., a thing: (Mgh:) or he struck it, or knocked it, [or struck or knocked against it,] namely, a hard thing with the like thereof. (M, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, Alkalobu UicaA qatala AlS-ayoda SadomFA laA yuWokalu [i. e. When the dog kills the game by dashing himself against it, it shall not be eaten]. (Mgh.) [See also 3.]

And Sadamahu, aor. as above, (Mṣb,) and so the inf. n., (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He pushed, thrust, or repelled, him, or it. (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) One says, Sadamotu AlX-ar-a biAlX-ar-i [I repelled evil with evil]. (TA.)
And Sadamatohu Humay-aA AlkaOosi i. e. ‡ [The intoxicating influence of the cup of wine] smote him [or attacked him] in his head. (TA.)
And Sadamahumo OamorN, (M, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) ‡ An event befell them. (M, Ḳ,* TA.)
And Sadamahu biAlqawoli † He silenced him by speech. (Mṣb.)

3. SAdmhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. muSaAdamapN, (TA,) He, or it, dashed against him, or it, being dashed against by him, or it: (Ṣ,* PṢ:) or struck, or knocked, him, or it, being struck, or knocked, by him, or it: (Ḳ,* PṢ:) or pushed, thrust, or repelled, him, or it, being pushed,, &c., by him, or it; (Ḳ,* TA;) syn. daAfaEahu: (TA, and Ḥam p. 313:) and i. q. saAk-ahu [i. e. he struck him, or it; or struck him, or it, vehemently, with a broad thing, or with anything; or slapped him with his hand; being struck,, &c., by him]: (Ḥam ibid.:) [but, like as daAfaEahu often signifies the same as dafaEahu, so accord. to Fei,] SaAdamahu AlHimaAru means Sadamahu [i. e. The ass dashed against him;, &c.]. (Mṣb in art. Xtm.)

6. taSaAdamaA, (Ṣ, Mgh,) said of two men running, (Mgh,) and AiSoTadamaA↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, Ḳ,) said of two horsemen, (Mgh,) and of two stallion [camels], (TA,) They dashed themselves together, each against the other: (Ṣ,* TA, PṢ:) or they struck, or knocked, [against] each other; they collided; (Ḳ,* TA;) each of them struck with himself the other: (Mgh:) or both verbs, said of two horsemen, they smote each other, each of them with his weight and his sharpness or vigorousness or valiantness: (Mṣb:) [or they pushed, thrust, or repelled, each other: (see 1:)] and tSAdmwA they pushed, pressed, crowded, or thronged, together; or dashed, one against another; (M, Ḳ, TA; but in the M, only the inf. n. is mentioned;) like two ships in the sea. (TA.)
8: see the next preceding paragraph {6}.

hom.sense: SadomapN A single shock, or collision: (KL:) a single impulsion, push, or thrust: (TA:) and † a vehement befalling of an event. (KL.) It is said in a trad., AlS-aboru Einoda AlS-adomapi AlOuwlaI (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) i. e. † [Patience is to be exercised] at the first [shock, or] assault, or attack, of the calamity: (TA:) meaning that patience is the last thing in the case of every misfortune, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) but it is [most] commended, (Ṣ,) or is most rewarded, (Mṣb,) on the occasion of the sharpness, or vehemence, thereof. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) And one says, Oatayotu EalaI AlOamorayoni SadomapF waAHidapF [I made an end of the two affairs at one dash, or at one stroke]. (TA.)
And A baldness in the side of the forehead; syn. nazoEapN. (Ḳ.)
See also AlS-adimataAni, in two places.

entry.sense: SidomapN: see SidomN.

AlS-adimataAni (AZ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and AlS-adomataAni↓ (Ḳ) The jabiynaAni [or two parts whereof each is termed jabiyn, above the temple, on either side of the forehead]: (Ḳ:) or the two sides (AZ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of the jabiyn (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ) or of the jabiynaAni: (M:) or, accord. to AA, as is stated in a marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ, the correct meaning is the two sides of the forehead. (TA.)
And AlSdmtAn [i. e. AlS-adimataAni or AlS-adomataAni↓] signifies also The two sides of the valley: as though, by reason of their confronting, they struck each other. (TA.)
SudaAmN: see what next follows.

SidaAmN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or SudaAmN↓, (M,) asserted by Az to be with damm, (TA,) or the latter is vulgar, (Ṣ,) not allowable, (Ḳ,) though agreeable with analogy, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) being like SudaAEN and zukaAmN and duwaArN and other terms for diseases, (TA,)
A certain disease in the heads of horses or similar beasts: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or, accord. to ISh, a certain disease that attacks camels, in consequence of which their bellies become affected with acidity, and they relinquish the water, though thirsty, for some days, until they recover or die. (TA.)
OaSodamu Bald in the sides of the forehead. (Ḳ.)
miSodamN A man vehement in war, and courageous; or a warrior; or known, experienced warrior; syn. miHorabN. (M.)
UibilN muSad-amapN: see what follows.
jamalN maSoduwmN A camel affected with [the disease termed] SidaAm: and UibilN muSad-amapN↓ [camels affected therewith]. (TA.)
SayodanN A firm, strong, or compact, building. (M.)
And A firm, strong, or compact, garment, or piece of cloth: (M:) or a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC that is stout, or strong, or that is thick, or compact, in texture. (Ḳ.)
And A king; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) because of the firmness of his rule, or his state, or condition; as also SayodanaAniI-N↓ and SayodalaAniI-N. (M.)
And A fox; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also SayodanaAniI-N↓: (Ḳ:) or AlS-ayodanu is one of the names thereof. (TA.)
And The hyena. (Ḳ.)
See also SayodanaAniI-N.
Also A species of fly, that makes a buzzing sound over the herbage. (IKh, TA.)

SayodaAnN Pieces of silver, (M, TA,) when struck from the stone [or ore] thereof: (TA:) n. un. with p {SayodaAnapN}. (M, TA.) [See also SayodanN, above, last signification. And see SayodaAnN in art. Syd.]

And Stone cooking-pots: (M, TA:) in this sense [likewise] a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p {SayodaAnapN}. (IB and L in art. Syd, in which it is mentioned in the Ṣ and L and Ḳ.) [See, again, SayodaAnN, and also SayodaMCu, in art. Syd.]
And Small pebbles: (IAạr, M, TA:) or so SayodaAnu AlHaSaI. (L in art. Syd.)
SayodaAnapN [as a n. un.: see SayodaAnN, above.]
[Also] Rugged, hard ground, in which is fine stone. (M, TA.)
See also two other significations (mentioned here in the TA) in art. Syd.

SayodanaAniI-N A certain creeping thing, (daAb-apN, M,) or a small creeping thing, (duwayob-apN, Ṣ, Ḳ,) that makes for itself a habitation in the ground, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) within the ground, (M,) and conceals it; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) i. e. covers it over; (M;) so says AʼObeyd; (Ṣ;) also called SayodanN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to IKh, a certain small creeping thing (dwyb-p) that collects pieces of stick, or wood, from the plants: accord. to IAạr, a certain creeping thing (daAb-apN) having many legs, so many that they cannot be counted, which are short and long. (TA.)
See also SayodanN, in two places.

Also i. q. SayodalaAniI-N (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA) as meaning A seller of medicines, (Mgh,) or of perfumes: so called as being likened to the small creeping thing mentioned above: or from SayodanN in a sense expl. above as syn. with SayodalN. (TA.)
1. SadowN as an inf. n. of which the verb is SadaA: see 2 in art. SdI, in two places.
SadowN as a subst. A certain liquid poison which is applied upon arrow-heads, or spear-heads, or the like, resembling the blood of the [serpent called] Oasowad. (M, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. SadiIa, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaSodaI, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. SadFI, He thirsted: (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he thirsted vehemently. (M.)
SadaA, inf. n. SadowN: see 2, in two places.

2. taSodiyapN signifies The clapping with the hands; syn. taSofiyqN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) accord. to Er-Rághib, as being like the echo (AlS-adaI), inasmuch as there is no profit in it; (TA;) or it is from AlS-ad-u, because they [who practised it in their worship] used to turn away (kaAnuwA yaSud-uwna) from El-Islám; (Ḳ;) [see more in the second paragraph {2} of art. Sd;] and SadowN [an inf. n. of which the verb is SadaA↓] signifies the same; (Ḳ;) and so taSad-K↓, of which AHeyth cites as an ex. the saying of Hassán
SalaAtuhumu Alt-aSad-aI waAlmukaMCu
[Their prayer is the clapping with the hands, and whistling: like the saying in the Ḳur viii. 35]: (TA:) one says of a man, Sd-I, (M,) or Sd-I biyadayohi, (TA,) meaning He clapped with his hands; (M, TA;) [said to be] originally Sad-ada; (M;) and SadaA↓ biyadayohi, inf. n. SadowN [mentioned above], meaning the same. (TḲ.)
also muSad-iyapN.

entry.sense: 3. SAdAhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muSaAdaApN, (Ṣ,) He imitated him, or it; syn. EaAraDahu: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) and he, or it, corresponded, and was equal, to him, or it. (TA.) In the Ḳur xxxviii. 1, some read SaAdi, with kesr, as an imperative from AlmuSaAdaApu (Bḍ, TA) as meaning AlmuEaAraDapu; and hence AlS-adaI [i. e. the echo], because it imitates (yuEaAriDu) the first sound: so that the meaning is, Imitate thou (EaAriD) the Ḳur-án by thy works. (Bḍ.)

[And] i. q. dab-arahu [i. e. He considered, or forecast, its issues, or results; did, performed, or executed, it with thought, or consideration; or managed, conducted, ordered, or regulated, it]; relating to an affair: (M:) [or] AlmuSaAdaApu signifies the turning about, or revolving, the opinion, or idea, [that one forms] respecting the management (tadobiyr) of a thing, and the doing of it: (Ḥam p. 35:) [or,] accord. to Aṣ, the minding a thing attentively, carefully, or solicitously: a man who had assisted his she-camel in her bringing forth said, bit-u OuSaAdiyhaA Tuwla layoliI [I passed all my night minding her attentively, carefully, or solicitously]; because he disliked binding her fore shank to her arm, as it would distress her; or leaving her, as she might go away at random and the wolf might devour her young one: and in like manner one says of the pastor, yuSaAdiI Uibilahu [He minds attentively,, &c., his camels]; when they thirst before the completion of their usual period of being kept from drinking, he restricts them to journeying by night so as to arrive at water on the morrow. (TA.)

And He soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him; or deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; or strove, endeavoured, or desired, to do so: syn. daAraAhu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) and daAjaAhu, and saAtarahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) all of which have one meaning, (TA,) [though the last implies concealing enmity,] and laAyanahu. (M.) mano SaAdaAka faqado SaAdaka [He who soothes thee, or coaxes thee, surely ensnares thee] is a saying mentioned in the A. (TA.)
4. ASdI It (a mountain) returned an echo. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)
And He (a man, TA) died; (Ḳ, TA;) as though [meaning] his echo ceased; the | having a privative effect. (TA.)

5. Alt-aSad-iI, accord. to Er-Rághib, signifies The corresponding to a thing like as does the echo returning from the mountain. (TA.) [But accord. to others,] tSd-I lahu is originally taSad-ada; (Az and L in art. Sd;) and signifies taEar-aDa, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and taDar-aEa. (M.) [See 5 in art. Sd; where the usages of this verb, except in the senses mentioned and indicated here below, are fully explained.]
It signifies also The feigning oneself unmindful, negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless, not being really so. (TA.)
And The diverting oneself. (TA.)
See also 2.

hom.sense: SadFI [sometimes written SadFA] An echo; i. e. AlS-adaI signifies what the mountain returns to him who utters a sound, or voice, or cry, therein; (Ḳ;) or the sound of the mountain and the like that responds to one; (M;) or what responds to one with the like of his voice, or cry, in the mountains, &c. (Ṣ.) One says, Sam-a SadaAhu ‡ [His echo became dumb, or may his echo become dumb]; (Ṣ, TA;) meaning he perished, or may he perish: (Ṣ and Ḳ and TA in art. Sm:) and OaSam-a Qll-ehu SadaAhu ‡ [May God make his echo to return no sound]; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) meaning may God destroy him: (Ṣ, Ḳ, and TA in art. Sm:) for when a man dies, the SdI hears not from him anything, that it should respond to him. (Ṣ. [See also another explanation of this saying in what follows.])
And A sound, voice, or cry, (M, TA,) in an absolute sense. (TA.)

Also The part of the head, (M,) or the part of the brain, (TA,) which is the place [or seat] of hearing. (M, TA.) And therefore one says, OaSam-a Qll-ehu SadaAhu [May God render deaf the part of his brain which is the seat of hearing]. (TA.)

And The brain, (M, Ḳ, TA,) itself. (TA.) And The [entire] contents (lit. the stuffing, HaXow,) of the head; (M, Ḳ, TA;) also called the haAmap. (TA.) One says, SadaEa Qll-ehu SadaAhu [May God crack his brain, or the contents of his head]. (M.)

And A bird that cries in the haAmap [or head] of the slain when his blood has not been avenged by retaliation: (M:) or a bird that comes forth (M, Ḳ) from his head, (mino raOosihi, M,) or from the head of the slain, (Ḳ,) when he, or it, has become consumed, or decayed, (M, Ḳ,) also called the haAmap; (M;) accord. to the assertion of the people of the Time of Ignorance; (M, Ḳ;) mentioned by AʼObeyd; and some of them used to say that the bones of the dead became a haAmap, which flew: pl. OaSodaMCN: (TA:) and [this may be meant by the saying that it signifies] the male of the buwm (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA) and haAm: pl. OaSodaMCN: (M:) they used to say that when a man was slain and his blood was not avenged by retaliation, there came forth from his head a bird like the buwmap, i. e. the haAmap, the male being called the SdI; and it cried upon his grave, AisoquwniI AisoquwniI [Give ye me to drink, give ye me to drink, meaning, of the blood of the slayer]; and if the slayer was slain, it abstained from its crying: (TA:) and [it is said that] it signifies also the body [itself] of a human being after his death; (M, Ḳ;) or the remains of the dead in his grave, i. e. his juv-ap [or corpse]. (Jm, TA.)

And, (Ḳ,) accord. to El-'Adebbes, (Ṣ,) [A cricket;] a certain flying thing, that creaks by night, and hops, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and flies, thought by the [common] people to be the junodab, but it is only the SdI, the jndb being smaller than the SdI. (Ṣ. [See also AlS-ar-aAru.])
And A certain fish, black, long, (Ḳ, TA,) and bulky: n. un. SadaApN. (TA.)
And [A man] small, or slender, in person; (AA, M, Ḳ, TA;) and so SadaOo, with C, as mentioned by Az. (TA. [See also SadoEN and SadaEN.])

And Knowing in respect of what is conducive to the good of cattle: (Ḳ:) or SadaI maAlK means thus: (M:) or gentle in the management of cattle; like UizaMCu maAlK: so in the Jm: (TA:) or, as some particularly say, of camels: (M, TA:) [i. e.] you say, Uin-ahu laSadaI UibilK, meaning Verily he is knowing in respect of camels, and of what is conducive to their good. (Ṣ.)

Also Thirst: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or vehement thirst: (M:) [see the first paragraph, in which it is mentioned as an inf. n.:] it is said that thirst does not become vehement but the brain dries, and therefore the skin of the forehead of him who dies of thirst cracks. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.

entry.sense: SadK and SaAdK↓ and SadoyaAnu↓ (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SadFI↓ [which last is an inf. n. used as an epithet] (M) Thirsting: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or thirsting vehemently: (M:) fem. [of the first] SadiyapN (Mṣb) and [of the second] SaAdiyapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of the third] SadoyaA↓: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and the pl. of SaAdiyapN is SawaAdK. (Ḥam p. 329.)
SadaApN: see SadFI, last sentence.
SaAdK (fem. SaAdapK, and pl. of the latter SawaAdK): see SadK.

As pl. of SaAdiyapN, (M,) SawaAdK signifies [also] Tall palm-trees: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and sometimes, such as drink not water: (Ṣ:) or palm-trees that drink water: [thus in a copy of the M:] and some say, such as are tall thereof, and of other trees. (M.)
kaOosN muSodaApN [A cup of wine] having much water: contr. of muEoraqapN, this meaning “having little water.” (M.)
miSodaMCN A man who thirsts much. (M.)

muSad-iyapN The woman who faces, or decorates, (tuSad-iI↓, [which I thus render conjecturally, finding nothing to indicate its meaning except what here follows,]) the wisaAdap [i. e. pillow, or cushion,] with AlOaranodaj, meaning black lines, upon the leather [that forms its covering]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Sar-a, (Ṣ, A, TA,) aor. _i {yaSoriru}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. SariyrN, said of the junodab [which is app. a species of locust], and of a writing-reed, and of a door, (Ṣ, A, TA,) or of a dog-tooth, (nAb, so in a copy of the Ṣ in the place of bAb in other copies as in the A and TA,) It made a sound, or noise; (Ṣ, A, TA;) or a prolonged sound or noise; [meaning it creaked; or made a creaking, or grating, sound;] and so anything that makes a similar prolonged sound: and [in like manner] AiSoTar-at↓ said of a mast (saAriyap), it creaked, or made a creaking sound: (TA:) but when there is a lightness, or slightness, and reiteration, of the sound, they use the reduplicative form, SaroSara↓, inf. n. SaroSarapN, (Ṣ,* TA,) signifying he (the bird called OaxoTab, Ṣ, A, TA, and the hawk, or falcon, Ṣ, M, TA, or other bird, or flying thing, M) uttered his [reiterated quavering] cry; (Ṣ, M, A, TA;) as though they imitated prolongation in the cry of the junodab [and the like], and reiteration in the cry of the OaxoTab [and the like thereof]. (Ṣ, TA.) Sar-a Aljunodabu is a prov., expl. in art. jdb [q. v.]. (TA in that art.)
Also He (a sparrow) [chirped, or] uttered a cry, or cries. (TA.)

Sar-a,, aor. _i {yaSoriru}, inf. n. Sar-N and SariyrN; and SaroSara↓; He cried, called out, or raised a cry or clamour, (M, Ḳ,) with vehemence, (Ḳ,) or with the utmost vehemence: (M:) and [in like manner] one says, jaMCa yaSoTar-u↓ He came [making a clamour, or] in clamour. (TA.)
And Sar-a SimaAxuhu, inf. n. SariyrN, His ear-hole sounded, (M, Ḳ,) or tingled, or rang, (A,) by reason of thirst. (M, A, Ḳ.) And Sar-ati AlOucunu The ear tingled, or rang. (ISk, A.)
And Sar-a, aor. as above, He thirsted [app. so as to hear a ringing in his ears]. (IAạr.)
Sar-N [as inf. n. of Sar-a] also signifies The act of binding [a captive, &c.: see the pass. part. n., maSoruwrN]. (Mgh.)
You say, Sar-a, [aor. _u {yaSoruru},] (Ṣ, M, A,) inf. n. Sar-N, (M, TA,) He tied up a purse, (Ṣ, M,* TA,) and money in a purse. (A.)

And Sar-aAln-aAqapa (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and biAln-aAqapi, (M, Ḳ,) or Sar-a Aln-aAqapa biAlS-iraAri, (Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaSoruru}, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. Sar-N; (M, Ḳ;) [and app. Sar-arahaA↓; (see the pass. part. n., voce maSoruwrN;)] He bound the SiraAr [q. v.] upon the she-camel; (Ṣ;) [i. e.] he bound the she-camel's udder with the SiraAri: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA:) and Sar-a AlOaTobaMCa biAlS-iraAri [He bound the teats with the SrAr]. (A.) [See a verse of El-Kumeyt cited voce rijolN: and see also what there follows it.]
[Hence,] Sar-ahaA means also † He left off milking her [i. e. the camel]. (Mṣb.)
And tuSar-u, [aor. of Sur-at,] said of a leathern bucket (dalow) that has become flaccid, It is tied, and has a loop-shaped handle affixed within it, having another such opposite to it. (Ḳ,* TA.)

And one says, Sar-a EalaI-a AlT-ariyqa qalaA Oajidu masolakFA ‡ [He closed, or has closed, against me the road, or way, so that I find not any passage]. (A.) And Sur-ato EalaI-a hecihi Albalodapu falaA Oajidu minohaA maxolaSFA ‡ [This town has become closed against me so that I find not any way of escape from it]. (A.)

And Sar-a Oucunayohi, [aor. _u {yaSoruru}, inf. n. Sar-N,] He (a horse) contracted his ears to his head: (ISk, Ṣ:) or pointed and raised his ears; which a horse does only when he exerts himself and hastens in his pace: (TA:) or he (an ass) straightened and erected his ears to listen; as also OaSar-ahumaA↓: (A:) and OaSar-a↓ used intransitively, (ISk, Ṣ,) without the mention of the ears, (A,) signifies the same as Sar-a Oucunayohi: (ISk, Ṣ, A:) and Sar-a biOucunihi and Sar-a Oucunahu, aor. and inf. n. as above; and OaSar-a↓ bihaA; he (a horse, and an ass,) straightened and erected his ear to listen; (M, Ḳ;) as also Sar-arahaA↓. (TA.)
[The inf. n.] Sar-N signifies also The act of confining, withholding, hindering, or preventing. (TA.)
And Sur-a ‡ He had an iron collar put upon his neck, or round his neck and hands together. (A.)

And Sar-a, aor. _u {yaSoruru}, He collected together a thing, or things, (IAạr,) or anything. (TA.) And Sar-ara↓ kalaAmFA † He collected something to be said in his bosom, or mind. (L and TA, from a trad.) And SaroSara↓ AlmaAla, inf. n. SaroSarapN, He collected together the property, or the camels or the like, and put back what had become scattered of the extreme portions thereof. (T, TA.)
And Sur-a It (a plant, or herbage,) became smitten by cold, or by intense cold. (M, Ḳ.)
2: see 1, in three places.
Sar-arato said of a she-camel, She preceded. (Aboo-Leylà, M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. SAr-hu EalaI AlX-aIoCi He compelled him against his will to do the thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4: see 1, latter part, in three places.

ASr- Ealayohi, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. UiSoraArN, (TA,) † He persevered, or persisted, in it; or kept to it perseveringly. (Ṣ, TA.) You say, ASr- EalaI fiEolihi † He persevered, or persisted, in doing it. (Mṣb.) And ASr- EalaI Alc-anobi ‡ He persevered, or persisted, in the crime, sin, or act of disobedience. (M, TA.) The verb is used in this sense when its object is evil, or crime, or the like. (TA.)
And † He determined, resolved, or decided, upon it. (M, Mgh, Ḳ.) You say, ASr- EalaI fiEolihi † He determined, resolved, or decided, upon going on in doing it, and not turning back. (TA.)

ASr- yaEoduw † He hastened (M, Ḳ) somewhat (M) in running: (M, Ḳ: [in the CK, for OaSar-a yaEoduw OasoraEa, is put AaSar-a baEuda waAasoraEa:]) accord. to AʼObeyd, the verb in this sense is OaDar-a; but Et-Toosee asserts that this is a mistranscription. (M.)

ASr-Als-unobulu The ears of corn became such as are termed Sarar [q. v.]: (M, Ḳ:) [or] accord. to ISh, one says, ASr- Alz-aroEu, inf. n. UiSoraArN, meaning The seed-produce [i. e. corn] put forth the extremities of its awn, before its ears had become developed. (TA.)
8: see 1, former half, in two places.
ASTr- said of a solid hoof, It was, or became, narrow, or contracted, (Ṣ, TA,) in an unseemly manner, or immoderately. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. SaroSara, inf. n. SaroSarapN: see 1, former half, in two places:
and the same paragraph {1}, last sentence but one.
Sar-N A leathern bucket (dalow) that, in consequence of its having become flaccid, is tied, and has a loop-shaped handle affixed within it, having another such opposite to it. (Ḳ,* TA.)
See also SariyrapN.

entry.sense: Sir-N (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Sir-apN↓ (M, A, Ḳ) Cold: (Th, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or intense cold; (Zj, M, A, Ḳ;) as also SaroSarN↓: (Ḥam p. 719:) or cold that smites the herbage and the seed-produce of the field: (Ṣ:) in the Ḳur iii. 113, the first of these words has the first of the meanings expl. above: (IAmb:) or the second meaning: (Zj:) or signifies noise and commotion: or, accord. to I’Ab, fire. (IAmb.)

And riyHN Sir-N (M, A, Ḳ) and SaroSarN↓ (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) A wind intensely cold: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) or very intensely cold: (T in explanation of the latter:) or vehemently loud: (M, A, Ḳ:) of SaroSarN↓ some say that it is originally Sar-arN, from Sir-N meaning “cold;” the incipient letter being repeated, and put in the place of the medial r: others, that it is from Sariyru AlbaAbi [“the creaking of the door”], and from Sar-apN meaning “vociferation, or clamour.” (ISk.)
And Sir-N is the name of A certain bird, like the sparrow (Ḳ, TA) in size, (TA,) of a yellow colour: (Ḳ, TA:) so called because of its cry: or, as some say, the sparrow (EuSofuwr) itself. (TA.)

hom.sense: Sar-apN Vociferation, or clamour: (Ṣ, M, A, TA:) so in the Ḳur li. 29: (TA:) or the most vehement vociferation or clamour or crying (Zj, M, Ḳ *) of a man and of a bird, &c. (Zj, M.) [In the Ḳ, this meaning is erroneously assigned to Sir-apN.]
And Vehemence of grief or anxiety (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and of war (M, Ḳ) and of heat, (Ḳ,) or of the hot season, (M,), &c.: (Ṣ, M:) and vehemence of the heat of summer. (Ṣ, A.)
And A contraction, or much contraction, and sternness, or moroseness, of the face, (Ḳ, TA,) by reason of dislike, or hatred. (TA.)

Also A company, a collection, or an assemblage. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) So in the following words of Imra-el-Ḳeys:
jawaAHiruhaA fiI Sar-apK lamo tuzay-ali
(Ṣ, M) i. e. Those of them that remained behind, in a herd, not dispersed: (EM p. 48: [see the entire verse voce duwnN:]) or fI Sr-p here means in [the midst of] clamour: (Ṣ:) or in vehemence of grief or anxiety. (Ṣ, M.)

Also i. q. EaTofapN (M, Ḳ) [i. e.] A certain bead (xarazapN) by which women fascinate men so as to withhold them from other women. (Lḥ, M, Ḳ, TA. [This is evidently what is meant by EaTofap, but is given in the M and Ḳ as a signification distinct therefrom.])
See also muSar-aApN.

entry.sense: Sur-apN A purse (XarajN, M, Ḳ, in the CK XarojN,) for money; (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also maSar-N↓, with fet-ḥ, (TA,) or miSar-N↓: (so in a copy of the A:) pl. of the first, SurazN. (Mṣb.) Hence the prov., AifotaHo Suraraka taEolamo Eujaraka, meaning † Return to thyself, [or lay open the recesses of thy mind,] and thou wilt know [thy vices, or faults, or] thy good from thy evil. (Meyd. [See also SuradN, last explanation.])
Sir-apN: see Sir-N.

SararN Ears of corn (sunobul) after the culm is produced, (M, Ḳ, [in the CK, yuqaS-abu is put in the place of yuqaS-ibu,]) before they become apparent: (M:) or ears of corn while the farina has not come forth into them: n. un. with p {SararapN}: (AḤn, M, Ḳ:) or, accord. to ISh, corn when the leaves become twisted, and the extremity of the ears becomes dry, or tough, though the farina have not come forth into them. (TA.) [See 4, last sentence.]
SaraArN: see SaruwrapN, in two places.

hom.sense: SiraArN The thing with which a she-camel's udder is bound: (M, Ḳ:) the string which is tied over the she-camel's udder and over the [piece of wood called] tawodiyap, in order that her young one may not suck her; (Ṣ;) and in order that it may not make any impression upon her, they smear her teats with fresh [dung of the kind called] baEar: (TA:) or a piece of rag which is bound upon the she-camel's teats, in order that her young one may not such her: (Mṣb:) pl. OaSir-apN. (M, A, Ḳ.) It is a custom of the Arabs to bind the SrAr upon the udders of their milch camels when they send them to pasture by themselves; and when they return in the evening, they loose the ASr-p, and milk. (IAth.)
[Hence,] jaEalotu duwna fulaAnK SiraArFA ‡ I put an obstruction, or obstacle, in the way of such a one. (A.)
Also Elevated places over which the water does not come. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: SaruwrN: see SaruwrapN.
SaraArapN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

SaruwrapN (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SaAruwrapN↓ (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SaruwrN↓ and SaAruwrN↓ (M, Ḳ) and SaraArapN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and SaruwriI-N↓ (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SaAruwriI-N↓ (M) or SaAruwraMCu↓, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) the last like EaAXuwraMCu, mentioned on the authority of Ks, (TA,) A man who has not performed the pilgrimage to Mekkeh: (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so called from Sar-N, signifying the “act of confining, withholding, hindering, or preventing;” (TA;) or because the person so called refrains from expending of his property in pilgrimage: (Mṣb:) you say also, AimoraOapN SaruwrapN a woman who has not performed the pilgrimage to Mekkeh: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. SaraArN↓ and SaraArapN↓: (Ḳ:) [or, rather, the former is a coll. gen. n., of which SaraArapN is the n. of un.; and the latter is a quasi-pl. n., like SaHaAbapN, as well as n. un. of SaraArN:] Fr cites, from certain of the Arabs, SaraArN↓ as used collectively; and one of the number is termed SaraArapN↓: (Ṣ:) each of the forms ending with the relative I receives the dual and pl. and fem. inflections: and accord. to IAạr, the forms preceding those receive also the dual and pl. inflections: (M,* TA:) and some say that SawaAriyru is pl. of SaAruwrapN↓: (TA:) or SaAruwrapN↓ and SaAruwrN↓, (M,) or SaruwrapN, (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb,) as occurring in the poetry of En-Nábighah, (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ,) not used without p, (Lḥ, M,) or all the sing. forms above mentioned, (Ḳ,) signify one who has not married: (M, A, Ḳ:) or who has not had intercourse with women: as though he had determined (OaSar-a) upon relinquishing them: (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Mṣb:*) applied in like manner to a woman, and to a plurality of persons: (M, Ḳ:) the p in SaruwrapN applied to a man and to a woman is not to denote the fem. gender, but to give the utmost intensiveness to the signification. (IJ, M.)

It is said in a trad., laA Saruwrapa fiI AlUisolaAmi, (Ṣ, M,) meaning, accord. to AʼObeyd, There is no abstinence from intercourse with women in El-Islám: (M, TA:) i. e., no one should say, I will not marry: (TA:) thus he makes Srwrp a noun signifying an accident: but it is better known as an epithet: (M:) and IAth says that the meaning is, he who slays another in the Haram [or sacred territory of Mekkeh] shall be slain: his saying, “I am a Srwrp; I have not performed the pilgrimage, and I know not the sacredness of the Haram;” shall not be accepted of him: for in the Time of Ignorance, the Kaabeh was a place of refuge. (TA.)

hom.sense: daraAhimu SariyrapN i. q. maSoruwrapN [i. e. Dirhems, or pieces of money, tied up in a purse]: (Ḳ:) termed in the present day Sar-N↓. (TA.)
See also SaAr-apN.

entry.sense: SaraAriI-N A sailor: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) like SaArK: (Ṣ:) pl. SaraAriy-uwna: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) it has no broken pl.: (M:) or Sar-AriI- should be [without tenween, imperfectly decl., and] mentioned in art. SrI; for it is pl. of Sur-aMCN, which is pl. of SaArK, which J has mentioned in art. SrI: AḤát used to say that Sur-aMCN is a sing., like Hus-aAnN; but without sufficient authority: and J has regarded SaraAriI- as a sing. in consequence of his finding it to have the same construction as a sing, in verses of Arabs; whence he imagined the I in it to be the relative I, as is shown by his mentioning the word in this place. (IB.)
SaruwriI-N: see SaruwrapN.

hom.sense: Sur-aI: see Sir-aI:
and see also art. SrI.

entry.sense: Sur-iI: see the next paragraph.

hiIa min-iI Sir-aI, said of an oath, (Ṣ,) or huwa min-iI Sir-aI, (M, Ḳ,) and OaSir-aI↓, and Sir-iI↓, and OaSir-iI↓, (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and Sur-aI↓ and Sur-iI↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or Sur-iI-N↓ and Sir-iI-N↓, (as in a copy of the M,) It is a determination, or resolution, from me; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) a serious assertion; not a jest. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Aboo-Semmál El-Asadee, his she-camel having strayed, said, “I swear to Thee, [O God,] that, if Thou restore her not to me, I will not serve Thee:” (Ṣ:) or, “O God, if Thou restore her not to me, I will not say a prayer to Thee:” (TA:) and he found her, her nose-rein having caught to a thorntree (Eawosajap); and he took her, and said, Ealima rab-iI Oan-ahaA min-iI Sir-aI My Lord knew that it was a determination, or resolution, or serious assertion, from me: (Ṣ:) or a confirmed determination: (ISk:) it is derived from OaSorarotu EalaI AlX-aIoCi “I persevered, or persisted, in the thing:” (Ṣ:) [or “I determined, or resolved, upon the thing:”] AHeyth says, Sir-iI↓, i. e., Determine thou, or resolve thou; as though he addressed himself; from OaSar-a EalaI fiEolihi “he determined, or resolved, upon going on in doing it, and not turning back:” it is also said that OaSir-I↓ is changed into OaSir-aI↓, like as they say biOabiI Oanota and biOabaA Oanota: and in like manner, Sir-iI↓ is changed into Sir-aI; the A in OaSir-iI being elided: not that they are two dial. vars., Sararotu EalaI AlX-aIoCi and OaSorarotu: and Fr. says that Sir-aI and OaSir-aI↓ are originally imperatives; and that, when they desired to change them [i. e. the imperatives] into nouns, they changed the I into | [written I after fet-ḥ]: and in like manner, [changing verbs into nouns,] they say, nuhiIa Eano qiylK waqaAlK;, &c. (TA.) Accord. to AZ, one says, Uin-ahaA min-iI laOaSir-aI↓ meaning Verily, it is a truth, or reality, from me; and Aboo-Málik says the same of OaSir-iI↓. (TA.)
Sir-iI: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

Sar-iI-N and Sir-I-N↓ A dirhem, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) and a deenár, (A,) that sounds, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or rings, (A,) when struck: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ; in some copies of the last of which, in the place of UicaA nuqira, is put AcA nuqida: TA:) accord. to some, used only in negative phrases: (IAạr, M:) thus used in the phrase, maA lifulaAnK Sar-iI-N, [expl. as] meaning Such a one has not a dirhem nor a deenár: (IAạr, A:*) and so used, as meaning a dirhem, by Khálid Ibn-Jembeh; who does not assign to it a dual nor a pl. (TA.)
Sur-iI-N: see Sir-I.

hom.sense: Sir-iI-N: see Sar-iI-:
and see also Sir-aI.

entry.sense: AlS-ar-aAru, (Mṣb,) or Sar-aAru All-ayoli, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or both, (Mgh in art. xTb,) and AlS-aroSaru↓, (M and L in art. jd,) The judojud; [a cricket, which is called the Sar-aAr in the present day]; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, L;) a certain thing that creaks (yaSir-u); (Mṣb;) a small flying thing; (Ḳ;) it is larger than the junodab, and is called by some of the Arabs AlS-adaI: (Ṣ, Mgh:) AʼObeyd says that this last term signifies a certain flying thing that creaks (yaSir-u) by night, and hops, and flies, thought by the [common] people to be the junodab, and found in the deserts. (Mṣb.)
Sur-aAnN Such as grow in hard ground (jalad [in the CK, erroneously, jilod]) of the trees termed Xajaru AlEiloki, (Ḳ, TA,) and of other trees. (TA.)

hom.sense: SaroSarN: see Sir-N, in three places.
and see AlS-ar-aAru.

Also A certain insect (duwayob-apN), (M, Ḳ, TA,) beneath the ground, that creaks (taSir-u) in the days of the [season called] rabiyE; (TA;) and so SuroSurN↓ and SuroSuwrN↓. (M, Ḳ, TA.) [Accord. to Forskål, (Descr. Animal., p. xxii.,) SrSr, pronounced “sursur,” is applied to an insect which he terms Blatta Aegyptiaca.]
And The cock: (Ḳ, TA: [written by Golius and Freytag SiroSirN:]) so called because of his cry. (TA.)
See also SuroSuwrN.

entry.sense: SuroSurN: see SaroSarN:
and see also SuroSuwrN.
SaroSaraAnN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

SaroSaraAniI-N sing. of SaroSaraAniy-aAtN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) which signifies Camels between the baxaAtiI- [or Bactrian (in the CK, erroneously, najAtiI)] and the Arabian: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or such as are called fawaAlij: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and SaroSaraAnN↓ [if not a mistranscription] signifies the same. (TA.) [See also SuroSuwrN.]
And SaroSaraAniI-N (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and SaroSaraAnN↓ (M, Ḳ) A species of fish, (Ṣ,) a certain smooth fish, (M, Ḳ,) of the sea. (Ṣ, M.)

hom.sense: SuroSuwrN Large camels; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also SuroSurN↓ and SaroSarN↓. (TA.)
And A camel of the species called buxotiI- [i. e. Bactrian]: (M, Ḳ:) [see also SaroSaraAniI-N:] or its offspring; as also surosuwrN: (M:) or an excellent stallion-camel. (IAạr.)
See also SaroSarN.
Also A ship, or boat: [or a long, or great, ship or boat:] and so quroquwrN. (TA.)

entry.sense: AlS-araASirapu The Nabathæans of Syria. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
rajulN SaAr-N bayona Eayonayohi A man contracted in the part between the eyes, like him who is grieving, or mourning. (TA.)
And SaAr-N signifies Trees (Xajar) tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, not without shade (Ḳ, TA) in their lower parts, by reason of their perplexedness. (TA.)

SaAr-apN A want; a thing wanted; an object of want; or a needful, or requisite, thing: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) pl. SawaAr-u. (TA.) One says, liI qibala fulaAnK SaAr-apN [I have a want to be supplied to me on the part of such a one]. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ.)

Also Thirst: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. SaraAYiru, (Ḳ,) which is extr., (TA,) and SawaAr-u: (Ḳ:) or the latter is pl. of SAr-p in the sense first expl. above; as AʼObeyd says; and this is meant in the Ḳ: (TA:) AA says that its pl. in the latter sense is SaraAYiru; and he cites the following words of Dhu-r-Rummeh:
faQnoSaAEati AlHuqobu lamo taqoSaEo SaraAYirahaA
[And the wild asses turned back, retreating quickly, not having quenched their thirst]: but fault has been found with AA for this; and it is said that SaraAYiru is pl. of SariyrapN↓, [which is not expl.,] and that the pl. of SAr-p is SawaAr-u. (Ṣ.) One says, qaSaEa AlHimaAru SaAr-atahu, meaning The ass drank water until he quenched his thirst. (Ṣ.)
SaAruwrN: see SaruwrapN, in two places.
SaAruwrN: see SaruwrapN, in three places.
SaAruwraMCu: see SaruwrapN.
SaAruwriI-N: see SaruwrapN.
Suwayor-apN Narrow in disposition and in mind or judgment or opinion. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
HajarN OaSar-u A hard stone: (Tekmileh, TA:) and SaxorapN Sar-aMCu a hard rock: (M, Ḳ:) or a smooth rock. (L.)
OaSir-aI: see Sir-aI, in four places.
OaSir-iI: see Sir-aI, in three places.
maSar-N or miSar-N: see Sur-apN.
maSar-ataA Albawoli waAlgaAYiTi [The two sphincters that serve as repressers of the urine and dung]. (Ḳ in art. Asr.)
muSir-apN A she-camel that does not yield her milk copiously. (M, Ḳ.)

muSar-aApN That has been left unmilked for some days, in order that the milk may collect in her udder, or until it has collected in her udder; (M, Ḳ;) as also Sar-apN↓; applied to a ewe, or she-goat: or the former is from Sar-aI, aor. yuSar-iI, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taSoriyapN, and therefore should be mentioned in art. SrI [q. v.]. (TA.)
muSar-arapN: see the next paragraph.
maSoruwrN Bound, as a captive. (Mgh.)
And maSoruwrapN and muSar-arapN↓ A she-camel having her udder bound with the SiraAr. (IAth, TA.)
And maSoruwrN applied to a solid hoof, Contracted: or narrow: (M, Ḳ:) or narrow and contracted: (Ṣ:) and muSoTar-N↓ signifies the same; (M, Ḳ;) or narrow in an unseemly manner, or immoderately. (TA.)
Also ‡ A man having an iron collar put upon his neck, or round his neck and hands together. (A.)

maSaAr- [app. an irregular pl. of maSiyrN, and therefore without tenween,] The OamoEaMC [or guts, bowels, or intestines, into which the food passes from the stomach]. (M, Ḳ.) One says, Xariba Hat-aI malaOa maSaAr-ahu, meaning [He drank until he filled] his OamoEaMC: mentioned by AḤn on the authority of IAạr, with no more explanation than this. (M.)

hom.sense: muSoTar-N: see maSoruwrN.
One says also AimoraOapN muSoTar-apu AlHaqowayoni [meaning ‡ A woman narrow in the flanks]. (A.)
See also muSoTaridN, in art. Srd.

1. Saraba He made the sour milk termed Sarob: (Ḳ,* TA:) [or] Saraba All-abana, (M, TA,) aor. _i {yaSoribu}, (M,) or _u, (TA,) inf. n. SarobN, he made the milk to become what is termed Sarob: and he milked some of the milk upon other milk, and left it to become sour: (M, TA:) or Saraba All-abana fiI AlwaTobi he collected the milk in the skin, portion after portion, and left it to become sour; as also AiSoTarabahu↓: (Ṣ:) or you say, Saraba All-abana fiI Als-iqaMCi and Als-amona fiI Aln-iHoIi [he collected, portion after portion, and left, the milk in the skin called siqaMC and the clarified butter in the skin called niHoI]. (M, TA.)
[Hence,] Sarabotu All-abana fiI AlD-aroEi † I caused the milk to collect in the udder, not drawing it forth. (Ḳṭ, TA.)

And Saraba † He kept in, or retained, and collected, [his] urine: (Ḳ, TA:) or withheld it long: and accord. to some, particularly said of a stallion-camel: (TA:) [or] Saraba bawolahu, (Ṣ, M,) aor. _u {yaSorubu} and _i {yaSoribu}, inf. n. SarobN, (M,) † he kept in, or retained, and collected, his urine: (Ṣ, M:) accord. to some, particularly said of a stallion-camel. (M.)

And Saraba AlS-abiI-u [caA baTonihi being app. understood] † The boy remained some days without discharging his excrement, or ordure: (M, TA:) and Saraba baTonu AlS-abiI-i, inf. n. SarobN, † the boy's belly became constipated (Eaqada), that he might become fat: (M:) [or] Saraba AlS-abiI-u liyasomana † the boy's excrement, or ordure, (cuw baTonihi,) became confined, so that he remained a day without discharging it, when he was about to become fat. (Ṣ.) [In the copies of the Ḳ, Saraba is expl. as signifying Eaqada baTona AlS-abiI-i liyasomana, to which, written without the syll. signs, the TA assigns the last of the meanings above; therefore, I doubt not, the right reading is baTonu, agreeably with the explanation of Saraba baTonu AlS-abiI-i in the M, given above: otherwise, the meaning must be † He, or it, caused the boy's belly to become bound, or constipated, that he might become fat.]
Sariba, aor. _a {yaSorabu}, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. SarabN, (TḲ,) said of milk, (TA,) It became collected (Ḳ, TA) in the udder. (TA.)
Sarabati AlOaroDu The land produced herbs, or trees, such as are termed Sarab [a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is SarabapN, q. v.]. (M, Ḳ.* [The meaning is indicated in both by the context.])
Saraba also signifies He cut, or cut off; (Ḳ, TA;) i. q. Sarama; like as one says Darobapa laAzibK and laAzimK. (TA.)
And i. q. kasaba [He gained, acquired, or earned;, &c.]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. taSoriybN The drinking of sour milk, (O, Ḳ, TA,) such as is called Sarob. (TA.)
And The eating of gum, (O, Ḳ, TA,) i. e., what is called Sarob. (TA.)
4. ASrb He (a man, TA) gave. (O, Ḳ.) One says, ASrb Uilayohi maAlFA He (a man) gave to him property. (TḲ.)
8: see 1, first sentence.
ASTrb SarobapF He provided, or took, for himself some milk, either fresh or sour, in a skin, for a journey. (M, TA.)
11. ASoraAb-a [said by MF to be written by ISd AiSoraOab-a↓] It was, or became, smooth, (M, O, Ḳ, TA,) and clear; (TA;) said of a thing, (M, Ḳ, TA,) or of milk. (O.)
Q. Q. 4. AiSoraOab-a: see what next precedes {11}.

SarobN and SarabN↓ (Ṣ, M, &c.) Sour milk (M, Mgh, Ḳ) that has been collected in a skin: (M, Ḳ:) or very sour milk: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or milk that has been collected in a skin for some days so that it has become very sour: (Aṣ, M:) n. un. SarobapN↓ and SarabapN↓: (M, TA:) SiraAbN, occurring in some of the Expositions of the Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer, is a mistranscription; or it may be a pl. of SarobN accord. to the analogy of HabolN and HibaAlN, and ramolN and rimaAlN. (Mgh.) One says, jaMCanaA baSarobapK↓ tazowiI Alwajoha [He brought us some sour milk, or very sour milk, that had been collected in a skin, making the face to contract in wrinkles]. (Ṣ.) [SM here adds,] Az says that AlS-aromu is like AlS-arobu, and is better known. (TA. [But this evidently relates to the signification of “the act of cutting,” or “cutting off;” not to AlS-arobu as applied to milk.])
Also, (Ḳ,) or the former word, (M,) Milk that is provided in a skin for a journey, (M, Ḳ,) whether fresh or sour. (M.)

And both words, (M, Ḳ, TA,) or SarabN↓ [only], (Ṣ, Mṣb,) Gum: (Mṣb:) or red gum: (T, Ṣ, M, L, TA: in the Ḳ, AlS-ibogu AlOaHomaru is erroneously put for AlS-amogu AlOaHomaru: TA:) some say (M) it is the gum of the TaloH (Ṣ, M) and of the EurofuT, peculiarly; the pieces of which are red, as though they were ingots [of gold], and they are broken with stones: (M:) the n. un. is SarabapN↓: (Ṣ, M: [SarobapN as a n. un. in this sense I do not find mentioned:]) and sometimes it [i. e. SarobN or SarabN] has SiraAbN for pl.: (M:) sometimes, (Ṣ,) what is called SarabapN↓ is a thing like the head of the cat [in size], within which is a thing [or substance] like dibos [or honey of dates], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and like glue, (Ṣ,) which is sucked and eaten. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
SirobN A few tents (buyuwt [in the O, erroneously, butuwt]) of the weak sort of the Arabs of the desert: (IAạr, O,* Ḳ, TA:) and so SiromN. (O.)
SarabN: see SarobN, in two places.
Also Red honey. (TA in art. Drb.)
See also SarabapN.
SarobapN: see SarobN, in two places.
Hence, ‡ The water [by which is meant the seminal fluid] that collects in the back [of a man]; as being likened to the [sour] milk that is collected in a skin. (M, TA.)
SarabapN: see SarobN, in three places.

Also A herb, (M, Ḳ,) and tree, (M,) that becomes green, and puts forth leaves, when dry, or that has grown, or become somewhat restored to a good state, after having been eaten [or depastured], (yatajab-aru, so in the M, [in the Ḳ yataxay-aru, which, as is remarked in the TḲ, is a mistake,]) after men [have fed their cattle therefrom]: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] SarabN↓. (M.)

SarobaI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) accord. to Saʼeed Ibn-El-Museiyib, (TA,) The [she-camel called] baHiyrap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) whose milk was forbidden [by the pagan Arabs] for the sake of the idols (AlT-awaAgiyt), no man milking her [for himself]: (TA:) thus called, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) it is said, (TA,) because they used not to milk her save for the guest, so that her milk became collected [and retained] (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) in her udder: (Ṣ, TA:) Ḳṭ says, it is from Sarabotu All-abana fiI AlD-aroEi [expl. above]; or, as some say, from [AlS-arobu as signifying] “the act of cutting,” or “cutting off;” and this seems to be the more correct of the two explanations: accord. to IAạr, it signifies a she-camel having the ear slit, like the baHiyrap, or cut off: and its pl., he says, is SurobN. (TA.)
SiraAbN See-produce, or corn, which has been sown after that which has been carried off to the place where it is trodden in the autumn. (O, Ḳ.)

SariybN Milk that has been made what is termed Sarob; as also maSoruwbN↓: (M, TA:) or sour milk: (A, Ḳ, TA:) pl. SurobN. (Ḳ.) So in the saying AlD-ariyba laA AlS-ariyba, i. e. [Give me] the thick [milk], from a number of milch camels, that has been mixed together; not the sour. (A, TA.)
SaraAbapN Clearness, and smoothness: thus in the phrase SaraAbapu HanoZalK in a verse of Imra-el-Ḳeys; as some relate it: (M, TA:) as others relate it, SaraAyap, (M,) or SalaAyap. (TA.)
miSorabN A vessel in which milk is collected, portion after portion, and left to become sour: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) and so mikoraSN and miqoraEN: pl. maSaAribu. (TA.)
maSoruwbN: see SariybN.
muSar-abapN † A she-camel that is kept from being milked, in order that she may become fat. (L in art. SfH, from the T.)
2. Sr-j, inf. n. taSoriyjN, He plastered with SaAruwj a watering-trough or tank (Ḳ,* TA), &c.: and sometimes they said Xr-q. (TA.)

SaAruwjN Quick lime (nuwrap), and the mixtures thereof; (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) with which are plastered watering-troughs, or tanks, and baths,, &c.: (M, TA:) a Pers. word, (Ṣ, TA,) originally JaAruw, (TA,) arabicized, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as is every word in which occur both S and j, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or SamajN is an exception to this rule: (TA in art. Swbj:) sometimes it is called XaAruwqN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. SaruHa, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaSoruHu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. SaraAHapN and SuruwHapN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) [both strangely said in the Ḳ, to be substs.,] It was, or became, pure, sheer, free from admixture, unmingled, unmixed, genuine, or clear; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) said of a thing (Ṣ, O, Mṣb) of any kind of which the meaning is predicable, (Ṣ, O,) [and particularly] said of one's race, or genealogy. (Ḳ.)
SaraHa: see 2, in two places.
2. Sar-aHato She (a camel) yielded pure, or clear, milk. (TA in art. Hlb.)

[Hence, probably,] taSoriyHN signifies The speaking clearly, plainly, explicitly, directly, or without ambiguity or equivocation; contr. of taEoriyDN. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say, Sr-H bimaA fiI nafosihi, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and bimaA Einodahu, (A,) He made apparent, manifest, or plain, or he manifested, exposed, or revealed, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) what was in his mind, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and what he had; (A;) as also SArH↓ bihi; (L, Ḳ;) and SaraHa↓ bh: (TA:) or he declared, or made clear, what was in his mind, so as to express the intended meaning according to the first [or most obvious] interpretation; or he made it free from expressions susceptible of tropical meanings and a secondary [or remote] interpretation. (Mṣb.) And Sr-H AlX-aIoCa, (TA,) inf. n. taSoriyHN; (Ḳ, TA;) and SaraHahu↓, (TA,) inf. n. SaroHN; (Ḳ, TA;) and ASrHhu↓, (TA,) inf. n. UiSoraAHN; (Ḳ, TA;) He made the thing apparent, manifest, clear, or plain. (Ḳ, TA.)

This verb is also intrans. (Ḳ.) One says, Sr-Ht Alxamoru, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. taSoriyHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) The wine became free from froth; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [it became clear] after fermenting and frothing. (Ṣ.) And Sr-H Aln-ahaAru The day became free from clouds, and sunny: (A:) or Sr-H Alyawomu the day became free from mists and clouds. (Mṣb.) And Sr-Ht kaHolu The year of drought, or sterility, became one of unmixed severity; (Ṣ, Meyd, L, Ḳ;) and in like manner, Sr-Ht Als-anapu: (L:) or the former means the sky became clear of clouds. (Ṣ in art. kHl, and Meyd.) And Sr-H, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ, TA,) said of an affair, (Ḳ, TA,) or, as in a copy of the Ḳ, [and in the Ṣ and Mṣb,] said of the truth, (TA,) It became apparent, manifest, exposed, or revealed; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and so AnSrH↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) said of the truth. (Ṣ, TA.) Hence the prov. Einoda Alt-aSoriyHi turiyHu, meaning On the appearing of the truth thou findest rest; (Meyd, TA;) no doubt remaining in thy mind. (Meyd.) And Sar-aHa AlHaq-N Eano maHoDihi, (Ṣ, Meyd, A, Mṣb,) another prov., meaning ‡ The truth, or affair, became revealed, or manifest, (Ṣ, Meyd, Mṣb,) after its being concealed: (Meyd, Mṣb:) or, as AA says, falsity became detected, or exposed, and the truth became apparent and known. (Meyd. [See also zubodN.]) And Sar-aHato bijilocaAna, another prov., (Meyd, L,) meaning It (the affair, or case,) became apparent, or manifest, to thee, in Jildhán; which last word is variously written, [see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 730, and Ḥar p. 106,] a place in Et-Táïf, soft and even, like the palm of the hand, containing no covert in which one may conceal himself; the t in Sr-Ht denoting the qiS-ap or xuT-ap: (Meyd:) i. e. the man made apparent, or revealed, the utmost of what he desired, or meant. (L.)
See also a trad. cited in art. SwH, conj. 2.
Sr-H said of an archer or the like means [He made his arrow, or missile, to go clear of the butt or mark; or] he shot, or cast, and missed (Ḳ, TA) the butt [or mark]. (TA.)
3. SArH bihi: see 2.

[SArHhu, inf. n. muSaAraHapN and SiraAHN, He confronted him, or faced him.] One says, Xatamahu muSaAraHapF, and SiraAHFA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and SuraAHFA↓, (Ḳ,) which last is a subst. [used as an inf. n., i. e. a quasi-inf. n.], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He reviled him confronting him, or face to face, or to his face. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And laqiytuhu muSaAraHapF, (A, TA,) and SiraAHFA, and SuraAHFA↓, (TA,) I met him face to face. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 2.
5. tSr-H Alz-abadu Eani Alxamori The froth became cleared away from the wine. (TA.)
7: see 2.
