And Whetstones; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA;) as also Sul-abapN↓ (TA) and Sul-abiI-N↓ (M, Ḳ, TA;) and Sul-abiy-apN↓: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA:) [or a whetstone:] or [a thing] like a whetstone. (A.)
See also Sul-abiI-N.
Sul-abapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Sul-abiI-N: see Sul-abN.

Also A spear-head sharpened; (Ṣ, TA;) and so muSal-abN↓, (Ṣ,) or Sul-abN↓: (TA: [but this last is perhaps a mistranscription for muSal-abN:]) or a thing polished and sharpened with whetstones: (Ḳ:) and muSal-abN↓ signifies a spear sharpened with the Dul-abiI-, (M, TA,) or a spear-head sharpened upon the Sul-ab, which is like the whetstone. (A.)
Sul-abiy-apN: see Sul-abN.
SulobuwbN The mizomaAr [or musical reed, or pipe]: (O, Ḳ:) or, as some say, the qaSabap [or tube] that is in the head of the mzmAr [app. meaning its mouth-piece]. (O.)

hom.sense: SaAlibN A hot fever; contr. of naAfiDN [which means “attended with shivering, or trembling”]: (Ṣ:) or a fever not such as is termed naAfiDN: (M:) or a fever attended with vehement heat, and not attended with cold: (TA:) or a fever attended with tremour (A, Ḳ, TA) and quivering of the skin: (TA:) or a continual fever: (Mṣb:) or a fever attended with SudaAE [or headache]: (Ḥam p. 345:) it is said by Ibn-Buzurj to be from the SudaAE: (L, TA:) it is masc. and fem.: one says, Oaxacatohu AlHum-aI biSaAlibK [which may be rendered Fever with burning heat,, &c., seized him] and Oaxacatohu Hum-aI SaAlibN [virtually meaning the same]; the former of which is the more chaste: and one seldom or never makes one of the two nouns to govern the other in the gen. case: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Fr, they said Hum-aI SaAlibN and Hum-aI SaAlibK and SaAlibu Hum-aI. (MF, TA.) SaAlibiI OaXad-u mino naAfiDika [My burning fever, or continual fever,, &c., is more severe than thy fever attended with shivering] is a prov., (Meyd, TA,) applied to two things, or events, of which one is more severe than the other. (Meyd.)
See also SulobN, in the middle of the paragraph.

entry.sense: SawolabN and SawoliybN↓, (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA,) in some of the lexicons SayoliybN↓, (TA,) Seed that is scattered (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA) upon the earth, (Lth, O, TA,) and upon which the earth is then turned with the plough: (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA:) Az thinks it to be not Arabic. (TA.)
SawoliybN: see the next preceding paragraph.
SayoliybN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: muSal-abN A garment, or piece of cloth, figured with the resemblance of the Saliyb [or cross]: (Ṣ, M, TA:) or figured with a Saliyb: (A, Mṣb:) or figured with the resemblances of SulobaAn [or crosses]. (TA.) [See 2.]

And A camel marked with the brand called the Saliyb; (M, A, TA;) as also maSoluwbN↓: fem. of the latter with p {maSoluwbapN}, applied to a she-camel; (M, TA;) as of the former also, applied to camels. (TA.)
And An Abyssinian (HabaXiI-N) marked with the figure of the Saliyb [or cross] upon his face. (A, TA.)
See also Sul-abiI-N, in two places.

ruTabN maSal-ibN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and tamorapN muSal-ibapN, (M,) [Ripe dates, and a date,] becoming, or having become, dry. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) When date-honey (dibos) has been poured on such dates, that they may become soft, they are termed muSaq-arN. (Ṣ.)
maTarN muSal-ibN Vehement, injurious rain. (L, TA.)
maSoluwbN (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SaliybN↓ (M, A, Ḳ) [Crucified;] put to death in a certain wellknown manner: (M:) applied to a slayer of another, (Mṣb,) or to a thief. (A.) [See 1, latter half.]
See also muSal-abN.
maSoluwbN Ealayohi Affected by a continual and vehement fever; (Ṣ, TA;) or by a fever such as is termed SaAlibN. (TA.)

1. Saluta, aor. _u {yaSolutu}, inf. n. SuluwtapN, said of the jabiyn [or side of the forehead], It was such as is termed Salot [i. e. conspicuous, or clear, or fair;, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he (a man) was such as is termed Salot in respect of the jabiyn, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) or of the face, or of the cheek (TA. [Accord. to the Ṣ and Ḳ, the verb is app. said of the jabiyn: accord. to the TA, of a man.])

Salatahu, (Ṣ,) aor. _u {yaSolutu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. SalotN, (Ḳ,) He urged him to run, by striking him with his foot, or leg; or struck him with his feet or legs, to urge him; namely, a horse; syn. rakaDahu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
And He poured it forth; namely, what was in the cup, or bowl. (Ṣ.)
jaMCa bilabanK yaSolitu, and bimaraqK yaSolitu, He brought milk, and broth, having much water, (T, Ṣ, M,) with little oily, or greasy matter. (T, Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 3. muSaAlatapN signifies The taking to oneself a verse of another poet without altering anything in it. (Ḥar p. 267. [But this I believe to be post-classical.])
4. ASlt sayofahu He drew his sword from the scabbard. (Ṣ, M, A.)

7. AnSlt He advanced with a penetrative energy, and outstripped; syn. maDaI, and sabaqa; (Ḳ;) or so AnSlt fiI sayorihi [i. e., in his pace]: (Ṣ:) he outstripped; syn. tajar-ada: and he was quick, or he hastened, in his pace, or going. (TA.) One says of the eagle (AlEuqaAb), AnoSalatato munoqaD-apF [It was swift in making a stoop]. (A. [This meaning is there indicated by the context.])
AnSlt yaEoduw He hastened in some measure, running: and so Ainokadara yaEoduw. (AʼObeyd, TA.)
AnSltt Als-aHaAbapu † The cloud was going to rain. (TA, from a trad.)

SalotN, applied to the jabiyn [or side of the forehead], Conspicuous, or clear, or fair; syn. waADiHN: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) open, or uncovered, and even: (M, Ḳ:) or smooth: (TA:) anything bare; and open, or uncovered: (IAạr, TA.) wide, even, and beautiful, or comely. (ISh, TA.)
One says rajulN Salotu Aljabiyni A man conspicuous, or clear, or fair, in respect of the jbyn: (M, TA:) or smooth and shining: (A:) or wide, white, conspicuous, or clear, or fair: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA:) or even: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or hard. (IAạr, TA.) And rajulN Salotu Alwajohi waAlxad-i A man conspicuous, or clear, or fair, in respect of the face and of the cheek. (TA.) And fulaAnN yukaw-inu AlOasowada SalotFA [Such a one makes the black to be white, or fair]. (TA.)

Also, and munoSalitN↓, (M, Ḳ,) and UiSoliytN↓, applied to a sword, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) Sharp: (Ṣ:) or polished, and sharp, or penetrating: (Ḳ:) or unsheathed, and sharp, or penetrating: (M:) or such as penetrates into that which is smitten with it: (A:) but some say that a sword is not termed SalotN unless long: (TA:) or UiSoliytN↓ may have the same meaning as muSolatN↓, i. e. unsheathed: (Ṣ:) accord. to AA, SalotN applied to a sword and to a knife and to a needle means having no sheath. (TA.) And one says, Darabahu biAls-ayofi SalotFA (Ṣ, M, A) and SulotFA↓ (Ṣ, M) He smote him with sword unsheathed. (Ṣ, M, A.)

SalotN applied to a man, as also OaSolatiI-N↓ and munoSalitN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and miSolatN↓ and miSolaAtN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) pl. [of the last] maSaAliytu, (Ṣ,) Hard, firm, strong, or hardy, (M,) sharp, or penetrating, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in affairs, (Ṣ,) or in needful affairs, (M, Ḳ,) light in clothing: (M:) and [in like manner] SalataAnN↓ signifies sharp, or penetrating, and quick (munoSalitN), in his affair. (Ḥam p. 536.)
See also SalataAnN below.
And see SulotN.
Oabuw AlS-aloti is a surname of The HidaOap [or kite]. (TA in art. HdO.)
SulotN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and SalotN↓ (M, Ḳ) A large knife: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or an unsheathed knife: (M:) pl. OaSolaAtN. (Ṣ, M.)
For the former, see also SalotN.
SilotN A thief, or robber: (Ḳ:) formed by transposition from liSotN. (TA.)

hom.sense: SalataAnN, applied to a man, and to an ass, Strong, and hard, firm, or hardy: pl. SilotaAnN: (M:) or, applied to a man, as expl. above voce SalotN, q. v.: (Ḥam p. 536:) and, applied to an ass, strong: (Ṣ: [in some copies of which, for mina AlHimaAri, meaning mina AlHumuri, we find mn AljimaAri, whence an error in the Lexicon of Golius:]) and, applied to a horse, brisk, lively, or sprightly, and sharp of spirit; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so applied to a man; like falataAnN: (T and TA in art. flt:) and, accord. to Aṣ, applied to an ass, smooth, having short hair: (TA:) or sometimes it means having no hair upon him; and so SalotN↓. (Ḥam p. 536.)
[And accord. to ISd, it seems to be an inf. n., of which the verb is not mentioned; for he says that] it signifies also The act of leaping, springing, or bounding. (M.)

entry.sense: OaSolatiI-u: see SalotN.
UiSoliytN: see SalotN, in two places.
muSolatN: see SalotN.
miSolatN: see SalotN.
miSolaAtN: see SalotN.
miSolaAtu AlEunuqi [app. applied to an ass] Having the neck stretching out, and smooth, or with short, or little, hair upon it. (Aṣ, TA.)
munoSalitN: see SalotN, in two places.
Also, applied to anything, Quick, or swift. (M, TA.)
Applied to a river, or rivulet, ‡ Vehement in its manner of running. (A, TA.)

1. SalaHa, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, &c.,) aor. _u {yaSoluHu}, (Ṣ, MA, Mgh, Mṣb,) the well-known form, though omitted in the Ḳ, (TA,) and _a, (MA, Ḳ, Mṣb,) [said by some to be] the more chaste, because agreeable with analogy, (TA,) [but the former is the more common,] inf. n. SuluwHN (Ṣ, MA, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ * [in the CK AlS-aluwH is erroneously put for AlS-uluwH]) and SalaAHN (Ṣ,* MA, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ *) and maSolaHapN; (MA;) and SaluHa, aor. _u {yaSoluHu}, (Ṣ, MA, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) mentioned by Fr, on the authority of his companions, (Ṣ, TA,) but said by IDrd to be not well established, (TA,) inf. n. SalaAHN and SalaAHapN, (MA,) or SalaAHiyapN; (TA;) said of a thing, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and of a man, (TA,) It, and he, was, or became, good, incorrupt, right, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest; it was or became, in a good, incorrupt, sound, right, or proper, state, or in a state of order; he, or it, throve; contr. of fsd [i. e. fasada and fasuda]; (MA; [and Ṣ and A and Mgh and Ḳ by implication; see SalaAHN below;]) in Pers. nyk Xd; (MA;) [and AstSlH↓ signifies the same, for] SalaAHN and AisotiSolaAHN both signify in Pers. nyk Xdn. (KL.) One says, SalaHato HaAlu fulaAnK [The state, or condition, of such a one became good, right, or proper]. (A, TA.)

[Hence,] hecaA OadiymN yaSoluHu liln-aEoli ‡ [This is leather that is suitable for the sandal]. (A.) And hecaA AlX-aIoCu yaSoluHu laka ‡ This thing is suitable to thee; or fit, or meet, for thee. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.) And fulaAnN laA yaSoluHu liSuHobatika ‡ [Such a one is not fit for being thy companion]. (A.)

3. SAlHhu, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. SalaAHN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and muSaAlaHapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the former of which is made fem. in a verse of Bishr Ibn-Abee-Házim, (TA,) [He made peace, or became at peace or reconciled, with him; or he reconciled himself with him: for] muSaAlaHapN is the contr. of muxaASamapN. (Mgh.) And SAlHhu EalaI kacaA He made peace, or reconciliation, [or a compromise,] with him on the condition of such a thing. (MA.) And SAlHhu EalaI baEoDi maA lahu [He compounded with him for part of what was owed to him; he made a compromise with him on the condition of receiving part of what was due to him]; said of a creditor and debtor. (Mgh in art. DgT.) And SaAlaHotu bayona Alqawomi, inf. n. muSaAlaHapN, I made peace, or a reconciliation, between the people, or party; syn. laMCamotu. (Mṣb in art. lOm. [See also 4.])

4. ASlHhu, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiSolaAHN, (Ṣ, A,) and quasi-inf. n. SalaAHN, (L in art. lqH,) said of a man, (A, Mṣb,) and of God, (TA,) [and of a thing,] He, and it, made, or rendered, it, or him, good, incorrupt, right, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest; constituted it, disposed it, arranged it, or qualified it, well, rightly, or properly; rectified, corrected, redressed, or reformed, it; put it into a good, incorrupt, sound, right, or proper, state; or restored it to such a state; put it to rights, or in a state of order; set it right, set it in order, ordered it, managed it well, cultured it; adjusted, dressed, or trimmed, it; prepared it properly for use; repaired, mended, amended, or improved, it; made it, or him, to thrive; contr. of Oafosadahu. (Ṣ,* Ḳ. [And so by implication in the Mgh, &c.]) One says, OaSolaHotu Alqidora biAlt-aAbali [I made good, qualified properly, or seasoned, (the contents of) the cooking-pot with the seeds that are used in cooking]. (Mṣb in art. tbl.) And OaSolaHotu Als-iqaMCa biAlr-ub-i [I seasoned the skin with rob, or inspissated juice]. (Ṣ in art. rb.) And OaSolaHotu bayona Alqawomi [in which AlOamora is understood, so that the meaning is I rectified, or reformed, or amended, the circumstances subsisting between the people, or party; or] I made peace, or I effected a rectification of affairs, an agreement, a harmony, a reconciliation, an accomodation, or an adjustment; [or I adjusted the affair;] between the people, or party. (Mṣb.) And saEaI fiI UiSolAaHi caAti Albayoni [He laboured in rectifying, or improving, the bad, or the good, state of circumstances, or the disunion or union, subsisting between people]. (A.) One says also, ASlH Ald-aAb-apa, (TA,) and ASlH UilaI Ald-aAb-api, (T, A, Mgh, TA,) the latter because ASlH implies the meaning of OaHosana, (Mgh,) ‡ He acted well to the beast, (T, A, TA,) and put it into a good, or right, or proper, state, or took care of it, or paid frequent attention to it. (A, TA.) And ASlH Uilayohi ‡ He acted well to him, did good to him, or benefited him. (Ḳ, TA.) And ASlH [alone] † He did that which was good, right, or just. (Mṣb.)
6. tSAlHA and AiS-aAlaHaA, &c.: see 8, in four places.
7. AnSlH [quasi-pass. of OaSolaHahu; thus signifying It became rectified,, &c.: see taXaE-aba]. (Ḳ in art. XEb.)

8. ASTlHA (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and AStlHA, (Ḳ,) and tSAlHA↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and AiS-aAlaHaA↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [the last a var. of tSAlHA,] all signify the same, (TA,) and tSAlH↓ Alqawomu, and ASTlHwA, (Mgh,) [They two, (i. e. two persons or two parties,) and] the people, or party, made peace, or became at peace or reconciled, [each with the other, and] one with another: (Mṣb:) [AiSoTilaAHN is the contr. of AixotiSaAmN and] taSaAluHN↓ is the contr. of taxaASumN. (Mgh.)
And ASTlHwA EalaI OamorK They (a particular class of persons) agreed together, or among themselves, respecting a particular thing. (El-Khafájee, MF.)
[Hence,] AiSoTilaAHN signifies also The agreement of a people to name a thing by any name turned from the primary application. (KT.)

And [as an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n., for muSoTalaHN Ealayohi,] Conventional [or technical] language: and a conventional [or technical] term: opposed to [lugapN and] tawoqiyfN. (Mz 1st nwE.)

hom.sense: 10. AstSlH is the contr. of Astfsd: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) [i. e. it signifies He regarded, or esteemed, a thing good, incorrupt, right, just, or the like; as expl. in the TḲ; and in like manner, a man.]
[He wished, or desired, a thing to be good, incorrupt, right, just,, &c.; as in the TḲ; and in like manner, a man.]
[And He sought to render good, incorrupt,, &c.]
[And hence, He treated in such a manner as to render well affected, or obedient.]
Also He sought to do good or to act well [UilaI fulaAnK to such a one]. (KL.)
And He sought peace, or concord. (KL.)
And It happened well. (KL.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: SuloHN a subst. from muSaAlaHapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, KT,) syn. with the latter; (Mgh;) masc. and fem.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) Peace, reconciliation, or agreement, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, KT, TA,) after contention: and in the law it means a compact to give over, or relinquish, contention. (KT.) One says, waqaEa bayonahumaA SuloHN (A, TA) Peace, or reconciliation, took place between them two. (TA.) [And Ouxica SuloHFA It (a fortress or the like) was taken peacefully, or by surrender.]
Also That in respect of which there has been made a peaceful compact: or which has been taken in the way of peace. (Mgh.)

And A party at peace with others. (TA.) You say, humo lanaA SuloHN They are [a party] at peace with us. (A, TA.) And you say also qawomN SuluwHN↓ A people, or party, who are at peace: the latter word in this case being app. an inf. n. used as an epithet. (TA. [See also SaAliHN.])
SaloHN: see SaAliHN.

hom.sense: SalaAHN an inf. n. of SalaHa (MA, Mgh, Mṣb) and of SaluHa: (MA:) [used as a simple subst, it signifies Goodness, incorruptness, rightness or rectitude, justness, righteousness, virtue, honesty;, &c.: see 1:] contr. of fasaAdN; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ;) as also SuluwHN↓: (Ḳ, TA: [AlS-aluwH in the CK being a mistake for AlS-uluwH:]) accord. to some, it is not used as an attribute of a prophet nor of an apostle, but only of a person inferior to these: accord. to others, however, this restriction is wrong. (MF.)
Also quasi-inf. n. of 4. (L in art. lqH.)
And [hence,] A thing that is good, and right. (Mṣb.) See also maSolaHapN.
SalaAHi, like qaTaAmi, is a name of Mekkeh; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) either from AlS-uloHu or from AlS-alaAHu; (TA;) and sometimes it is perfectly decl. [pronounced SalaAHN]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: SuluwHN: see SuloHN, and SalaAHN:
and see also SaAliHN.
SaliyHN: see what next follows.

SaAliHN, (MA, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from SalaHa; (MA;) and SaliyHN↓, (IAạr, L, Ḳ,) from SaluHa; (MA;) and SiloHN↓; (Ḳ;) applied to a thing, (Mṣb,) and to a man, (MA,) Good, incorrupt, right, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest;, &c.; [see 1; contr. of faAsidN:] (MA, L, Ḳ:) pl. SulaHaMCu [accord. to general analogy of SaliyHN, and app. applied only to rational beings, like SaAliHuwna,] and SuluwHN↓ [q. v.; this being said by some to be a pl. of SaAliHN; and by others, to be originally an inf. n.; like as is said of XuhuwdN]. (L.) One says rajulN SaAliHN fiI nafosihi [A man good, incorrupt,, &c., in himself], mino qawomK SulaHaMCa [of a people good, incorrupt,, &c.]. (L.) And huwa EalaI HaAlapK SaAliHapK [He is in a good, right, or proper, state or condition]. (TA.)
[Hence,] SaAliHN signifies also † Suitable, fit, or meet: so in the saying, huwa SaAliHN lilowilaAyapi † [He is fit for the office of prefect, or the like]. (Mṣb.)

And ‡ Much, copious, or frequent: one says maTorapN SaAliHapN ‡ A copious rain. (Yaạḳoob, L, TA.) And hence the saying of IJ, Oubodilati Alt-aMCu mina AlwaAwi UibodaAlFA SaAliHFA, meaning ‡ [t is substituted for w] frequently. (TA.)

The A in SaAliHN is [often] omitted in writing [though not in pronunciation] when it is used as a proper name [so that the name is written SlH, or more properly SeliHN]. (Durrat el-Ghowwáṣ in De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Ar. p. 66 of the Arabic text.)

SaAliHapN [a subst. from SaAliHN, made so by the affix p; A good deed or action; an act of beneficence; a benefit]. One says, laA tuEad-u SaAliHaAtuhu [His good deeds, or beneficent actions, are not to be numbered]. (A, TA.) And OatatoniI SaAliHapN mino fulaAnK [A benefit came to me from such a one]. (TA.)
AiSoTilaAHN [for muSoTalaHN Ealayohi: see 8, last sentence].
AiSoTilaAHiI-N Conventional [or technical] language: opposed to [lugawiI-N and] tawoqiyfiI-N. (Mz 1st nwE.)
muSoliHN [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. One says, rajulN muSoliHN fiI Oumuwrihi waOaEomaAlihi [A man who does well, rightly, justly, or properly, in his affairs and his actions]. (L.)

maSolaHapN A cause, a means, or an occasion, of good; a thing, an affair, or a business, conducive to good, or that is for good; [and hence it may often be rendered simply an affair, when the context shows it to mean what is conducive to good or done for a good purpose;] contr. of mafosadapN; (Ṣ and Mṣb and Ḳ in art. fsd;) a good, right, or virtuous, affair; (KL;) a thing that is good and right; syn. SalaAHN↓ [q. v.]: pl. maSaAliHu. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says, naZara fiI maSAliHi Aln-aAsi [He considered the things that were for the good of the people]. (A, TA.) And humo mino Oaholi AlmafaAsidi laA AlmaSaAliHi [They are of the people who occupy themselves in the things conducive to evil, not the things conducive to good]. (A, TA.*) And fiI AlOamori maSolaHapN In the affair is that which is good: (Mṣb:) [or a cause of good.] And raOaI AlUimaAmu AlmaSolaHapa fiI kacaA The Imám saw what was good and right [or what was conducive to good] in such a thing. (TA.)
It is also an inf. n. of SalaHa. (MA.)
mutaSal-aHN A place, of a garment [&c.], that is to be repaired, or mended; syn. mutarad-amN. (T in art. rdm.)

hom.sense: 1. Salixa samoEuhu, [and app. Salixa alone,] aor. _a {yaSolaxu}, (L,) inf. n. SalaxN; (Ṣ, A, L;) as also Salija; (IAạr, L;) [the former of the dial. of El-Koofeh, and the latter of that of El-Basrah; (see OaSolaxu;)] He was, or became, deaf, so as not to hear at all. (Ṣ, A,* L.) SalaxFA kaSalaxi Aln-aEaAmi [Mayest thou, or may he, suffer a deafness like the deafness of the ostrich] is a form of imprecation uttered against a man; for all ostriches are [said to be] totally deaf. (L, TA.)
Salaxato jilodahaA is said of a serpent (Hay-ape) [meaning It cast off its slough: like salaxato]. (TA.)
And Salaxahu, namely, a camel, is said of the mange, or scab, meaning [It excoriated him; like salaxahu; or] it extended over the whole of his body. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6. tSAlx EalayonaA He feigned himself totally deaf to us; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also tSAlj, with j. (TA.)
9. ASlx-, inf. n. AiSolixaAxN, He (a man, TA) lay upon his side. (Ḳ, TA.)
daAhiyapN SaluwxN A destructive calamity. (Ḳ.)
Oasowadu SaAlixN i. q. Oasowadu saAlixN [q. v.], A certain species of serpents, that casts off its slough. (AḤát, L.)
And jarabN SaAlixN i. q. saAlixN [i. e. Excoriating mange or scab]: (Ḳ, TA:) it is such as occurs in the hinder part of the camel, and one doubts not its extending over the whole of his body. (TA.)

hom.sense: OaSolaxu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) so accord. to all the people of El-Koofeh, but the people of El-Basrah and the Arabs of that region say OaSolaju, (IAạr, TA,) Deaf: (Fr, AʼObeyd, TA:) or deaf so as not to hear at all: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or very deaf: (Mgh:) or OaSam-u OaSolaxu has this last meaning. (IAạr, TA.) Fr said, (Ṣ,) kaAna Alkumayotu OaSam-a OaSolaxa, meaning El-Kumeyt was deaf so as not to hear at all. (Ṣ, A.*)
Also A camel affected with mange, or scab: [or having mange, or scab, by which he is excoriated: like Oasolaxu:] fem. SaloxaMCu: and pl. SaloxaI. (Ḳ.)
And Affected with [the malignant species of leprosy termed] baraS. (TA.)

1. SalaAdapN and SuluwdapN, [inf. ns. of which the verb is Saluda,] used in relation to a stone [&c.], signify The being hard and smooth. (M.) [And SalodN has a similar meaning.] You say, Saladati AlOaroDu, and OaSoladat↓, The land was, or became, hard: (Ḳ:)
or ‡ so that it produced no plants, or herbage: (TA:) and Salada AlmakaAnu, and OaSolada↓, (M, TA,) the place was, or became, hard: (TA:) or † produced no plants, or herbage. (M.) And Salada Ealayohi Aljabalu, aor. _i {yaSolidu}, inf. n. SalodN; and Saluda, [aor. _u {yaSoludu},] inf. n. SalaAdapN and SuluwdapN and SuluwdN; The mountain, or rock, baffled him, namely, a welldigger, [by its hardness,] and resisted his efforts. (M.)

[Hence,] Salada Alz-anodu, (M, Ḳ, and so in some copies of the Ṣ,) aor. _i {yaSolidu}, inf. n. SalodN; (M;) or Salida, with kesr to the l, aor. _a {yaSoladu}, inf. n. SuluwdN; (AZ, Ṣ;) The znd [or piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire] gave a sound without emitting fire; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and ASld↓ signifies [the same, or] it emitted no fire. (Ḥam p. 407.)

And [hence,] Saladato zinaAduhu [lit. “His pieces of stick, or wood, for producing fire, gave a sound without emitting fire”] means ‡ He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, penurious, or avaricious: (AA, L, TA:) and Saluda, alone, aor. _u {yaSoludu}, (M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. SalaAdapN; (M, A;) and Salada, (M, A,) aor. _i {yaSolidu}, (M,) or _u, (A,) inf. n. SalodN, (M,) or SuluwdN; (A;) and Sl-d↓, inf. n. taSoliydN; (Ḳ;) signify the same: (M, Ḳ:) or he was, or became, very niggardly, &c. (A.)

And Saladato SalaEatuhu, or SaloEatuhu, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, in the TA the former,) The bald place on the front of his head shone, or glistened. (Ḳ, TA.) Salada is also used in the same sense, in a trad., in relation to milk flowing forth. (TA.)
And one says, jaMCa bimaraqK yaSolidu, and bilabanK yaSolidu, meaning He brought broth, and milk, containing little oily, or greasy, matter, and much water: for yaSolitu. (T in art. Slt.)
Saladato OanoyaAbuhu His canine teeth caused a grating sound to be heard. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Salada biyadayohi He clapped with his hands. (M.)
Saladati Ald-aAb-apu, aor. _i {yaSolidu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. SalodN, (TA,) The beast beat the ground with its fore feet in its running. (Ḳ.)
Salada, (M,) or Salada fiI Aljabali, (Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaSolidu}, inf. n. SalodN, said of a mountain-goat, (M,) He ascended the mountain. (M, Ḳ.)

taSoludu, [or probably taSolidu,] said of a wild cow or wild ox (baqarap waHoXiy-ap), in a verse ascribed to a Hudhalee, [but not found by SM in the Deewán of the Hudhalees,] is expl. as meaning She, or he, stands erect. (TA.)
Salada Als-aAYila † He gave nothing to the asker, or beggar. (L.)

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
4. ASld: see 1, in three places.
Also ‡ He (a man) failed to produce fire with his zanod [or piece of stick, or wood, used for that purpose]. (Ṣ, A.)

And ASld zanodahu ‡ He made his znd to give a sound without emitting fire. (M, TA.) And ‡ He (God) caused his znd to emit no fire. (A.) And saOalahu faOaSolada † He asked, or begged, of him, and found him niggardly: thus related on the authority of IAạr; but by rule it should be faOaSoladahu. (M.)

SalodN Hard and smooth; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) as also SilodN↓ (Ḳ) and SaluwdN↓ (M) and SaliydN↓ (A) and OaSoladu↓; (M;) applied to a stone; (Ṣ, M, A;) and so the first applied to land or ground (OaroD); (Ṣ;) and to a solid hoof, as also SilodimN↓ and SulaAdimN↓, which last is of the measure fuEaAlimN accord. to Kh, but fuEaAlilN accord. to others; (M;) and to a side of the forehead, (Ṣ, M,) or thus applied meaning smooth and tough; (L;) and to a head, as also SulaAdimN↓, (M,) or thus applied meaning ‡ upon which no hair grows: (A:) and SalawodadN↓, (M, Ḳ,) which is of an extr. form, (M,) has the first of the significations above, (Ḳ,) or signifies [simply] hard: (M:) the pl. of SalodN (M, L) and of SaluwdN↓ (M) is OaSolaAdN. (M, L.)

Also applied to a place, (makaAnN, M,) and SalodapN applied to land, (OaroDN, A,) ‡ That produces no plants, or herbage. (M, A.) And OaSolaAdu Aljabiyni ‡ The part of the side of the forehead upon which is no hair: likened to smooth stone. (AHeyth.)

[Hence,] HajarN SalodN and SaluwdN↓ ‡ A stone that will not emit fire: (L, TA:) and zanodN SaluwdN↓ (M, A) and SaAlidN↓ and Sal-aAdN↓ and miSolaAdN↓ (M) [and muSolidN↓] ‡ [A piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire] that gives a sound, (M,) not emitting fire: (M, A:) and EuwdN Sal-aAdN↓ ‡ Wood, or a stick, from which fire cannot be produced. (T, L, Ḳ.*)

And farasN SalodN (Ḳ) and SaluwdN↓ (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) ‡ A horse that does not sweat: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) such a horse is discommended: (Ḳ:) or slow to sweat: or having little seminal fluid: and slow in impregnating. (M.)
And rajulN SalodN (M) and SaluwdN↓ (M, A) and OaSoladu↓ (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) ‡ A niggardly, tenacious, penurious, or avaricious, man: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or a man very niggardly, &c. (A.)
And naAqapN SalodapN ‡ A hardy, strong, enduring she-camel. (Ḳ.) And xayolN SilaAdN ‡ Hard, hardy, or strong, horses. (A.) [And SilodaAmN↓, also, signifies Robust, or strong. (Freytag, from Jereer.)]
SilodN: see SalodN, first sentence.
SilodaMCN and SilodaMCapN Rugged and hard ground, (ISk, Ḳ,) † that produces no plants, or herbage. (ISk.)
SilodimN: see SafodN, first sentence.
SilodaAmN: see SalodN, last sentence.
SaluwdN: see SalodN, in six places.
Also, applied to a well, Such that its mountain, or rock, baffles the digger [by its hardness], and resists his efforts. (M.)
† A woman in whom is little, or no, good: or hard, having no compassion in her heart. (M.)
‡ A cooking-pot (qidorN) slow to boil. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.)
A beast (daAb-apN) that beats the ground with its fore feet in its running. (TA.)
One who ascends a mountain by reason of fear; (Ḳ, TA;) as also miSolaAdN↓: (TA:) [or] a mountain-goat that ascends the mountain. (M.)
And Alone, apart from others, or separate; (Aṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also SaliydN↓. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: SaliydN: see SalodN, first sentence:
and SaluwdN, last sentence.
Also A shining, gleaming, or glistening. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: SulaAdimN: see SalodN, first sentence, in two places.
SalawodadN: see SalodN, first sentence.
SaAlidN: see SalodN.
OanoyaAbN SaAlidapN Canine teeth causing a grating sound to be heard; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also SawaAlidu, (Ḳ, TA,) which is the pl. (TA.)
OaSoladu: see SalodN, first sentence:
and see the same also near the end of the paragraph.

hom.sense: muSolidN: see SalodN.

[Hence,] one says, layosa bimuSolidi AlqadoHi [lit. He is not one whose wood gives only a sound when one endeavours to produce fire from it; meaning † he is not one who ungenerously refuses when asked]; an expression of praise; (TA in art. ksr;) and [in like manner] layosa biSal-aAdi↓ AlqadoHi. (TA. in art. hX.)
Also Milk milked into a greasy vessel, and therefore without froth. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: miSolaAdN: see SalodN:
and SaluwdN, in two places.
2. Sal-aTahu Qll-ehu Ealayohi, inf. n. taSoliyTN, a dial. var. of sal-aTahu, q. v. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. SaliEa, aor. _a {yaSolaEu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. SalaEN, (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) He (a man, Ṣ, O, Ḳ *) was, or became, bald in the fore part of the head: (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ:* but in the Mṣb it is said in this sense of the head:) or in the fore part of the head to the kinder part thereof: and likewise in the middle of the head. (TA.) [See also jaliHN and jalaHN.] Accord. to Ibn-Seenà, the baldness termed SalaEN does not happen to women, because of the abundance of their moisture; nor to eunuchs, because their constitutions are nearly like those of women. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] SaliEati AlEurofuTapu, inf. n. as above, ‡ The ErfTp [a species of mimosa] dropped the heads of its branches: and had them eaten by the camels. (TA.)
See also 7.
SalaEa said of such as is termed EicoyawoT, [but the verb in this sense is probably Sal-aEa↓, (see this latter,)] He voided his ordure (OaHodava) on the occasion of jimaAE. (TA.)
2. Sl-E: see above {1}, last sentence but one.

Sl-Et AlHay-apu ‡ The serpent came forth from concealment (barazat) without any earth, or dust, upon it. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ, TA. [But in the O, the verb in this and the following senses is carelessly written without the sheddeh.])

Sl-E, inf. n. taSoliyEN, (said of a man, IAạr, TA,) i. q. OaEocara [meaning He voided his ordure: see taSoliyEN as a subst., below; and what here follows]. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA.) And Sl-E fulaAnN, (inf. n. as above, TA,) Such a one put his hand evenly expanded (Ḳ, TA) on the ground (TA) and voided his ordure or his ordure in a thin state (salaHa): (Ḳ, TA:) thus expl. by Lth. (TA.) See also 1, last sentence.

entry.sense: 5. tSl-Et Als-amaMCu † The sky became bared by the disruption of its clouds. (TA.)
See also what next follows {7}.

7. AnSlEt AlX-amosu ‡ The sun rose, or began to rise: syn. bazagat: or culminated: or came forth from the clouds, (O, Ḳ, TA,) appearing in the time of intense heat, with nothing intervening and concealing it; (TA;) and so tiSl-Et↓, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and SalaEat↓ [or more probably SaliEat]. (TA.)
[8. ASTlE, accord. to Reiske, as stated by Freytag, signifies He, or it, was defiled, or polluted; “conspurcatus fuit:” but he names no authority.]

SalaEN Baldness in the fore part of the head: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or in the fore part of the head to the hinder part thereof: and likewise in the middle of the head. (TA. [See SaliEa, of which it is the inf. n.: and see also jalaHN.])
Also a dial. var. of Sul-aEN, q. v. (TA.)
One says also, laOuqiyman-a SalaEaka meaning [I will assuredly straighten] thy [natural] crookedness; like DalaEaka. (TA in art. DlE, from the T and M.)
SaloEapN: see what next follows.
SuloEapN: see what next follows.

SalaEapN A place of baldness such as is termed SalaEN; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also SuloEapN↓; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and SaloEapN↓ is said to be a contraction of the first, (O, Mṣb,) by Lth, (O,) but it is disallowed by the thoroughly learned. (Mṣb.)
SalaAEN, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, with kesr, (O,) like kitaAbN, (Ḳ,) in the L [written] with damm, (TA,) The heat of the sun. (O, Ḳ.)
SaliyEN: see OaSolaEu.
[Hence,] ‡ A mountain having upon it no plants, or herbage. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
SulayoEaMCu: see OaSolaEu, in six places.
Sul-aEN: see Sul-aAEN.

Accord. to Aṣ, (Ṣ, O, TA,) ‡ A place that produces no plants, or herbage; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) whether it be a mountain or land; (TA;) from SalaEN in relation to the head; (Ṣ, O, TA;) and SalaEN↓ is also syn. with Sul-aEN in the sense expl. above. (TA.) And [the n. un.] Sul-aEapN signifies A smooth rock. (TA.)

Sul-aAEN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or Sul-aEN↓, (Ḳ,) or the latter also, which is app. a contraction of the former, (Ṣ, O,) † Broad, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) hard, (Ḳ, TA,) smooth, (TA,) rock: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) n. un. (of the former, Ṣ, O, [and of the latter also,]) with p. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
SawolaEN: see the next paragraph.

OaSolaEu, applied to a man, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) Bald in the fore part of the head; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) denoting more than OajolaHu: (Mgh:) or bald in the fore part of the head to the hinder part thereof: (TA:) and likewise, (TA,) or accord. to Aṣ, (O,) bald in the middle of the head: (O, TA:) and applied also to a head, (Mṣb, TA,) meaning bald in the fore part: (Mṣb:) and SaliyEN↓ signifies the same, applied to a head, (Mṣb, TA,) and to a man: (Mṣb:) fem. SaloEaMCu; (Ḳ;) but some disapprove this, and say that the fem. epithet is zaEoraMCu, and qaroEaMCu: (TA:) the pl. is SuloEN (O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SuloEaAnN: (O, Ḳ:) OuSayoliEu↓ is the dim. of the masc., [and SulayoEaMCu↓ is that of the fem.,] meaning as expl. above. (TA.)

[Hence,] the fem., applied to a tree such as is termed EurofuTap, [a species of mimosa,] ‡ That has dropped the heads of its branches: (Ṣ, TA:) and that has had its branches eaten by the camels. (TA.)

And, applied to a tract of sand, (ramolapN, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and to a land, (OaroDN, Ḳ,) ‡ In which are no trees: (Ṣ, O, TA:) and (TA) in which is no herbage. (O, Ḳ, TA.) It also occurs, alone, as meaning † A desert (SaHoraMC) that produces nothing; like the head termed OaSolaE. (TA.) And SulayoEaMCu↓, applied to a land, † That produces no plants, or herbage. (TA.)
And the masc., applied to a mountain, † Open to view, smooth, and glistening. (TA.)
And, applied to a spear-head, ‡ Glistening and smooth: (O, TA:) or polished; (Ḳ;) and so SawolaEN↓. (O, Ḳ.)
[Hence also,] AlOuSayoliEu↓ signifies ‡ The penis. (O, Ḳ, TA.) And AlOaSolaEu is said to signify ‡ The head of the penis. (TA.)

And AlOuSayoliEu↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) or AlOaSolaEu, (TA,) † A certain serpent, slender in the neck, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) or, accord. to Az, wide in the neck, round in the head, (TA,) its head being like a hazel-nut: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) thought by Az to be so called as being likened to the penis. (TA.)

OaSolaEu applied to an affair, or event, (OamorN,) means † Hard, distressing, or calamitous; (TA;) and so applied to a day; as also OajolaHu: (A and TA in art. jlH:) or, applied to a day, ‡ intensely hot. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Z, O, TA.)

Also, the fem., [used as a subst.,] ‡ Any notorious affair or event; or any such affair that is dubious, of great magnitude or moment, to accomplish which, or to perform which, one finds not the way: (O, Ḳ, TA:) and ‡ a calamity, or misfortune, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) [or] such as is hard to be borne; [as though it were smooth and slippery;] because there is no escape from it: (TA:) and [in like manner] SulayoEaMCu↓ (O, Ḳ, TA) and SaloEaMCu, and sawoCapN SaloEaMCu and SulayoEaMCu↓, (TA,) an evil, abominable, or unseemly, action or saying, such as is apparent, manifest, or unconcealed: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or a calamity, or misfortune, hard to be borne: (Ḳ, TA:) and hence the saying of ʼÁïsheh to Mo'áwiyeh, (O, Ḳ, TA,) when she reproached him for his having asserted the relationship to him of Ziyád, and he replied that the witnesses gave testimony, (O, Ḳ,* TA, [see Abulfedæ Annales, i. 360,]) maA Xahidati AlX-uhuwdu walekino rakibota AlS-ulayoEaMCa↓ [The witnesses did not bear witness (in the CK, erroneously, mA Xahidota AlXuhuwda,) but thou committedst that which was an evil, abominable, or unseemly, action,, &c.]. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
SulayoEaMCu↓ is also said to signify † The act of glorying, or boasting; syn. faxorN. (TA.)
OuSayoliEu, dim. of OaSolaEu: (TA:) see the latter, in three places.
taSoliyEN inf. n. of 2 [q. v.]. (Ḳ, TA.)
And a subst., like tamotiynN and tanobiytN, signifying Ordure, or dung; or such as is thin; syn. sulaAHN: (TA:) thus expl. by Lth. (O.)

1. Salagati Albaqarapu, and AlX-aApu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaSolagu}, (O,) inf. n. SuluwgN, (Ṣ, O,) i. q. salagat, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) i. e. The bovine animal, and the sheep or goat, shed the tooth [next] behind that called the sadiys: (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. slg;) or bred its [tooth called the] naAb: (Ḳ in that art. [in which see more]:) or Salaga said of any cloven-hoofed animal, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies he entered the sixth year: or, as some say, the fifth: this is the utmost of the ages thereof [that have verbs and epithets to denote them]: (Mṣb:) SuluwgN (Mgh, Mṣb) in these animals (Mṣb) or in sheep or goats and animals of the bovine kind (Mgh) is like buzuwlN in camels. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

hom.sense: SalagN: see SalagapN.
Also A red [hill or mountain, such as is termed] haDobap [q. v.]. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: SalogapN A large ship or boat. (Lth, O, Ḳ.)

SalagapN [a n. un. of which SalagN↓ is the coll. gen. n., as is indicated in the O and TA,] applied to a she-camel i. q. rabaAEiyapN [i. e. In her seventh year], and fat: or i. q. sadiysN [i. e. in the eighth year]. (AA, O, Ḳ.)

SaAligN part. n. of 1 [q. v.], (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) an epithet applied to the male and the female of all cloven-hoofed animals, (Mṣb,) or to an animal of the bovine kind and to the sheep or goat, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) I. q. saAligN, (IDrd, O, TA,) which latter is said by Sb to be the original, the S being substituted for the s because of the g: (TA:) or, applied to a sheep or goat (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ) and to a bovine animal, (Ḳ,) it is like qaAriHN [q. v.] applied to a horse: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:) or in the fifth year, (Aṣ, IF, O, Ḳ,) as applied to a sheep: (Aṣ, IF, O:) or in the sixth year, (AZ, O, Ḳ,) as applied to a sheep or goat: (AZ, O:) or a sheep or goat advanced in age: (IDrd, O:) [see more in art. slg:] the pl. is Sul-agN (IAạr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and SawaAligu, (IAạr, O, Ḳ,) both of which are applied to kibaAX, (Ḳ,) [or rather] the former pl. is thus applied by Ru-beh, who by kibaAX in this instance means “heroes,” or “brave men.” (Ṣ, O.)

hom.sense:
1. Salifa Als-aHaAbu, [aor. _a {yaSolafu},] inf. n. SalafN, The clouds had in them no water: (M:)
or Salifati Als-aHaAbapu the cloud had little water. (A, TA. [It is implied in the TA that this is tropical; but I doubt its being so.]) See also its part. n., SalifN.
Salifa said of a man's Harov [or seed-produce], It did not increase, or multiply, or become plentiful or abundant. (TA.)
SalafN as a quality of TaEaAm [or wheat] signifies Its having little increase (nuzol, Ṣ, or nazal, L, or namaMC and barakap, Ḳ) and little goodness. (L, TA: said in the latter to be tropical.)

[Hence, app., or from the verb as used in the sense expl. in the next sentence below,] mano yabogi fiI Ald-iyni yaSolafo, (Ṣ, M, Meyd, &c.,) a prov., (Ṣ, Meyd, O, Ḳ,) relating to the holding fast to religion, (Ṣ,) or used in urging to the mixing in social intercourse with the holding fast to religion, (O, Ḳ,) or, accord. to IAth, a trad., (TA,) i. e., accord. to Aṣ, He who exceeds the right bounds in religion (Meyd) will not be in favour with men, or beloved by them; (Ṣ, Meyd;) or will have little increase therein: (M:) or he who finds fault with men in respect of religion, (O, Ḳ,) and regards it as an excellence [that he possesses] above them, will have little goodness in their estimation, and (O) will not be in favour with them, or beloved by them: (O, Ḳ:) or the meaning is, he who seeks worldly good by means of religion, his share of the former will be little: (Meyd:) or he who seeks, in respect of religion, more than he has had revealed to him, his share will be little. (IAth.)

Salifato, (Ṣ, M, O,) aor. _a {yaSolafu}, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. SalafN, said of a woman, means She was not in favour with, or was not beloved by, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,*) her husband, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or him by whom she was supported; (M;) and was hated by him. (Ṣ, O.)
SalafN, (O, Ḳ,) in a man and in a woman, (O,) signifies also The saying that which one's companion dislikes, or hates. (O, Ḳ.)

And, (O, Ḳ,) likewise in a man and in a woman, (O,) † The commending, or praising, oneself for, or the boasting of, or glorying in, that which one does not possess: (O, Ḳ:) or, (Ḳ,) as Kh asserts, (Ṣ, O,) the overpassing the due limits in AlZ-arof [here meaning elegance of mind, manners, address, speech, person, attire, and the like], (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) and in excellence in knowledge or courage or other qualities, (TA,) and arrogating to oneself more than is due, through pride: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) but some say that this is post-classical: (M, TA:) [see an ex. voce MfapN, in art. Awf; mentioned here in the TA as occurring in a trad.:] one says, of a man, Salifa, (M, MA,) inf. n. SalafN, (M,) meaning † He commended, or praised, himself [&c.]; (MA;) and tSl-f↓, (Ṣ, MA, O,) meaning the same; (MA;) or this latter means takal-afa AlS-alafa, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. [he affected the overpassing of the due limits in AlZ-arof (meaning as expl. above); or he took upon himself as a task] the arrogating to himself more than was due, through pride: (TA:) [you say, tSl-f bimaA layosa Einodahu † He commended, or praised, himself for, or he boasted of, or gloried in, that which he did not possess:] the epithet from the former verb is SalifN↓, (AZ, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) applied to a man, (AZ, Ṣ, M, O,) and SalifapN applied to a woman; (M;) and the pl. of SalifN is SalaAfaI (AZ, M, Ḳ) and SulafaMCu and Salifuwna: (AZ, O, Ḳ:) it is said to be from SalifN applied to a vessel, accord. to IAạr as meaning “that takes little water;” but rather, as others say, as meaning “thick and heavy:” the vulgar misapply it [app. by using it in the sense assigned to it by IAạr]. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph {4}.
4. ASlf i. q. qal-a xayoruhu [His good things became few; or his wealth, or his goodness or beneficence, became little]: (IAạr, O, Ḳ:) and (TA) so tSl-f↓. (M, TA.)
And His soul, or spirit, (ruwHuhu,) became heavy; (IAạr, O, Ḳ;) and he became oppressed as though by the nightmare. (TḲ.)
And He became one whose wife was not in favour with him, or not beloved by him. (M.)

ASlfhA He hated her, namely, his wife; (M;) as also SalifahaA↓, (so in a copy of the M,) or SalafahaA, aor. _i {yaSolifu}; (so in the L and TA;) the latter mentioned by IAmb: (L,TA:) or ASlfhu he hated him, namely, another man. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
And ASlf nisaMCahu He divorced his wives: and he made their share of his favours to be small. (A, TA.)
And one says to a woman, OaSolafa Qll-ehu rufogaki, meaning May God make thee [or thy faroj or the like] to be hated by thy husband. (EshSheybánee, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

ASlf Alqawomu, (thus in the O, on the authority of Ibn-ʼAbbád, [like OaHozana, and its contr. Oasohala, &c.,]) or tSl-f↓, (thus in the Ḳ, [but the former is preferable on the ground of analogy, and the latter I think a mistake,]) The people, or party, became in the [kind of tract termed] SalofaMC. (O, Ḳ.)
5. tSl-f: see 4, first sentence.
And see 1, latter part.
Also He behaved in a loving, or an affectionate, and a blandishing, or coaxing, manner. (O, Ḳ.)
And, said of a camel, He loathed, or turned away with disgust from, the [pasturage termed] xul-ap, and inclined to the HamoD. (O, Ḳ.)
See also 4, last sentence.

entry.sense: AlS-alofu The branches of the heart of the palmtree that are next belong the qilabap: [in the CK, xawACN fI qulobi Aln-axolapi is erroneously put for xawaAfiI qlbi Aln-xlpi; and the same mistake was originally made in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ:] n. un. with p. (IAạr, O, Ḳ,* TA. [See xaAfiyapN, last sentence.])

SalifN, applied to clouds (saHaAb, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ), Containing no water: (M:) or having little water and much thunder. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ. [Said in the TA to be tropical; but I doubt its being so.]) It is said in a prov., rub-a SalifK taHota Alr-aAEidapi, (Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or rub-a SalafK↓, (M, O, and so in some copies of the Ḳ, [with an inf. n. in the place of an epithet,]) i. e. Many a cloud is there, [or many clouds are there, lacking rain, or] having much thunder with little rain, [beneath that which thunders:] (AʼObeyd, O:) applied to the wealthy niggard: (AʼObeyd, O, Ḳ:) or to him who threatens, and does not perform what he threatens: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or to him who commends himself much, (M, O, Ḳ,) and is loquacious, (M, O,) but is destitute of good. (M, O, Ḳ.)

And A vessel that takes little water: (IAạr, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) a small vessel: one that leaks; that will not hold water. (IAạr, TA. [This, also, is said in the TA to be tropical.]) And A heavy (Ḳ, TA) and thick (TA) vessel. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also High ground (quf-), or a hard plain, that produces no plants or herbage: (TA:) and so the fem., with p {SalifapN}, applied to land (OaroD). (M, TA.)
Wheat (TaEaAm) having little increase (qaliylu Aln-azali and Alr-ayoEi): (M:) or tasteless: (M, O, Ḳ:) and SaliyfN↓ signifies the same, in the former sense or in the latter. (M.)

And [A man] heavy in soul, or spirit; syn. vaqiylu Alr-uwHi. (TA. [See 4, second sentence, which shows that muSolifN has this meaning: but the epithet thus expl. in the TA is there said to be like katifN.])

And SalifapN signifies A woman not in favour with, or not beloved by, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) her husband, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or him by whom she is supported; (M;) and hated by him: (Ṣ, O:) pl. SalaAYifu, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) which is extr. [in respect of analogy], (M,) and SalifaAtN. (O, Ḳ.)
See also 1, near the end.
SalofaMC and SilofaMC, and each with p {SalofaMCapN and SilofaMCapN: see OaSolafu, in five places.

hom.sense: SaliyfN The side (EuroD [in one of my copies of the Ṣ EaroD, and in the other copy Eirq,]) of the neck; the two being called SaliyfaAni; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) [i. e.] AlS-aliyfaAni signifies the two sides of the neck (jaAnibaA AlEunuqi): or this signifies what are between the liyt [or part beneath the earring] and the qaSarap [or base of the neck, on the two sides]: (M:) or the two heads of the vertebra that is next to the head, in the two sides of the neck. (AZ, O,* Ḳ,* TA.) In this last explanation, in the copies of the Ḳ, rOs is put for rOsA. (TA. [And in some copies of the Ḳ, Xiq-ayohimaA is there erroneously put for Xiq-ayohaA, which, as is said in the TA, refers to the neck.]) Oaxaca biSaliyfihi and biSaliyfatihi↓ mean, accord. to Aṣ, He took hold of the back of his neck: (O, TA:) and one says also, Oaxacahu biSaliyfatihi↓ meaning He took him, or it, altogether. (TA. [But I think it not improbable that biSaliyfatihi↓ in these two instances may be a mistranscription for biSaliyfayohi.])

AlS-aliyfaAni signifies also Two staves, or pieces of wood, which are placed across [horizontally] upon the [camel's saddle called] gabiyT, by means of which the maHaAmil [pl. of maHomilN, q. v.,] are bound. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And (TA) SaliyfaA AlUikaAfi signifies The two [similar] pieces of wood that are bound upon the upper part of the [saddle called] UikaAf. (M, TA.)
See also SalifN, latter half.

entry.sense: SaliyfapN: see SaliyfN, in three places.
SalanofFI and SalanofaMCN A loquacious man. (M, TA.)

OaSolafu Hard, applied to a place; and so [the fem.] SalofaMCu↓ applied to land (OaroD): (Ṣ, O:) or both signify hard ground (M, Ḳ) containing stones; (M;)
or hard and rugged ground; (Aṣ, O;) and the pl. is SalaAfK, (M, O, Ḳ,* [in the last, erroneously, SalaAfiI, and in the O, correctly, AlS-alaAfiI, being made determinate,]) thus pluralized in the same manner as SaHoraMC because the quality of a subst. is predominant therein, (M,) and [for the same reason] OaSaAlifu also; (O, Ḳ;) [the former pl. of SlfMC, and the latter of ASlf:] or SalofaMC↓ (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ) and SilofaMC↓, [each, app., with tenween, the latter because of the measure fiEolaMC, and each because receiving the affix p, for it is added,] and likewise SalofaMCapN↓ (Ḳ) and SilofaMCapN↓, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,) rugged, hard ground: (Ḳ:) or a smooth rock, or a hard, smooth, bare rock, even with the ground. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
muSolifN A man whose wife is not in favour with him or not beloved by him. (IAạr, M, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. Salaqa, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaSoliqu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. SaloqN, (Aṣ,* Ṣ,* M,* TA,) He called out, cried out, or shouted, vehemently; or made a vehement sound; (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also ASlq↓: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) he raised his voice on the occasion of a calamity, and of a death: (TA:) and he wailed; (M, TA;) and so ↓the latter verb: (M:) AʼObeyd mentions it as with s [in the place of S]. (TA.)
Also, (Ṣ, O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) said of the tush of a camel; (Ṣ, O, TA;) and so ASlq↓; (Ṣ,* M, O;*) It made a sound by its being grated against another. (Ṣ,* M, O,* TA.)
And Salaqati Alxayolu, (M,* O, TA,) aor. _i {yaSoliqu}, or, accord. to Lth, _u, inf. n. as above, (O,) The horsemen dashed amid others (fiyhimo) in making a sudden attack or incursion. (M,* O, TA.*)

Salaqa naAbahu, inf. n. SaloqN, He (a camel) grated his tush against another so as to make them produce a sound: and ASlq↓, said of a stallion [camel], he made his tushes to produce a grating sound: (M, TA:) and ASTlq↓ binaAbihi, likewise said of a stallion [camel], he made a grating sound with his tush. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)

Salaqahu biAlEaSaA, (AZ, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaSoluqu}, inf. n. SaloqN, (M,) He struck him with the staff, or stick, (AZ, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) namely, another man, (Ḳ,) upon any part of his body. (M.) And SaloqN is also said to signify The striking with stone-cutter's picks, or pickaxes. (O.) See also SulaAqapN.
Salaqatohu AlX-amosu The sun smote him with its heat. (O, Ḳ.)
Salaqa baniI fulaAnK (aor. _i {yaSoliqu} TA) He attacked the sons of such a one with an abominable onslaught. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.)

Salaqahu bilisaAnihi, aor. _u {yaSoluqu}, inf. n. SaloqN, † He reviled him; syn. Xatamahu. (M.) Fr says that Salaquwkumo is allowable in the sense of salaquwkumo in the Ḳur xxxiii. 19: (Ṣ * and TA in this art.:) but it is not allowable in the reading [of the Ḳur]. (TA in art. slq, q. v.)
Salaqa jaAriyatahu He spread his girl, or young woman, (Ḳ, TA,) upon her back, (TA,) and compressed her. (Ḳ, TA.)
Salaqotu AlX-aMpa I roasted the sheep, or goat, upon its sides. (TA.)
Suliqa bisahomihi He was rendered unfortunate by his arrow [in the game called Almayosir]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, former half, in four places.

5. tSl-qt AlmaroOapu The woman, being taken with the pains of parturition, screamed, or cried out vehemently: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or threw herself upon her sides, one time thus and another time thus. (Lth, O.) And tSl-qt Aln-aAqapu, (Lth, O,) or Ald-aAb-apu, (Ḳ,) The she-camel, (Lth, O,) or the beast, (Ḳ,) rolled over, back for belly, by reason of distress: and in like manner the verb is used of any one suffering pain. (Lth, O, Ḳ.) And tSl-q EalaI firaAXihi, occurring in a trad., means He writhed about upon his sides on his bed, (O, TA,) and rolled over. (TA.) And tSl-q AlHuwtu fiI AlmaMCi The fish went and came in the water. (O.)
8: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.

hom.sense: SaloqN, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M,) an inf. n., (TA, [see 1, first sentence,]) and SalaqN↓ and SaloqapN↓, (M, TA,) A vehement crying or shouting (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, TA) or sounding: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) and a wailing. (M, TA.)

And the first, [thus written in a copy of the JK and in a copy of the M, but perhaps correctly SalaqN↓, q. v.,] A round plain: (JK:) or a depressed, soft, round plain: (M:) pl. OaSaAliqu (JK, M) and SuloqaAnN. (M.)
SalaqN: see SaloqN, first sentence.
Also An even plain; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) like salaqN [q. v.]: (Ṣ, O:) pl. OaSolaAqN, and pl. pl. OaSaAlqu, (O, Ḳ, TA,) in one copy of the Ḳ AaSAlyq. (TA.) See also SaloqN, latter sentence.

entry.sense: SaloqapN: see SaloqN.
Also An onslaught, or a shock in battle. (M, TA.)
SalaqaAtu AlUibili The tushes of camels, that make a sound by their being grated, one against another. (Ṣ,* O,* TA.)
SaliyqN Smooth. (O, Ḳ.)

SulaAqapN Water that has long preserved a still, or motionless, state, (OaTaAla SiyaAmFA, JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,* in which last SyAmA is omitted,) in the place, (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, O,) or in a place, (Ḳ,) i. e. in one place, (TA,) and which the beasts have beaten [with their feet], (SalaqahaA↓ Ald-awaAb-u, [which, accord. to MF, should be Salaqahu Ald-awaAb-u, referring to the word maMC, but accord. to the TA it may refer to SulaAqap,]) wherefore it is [said to be] maSoluwqap↓. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ, TA.) In such water the ablution termed AlwuDuwoC should not be performed. (TḲ.)

SaliyqapN Flesh-meat (Jm, O, Ḳ) thoroughly cooked, (Jm, TA,) or spread to dry, (maXoriI-N, O,) or roasted, (maXowiI-N, Ḳ,) and thoroughly cooked: (O, Ḳ:) or a piece of roasted flesh-meat: (M:) pl. SalaAYiqu: (Jm, M, O, Ḳ:) accord. to AA, salaAYiqu, with s, signifies “roasted lambs,” from salaqotu AlX-aApa “I roasted the sheep or goat.” (TA. See also saliyqapN.)
And A thin cake of bread: (M, TA:) accord. to some, (O,) [the pl.] SalaAYiqu signifies thin bread: (JK, Ṣ, O:) but some say that it is SaraAYiqu, with r, that has this meaning. (TA.)
SalanoqFI [said in the copies of the Ḳ to be like EalanodaI, but correctly EalanodFI,] and SalanoqaMCN Loquacious: (O, Ḳ:) the n is augmentative. (O.)
SulayoqaMCu A species of bird. (M, TA.)
And DarobN Sal-aAqN and miSolaAqN↓ A vehement striking or beating. (M, TA.)
miSolaqN: see the next preceding paragraph.
miSolaAqN: see Sal-aAqN, in two places.
maSaAliyqu [a pl. of which the sing., if it have one, is not specified,] Large, or bulky, stones. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
And Light, or active, camels. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
maSoluwqN: see its fem., with p {maSoluwqapN}, voce SulaAqapN.

hom.sense: 1. Salama, aor. _i {yaSolimu}, [in one of my copies of the Ṣ _u,] inf. n. SalomN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He cut off, (Ḳ,) or he cut off so as to extirpate, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) a thing, (M, Ḳ,*) or an ear, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and a nose; (M, Ḳ;) as also Sl-m↓, (M, Ḳ,*) inf. n. taSoliymN; (Ḳ;) [but] the latter verb is with teshdeed to denote muchness [of the action], or multiplicity [of the objects]: (TA:) and AiSoTalama↓ [likewise] signifies he cut off so as to extirpate (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ) a nose. (Mṣb.)
And Salima, aor. _a {yaSolamu}, inf. n. SalamN, He had his ear extirpated [by amputation]. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
8: see 1.
[Hence,] AuSoTulima Alqawomu The people, or party, were destroyed [or cut off] (M, TA) utterly. (TA.)
SulomapN i. q. migofarN. (Ḳ. [See the latter word, which is variously explained.])

hom.sense: SalamapN [written by Golius and Freytag SalamN] Strong men: (Ḳ, TA:) as though pl. of SaAlimN. (TA.)
See also SayolamN.

entry.sense: SilaAmapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and SulaAmapN and SalaAmapN, (Ḳ,) the last on the authority of IAạr, (TA,) [all three written in a copy of the M with teshdeed to the l,] A party, or distinct body, of men: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) pl. SlAmAt, signifying companies, and parties, or distinct bodies: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, SulaAmapN, with damm, means a party, or company, equals in age and courage and liberality or bounty. (TA.)
Sal-aAmN and Sul-aAmN The kernel of the stone of the nabiq [or fruit of the lote-tree]; (M, Ḳ;) which is also called OulobuwbN; and is eaten: mentioned by Az. (TA.)

hom.sense: SayolamN A difficult, severe, or distressing, event; (M, Ḳ;) such as extirpates: you say OamorN SayolamN: and such is termed Sayolamiy-apN↓. (M.) And you say also waqoEapN SayolamapN i. e. [An onslaught] that extirpates. (Ḳ.)
And A calamity; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) because it [often] extirpates; and so SalamapN↓. (TA.)
And An abominable severing from friendly, or loving, communion or intercourse. (TA.)
And A sword. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also i. q. wajobapN: like SayoramN [q. v.]: (M, Ḳ:) both mentioned by Yaạḳoob. (M.)

entry.sense: Sayolamiy-apN: see the next preceding paragraph.
muSal-amN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
Q. 4. AiSolahab-ati AlOaXoyaMCu i. q. Aimotad-ato EalaI jihatihaA [The things extended in their proper direction]. (Ḳ. [In the O, AiXotad-ato is put in the place of Amtd-t. Compare Aisolahab-a.])
SalohabN A tall man; (Aṣ, IJ, O, Ḳ;) and so salohabN [q. v.]; (IJ, TA;) as also muSolahib-N↓ or muSalohabN↓. (Ḳ accord. to different copies.)

And A strong camel; (Ḳ;) and so SalahobFI↓, (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which the final letter is [not a sign of the fem. gender but] to render the word quasi-coordinate to the quadriliteral-radical class; (Ṣ;) fem. SalohabapN (TA) and SalahobaApN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. SalaAhibu. (AA, O, TA.)
And A large, or great, house or tent. (Lth, O, Ḳ.)
And A hard stone; as also SulaAhibN↓. (AA, TA.)
SalahobFI, and its fem. {SalahobaApN}: see the next preceding paragraph.
SulaAhibN: see the next preceding paragraph.
muSolahib-N or muSalohabN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. Salawotuhu, (Ḳ,) or Salawotu AlZ-ahora, (M,) I struck, or beat, that part, [of him, or] of the back, which is called SalFA: (M:) or I hit that part (M, Ḳ) with a thing, or with an arrow or some other thing: on the authority of Lḥ, who says that it is of the dial. of Hudheyl: and one says also Salayotuhu; which is extr. [with respect to derivation], unless it be an instance of interchangeableness [of w and I]. (M.)
Saliyato and Salato, said of a mare, or she-camel: see 4.

2. Sl-I, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) quasi-inf. n. SalaApN or Salewp, for which one should not say taSoliyapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the latter is allowable as agreeable with rule and as occurring in old poetry, (MF, TA,) He prayed, supplicated, or petitioned: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and [particularly] he performed the divinely-appointed act [of prayer commonly] termed SalaAp or Salewp. (Ṣ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [ix. 104], (TA,) waSal-i Ealayohimo And pray thou for them. (Mṣb, TA.) Sal-aI EalaI fulaAnK means He prayed for such a one, and praised him. (TA.) And hence the verse of El-Aạshà cited in art. rsm, conj. 8. (Ṣ, Mgh,* TA.) It is said in a trad., mano duEiIa UilaI waliymapK faloyujibo waUil-aA faloyuSal-i [i. e. Whoso is invited to a banquet, or a marriage-feast, let him comply, or, if not, let him pray for the inviter]. (M.) And the saying, in a verse of El-Aạshà, Ealayoki mivola Al-aciI Sal-ayoti means Keep thou to the like of thy prayer; i. e. he enjoined her to repeat the prayer for him: or, as some relate it, Ealayoki mivolu Al-aciI Sal-ayoti, meaning upon thee be the like of that for which thou hast prayed: (M:) these words he addressed to his daughter, on the occasion of her saying, “O my Lord, ward off from my father diseases and pain.” (Mgh.) The saying Eabiydu fulaAnK yuSal-uwna [The slaves of such a one perform the divinely-appointed act of prayer] means that they have attained to the age of virility. (Mgh.)

Sl-I Ealayohi, said of an angel, means He prayed for, or begged, forgiveness, or pardon, for him: and thus the verb sometimes means when said of other than an angel; as in the trad. of Sowdeh, in which it is said, UicaA mitonaA Sal-aI lanaA EuvomaAnu bonu maZoEuwnK [When we die, ʼOthmán Ibn-Madh'oon will pray for forgiveness for us]; he having then died. (TA.)

[And, said of a man, He blessed him, meaning he invoked God's blessing upon him; namely, the Prophet; or he said, Aall-ehum-a Sal-i Ealayohi (expl. by what here follows) accord. to the rendering of Sal-uwA Ealayohi, i. e. EalaI Aln-abiI-i, by Bḍ and others in the Ḳur xxxiii. 56.] One says, Sal-ayotu EalaI Aln-abiI-i [I blessed the Prophet;, &c.]. (Ṣ.)

And, said of God, He blessed him, meaning He conferred blessing upon him: and He had mercy on him: and He magnified him, or conferred honour upon him: hence the saying, Aall-ehum-a Sal-i EalaI Mli OabiI OawofaI, meaning O God, bless the family of Aboo-Owfà: or have mercy on, &c.: but in the saying [in the Ḳur xxxiii. 56], Uin-a Qll-eha wamalaAYikatahu yuSal-uwna EalaI Aln-abiI-i, the verb does not import two meanings; for it has there only one meaning, which is “magnification” [i. e. these words mean Verily God and his angels magnify the Prophet; or rather I would render them, bless the Prophet, as this rendering implies magnification and also a meaning of the quasi-inf. n. given in the M and Ḳ, which is “eulogy,” or “commendation,” bestowed by God upon his apostle, while it imports God's “conferring of blessing” and the angels' “invoking thereof”]: (Mṣb, TA:) [it is said that] Qll-ehum-a Sal-i EalaI muHam-adK means O God, magnify Moḥammad in the present world by exalting his renown and manifesting his invitation [to El-Islám] and rendering permanent his law, and in the world to come by accepting his intercession for his people and multiplying his reward: and it is disputed whether or not this form of prayer may be used for any but the Prophet [Moḥammad]: El-Khaṭṭábee says that it may not, though he himself used it for others. (TA.) [Sal-aI Qll-ehu Ealayohi wasal-ama is a phrase commonly used by the Muslims after the mention of their prophet: see art. slm. See also SalaApN below.]

Sl-I said of a horse, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taSoliyapN, (TA,) He followed next after the foremost [in a race, at the goal]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the saying [in a trad. of ʼAlee], sabaqa rasuwlu Qll-ehi waSal-aI Oabuw bakorK waval-ava Eumaru [expl. in art. sbq]. (Mgh.)
And Sl-I AlHimaAru Outunahu, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. taSoliyapN, (Ṣgh, TA,) The [wild] ass drove together his she-asses, and made them to take the way [that he would follow]. (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 4. OaSolato, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and Saliyato↓, (Fr, Ḳ, TA,) and Salato↓, (Zj, TA,) said of a mare, The parts on the right and left of her tail, (SalawaAhaA, Ṣ,) or the part on either side of her tail, (SalaAhaA, Ḳ, [see SalFA, below,]) became relaxed, she being near to bringing forth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, said of a she-camel, her young one fell into the part of her called SalFA, and she was near to bringing forth. (T, TA.)

SalFA The middle of the back of a human being and of any quadruped: (M, Ḳ:) and, (Ḳ,) or as some say, (M,) [app. in a beast,] the part that slopes down from the hips, or haunches: or the space intervening between the jaAEirap [app. meaning the hinder projection of the haunch or rump of a beast] and the tail: (M, Ḳ:) or the part on the right and left of the tail; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) the two together being called [the] SalawaAni, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is similarly expl. by Zj in relation to a she-camel; app. properly meaning the two parts bordering upon the tail-bone: (TA:) or the place in which is set the tail of the horse; dual as above: (Mṣb:) or the bone upon which are the two buttocks: (Mgh: [there thus expl. in relation to a man:]) or the bone in which is the place of setting of the tail-bone; thus expl. by IDrd: or the SalawaAni are the two bones projecting from the two sides of the rump: or, accord. to some of the lexicologists, two veins (EiroqaAni) in the place of the ridof [i. e. in the rump]: (Ḥam p. 46:) the pl. is SalawaAtN, (M, Ḳ,) an instance of a pl. formed by the addition of A and t from a masc. sing., (M,) and OaSolaMCN. (M, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] one says, jiYotu fiI OaSolaAYihimo, meaning I came at their rears. (TA.)

hom.sense:
SalaApN, or Salewp, [accord. to El-Ḥareeree, to be written with A when prefixed to a pronoun, and also in the dual number, (see De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Arabe, p. 67 of the Arabic text,) but this rule I have not found to be generally observed, even in the best MSS., nor have I in the similar case of HayewpN, (to which it is also applied,) in the best copies of the Ḳur-án,]
is said to be [originally SalawapN,] of the measure faEalapN, (Mgh, MF, TA,) or, accord. to some, [SalowapN,] of the measure faEolapN: (MF, TA:) it is a quasi-inf. n. of Sal-aI [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and [used as a simple subst.] it signifies Prayer, supplication, or petition: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) this is said to be its primary signification: and muSal-FI↓ is said to have the same meaning. (Mṣb, TA.)

Then applied to signify A certain well-known mode, or manner, [of religious service,] because comprising prayer; (Mṣb;) [the divinelyappointed act of prayer;] one of the divinelyappointed SalawaAt; (Ṣ;) a certain religious service in which are rukuwE [or lowering of the head so that the palms of the hands reach the knees] and sujuwd [or prostration of oneself in a particular manner expl. voce sajada]: (M,* Ḳ:) and muSal-FI↓ is said to have the same meaning. (TA.) [The performance of this act is fully described in my work on the Modern Egyptians.] It is said to be, in this sense, a proper term of the law, not indicated by the language of the Arabs [before El-Islám] except as importing prayer, which is its primary signification: what Esh-Shiháb says respecting it necessarily implies its being a proper term of the law known to the Arabs [before El-Islám]: in the Mz it is said to be one of the words of El-Islám: but all of these sayings require consideration. (MF, TA, [Much more, which I omit as being unprofitable, is added on this point in the TA, partly from the Mṣb; as well as several different opinions respecting the derivation of the word as used in this sense, which are fanciful or absurd.]) The saying of the Prophet, laA Salewpa lijaAri Almasojidi Uil-aA fiI Almasojidi means There is no Slwp [or divinely-appointed act of prayer] that is excellent or complete [to the neighbour of the mosque unless in the mosque]. (M.) And his saying, to Usámeh, AlS-alewpu OamaAmaka means The time of the Slwp [or divinely-appointed prayer], or the place thereof, [is before thee,] alluding to that of sunset. (Mgh.) And he used the term AlS-alewpu as meaning suwrapu AlS-alewpi, i. e. The faAtiHap [or Opening Chapter of the Ḳur-án, because it is a form of prayer, or] because the recital thereof is excellent, or satisfactory. (Mgh.) In the Ḳur xxii. 41, (I’Ab, Ṣ, M, Ksh, Bḍ,) [the pl.] SalawaAtN means Places of worship of the Jews: (I’Ab, Ṣ, M, Ksh, Bḍ, Ḳ:) said to be (Ksh, Bḍ) originally SaluwtaA, a Hebrew word, (Ksh, Bḍ, Ḳ,) arabicized: (Ksh, Bḍ:) this is the common reading of the word, and the most valid: other readings are SuluwaAtN and SulawaAtN and SilawaAtN; and beside these, some others which are perverted forms. (TA.)
Also Prayer for forgiveness or pardon. (M, Mgh, Ḳ.)
[And A blessing, as meaning an invocation of God's blessing upon any one. See 2.]

And i. q. barakapN [as meaning A blessing, such as is bestowed by God]: (Mṣb:) and mercy (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of God (Ṣ, M) on his apostle: (M:) and magnification; and this is [said to be] specially denoted by its verb when the Prophet is the object: (Mṣb:) and God's eulogy, or commendation, bestowed upon his apostle. (M, Ḳ.)
AlS-alaApu [from SalFA] also means UitoyaAnu AlmaroOapi fiI duburihaA. (TA in art. Swm.)

entry.sense: muSoliyapN part. n. of OaSolato [q. v.] said of a she-camel [or of a mare]. (T, TA.)

muSal-FI A place of AlS-alaAp [as meaning the performance of the divinely-appointed act of prayer]; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or of any prayer or supplication: (Mgh:) [and particularly] a place of the performance of the divinely-appointed prayer on the occasion of the [festival termed] Eiyd: (MA:) [and also such a place at a burial-ground: the place for this purpose is particularly termed muSal-aI AlOamowaAti: see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., i. 192.]
And A carpet upon which one performs the divinely-appointed act of prayer. (MA.)
See also SalaApN, former half, in two places.

hom.sense: muSal-K Any one praying [in any manner: and particularly performing the divinely-appointed act of prayer]. (TA.)

And AlmuSal-iI signifies, as applied to a horse, The one that follows next after the foremost [at the goal] (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb) in a race: (Mgh, Mṣb:) because his head is next to the part called SalFA, (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) or next to the SalawaAni, (Mgh,) of the foremost. (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb.)

1. SalaAhu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaSoliyhi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. SaloIN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) He roasted, broiled, or fried, it, namely, flesh-meat, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,), &c.; (Ṣ;) and SalaAhu fiI Aln-aAri and EalaI Aln-aAri signify the same; and also he burned it. (TA.) And (so in the M, but in the Ḳ “or”) SalaAhu (M, Ḳ) fiI Aln-aAri (M) He threw it into the fire to be burned; as also ASlAhu↓; and Sl-Ahu↓, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. taSoliyapN; (TA;) namely, flesh-meat. (M, Ḳ. [But see the next sentence.]) And SalaAhu Aln-aAra and fiI Aln-aAri and EalaI Aln-aAri, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. SaloIN and SuliI-N and SiliI-N; (M;) and ASlAhu↓ Aln-aAra, and Sl-Ahu↓ Aln-aAra; He made him to enter into the fire, and to remain, stay, dwell, or abide, therein: (M, Ḳ:) and Sul-iIa↓ fulaAnN Aln-aAra [Such as one was made to enter into the fire,, &c.]: (M:) [or] you say, Salayotu Alr-ajula naArFA, meaning I made the man to enter fire and to be burned: and OaSolayotuhu↓, with A, when you mean I threw him, or cast him, into the fire, as though intending burning [him]; as also Sal-ayotuhu↓, inf. n. taSoliyapN. (Ṣ.)

And Salayotu fulaAnFA, (T, TA,) or lifulaAnK, (Ṣ, TA,) ‡ I laboured in a case, or an affair, desiring to calumniate, or slander, such a one therein, and to cause him to fall into destruction: (T, Ṣ, TA:) or Salayotuhu and Salayotu lahu both signify I calumniated, or slandered, him, and caused him to fall into destruction, (M, TA,) in consequence thereof: (M:) or, accord. to the Ḳ, SalaI fulaAnFA, of which the inf. n. is SaloIN, signifies he soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, such a one: or deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him: which meanings are not in any of the three lexicons above mentioned: accord. to the A, Salayotu bifulaAnK [probably a mistranscription for lifulaAnK] means ‡ I framed a stratagem, or plot, to cause such a one to fall; there said to be tropical. (TA.)
SalaI yadahu biAln-aAri [said in the TA to be a mistake]: see 2.

SaliIa Aln-aAra, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and biAln-aAri, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaSolaI, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,*) inf. n. SalFI, (Mṣb,) or SuliI-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ, [SaloyFA in the CK being a mistranscription for Suliy-FA,]) or both, (M,) and SiliI-N and SilaMCN, (M, Ḳ,) and accord. to the Ḳ SalaMCN, but this is a mistake for SalFI, (TA,) He was, or became, burned [by the fire]: (Ṣ:) or he endured, or suffered, the heat of the fire; as also tSl-I↓ Aln-aAra: (M, Ḳ:) or he felt the heat of the fire: (Mṣb:) and one says tSl-I↓ Har-a Aln-aAri and ASTlAhu↓ [in this last sense or in the sense next preceding]: (Ḥam p. 792:) and SaliIa Aln-aAra he entered into the fire: (TA in art. blh: see an ex. voce baloha:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, SaliIa biAln-aAri means he was tried (buliIa) by fire, or by the fire; and so bikacaA † [by such a thing, as though by fire]. (TA.) [In the Ḳur, in which are many exs. of it, (iv. 11, xiv. 34, xvii. 19, &c.,) it is always trans. by itself, without bi.] And SaliIa biAlOamori, (Ṣ, M,*) and biAlHarobi; (Ṣ;) and tSl-I↓ AlOamora, and AlHaroba; (M;) He endured, or suffered, the heat, and severity, or vehemence, of the affair, or case, and of the war, or fight: (Ṣ, M:) Aboo-Zubeyd says,
faqado taSal-ayotu↓ Har-a Harobihimu
kamaA taSal-aI↓ Almaqoruwru mino qarasi
[And I have suffered the heat and vehemence of their war, like as he who is affected with cold suffers in consequence of coldest and most abundant hoar-frost]. (M.)

[It is said that] SaliIa Alr-ajulu signifies also lazima [i. e. The man kept to, or clave to, a thing]; and so ASTlI↓: whence Zj holds SalaApN [expl. in art. Slw] to be derived; because it is a keeping, or cleaving, to that which God has appointed: and hence also, [it is said,] mano yuSal-aI↓ fiI Aln-aAri, i. e. ylzm [app. yulozamu, meaning mano yulozamu Aln-aAra He who is made to keep, or cleave, to the fire; nearly agreeing with Sal-aAhu Aln-aAra as expl. above from the M and Ḳ]. (TA.)

And Salayotu AlZ-ahora means I struck, or beat, that part of the back which is called SalFA: or I hit that part: but this is extr.; for by rule it should be Salawotuhu, like as Hudheyl say. (M. [See 1 in art. Slw.])

entry.sense: 2: see 1, second sentence; and third sentence in three places; and last sentence but one.

One says also, Sl-I yadahu biAln-aAri, (M, TA,) accord. to the Ḳ SalaI↓, [without teshdeed,] but this is wrong, as is shown by a verse cited in the M, (TA,) He warmed his hand with the fire. (M, Ḳ, TA.) [And it is said in the TA that SlA Zahorahu bAlnhr means OadofaOahu: but I think that the right reading is Sl-I Zahorahu biAln-amirapi, i. e. He warmed his back with the woollen garment called namirap.]

And Sal-ayotu AlEaSaA biAln-aAri I made the staff supple, and straightened it, by means of fire: (Ṣ:) or Sl-I AlEaSaA EalaI Aln-aAri, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. taSoliyapN; (Ḳ;) and tSl-AhA↓; he parched and darkened the staff upon the fire; syn. law-aHahaA: (M, Ḳ:) or Sl-I AlEaSaA he straightened the staff by turning it round over the fire: (T in art. dwm: see an ex. in a verse cited in that art., conj. 10:) and Sal-ayotu AlqanaApa I straightened the spear-shaft by means of fire: (A, TA:) and Sal-ayotu AlEuwda biAln-aAri I rendered supple the stick, or branch, by means of fire. (Mṣb.)
4: see 1, second sentence; and third sentence in two places.
5: see the next paragraph {8}, in two places:
see also 1, latter half, in five places:
and see 2, last sentence.

8. ASTlI He warmed himself (M, Ḳ) biAln-aAri [by means of the fire]: (M:) one says, AiSoTalayotu biAln-aAri and taSal-ayotu↓ bihaA [app. meaning I warmed myself by means of the fire]: (Ṣ:) or ASTlI Aln-aAra and biAln-aAri mean he became warm by means of the fire: and tSl-I↓ biAln-aAri, he became burnt by the fire. (MA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xxvii. 7 and xxviii. 29], laEal-akumo taSoTaluwna [May-be ye will warm yourselves]: (TA:) in relation to which it is said that the time was winter, and therefore AlAiSoTilaMC was needed. (M, TA.)
It is also said of the chameleon, as meaning He repaired to the sun. (M and L in art. Xqc: see an ex. in a verse cited voce XaqacaAnN.)

And one says of a courageous man, with whom one cannot cope, laA yuSoTalaI binaArihi [lit. One cannot warm himself by means of his fire; meaning † one cannot approach him when he is inflamed with rage, especially in fight, or battle]. (Ṣ.) The phrase may be also used satirically, as meaning † One will not seek his hospitality. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 588.])
See also 1, latter half, in two places.
SalFI: see SalaMCN.
SalaMCN: see SalaAyapN.
SilaMCN Roasted, broiled, or fried, flesh-meat. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

And, as also SalFI↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) the former with kesr and the latter with fet-ḥ, (Ṣ,) Fuel; (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ;) syn. waquwdN; (M, Ḳ, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, wuquwd;]) i. e. maA tuwqadu bihi Aln-aAru; (TA;) you say SilaMCu Aln-aAri and SalaI Aln-aAri: (Ṣ:) or both signify fire: (M, Mgh, Ḳ:) or SilaMCN signifies the heat of fire. (Mṣb.) One says, huwa OaHosanu mina AlS-ilaMCi fiI AlX-itaMCi [It, or he, is better than fire in winter]. (TA.)
SaliI-N: see maSoliI-N.
SalaMCapN: see what next follows.

SalaAyapN and SalaMCapN↓, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) the latter with C because SalaMCN↓ is used as the pl., [or rather coll. gen. n.,] but not by those who say SalaAyapN, (Sb, M,) [for] the pl. [of this] is SuliI-N and SiliI-N (Ḳ) and SalaAyaAtN, (MA,) i. q. fihorN [i. e. A stone such as fills the hand; or of the size of that with which one bruises and breaks walnuts and the like]: (Ṣ:) or a thing with which perfume is bruised, brayed, or pounded: (M, Ḳ:) or a stone upon which one bruises, or powders, (MA, Mgh,) perfume or some other thing; (Mgh;) that with which [not upon which] one does so being called midowakN. (MA.) Imra-el-Ḳeys [in a verse of his Mo'allakah, (see EM p. 45,) as some relate it,] uses the phrase SalaAyapu HanoZali, because colocynths, when they have become dry, are split therewith. (Ṣ. [But there are two other readings, SaraAyap and SaraAbap.])
Also, (Ḳ,) as being likened thereto, (TA,) † The forehead. (Ḳ.)
And the former word, A rough, rugged, sariyHap [or long strip] of [high ground such as is termed] quf-. (ISh, Az, TA.)
Sil-iyaAnN: see art. Sl.

[SaAlK is expl. by Freytag as meaning Heated or warmed (“calefactus”), and burnt: and the pl. is said by him to be SuliI-N: but he names no authority: if this be correct, it must be a possessive epithet from SaliIa.]
SaAliyapN A support for the cooking-pot, such as is termed Ouvofiy-apN. (MA.)

maSoliI-N Roasted, broiled, or fried; as also SaliI-N↓. (Ḥam pp. 13-14. [Both of these words are there without any syll. signs.]) It is said in a trad., OutiIa biXaApK maSoliy-apK i. e. A roasted sheep, or goat, was brought. (Ṣ, TA.)
And SayoHaAniy-apN maSoliy-apN means [A date of the sort called SayoHaAniI-] dried in the sun. (A, TA.)
OaroDN maSolaApN A land abounding with the plant called Sil-iyaAn. (Ḳ.)

miSolaApN A snare that is set up for birds, &c.: (Ṣ, M:*) pl. maSaAlK. (Ṣ, M.) It is said in a trad., Uin-a lilX-ayoTaAni fuxuwxFA wamaSaAliIa (Ṣ) or maSaAliIa wafuxuwxFA i. e. [Verily to the Devil belong snares and traps] with which he catches men. (M.)

muSoTalFI The limbs of a man, or his arms and legs and face and every prominent part, which become cold at the time of death, and which are warmed at the fire: (AHeyth, L in art. brd:) or the face and extremities. (Z, TA.) One says, barada Almawotu EalaI muSoTalaAhu. (AHeyth, L in art. brd: see 1 in that art.)

hom.sense: 1. S-m-a, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Samima, which is extr., (M, Ḳ,) [first pers. of each Samimotu,] aor. yaSam-u, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. SamamN (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Sam-N; (M, Ḳ;) and OaSam-a↓; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He was, or became, deaf; (M,* Mṣb, Ḳ;*) [or] he had a stoppage of the ear, and a heaviness of hearing. (M, Ḳ.) And Sam-ati AlOucunu, aor. as above, inf. n. SamamN, The ear was, or became, deaf. (Mṣb.)
[And He was, or became, as though he heard not.] One says, Sam-a Eanohu † [He was as though he heard not him, or it; he was deaf to him, or it]; (M;) and OaSam-a↓ Eanohu [meaning the same]. (Ṣ, M.)

[Hence Sam-a signifies also † He or it, uttered, or made, no sound or noise; like him who, not hearing, returns no reply to a call or question; † was dumb, or mute.] One says, Sam-ato HaSaApN bidamK ‡ [A pebble made no sound in falling upon the ground by reason of blood]; i. e. the blood was so copious that if one threw a pebble into it no sound would be heard in consequence thereof, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Meyd, Ḳ, TA,) because it would not fall upon the ground: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Meyd:) the saying is a prov. (Meyd.) And hence the saying of Imra-el-Ḳeys, Sm-iI Qbonapa Aljabali, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the following verse:
bud-ilotu mino waAYilK wakinodapa Eado
waAna wafahomFA Sam-iI Qbonapa Aljabali
† [I have been given in exchange, for Wáïl and Kindeh,' Adwán and Fahm: make no sound, O pebble: app. meaning that he would shed much blood]: (Ṣ, TA: but this verse is omitted in one of my two copies of the Ṣ:) or the meaning is, O echo; (Ṣ, M, Meyd, Ḳ;) so they assert: (AHeyth, TA:) or O calamity; the saying being a prov.; (Meyd, TA;) applied to the case of a severe calamity; as though meaning be dumb, O calamity; said by Aṣ to be applied in relation to an event deemed excessively foul or evil: (TA:) or O serpent; (Meyd, TA;) which is said to be the primary meaning: (Meyd:) or O rock. (AHeyth, Ḳ, TA. [See also the second of the sentences here following.]) One says also, Sam-a SadaAhu ‡ [His echo became dumb, or may his echo become dumb;] meaning he perished, or may he perish. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And Sam-iI SamaAmi↓ [in the CK erroneously written Sum-iI] meaning ‡ Increase, O calamity: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or it is applied to a man who brings to pass a calamity, and means be dumb, O calamity: (TA:) or SamaAmi means calamity, and war; but primarily, the serpent; and this saying, like Sam-iI Qbonapa Aljabali, is a prov. said when two parties refuse to make peace, and persist in opposition; meaning answer not the charmer, O serpent, but continue as thou art wont to be. (Meyd.)

SamamN in relation to stones, (Lth, TA,) or stone, (M,) [app. as an inf. n.,] signifies The being hard [and solid (see OaSam-u)]; or [as a simple subst.] hardness [and solidity]: (Lth, M, TA:) and in relation to a spear-shaft, the being compact; or compactness. (M.) One says, Sam-a AlHajaru, inf. n. SamamN, The stone was hard [and solid]. (MA.) And Sam-ati Alfitonapu, meaning [The trial, or civil war,, &c.,] was, or became, hard, vehement, or severe. (Mṣb.)
