entry.sense: Sin-aworN A niggardly man, of evil disposition: (T, O, Ḳ:) mentioned by IAạr. (T, O.) [See also Sin-aArapN.]
San-aArapN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: Sin-aArapN: see Sin-aArN.
Also The handle of the [kind of shield called] Hajafap: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. SanaAniyru. (Ḳ.)
And The ear: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Ṣ, M.)

Also A man evil in disposition; (M, Ḳ;) on the authority of IAạr; (M;) as also San-aArapN↓; (M, Ḳ;) on the authority of Kr: Aboo-ʼAlee says that the former has this meaning; but it is not of the form of words mentioned in the Book [of Sb], because [it is said that] this form does not occur as an epithet. (M.) And the former, (Ḳ, TA,) accord. to IAạr, (TA,) Bad in respect of O-dab [or discipline of the mind and manners,, &c.], even though eminent, or celebrated, or well known: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.)

entry.sense: SanoTN, thus pronounced by the people of Egypt, (TA,) a dial. var. of sanoTN, q. v. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. SanaEa AlX-aIoCa, aor. _a {yaSonaEu}, inf. n. SunoEN and SanoEN, He made, wrought, manufactured, fabricated, or constructed, the thing; syn. Eamilahu: (Ḳ:) [or he made it,, &c., skilfully, or well; for] AlS-unoEu signifies UijaAdapu AlfiEoli; and every SunoE is a fiEol, but every fiEol is not a SunoE; and it is not predicated of [irrational] animals [unless tropically, (see OaSonaEu,)] nor of inanimate things, like as AlfiEolu is. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
[Hence,] SanaEa signifies also † [He fabricated speech or a saying or sentence or the like:] he forged a word; and poetry, EalaI fulaAnK in the name of such a one. (Mz, 8th nwE.)
And SanaEa, inf. n. SanoEN [and SunoEN] and SaniyEN, [with the objective complement understood,] He worked, or wrought; he practised, or exercised, an art, a craft, or a manufacture. (MA.)

And SanaEa Uilayohi maEoruwfFA, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) inf. n. SunoEN, with damm, He did to him a benefit, favour, or kind act: and SanaEa bihi SaniyEFA qabiyHFA he did to him an evil, or a foul, deed: syn. faEalahu: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and one says also [in the former of these two senses], AiSoTanaEa↓ Einodahu SaniyEapF; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) syn. Ait-axacahaA; (Ḳ;) or OaHosana Uilayohi. (Mgh.) The saying maA SanaEota waOabaAka means maEa Oabiyka [i. e. What didst thou together with thy father?]. (Ṣ.) The saying of the Prophet, UicaA lamo tasotaHoIi faQSonaEo maA XiYota [If thou be not ashamed, do what thou wilt,] is said to be an instance of an imperative phrase of which the meaning is predicative; i. e. it is as though he said, he who is not ashamed does what he will: (O, L, TA:*) and other explanations of it are mentioned in the O and L: (TA:) [but] this is held by AʼObeyd to be the right meaning. (L.) In the phrase SunoEa Qll-ehi, in the Ḳur [xxvii. 90, which may be rendered By the doing of God], SnE is in the accus. case as an inf. n.: but one may read it in the nom. case, meaning celika to be understood before it. (Zj, O, TA.) One says also, maA OaHosana SunoEa Qll-ehi Einodaka and SaniyEa Qll-ehi [How good is the doing of God with thee, or at thine abode!]. (Ḳ.)

And SanaEotu farasiI, inf. n. SanoEN and SanoEapN, ‡ I tended well my horse; or took good care of him; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) supplied him with fodder, and fattened him: and SanaEa jaAriyatahu ‡ he reared, or nourished, his girl, or young woman: (TA:) and SuniEati AljaAriyapu ‡ the girl, or young woman, was treated [or nourished] well, so that she became fat; as also Sun-iEat↓, inf. n. taSoniyEN: (Ḳ, TA:) or you say AiSonaEi Alfarasa, (so accord. to my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) or OaSonaEa↓ Alfarasa, (so accord. to other copies of the Ḳ, and in the O, [in the CK AuSoniEa Alfarasu,]) without teshdeed; [which seems to indicate that the right reading is SanaEa, agreeably with the reading in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ which gives the imperative form; though it is stated in the TA that OaSonaEa Alfarasa is said by IḲṭṭ to be a dial. var. of SanaEahu;] (O, Ḳ;) and San-aEa↓ AljaAriyapa, with teshdeed, meaning he treated [or nourished] well the girl, or young woman, and fattened her; (O, Ḳ; [in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ San-iEi AljaAriyapa;])
because the tSnyE of the girl, or young woman, is by means of many things, and by careful tending: (O, Ḳ:) so says Lth: (O:) but Az says that by other, or others, than Lth, it is allowed to say SanaEa jaAriyatahu, without teshdeed: and hence the phrase in the Ḳur [xx. 40.], walituSonaEa EalaI EayoniI, (TA,) meaning † [And this I did] that thou mightest be reared and nourished in my sight; (O, TA;) for which some read walituSonaEo, as an imperative; and some, walitaSonaEa, meaning and that thou mightest work in my sight, (Ksh, Bḍ,) lest thou shouldst do so contrary to my command. (Bḍ.) You say likewise, of a woman, SanaEato nafosahaA: see 5. And you say also AiSoTanaEotuhu↓, meaning ‡ I reared him; and educated, disciplined, or trained, him well. (Ṣ,* O, Ḳ, TA.)
Accord. to IDrst, SaniEa, inf. n. SanaEN, signifies He was, or became, skilled, or skilful: but IB says that SaniEa has not been heard. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, latter half, in two places.
3. muSaAnaEapN primarily signifies The doing to one a thing in order that he may do another thing to the doer of the former thing. (TA.)

Hence, (TA,) † The treating with gentleness, or blandishment; soothing, coaxing, wheedling, or cajoling; and endeavouring to conciliate. (O, Ḳ, TA.) Or this is from the last of the following significations. (TA.) You say SAnEhu † He treated him with gentleness, or blandishment;, &c. (O, TA.) And † He acted hypocritically with him. (TA.) And SAnEhu Eani AlX-aIoCi † He strove, or endeavoured, to turn him from the thing by deceit, or guile. (TA.)

And hence, (A, TA,) or from the last signification in this paragraph, (TA,) ‡ The act of bribing. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA.) One says, SAnE AlwaAliIa ‡ He bribed [the prefect, ruler, judge, or the like]. (TA.) And SAnEhu biAlmaAli ‡ He bribed him with property, wealth, or money. (Mgh, TA.*) And it is said in a prov., mano SaAnaEa biAlmaAli lamo yaHotaXimo mino Talabi AlHaAjapi ‡ [He who bribes with property is not ashamed of demanding the thing wanted]. (Ṣ, O, TA.)

Also ‡ A horse's not putting forth, or giving, the whole of his strength in going; reserving somewhat thereof: one says, yuSaAniEuka bibacolihi sayorahu ‡ [He keeps back from thee somewhat by the manner in which he exerts his power of going]. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. ASnE He (a man, O) aided, or assisted, another. (O, Ḳ.) And accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, followed in the O and TṢ and Ḳ, one says also, ASnE AlOaxoraqu, meaning The unskilful learned, and did soundly, thoroughly, skilfully, or well: but this is a mistake, occasioned by his deeming dubious, or obscure, a passage in the Nawádir of IAạr, where the latter says that ASnE Alr-ajulu means OaEaAna AlOaxoraqa [i. e. The man aided, or assisted, the unskilful]. (TA.)

ASnE Alfarasa: see 1, latter half. [Freytag states, as on the authority of the Ḳ, that OaSonaEa, said of a horse, signifies “Non omnibus viribus usus cucurrit, sed ita tamen ut eques eo contentus esset” (which is nearly the same as a signification of SaAnaEa likewise mentioned by him): but this is a mistake.]

entry.sense: 5. taSan-uEN signifies The affecting a goodly way, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA; [AlS-amot in the CK is a mistranscription for Als-amot;]) and the making a show thereof; (TA;) and the adorning oneself (Ḳ, TA) thereby, while internally unsound in the grounds of pretension to respect. (TA.) And tSn-Et, said of a woman, means SanaEato↓ nafosahaA [She cultivated and improved her person, so as to render herself comely, by art, and good nurture]: (Ṣ, O:) or she adorned, or embellished, herself. (PṢ.)
8: see 1, former half.
Accord. to Er-Rághib, AiSoTinaAEN signifies The exceeding the usual, or ordinary, bounds, or degree, in putting a thing into a good, sound, right, or proper, state. (TA.)

And hence, he says, the phrase in the Ḳur [xx. 43], waQSoTanaEotuka linafosiI, which means † And I have chosen thee [for myself] to establish my evidence and to serve as my spokesman between me and my creatures so that thy doing thus shall be as though I did it: (TA:) or it means I have reared thee, (Az, TA,) or I have chosen thee, (O, Ḳ, TA,) [for myself,] for a special affair which I require thee to accomplish in a sufficient manner, (Az, O, Ḳ, TA,) concerning Pharaoh and his forces. (Az, TA.) See also 1, last sentence but one.
One says also, ASTnE xaAtamFA He ordered that a signet-ring should be made for him. (O, Ḳ.) [See also 10.]
And ASTnEhu [in which the pronoun seems to refer to rizoq i. e. sustenance, &c.,] also signifies qad-amahu [app. meaning He offered it]. (TA.)

And ASTnE [alone, for ASTnE maSonaEapF,] ‡ He made, or prepared, a repast, feast, or banquet, to which to invite friends. (O, Ḳ, TA.) And ‡ He prepared food to be dispensed in the way, or cause, of God. (O and TA, from a trad.; mentioned also in the CK, but not in other copies of the Ḳ.)

10. AstSnEhu, accord. to the O, signifies He asked for it to be made for him: accord. to the L, AstSnE AlX-aIoCa signifies he invited, or he induced, or caused (daEaA,) [another] to make the thing. (TA.) In the saying of Es-Sarakhsee, AisotaSonaEa Einoda Alr-ajuli qalanosuwapF [app. meaning He asked, or desired, the man to make for him a qlnswp (q. v.)], End is redundant. (Mgh.) [See also 8.]

hom.sense: SanoEN: see SanaEN, in two places.

Also, and SawonaEN↓, A certain small creeping thing, or insect, (duwayob-apN,) or a flying thing (TaAYirN): (Ḳ, TA:) mentioned by Ṣgh: (TA:) also written in the Ḳ (in art. DtE) DatoEN and DawotaEN: in one case or the other mistranscribed. (TA in art. DtE.)
SunoEN an inf. n. of SanaEa [q. v.] (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.)
And i. q. rizoqN [Sustenance,, &c.]. (TA.)
See also SanaEN, in two places.

SinoEN A tailor: (O, Ḳ:) or one who is gentle, delicate, or skilful, (rafiyq, O,) or thin, fine, or delicate, (raqiyq, so in the copies of the Ḳ,) or slender, or small, (daqiyq, so in the TA,) [of which readings that in the O is app. the right,] in respect of the hands. (O, Ḳ.) See also SanaEN, in five places.

Also A maSonaEap↓ of water; (O, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. a piece of wood [app. a plank or board] by means of which water is confined, and retained for a while: (TA:) pl. OaSonaAEN: (O, Ḳ:) [but this explanation in the TA seems to have been founded upon a statement there made, that Az heard the Arabs call OaHobaAs of water OaSonaAE; (see HibosN, of which AHbAs is the pl.;) for I do not find maSonaEapN↓ thus expl. in any lexicon except the TA:] and San-aAEapN↓, with teshdeed, and SanaAEN↓, (O, Ḳ,) like saHaAbN, (Ḳ,) accord. to Lth, (O,) signify pieces of wood [or planks or boards] put together in water, to confine the water, and retain it for a while; (O, Ḳ;) like the HibaAsap [q. v.]. (O.)
See also maSonaEapN, in two senses.
Also A manufactured thing (Ḳ, TA) of any kind, (TA,) such as a suforap [q. v.], (Ḳ, TA,), &c. (TA.)
And ‡ A garment. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ, TA.) You say, raOayotu Ealayohi SinoEFA jay-idFA ‡ [I saw upon him a goodly garment]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA.)
And ‡ A turban. (IAạr, O, Ḳ, TA.)

And The [iron instrument with which flesh-meat is roasted, called] saf-uwd. (O, TṢ, Ḳ.) El-Marrár El-Fak'asee says, describing camels,
wajaMCato warukobaAnuhaA kaAlX-uruwbi
wasaAYiquhaA mivolu SinoEi AlX-iwaMC
[And they came, their riders being like drinkers, or drunkards, and their driver like the saf-uwd of roasted flesh-meat]. (O.) In the L, Alswd is put in the place of Alsf-wd; and after citing the verse above, [and app. reading mivola, regarding it as relating to the camels,] the author says that the poet means, suwda AlOalowaAni. (TA.)

And Roasted flesh-meat [itself]; syn. XiwaMCN. (So in copies of the Ḳ. [SM says that the right reading, as the explanation of AlS-inoEu in this instance, is AlX-awaA; and cites IAạr as saying AlS-inoEu AlX-awaA nafosuhu: but I think that the right reading is indicated by the addition nafosuhu to be AlX-iwaMCu; and that IAạr gives this signification after mentioning that which here next precedes it.])

entry.sense:
rajulN SanaEN, (Mgh, L, Mṣb,) and rajulN SanaEu Alyadayoni, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and SanaEu Alyadi, (Th, TA,) and SinoEu↓ Alyadayoni, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and SinoEu↓ Alyadi, (TA,) and SunoEu↓ Alyadi, (IB, TA,) and Sh is related to have said, rajulN SanoEN↓, (TA,) and SaniyEu↓ Alyadayoni, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and SaniyEu↓ Alyadi, (TA,) and SanaAEu↓ Alyadayoni, (Ḳ,) and SanaAEu↓ Alyadi, but not SanaAEN alone when applied to a male, (TA,) A man skilful in the work of the hands or hand: (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) and a company of men you term qawomN SunoEaI↓ AlOayodiI and SunuEaI AlOayodiI↓,
and SanaEaI↓ AlOayodiI, and SinoEaI↓ AlOayodiI, (Ḳ,) [all of which are instances of quasi-pl. ns., except, perhaps, the last, which is said in the TA to be a pl. of SinoE↓,] and OaSonaAEu AlOayodiI, (Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, AaSonaAEiI,]) which is pl. of SinoEu↓ Alyadi or of SaniyEu↓ Alyadi, or, accord. to Sh, as IB says, the only pl. of SinoEN↓ is SinoEuwna, and in like manner in the case of SunoE↓ you say SunoEuw Alyadi, (TA,) and rijaAlN SunuEN is mentioned as on the authority of Sb, (Ḳ,) and Sh is related to have said qawomN SanoEuwna, [using the latter word as pl. of SanoEN↓,] with the n quiescent. (TA.) And you say AimoraOapN SanaAEN↓, (ISk, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) and SanaAEu↓ Alyadayoni, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and SanaAEu↓ Alyadi, (IJ, TA,) an instance of an epithet applied to a woman like kaEaAbN and radaAHN and HaSaAnN, (TA,) the A of prolongation before the final letter resembling, and rendering needless, the p in SanaEapN, (IJ, TA,) which is not allowable, (IJ,* Mgh, Mṣb, TA,*) though an instance of it occurs used on the ground of analogy: (Mgh:) A woman skilful in the work of the hands or hand; (ISk, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) who makes things in a suitable manner; who sews, and cuts out or makes, leathern buckets; (ISk, TA;) contr. of xaroqaMCu; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and AimoraOapN SaniyEapN↓ signifies the same: (TA:) and AimoraOataAni SanaAEaAni: and nisowapN SunuEN. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) Th preferred SanaEu Alyadi as applied to a man; and SanaAEu↓ Alyadi as applied to a woman. (IB, TA.) Accord. to IDrst, SanaEN is an inf. n. used as an epithet. (TA. [But see 1, last sentence.]) It is said in a prov., laA taEodamu SanaAEN↓ val-apF [expl. in art. vl]. (TA.)

[Hence,] one says of a poet, and of any one who is eloquent, rajulN SanaEu Alil-saAni ‡ [A man skilful in the use of the tongue]: and in like manner, lisaAnN SanaEN ‡ [a skilful tongue]. (Ḳ, TA.) And AimoraOapN SanaAEu↓ All-isaAni † A woman sharp-tongued: or long-tongued: syn. saliyTap. (TA.)
SaniEN: see SaniyEN, last sentence.

SanoEapN Work or handiwork, an art, a craft or handicraft, or a trade; (KL;) as also SinaAEapN↓: (KL, PṢ:) any habitual work or occupation of a man; as also HirofapN; (Ḳ in art. Hrf;) [and so SinaAEapN↓, as is indicated in the Ḳ voce HirofapN; whence] one says, SinaAEatuhu riEaAyapu AlUibili [His habitual work or occupation, or his business, is the tending, or pasturing, of camels]: (M, and Ḳ in art. rEI:) or SanoEapN [more particularly] signifies the work of the SaAniE; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) [a manufacture, or work of art; and workmanship, or the skill of a worker, which last meaning is plainly indicated in the O, and by common usage:] and SinaAEapN↓, the Hirofap [i. e. craft, or habitual work or occupation,] of the SaAniE, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) meaning of him who works with his hand: (Mgh:) the pl. of SinaAEapN↓ is [SanaAYiEu and] SinaAEaAtN. (KL.)
It is also an inf. n. of 1 as used in the phrase SanaEotu farasiI [q. v.]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.)
OasohumN SunoEapN, with damm, Arrows that are equal, equable, uniform, or even, the work of one man. (TA.) [Perhaps SunoEapN is a quasi-pl. n. of SaniyEN applied to an arrow.]
SunoEaI and SinoEaI and SanaEaI and SunoEaI: see SanaEN.

hom.sense: SanaAEN: see SinoEN:
and see also SanaEN, in eight places.

entry.sense: SunuwEN in a sense in which it is used in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb is a pl. of which ISd says, “I know not any sing. thereof:” accord. to Skr, it means The xuraz [app. either the seams or the stitch-holes] of a mazaAdap or of an UidaAwap: or, as some say, the thongs used in the sewing thereof: and some say the making thereof, so that in this case it is an inf. n. (TA.)

hom.sense: SaniyEN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (MA.)
And i. q. maSonuwEN↓ [meaning Made, wrought, manufactured, fabricated, or constructed: or made,, &c., skilfully, or well: see 1, first sentence]. (TA.)

[Hence,] ‡ Food (O, Ḳ, TA) that is made, or prepared, and to which people are invited; (TA;) and maSonaEapN↓ signifies [the same, i. e.] ‡ a repast, feast, or banquet, to which friends are invited: (O, Ḳ, TA:) one says, kunotu fiI SaniyEi fulaAnK ‡ I was at the repast of such a one, made, or prepared, by him, to which people were invited: and AlmaSonaEapi↓ ‡ the repast to which friends were invited. (TA.) And (i. e. the former word) ‡ Food prepared to be dispensed in the way, or cause, of God. (TA.)
Also, applied to a sword, Polished, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and proved by experience; and so applied to an arrow: (Ḳ, TA:) or, applied to a sword, frequently renovated by polishing: (A, TA:) pl. SunuEN. (TA.)

And, applied to a horse, ‡ Well tended; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) supplied with fodder, and fattened. (TA.) And [in like manner it is applied to a human being:] one says, huwa SaniyEiI ‡ He is the person whom I have reared; and whom I have educated, disciplined, or trained, well; (O, Ḳ, TA;) and so SaniyEatiI↓; (Ṣ,* O, Ḳ, TA;) and huwa muSoTanaEapu↓ fulaAnK ‡ he is the person whom such a one has reared;, &c. (Z, TA.)
And ‡ A goodly and clean garment. (A, L, TA.)

And A deed, or an action; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, KL;) and so SaniyEapN↓: (Ḥam p. 198:) one says, SanaEa bihi SaniyEFA qabiyHFA He did to him an evil, or a foul, deed: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and suwoCu SaniyEapK↓ means The evil [consequence] of a deed. (Ḥam ubi suprà.) And [particularly] A good deed, a benefit, favour, or kind act; (O, Ḳ, TA;) and so SaniyEapN↓: (Ṣ,* O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [see a verse cited voce maSonaEN:] pl. [of either, of the latter agreeably with rule,] SanaAYiEu. (O, Ḳ.)

Also Skilful in work of the hands or hand: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) fem. [in this sense] with p {SaniyEapN}. (TA.) See SanaEN, in four places. Accord. to IDrst, SaniEN↓ [likewise] signifies Skilled, or skilful, as part. n. of SaniEa; but IB says that SaniEa has not been heard. (TA.)

entry.sense: SinaAEapN: see SanoEapN, in four places. The saying of ʼAlee, yuWoxacu mino kul-i SinaAEapK SinaAEatuhu, if correctly related, means yuWoxacu mino kul-i ciI SinaAEapK maSonuwEuhu [From every one possessing skill in manufacture should be taken, or procured, that which he has manufactured: or perhaps mino is a mistake for Eano, and the meaning is, from every craftsman is to be acquired his craft]. (Mgh.)
SaniyEapN: see SaniyEN, latter half, in four places.

SanaAEiyapN Persons who tend their camels well, and fatten the young ones thereof, and give not their camels' milk to guests: occurring in a verse of 'Ámir Ibn-Et-Tufeyl. (TA, in this art. and in art. SlmE.)
SanaAYiEiI-N: see SaAniEN.
San-aAEN [An expert SaAniE i. e. manufacturer, &c.] (TA. [There mentioned only as a proper name, or surname.])
San-aAEapN: see SinoEN, former half.

SaAniEN A handicraftsman; manufacturer; or worker, or maker, with his hand; (Ṣ,* Mgh, O,* Mṣb,* Ḳ;) or one having a SanoEap [i. e. craft, &c.] which he exercises; (TA;) [an artificer, or artisan;] and SanaAYiEiI-N↓ is [used in the same sense, and particularly as meaning one who works for hire under a master; being] a rel. n. from SanaAYiEu [pl. of SinaAEapN], like OanomaATiI-N and OanoSaAriI-N: (TA:) the pl. of SaAniEN is Sun-aAEN. (Mṣb, TA.)
SawonaEN: see SanoEN.
OaSonaEu [More, or most, skilled in working with the hands, manufacturing, fabricating, or constructing]. See an ex. voce surofapN, and another voce tanaw-uTN.

maSonaEN [may be used, agreeably with analogy, as an inf. n.: and as a n. of place, and of time]. A poet says,
Uin-a AlS-aniyEapa lA takuwnu SaniyEapF
Hat-aI yuSaAba bihaA Tariyqu AlmaSonaEi [which may be rendered Verily that which is a good deed considered abstractedly, or without relation to the manner or object, &c., will not be a good deed in effect except, or unless, the way of the doing, or the way that leads to the place (here meaning the object) of the doing, be rightly hit upon therewith]. (O, TA.)

In the following verse of Náfi' Ibn-Lakeet, (TA in this art. and in art. ryX,) wrongly ascribed by J [in arts. ryX and mrT] to Lebeed, (TA in art. ryX,) and ascribed by others to other poets, (TA in art. mrT,) it is expl. by IAạr as signifying A place that is deemed goodly [in workmanship]; syn. musotamolaHN [a n. of place, accord. to a general rule, as well as pass. part. n.: or maSonaEN may be here more literally rendered a place of skilful workmanship]: the poet says,
muruTu AlqicaAci falayosa fiyhi maSonaEN
laA Alr-iyXu yanofaEuhu walaA Alt-aEoqiybu (TA in the present art.) meaning Having no feathers upon it, [and having in it no place exhibiting skilful workmanship, neither the feathers being of use to it] nor the binding around with sinews. (TA in art. ryX.)
See also what here follows.

hom.sense: maSonaEapN (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maSonuEapN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and maSonaEN↓ (O, Mṣb, Ḳ) [A kind of tank, or reservoir, for rain-water; i. e.] a thing like a HawoD, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ, TA,) or like a Sihoriyj (Mṣb, TA) and a birokap, (Mṣb,) that is made, or constructed, (Mgh, Mṣb,) for collecting the water of the rain: (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) pl. maSaAniEu, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) a pl. of all the three words above, expl. by Aṣ as meaning excavations which people make for the rain-water, which they fill therewith, and from which they drink; and maSaAniyEu is another pl. of maSonaEapN, the I being inserted by poetic license; or it may be pl. of maSonuwEN↓ or maSonuwEapN: and SinoEN↓ [in like manner] signifies a HawoD or a thing like a Sihoriyj: and SunuwEN is said to be a pl. thereof: (TA:) or SinoEN signifies a watering-trough, or tank, made for the rain-water, and not cased with baked bricks; and its pl. is OaSonaAEN. (TA voce birokapN.) See also SinoEN, in two places.

[The pl.] maSaAniEu signifies also Constructions such as quSuwr [or pavilions,, &c.], (O, Ḳ,) and fortresses; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and SinoEN↓ also signifies a fortress: and the former, wells also. (TA.) And Towns, or villages, are thus called, (O, Ḳ,) by the Arabs, accord. to Aṣ: sing. maSonaEapN: (O, TA:) one says, huwa mino Oaholi AlmaSaAniEi, meaning He is of the people of the towns, or villages, and of the cultivated land. (A, TA.) Also Places set apart for horses, away from the tents or houses: sing. maSonaEapN. (AḤn, TA.) [In Abul. Ann. ii. 42, where it seems to mean “reservoir for rain-water,” Reiske renders it “Hospitia publica.”]
See also SaniyEN, in two places.

entry.sense: maSonuwEN: see SaniyEN, and maSonaEapN.

Also † [Fabricated, as applied to speech or a saying or sentence: a phrase, or word,] innovated, [or coined,] and given by its author as chaste (faSiyH) Arabic; differing from muwal-adN, which is applied to what is not so given: (Mz, 21st nwE:) forged, as applied to a word, and poetry. (Id. 8th nwE.)
huwa muSoTanaEapu fulaAnK: see SaniyEN.

hom.sense: 2. Sn-fhu, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. taSoniyfN, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) He assorted it; i. e. made it into, or disposed it in, sorts, or species; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and separated, or distinguished, its several parts or portions or constituents, one from another: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) Alt-aSoniyfu is the separating, or distinguishing, of things, one from another. (Mṣb.)
And hence, (Z, Mṣb,* TA,) taSoniyfu Alkutubi (Z, TA) or AlkitaAbi: (Mṣb:) you say, Sn-f AlkitaAba, inf. n. as above, He composed the book. (MA.)

Sn-ft AlEiDaAhu The [trees called] EDAh became green: (M:) and Sn-f AlX-ajaru the trees put forth their leaves: (O, Ḳ: [and the like is said in the Mṣb:]) AḤn says that this signifies the trees began to leaf, so that they were of two sorts, one sort that had leaved and one sort that had not leaved; but this is not a valid saying; and in like manner tSn-f↓: (M:) accord. to the A, both signify the trees became of different sorts; and in like manner Aln-abaAtu [the plants, or herbage]: (TA:) and Sn-f Alv-amaru, inf. n. as above, signifies the fruits became so that some of them were ripe exclusively of others, and some of them coloured exclusively of others: (Mṣb:) and tSn-f↓ AlOaroTaI, and Aln-abotu, the [trees called] ArTI, and the plants, or herbage, broke forth to leaf. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.) 'ObeydAlláh Ibn-Keys-er-Rukeiyát says,
saqoyFA liHulowaAna ciI Alkuruwmi wamaA
San-afa mino tiynihi wamino Einabiho
[May there be a sending down of rain to Hulwán, the possessor of vines, and of such as have put forth their leaves, of the fig-trees and the grape-vines thereof]: (O, Ḳ:) it is said in the Ḳ that the verb in this verse is thus, from Sn-f AlX-ajaru, not from Sn-fhu; and that J has erred in the reading that he has given; for the reading given by J, who ascribes this verse to Ibn-Aḥmar, is Sun-ifa; but this is the reading of Fr, [as is said in the O,] and both readings are correct; and of the latter, [accord. to which the meaning is, and of such as have been made to consist of various sorts or species, of the fig-trees and the grape-vines thereof,] MF says, it is that which the case requires, the commendation being for the abundance and variety of the fruits of the trees, rather than for the trees putting forth their leaves. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see above {2}, in two places.
One says also, tSn-ft Xafatuhu His lip became chapped. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.) And tSn-f saAqu Aln-aEaAmapi The shank of the ostrich became chapped. (TA.)
SanofN: see what next follows.

SinofN and SanofN↓ A sort, or species, (Lth, Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a thing, (M, TA,) or of things, (Lth, TA,) as, for instance, of householdgoods, or furniture and utensils: (TA:) [a term subordinate to jinosN:] and a part, or portion, or constituent, of anything: (Lth, Mṣb, TA:) pl. (of the former, Mṣb) OaSonaAfN and (of the latter, Mṣb) SunuwfN. (M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Also the former, i. q. SifapN [meaning A quality, an attribute, a property; or a description, as meaning the aggregate of the qualities or attributes or properties, of a thing, or the state, condition, or case, of a thing]. (M, Ḳ.)
See also SanifapN.
SanifN: see the next paragraph.
SinofapN: see the next paragraph.

SanifapN (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) and SinofapN↓ and SinofN↓, (Sh, O, Ḳ,) the first of which is the most chaste, (O, TA,) of a waist-wrapper (UizaAr), (Ṣ, M,) or of a garment, (O, Ḳ,) The Tur-ap thereof, i. e. (Ṣ, O) the side thereof that has no fringe of unwoven threads: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or (M, Ḳ) its Tur-ap [or border] (M) upon which is the fringe consisting of unwoven threads: (M, Ḳ:) or any border, or side, thereof: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) accord. to IDrd, it is, with the lexicologists, the side (HaAXiyap) of a garment; and with others, the part in which is the fringe of unwoven threads: (O:) and the corner of a garment: the pl. of SanifapN is SanifaAtN and [coll. gen. n.] SanifN↓. (M.)

SanifaAtN, as used by a poet describing the saraAb [or mirage], means, accord. to Th, ‡ The sides, or borders, of the srAb; the srAb being likened by him to a [garment such as is called] mulaMCap. (M.)
And SanifapN signifies also † A portion of a qabiylap [or tribe]. (Sh, TA.)

EuwdN SanofiI-N A species, or sort, of Euwdu AlT-iybi [i. e. aloes-wood] not of good quality: (M:) or one of the worst kinds of Euwd, (O, Ḳ,) little differing from xaXab [i. e. wood used in carpentry and the like]: (O:) or inferior to the qamaAriI- and superior to the qaAqul-iI-: (Ḳ:) used for fumigating therewith: (TA:) so called in relation to a place [the situation of which I am unable to determine with certainty: see, respecting it, note 12 to ch. xx. of my Translation of the Thousand and One Nights]. (Ṣ, O.)
OaSonafu, (O, Ḳ,) or OaSonafu Als-aAqayoni, (M,) A male ostrich having his shanks excoriated: (M, O, Ḳ:) pl. SunofN. (Ḳ.)
taSoniyfN inf. n. of 2 [q. v.].
[As a subst., A literary composition; as also muSan-afN↓: pl. of the former taSaAniyfu; and of the latter muSan-afaAtN.]
OaSonaAfN muSan-afapN [Sorts, or species, separated, or distinguished, one from another; distributed, or classified;] is a phrase similar to OabowaAbN mubaw-abapN. (Ṣ in art. bwb.)
See also taSoniyfN.
muSan-ifN [A literary composer; an author of a book or books].

XajarN muSan-ifN, (Z, O, Ḳ, TA,) [in the CK muSan-af, which is wrong, for it is] like muHad-ivN, (TA,) Trees among which are two sorts, dry and fresh: (O, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Z, trees varying in colours and fruits. (TA.)
2. Sn-m, inf. n. taSoniymN, i. q. Saw-ara [He formed, fashioned, figured, shaped, sculptured, or pictured: app. from the noun here following]. (Ḳ.)

SanamN [An idol: or an idol of a particular kind:] a wavan: (Ṣ:) or a wavan that is worshipped: (Ḳ:) or a wavan that is made of stones, and of wood; as is said on the authority of I’Ab: (Mṣb:) or a thing well known, that is carved of wood, and that is made of molten and cast silver and copper or brass: (M; and the like is said in the Mṣb on the authority of IF:) or the Snm is made of metals that melt; and the wvn is made of stone or of wood: (Mṣb:)
or, accord. to Hishám El-Kelbee, the former is made of wood or of gold or of silver or of other metal; and the latter, of stones: or, accord. to Ibn-ʼArafeh and El-Fihree, the former is an image; and the latter is a shapeless thing: or, as some say, the former is a thing having corporeal from, carved of wood or of stone or of silver, and worshipped; and [the latter (in the TA the Snm, but this I suppose to be a mistake for the wvn,)] is a incorporeal form: or the former is a thing having the form of a human being; and the latter, a thing having some other form: or the former is a thing having material substance or shape; and the latter, a thing not having material substance or shape: or the former is of stones or other material; and the latter, an embodied form: (TA:) or, accord. to IAth, the latter [?] is anything having corporeal form, made of metal or of wood and stones, like the form of a human being, made, and set up, and worshipped; and the former [?] an incorporeal form: (TA in art. wvn: [from explanations given above, it seems that the reverse of this is the case:]) and Abu-l-ʼAbbás states, on the authority of IAạr, that SanamapN↓ and naSamapN signify an image (SuwrapN) that is worshipped; (TA in the present art.;) each of these two words is thus (biAlt-aHoriyk), though it would seem that accord. to the Ḳ the latter is naSomapN: (TA in art. nSm:) SanamN (Ṣ, Ḳ) it is said (Ṣ) is an arabicized word, from Xaman (Ṣ, Ḳ) [which is Pers., though SM says,] I know not in what language, for in Pers. it is bt [i. e. buto]: (TA:) the pl. is OaSonaAmN; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) which, as used in the Ḳur xiv. 38, is said by Er-Rághib to mean things that divert one from God. (TA.)

hom.sense: SanamapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Also A calamity; a dial. var. of SalamapN; (Ḳ, TA;) which is mentioned by Az, but omitted in the Ḳ in art. Slm. (TA.)
And The qaSabap [or quill] of any feather. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. ASnI Aln-axolu The palm-trees had pairs, or triplets, or more, growing together from single roots. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)
SanowN: see the next paragraph.
SunowN: see the next paragraph.

SinowN One of a pair, (AḤn, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or of three, (Ṣ, M,) or of more than two, (Ḳ,) or of more than three, (M,) or of five, or of six, (TA,) of palmtrees, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or of any trees, (AḤn, M, Ḳ,) or of trees resembling one another, (M,) growing from one root; (AḤn, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) each [or every one] of such being called the Sinow of the other [or others growing with it]; (AḤn, M;) as also SunowN↓, (M, Ḳ,) mentioned by Zj: (M:) two of such are termed SinowaAni (Ṣ, Ḳ) and SunowaAni and SanowaAni, [which last implies that SanowN↓ as well as SunowN is a dial. var. of SinowN,] and also SinoyaAni and SunoyaAni and SanoyaAni, [which imply that SinoIN and SunoIN and SanoIN are also dial. vars. of SinowN and SunowN and SanowN;] (Ḳ;) and the pl. is SinowaAnN (AZ, Ṣ, M) and [of pauc.] OaSonaMCN, (M,) the former pl. differing from the first of the duals mentioned above by being perfectly decl. (AZ, Ṣ,* TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xiii. 4], SinowaAnN wagayoru SinowaAnK, (TA,) i. e. Palmtrees having one root and [others] having distinct roots: Hafs read SunowaAn, like qunowaAn pl. of qinowN; of the dial. of Temeem. (Bḍ.)

And hence, (TA,) † A brother; but not so called unless coupled with another: (Sh, TA:) or a brother by the same father: (Az, TA:) [or a brother by the same mother; as is indicated by an explanation of one of the pls in what follows:] or a brother such as is termed Xqiyq, (M, Ḳ,) which means by the father and mother: (TA in art. Xq:) and a son; (M, Ḳ;) because he has branched forth from one stock [with his father]: (TA:) and a paternal uncle; (M, Ḳ;) but this last meaning is taken from a trad. cited in what follows: (TA:) the fem. is with p {SinowapN}: and the pl. is OaSonaMCN [a pl. of pauc.] and SinowaAnN [as above]. (M, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., Eam-u Alr-ajuli Sinowu Oabiyhi ‡ [The paternal uncle of the man is the Sinow of his father]; (T, Ṣ;) meaning that the stock of both is one. (T, TA.) [And it is said that] SanowaAnN wgayoru SinowaAnK, relating to a man's children, means † Sons of one mother by different fathers, and children of different mothers by one father. (Ḥar p. 608.)
[Hence the pl.] OaSonaMCN signifies also † Likes, or fellows. (IAạr, TA.)
And rakiy-ataAni SinowaAni ‡ Two wells near together, (AZ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) or (so in the TA and in some copies of the Ḳ) that yield water from one spring. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
SinowN also signifies A widened well (HafarN) from which water is not drawn and of the water of which no use is made: (Ibn-Buzurj, Ḳ:) pl. SinowaAnN. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.)
See also what follows.

SunaI-N A small HisoI [q. v.] to which no one comes for water, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and for which no one cares: dim. of SinowN↓: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, (Ṣ,) a cleft in a mountain: (Ṣ, TA:) or a ravine, or gap, (XiEobN,) in which water flows, between two mountains. (TA.)
SinoIN and SunoIN and SanoIN: see SinowN, in art. Snw.
SunaI-N: dim. of SinowN: see art. Snw.
Oaxacahu biSinaAyatihi He took it (a thing, Ṣ) wholly: (Fr, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and so bisinaAyatihi. (M.)
1. Sah-a Alqawoma He chid the people or party [app. saying to them Saho: see what next follows]. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. SahoSaha bihimo He silenced them, saying to them Saho Saho: (Ḳ, TA:) and they said also SahoSayotu [for SahoSahotu], like as they said dahodayotu for dahodahotu. (TA.)

Saho, as also SahK, (Ṣ, IAth, Ḳ,) and Sahi, and SahFA, (TA,) a word used in chiding the person [or persons] to whom it is said, (Ḳ, TA,) thus in the M, or rather (TA) it is a verbal noun, (Ṣ, IAth, TA,) used in commanding silence, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning Be silent, (Ṣ, IAth, Ḳ, TA,) addressed to a single person, and to two persons, and to a pl. number, and to a male, and to a female: (IAth, TA:) and one says also SahK Saho: Mbr says, if you say, SahK yaA rajulu [Be silent, O man], it is to distinguish between that which is determinate and that which is indeterminate; SahK being indeterminate: (Ṣ, TA:) [i. e.,] as IJ says, the saying SahK, with tenween, is as though you said sukuwtFA; and when you pronounce it without tenween, it is as though you said Als-ukuwta: or, as IAth says, when with tenween, it is as though you said, Ausokuto sukuwtFA; and when without tenween, as though you said, Ausokuti Als-ukuwta AlmaEoruwfa minoka. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Sahiba, (Mgh, L, Mṣb, TA,) aor. _a {yaSohabu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. SahabN (Mgh,* L, Mṣb, TA) [and app. SuhuwbapN also, and perhaps SuhobapN, q. v.], said of hair, [and of a camel's fur or hair,] It was, or became, such as is termed OaSohab, i. e., of the colour termed Suhobap; (Mgh, L, Mṣb, TA;) as also AShb-↓ and AShAb-↓. (L, TA.)
See also SaAhibo.

4. AShb He (a stallion [meaning a stallion camel]) had young ones such as are termed Suhob [pl. of OaSohabu] born to him: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to the M and L, he (a man) had children such as are so termed born to him. (TA.)
See also SaAhibo.

entry.sense: 9: see the first paragraph {1}.
11: see the first paragraph {1}.
SahabN: see what next follows.

SuhobapN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SuhuwbapN↓ (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SahabN↓, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) [the last said in the L and Mṣb and TA to be an inf. n., (see 1,) and so may be each of the others, used as simple substs.,] Redness, (T, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or [a redness such as is termed] Xuqorap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the hair (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of the head (T, Ṣ, Mgh) and of the beard, when the exterior is red, with blackness in the interior: (T, Mgh:) or a tinge of redness over the hair, the roots being black, so that the hair when anointed appears as though it were black: (Aṣ, TA:) or redness in blackness: (A:) or redness, of the hair, tinged over with blackness: or, as some say, redness of the whole of the hair. (TA.)
SuhuwbapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SuhaAbiI-N, applied to a camel, i. q. OaSohabu [q. v.]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and its fem. with p {SuhaAbiy-apN}, is syn. with SahobaMCu [fem. of OaSohabu]: or a camel of which the origin is referred to a certain stallion, or a place, named SuhaAbN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, if not used as a prefixed noun, it means sprung from a stallion named SuhaAbN: Tarafeh uses the fem. as a prefixed noun in the phrase SuhaAbiy-apu AlEuvonuwni [A she-camel of the colour termed Suhobap in the long hairs beneath the lower jaw]: (T, TA:) but Himyán [without using it as a prefixed noun] says,
yuTiyru EanohaA Alwabara AlS-uhaAbijaA
[Making to fly from her, or it makes to fly from her, the fur of the colour termed Suhobap]; meaning AlS-uhaAbiI-a;
contracting it, and changing the I into j: and El-ʼAjjáj applies SuhaAbiI- in a similar manner, as an epithet, to a camel's lip. (TA.)
Also Full, or complete, without lack or defect. (Ḳ.)
And applied to camels (naEamN) as meaning From which the poor-rate has not been taken; (Ḳ, TA;) they being left complete, without lack or deficiency. (TA.)
And, applied to a man, (Ḳ, TA,) Low, ignoble, or mean; (TA;) for whom, or to whom, there is no diywaAn [or register of the names of pensioners or the like]. (Ḳ, TA.)
And Hard, strong, vehement, or violent. (A, Ḳ.) Hence, mawotN SuhaAbiI-N ‡ A hard, or violent, death; like mawotN OaHomaru. (A, TA.)

AiSohabo↓ SaAhibo, (O,) or OaSohibo↓ SaAhibo, (so in a copy of the Ḳ, in the CK AaSohabo SaAhibo,) a call to ewes to be milked: (O, Ḳ:) it [i. e. SAhb] is a name for Ewes: (O:) in one copy of the Ḳ, a call to the stallion [meaning the stallion camel] on the occasion of covering. (TA.)

SayohabN A hard place: (Sh, Ḳ:) pl. SayaAhibu. (Sh, TA.) Level ground: (Ḳ:) so some say: (Sh, TA:) pl. as above: (TA:) or DayohabN has this meaning. (O.) Any place, (Ḳ,) or any high, or rugged, or high and rugged, ground, or place of a mountain, (O,) upon which the sun is vehemently hot so that flesh-meat is broiled upon it: (O, Ḳ:) Lth assigns this meaning to DayohabN; but AM says that the right word is SayohabN. (TA in art. Dhb.) And A hard rock: and stones: (Ḳ:) [or] by stones are here meant hard rocks: (O:) [but] this is a meaning of the pl. SayaAhibu. (JK.)
A hard, or strong, camel; fem. with p {SayohabapN}: likened to the stones so called. (T, O, TA.)
And A tall man. (Ḳ.)
And A hot day: (Ḳ:) or a day intensely hot: (O, TA:) and so SayohadN. (TA.)
And Intenseness of heat: (Ḳ:) so on the authority of IAạr alone; others explaining it as an epithet. (TA.)

OaSohabu, applied to hair, (A, TA,) [and to camel's fur or hair,] and to a man, (Ṣ,) and to a camel, (A,) or to a male [of mankind and of camels], (Mgh, Mṣb,) fem. SahobaMCu: (A, Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. SuhobN: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) Of the colour termed Suhobap [expl. above]: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb:) as some say, (TA,) applied to hair, it means having redness intermixed with its whiteness: (Ḳ, TA:) accord. to Aṣ, it is nearly the same as OaSobaHu: (TA:) applied to a camel, having redness intermixed with his whiteness, the upper part of the fur being red, and the inner parts white: (Ṣ:) or not having the inner parts [of the fur] intensely white, the flanks and sides having somewhat of whiteness; the AShb being less white than what is termed Mdamu, having a dusky hue in the upper parts and a whiteness in the lower parts: (T, TA:) or not intensely white: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to IAạr, white: and he says that the Suhob and Oudom were called by the Arabs “the Kureysh of camels,” i. e. the most noble, and the best, as Kureysh were considered by them the best of them; also, that Suhobap was said to be the most famous and the best of colours, and that a she-camel of that colour was said to be the most swift of all: [see also OaHomaru as applied to a camel:] but accord. to Aṣ, Mdamu applied to a camel signifies white; and OaSohabu, white intermixed with redness: (TA:) [see also SuhaAbiI-N:] the dim. is OuSayohibu↓. (Mṣb.)

Suhobu Als-ibaAli [lit. Persons red, or reddish,, &c., in respect of the mustaches,, &c.,] is a designation of ‡ enemies; and is applied to them even if not really Suhobu Als-ibaAli: (Aṣ, Ṣ, A,* L, Ḳ:) originally applied to the Greeks (Alr-uwm), because redness of the hair was [common] among them, and they were enemies of the Arabs: (Ṣ, L, TA:) applied to others, it designates them as being as great enemies as the Greeks. (TA.)
AlOaSohabu is an appellation of The lion: (Ḳ:) because of his colour. (TA.)
And [for the same reason] OaSohabu is a designation of The male ostrich. (L, TA.)

Hence also (Ṣ, TA) AlS-ahobaMCu signifies Wine: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or wine expressed from white grapes: (Ḳ:) used in this sense as a proper name: (AḤn, Ḳ:) but also used without the article Al; being originally an epithet. (TA.)
yawomN OaSohabu ‡ A cold day: (Ḳ:) or a day intensely cold. (A, TA.)
OuSayohibu dim. of OaSohabu, q. v. (Mṣb.)
muSah-abN ‡ Flesh-meat mixed with fat. (A, TA.)

† What is termed Safiyf [here app. meaning cut into strips or slices, and laid upon live coals, or upon rocky ground vehemently heated by the sun (see SayohabN)], (O, Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ, in some copies of the Ḳ galiyZ, and in one copy DaEiyf,) of roast flesh-meat. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And Wild animals (waHoX) [of various kinds or species] mixed together. (O, Ḳ, and in one of my copies of the Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. Sahara, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaSoharu}, inf. n. SahorN, (Ḳ,) He melted, or liquefied, a thing, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) such as fat, (A, TA,) and the like; (TA;) as also ASThr↓. (Ḳ.) The saying laOaSoharan-aka biyamiynK mur-apK app. means † I will assuredly melt thee [in the fire of Hell by making thee to swear a bitter oath]: (Ṣ:) or ‡ I will assuredly make thee to swear a hard oath. (A.) One says also, Saharotu fulaAnFA biyamiynK kaAcibapK tuwojibu lahu Aln-aAra † [I caused such a one to melt, by making him to swear a false oath that would procure for him, as a consequence thereof, the fire of Hell]. (AO.)
Also, inf. n. as above, He, or it, burned: he thoroughly cooked with fire. (TA.)

‡ It (heat) affected him severely. (A.) And Saharatohu AlX-amosu ‡ The sun affected him severely by its heat, (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ,* TA,) so that it pained his brain. (TA.) Ibn-Aḥmar says, describing the young one of a qaTaAp, (Ṣ, O,) which was bearing water to it, (O,)
tarowiI laqFI OuloqiIa fiI SafoSafK
taSoharuhu AlX-amosu famaA yanoSahiro↓
i. e. [She bearing water to a castaway, cast upon a plain,] which the sun was melting, [or severely affecting,] and [which did not melt, meaning] which endured the sun's melting it. (Ṣ,* O. [In both of my copies of the Ṣ, and in the O and TA, the first word is tarowiI, as above; not turowiI.]) And you say, Sahara AlHar-u AlHirobaMCa ‡ The heat made the chameleon's back to glisten. (TA.)

And Sahara xubozahu He seasoned his bread with SuhaArap, (AZ, A, TA,) i. e. melted fat. (A, TA.) And Sahara raOosahu He anointed his head with SuhaArap. (A, Ḳ.) And Sahara badanahu He anointed his body with Sahiyr [which is like SuhaArap]. (L, TA.)
Saharahu also signifies † He brought, or drew, it (i. e. a thing, O) near, Uilayohi [to him or it]; and so AShrhu↓. (O, TA.)

entry.sense: 3. SaAharahumo, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muSaAharapN; (TA;) and SAhr fiyhimo; and AShr↓ bihimo, and Uilayohimo; He became that kind of relation to them termed Sihor; (Ḳ;) and so OaSoharahumo: (Mgh in art. xtn:) or SAhr Uilayohimo he took to himself a wife from among them; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb;) and so AShr↓ Uilayohimo: (A:) and AShr↓ bihimo he connected himself with them, and became, or made himself, an object of inviolable respect, by a covenant of mutual protection, or by relationship, or consanguinity, or by marriage: (IAạr, Ṣ:) or AShr bhm he sought to bring himself near to them by the relationship termed Sihor. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: 4: see 3, in three places.
One says also, Shr AAljayoXu lilojayoXi ‡ The army drew near to the [other] army. (A, O, Ḳ.)
See also 1, last sentence.

entry.sense: 7. AnShr It (a thing, Ṣ, Ḳ, such as fat, and the like, TA) became melted, or liquefied. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 1.

hom.sense: 8. ASThr: see 1.
Also ‡ His (a chameleon's) back glistened by reason of the heat of the sun; (A,* Ḳ;) and so AShAr-↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And He ate SuhaArap. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 11: see the next preceding paragraph {8}.
SahorN Roasted, broiled, or fried; syn. maXowiI-N. (TA.)
And Hot; syn. HaAr-N. (Kr, Ḳ.)

SihorN Relationship; nearness with respect to kindred; syn. qaraAbapN: (A, Ḳ:) and [affinity; or] the sacred, or inviolable, tie (Huromap) of relationship consisting in being a father or brother or other kinsman of a man's wife: (Mgh, Ḳ:) and SuhuwrapN↓ the sacred, or inviolable, tie (Huromap) of relationship by marriage: (A:) Fr makes the former word of the fem. gender. (Ṣgh, TA.)

And A relation, or kinsman, or kinswoman, of a man's wife: (Kh, Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) and of a woman's husband: (A:) or the father or brother or other kinsman of a woman's husband; syn. HamoCN [and HamN, &c. (see art. Hmw)]: (Kh, Aṣ, ISk, Mṣb:) and the father or brother or other kinsman of a man's wife: (Kh, Aṣ, ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so accord. to some of the Arabs: (Kh, Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb:) or none says otherwise, accord. to Aṣ, and IAạr says the like: (Mgh:) or any relation of a man's wife or of a woman's husband whom it is unlawful to marry; as the father, and brother, and son, and paternal uncle, and maternal uncle: (Az, Mṣb:)
or a man's relation by marriage: and a kinsman of a man's relation by marriage: (A:) or a man who has married among a people: (Lth, Mgh:) and the husband of a man's daughter: and the husband of a man's sister: (IAạr, Ḳ:) Fr says that, in the Ḳur xxv. 56, it signifies, a relation whom it is lawful to marry; as the daughter of a paternal uncle, and of a maternal uncle, and the like: and nasab in the same, a relation whom it is unlawful to marry: Zj, that the former signifies a relation whom it is unlawful to marry: and the latter, such as is not a Sihor, of those mentioned in the Ḳur [iv. 27], from the words “your mothers are forbidden unto you” to the words “and your combining [as your wives] two sisters:” I’Ab explains nsb and Shr in the former passage of the Ḳur differently from Fr [altogether], and differently in part from Zj; saying that the former applies to the seven relations first mentioned in iv. 27 in the Ḳur, and Shr to the remaining six there mentioned and that mentioned in the next preceding verse; [so that it includes a man's foster-mother, who has suckled him; his fostersister, who has been suckled with him; his wife's mother; his step-daughter under his guardianship, born of his wife unto whom he has gone in; his son's wife; his wife's sister combined with that wife; and his father's wife;] and this, says Az, is correct: (Mgh:) in the Ḳur xxv. 56, it means cuw SihorK, whether male or female: (Jel:) or cawaAtu SihorK: (Bḍ:) pl. OaSohaArN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and SuhoraMCu; (Ḳ;) which latter is extr. (TA.) [SihorapN, applied to a female, pl. DiharaAtN, is app. post-classical.]

And ‡ A grave, or sepulchre: (ISd, Ḳ:) for they used to bury their daughters alive, and say, “We have married them to the grave:” then, in the time of El-Islám, this expression was used, and it was said, niEoma AlS-ihoru Alqaboru [An excel-lent son-in-law is the grave]: or it means, correctly, that which supplies the place of the Shr. (ISd.)

SihoriI-N i. q. SihoriyjN [q. v.]; (Ḳ;) a dial. var. of the latter word; signifying A thing like a HawoD [or watering-trough, or tank]: (Ṣ:) accord. to Az, a construction of clay and stones, built between [and across] two narrow branches (maOozimaAni) of a small water-course (XuEobap) of a valley, so that the water is kept back thereby, and they drink from it a long time. (TA.)
SahuwrN A melter of fat: and a roaster, broiler, or frier: pl. SuhorN. (Ḳ.)
SahiyrN [i. q. maSohuwrN↓ as meaning] Melted, or liquefied. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [And used also as a subst., in the sense of SuhaArapN.]
Also Bread seasoned with SuhaArap; and so maSohuwrN↓. (A, O, TA.)

SuhaArapN What is melted (Aṣ, Ḳ, TA) of fat, (Aṣ, TA,) and the like: (TA:) or (TA, in the Ḳ “and”) any piece of fat, (Ḳ, TA,) whether small or large: (TA:) and ‡ marrow; syn. niqoIN and mux-N; (Ḳ, TA;) which mean the same. (TA.) One says, maA biAlbaEiyri SuhaArapN ‡ There is not in the camel any fatness (TiroqN); (ISk, Ṣ;) or any marrow. (TA.)
SuhuwrapN: see SihorN, first sentence.
SaAhuwrN The sheath of the moon. (Ḳ. [See what is meant thereby voce saAhuwrN; of which it is a dial. var. in this sense, and app. in other senses also.])

SayohuwrN A thing (A, O, Ḳ, TA) like a mnobar [or pulpit], of clay, (Ḳ, TA,) or of wood, (TA,) for the household utensils of brass (A, O, Ḳ, TA) and the like, (O, Ḳ,) which are put thereon: (A, O:) but ISd says that it is not of established authority. (TA.)
maSohuwrN: see SahiyrN, in two places.
Q. 1. SahorajuwA SihoriyjFA They plastered a Sihoriyj with SaAruwj [or plaster of quick lime]. (L.)
Q. 2. taSahorajuwA Sihoriy-FA [They made for themselves a SihoriI-, i. e. a Sihoriyj]. (T and TA in art. Shr.)

SihoriyjN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SahoriyjN, but this latter is of weak authority, (Mṣb,) and SuhaArijN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also SihoriI-N, by a change of the last letter, (ISd, TA,) A HawoD [i. e. watering-trough, or tank], (Ḳ,) or a thing like a HawoD, (Ṣ, A,) in which water collects; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) a tank, or cistern, for rain-water: (ISd, TA:) arabicized: (Mṣb:) originally Pers.: pl. SahaAriyju. (Ṣ.) [See also SihoriI-N, in art. Shr.]
SuhaArijN: see the next preceding paragraph:
and also that here following.

muSahorajN Made with SaAruwj, (Ḳ,) i. e. nuwrap [or plaster of quick lime]. (TA.) One says birokapN muSahorajapN [A tank, or the like,] made with SaAruwj. (Ṣ.) And in like manner, HawoDN SuhaArijN↓ [A watering-trough, or tank,] plastered with SArwj. (L.)

SahoSaliqN A vehement voice. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) A rájiz says,
qado Xay-abato raOosiI biSawotK SahoSaliqN
[She has rendered my head hoary by a vehement voice]. (TA.)

And A clamorous old woman; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) vehement of voice; (TA;) and so SahoSalaqN; (TA;) so too SahoSaliyqN↓. (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) SahoSaliqu AlS-awoti is applied to a man, as meaning Vehement of voice: and in like manner to a hawk. (TA.)
SahoSaliyqN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Q. 1. SahoSayotu for SahoSahotu: see R. Q. 1 in art. Sh.

1. Sahala, said of a horse, aor. _i {yaSohilu} (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _a {yaSohalu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. SahiylN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [and taSohaAlN is an intensive inf. n., (see SahiylN below,)] He neighed; lit. uttered his voice; or voiced. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
[6. taSaAhalati Alxayolu The horses neighed, one to another. See an ex. in a verse cited voce ruwdN, where taSaAhalo occurs for tataSaAhalo.]
SaholN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

SahalN A voice with hoarseness, roughness, harshness, or gruffness; [this is app. correct, or nearly so; but what follows I think evidently wrong; and probably taken from a copy of the O, in this instance incorrect;] like SaholN↓: and SaholN is syn. with SaHolN: (Ḳ accord. to the CK and TA: [to which is added in the TA, i. e. hoarseness, roughness, harshness, or gruffness, in the voice:]) or syn. with SaHalN: (so in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ:) [the explanation given by Ṣgh appears to be correctly as follows:] one says, fiI Sawotihi SahalN and SaHalN, i. e. [In his voice is] sharpness and hardness: it is said in a trad. of Umm-Maabad, fiI Sawotihi SahalN or SaHalN, accord. to different relations: and AʼObeyd says that AlS-ahalu is like AlbaHaHu [i. e. hoarseness,, &c.], not intense, but pleasing. (Thus I find in the O.) [It is said in Ḥar p. 646 that AlSHl and AlShl↓ signify AlmaMC Alqlyl: but I think that this has been taken from some commentator who had found AlSHl and AlShl erroneously written for AlD-aHolu and AlD-aholu, with D.]
SahaAlN: see the next paragraph.

SahiylN [an inf. n., see 1,] and SuhaAlN↓ (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and SaAhilapN↓, of which the pl. is SawaAhilu, (O, Ḳ,) and taSohaAlN↓, [which last is an intensive inf. n.,] (O,) The neighing or neigh, lit. the voicing or voice, of the horse: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) similar to nahiyqN and nuhaAqN (Ṣ, TA) in relation to the ass. (TA.) Oaholu SahiylK waOaTiyTK means Possessors of horses and of camels: (TA in art. AT:) it is said in a trad. of Umm-Zarạ, fajaEalaniI fiI Oaholi SahiylK waOaTiyTK [And he set me among possessors of horses and of camels]: (O, TA:) she meant that she was among people of little property, and he transferred her to people of much wealth; for the possessors of horses and of camels are more [rich] than the possessors of sheep or goats. (TA in the present art.)

Sah-aAlN Neighing, lit. uttering his voice; [or rather that neighs much or often;] an epithet applied to a horse; (JK,* Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) and so SaAhilN↓ and cuw SaAhilK↓. (JK. [But these two I find not elsewhere in this sense.])
[Hence,] banaAtu Sah-aAlK Horses. (TA in art. bnI. [It should be observed that banaAt applied to irrational beings is pl. of AibonN as well as of AibonapN.])
SaAhilN and cuw SaAhilK: see Sah-aAlN.

SaAhilN applied to a he-camel signifies That strikes, or beats, (O, Ḳ,) with his fore leg and his hind leg, (Ḳ,) and bites, and does not ever utter a grumbling cry, in consequence of his disdainfulness, (O, Ḳ,) but whose inside makes a confused and continued, or rumbling, sound, (Ḳ, TA,) by reason of his disdainfulness: (TA:) so expl. by Lth:
one says jamalN SaAhilN and cuw SaAhilK: (O, TA:) and naAqapN caAtu SaAhilK (O, Ḳ) and bihaA SaAhilN: (O, TA:) or cuw SaAhilK signifies a stallion camel excited by lust, assaulting [the she-camels], and causing a sound to be heard from his inside; as also cuw XaAhiqK. (TA in art. Xhq.) And cuw SaAhilK applied to a man, † Vehement in springing or rushing, or in assaulting or attacking, and in excitement or provocation: (M, Ḳ, TA:) or a man whose anger is vehement; as also cuw XaAhiqK. (TA in art. Xhq.)
[SayohalN is expl. by Reiske as signifying Firma ac tenax durities: so says Freytag: but I find not any authority for this.]
SaAhilapN: see SahiylN: and see also vugaMCN, in art. vgw.

Its pl., SawaAhilu, is also applied (by the poet Aboo-Zubeyd Et-Tá-ee, O, TA) to The sounds of masaAHK [i. e. iron shovels or spades]. (O, Ḳ.) Also (by the poet Temeem Ibn-Abee-Mukbil, O, TA) to The sounds of flies among herbage; (O, Ḳ;) app. meaning the humming or buzzing, [sounds] of their flying. (O, TA.)
taSohaAlN: see SahiylN.

1. SahaA [or SahaI], aor. yaSohaIi, inf. n. SahoIN, accord. to AʼObeyd; or SahiIa accord. to Kh; It (a wound) was, or became, moist: (Ṣ:) or SahaA or SahaI [as written in different copies of the Ḳ], aor. _a; and SahiIa; he had a wound and it became moist. (Ḳ.)
And the former, He had much property. (Az, Ḳ.)
And i. q. Oasan-a [He became advanced in age, or full-grown;, &c.]. (TA.)
3. SAhAhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muSaAhaApN, (TA,) as expl. by IAạr, (TA,) He mounted upon its, or his, Sahowap [q. v.]; (Ḳ, TA;) said with reference to a mountain and to an animal. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AShI He had a complaint of the Sahowap [q. v.]; (Ḳ, TA;) said of a horse. (TA.)

AShI AlS-abiI-a He anointed the boy, or young male child, with clarified butter, and put him in the sun, in consequence of a disease (M, Ḳ) that had befallen him: (Ḳ:) or he so anointed him, and put him to sleep in the sun, in consequence of a disease. (JK.)

entry.sense: SahFA: see Saho, in art. Sh.
SahaApN: see the next following paragraph, last sentence but one.

SahowapN The part of the back, of a horse, which is the place of the saddle-cloth: (Ṣ:) or the smooth, or soft, part (mA Oasohala [so in copies of the Ḳ, but the right reading is app. mA Ousohila, lit. the part that is found to be smooth, or soft, to sit upon, see an ex. of this verb in the Ḥam p. 675,]) of the two sides of the saraAp [or back] of the horse: (Ḳ:) or the part, of the back, of the horse, whereon the rider sits: (Ḳ, and EM p. 43: [see an ex. of one of its pls. voce xafiyfN:]) and (Ḳ) the hinder part of the hump of the camel; (JK, Ḳ;) also called the raAdifap; (JK;) or, as some say, the [part called] raAdifap, which one sees above the rump: (TA:) pl. SahawaAtN and SihaMCN. (Ḳ.) [Hence, app.,] one says, tayosN cuw SahawaAtK meaning ‡ A fat he-goat. (TA.) And SahawaAtN signifies also The middle portions of the flesh extending along the two sides of the backbone of a bird of the species termed qaTFA. (TA.)
Also The uppermost part of any mountain, (Ṣ,) and of anything. (Ḥar p. 374.)
And The exterior uppermost part of a house, or chamber; the interior uppermost part thereof being called samokN. (Ḥam p. 725.)

And A tower (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) made (JK, Ṣ) upon a hill, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) on the highest part thereof: (JK, Ḳ:) pl. SahawaAtN, (JK,) or SuhFI, (Ḳ,) which is extr. [in respect of rule], like XuhFI pl. of XahowapN: mentioned by AḤei. (TA.)

And The like of a cave, or cavern, in a mountain, in which is water (Ḳ, TA) of the rain: (TA:) pl. SihaMCN, (Ḳ, TA,) with kesr and the long A: (TA:) or SihaMCN signifies places in which water falls, upon the heads of mountains, like the qalob [a mistranscription for qalot, q. v.]: (JK:) [or,] accord. to AA, places in which water wells forth; pl. of SahowapN: but in the handwriting of Az, AlS-uhaA is expl. as meaning the places in which water wells forth; and as pl. of SahowapN: in the Mj, SihaMCN is said to be pl. of SahaApN↓ and of SahowapN also. (TA.)
And A depressed tract of land to which stray camels betake themselves: (Ḳ:) or a depressed place surrounded by mountains; (JK;) [or] so SuhaAwiy-apN↓, accord. to Az. (TA.)
SuhaAwiy-apN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: 2. Saw-aI SuwFI He made SuwFI [i. e. signs set up for the guidance of travellers] in the way. (TA. [The verb is originally Saw-awa: and SuwFI is pl. of Suw-apN.])
[See also art. SwI.]
4. ASwI Alqawomu The people, or party, alighted in what are termed SuwFI, meaning elevated [or rugged and elevated] tracts of land. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)
[See also art. SwI.]

entry.sense: Saw-N i. q. faArigN, (Ḳ,) so in the Tekmileh, (TA,) applied to a thing, meaning Empty, void, or vacant. (TḲ.)
Saw-apN: see what follows, near the end.

hom.sense: Suw-apN A sign for the guidance of travellers, consisting of stones, (AA, Ṣ, IAth, Mṣb,) set up (IAth, Mṣb) in the way (Mṣb) in an unknown desert: (IAth:) or a stone that is a sign [for guidance] in the way: (M, Ḳ:) or an elevated sign of the way, set up in rugged ground: (M:) pl. SuwFI (AA, Ṣ, M, IAth, Mṣb) and pl. pl. OaSowaMCN, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter like OaroTaAbN pl. of ruTabN, (Mṣb, TA,) or, as some say, this is a pl., not a pl. pl. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Uin-a liloUisolaAmi SuwFI wamanaArFA kamanaAri AlT-ariyqi † [Verily El-Islám has signs and marks of guidance like those of the way]. (Ṣ.)
Hence [the pl.] OaSowaMCN is applied to signify Graves: (Ṣ:) occurring in a trad. in this sense. (TA.)

And the sing., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) accord. to Aṣ, (Ṣ,) signifies Rugged and elevated ground, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but inferior to a mountain: (Ṣ:) or an elevated and a rugged spot, upon which, sometimes, stones are set up in order that one may be directed thereby to the right way; like vuw-apN. (M in art. vw.)

And A place of varying, or of coming and going, (muxotalaf) of the wind: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a poet says, (namely, Imra-el-Ḳeys, TA,)
wahab-ato lahu riyHN bimuxotalafi AlS-uwaI
[meaning, if the explanation be correct, and the citation appropriate, And a wind blew them (referring to the word jamor, i. e. live coals, in a verse immediately preceding) in the place of varying of the places of varying of the wind]: (Ṣ:) but Aboo-Zekereeyà, in the margin of his book [or his copy of the Ṣ], throws doubt upon the word meaning “wind” [in this explanation]. (TA. [See De Slane's “Diwan d'Amro'lkais,” p. 20 of the Arabic text and p. 34 of his translation.])
Also An assemblage of beasts, or birds, of prey: (M, Ḳ:) on the authority of Kr. (M.)
And The sound of the echo: (Ḳ:) mentioned by Az; but written by him with fet-ḥ [i. e. Saw-apN↓]. (TA.)

Oaxacahu biSuwaAhu, expl. in the Ḳ as meaning He took it in its fresh state (biTaraMCatihi [in the CK erroneously bAaTorAfih]), is a mistranscription; correctly, biSaraAhu, with fet-ḥ to the S, and with r, as written by Az. (TA. [SarFA and SaraAwapN, both omitted in the Ḳ, are expl. in their proper place in the TA as syn. with jid-apN and gaDaADapN.])

1. SaAba, (Ṣ, M, A,) [aor. yaSuwbu,] inf. n. SawobN (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and maSaAbN, (Ḥar p. 240,) said of rain, (Ṣ, M, A,*) It poured forth; (M, A, Ḳ;) as also AnSAb↓: (M, Ḳ:) or it descended; and tSw-b↓ signifies the like. (Ṣ.) A poet says,
fasaqaI diyaAraka gayora mufosidihaA
Sawobu Alr-abiyEi wadiymapN tahomiI
which may mean, [And may] the descending of the rain called the rbyE [and continuous rain, or continuous and still rain, pouring forth, water thy districts, not injuring them]: or it may mean, [may] the rain of the season called the rbyE [&c.]: so says IHsh. (MF, TA.) And one says of a calamity (Xid-ap), on the occasion of its befalling, SaAbato biqur-K, meaning It became [or fell] in its qaraAr [or settled or fixed place, or in the place where it should remain]. (Ṣ, TA. [See also art. qr.])

[Hence, app.,] SaAbuwA bihimo They fell upon them, or assaulted them: and agreeably with this meaning is expl. the saying of the Hudhalee,
SaAbuwA bisit-api OaboyaAtK waOarobaEapK
Hat-aI kaOan-a Ealayohimo jaAbiYFA lubadaA
meaning [They fell upon, or assaulted, six tents, or dwellings, and four; so that it was as though there were upon them] numerous locusts. (TA.)
SawobN [app. meaning Sawobu maTarK] signifies also The sky's bringing rain. (A, Ḳ.)
SAb as syn. with OaSaAba: see the latter in eight places.
2: see above {1}, last sentence but one.
[Hence, app.,] Saw-abotu Alfarasa † I sent forth, or started, or let go, the horse in running. (Ṣ, TA.)

And taSowiybN is the contr. of taSoEiydN [generally in a trans. sense (though also in an intrans. sense as will be seen below); i. e. it signifies The making to descend]. (M, TA.) One says, Sw-b raOosahu He lowered, or depressed, his head. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And Saw-aba Qll-ehu raOosahu ‡ [May God degrade him; lit.] may God lower, or depress, his head. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mano qaTaEa sidorapF Saw-aba Qll-ehu raOosahu fiI Aln-aAri, which, accord. to Aboo-Dáwood Es-Sijistánee, is abridged, and means, Whoso cuts down, or lops, a sdrp [which is a species of lote-tree], in a desert, by the shade whereof the traveller shelters himself, without just cause, God will, or may God, lower his head [in the fire of Hell]. (L, TA.) And one says, Sw-b yadahu He lowered, or depressed, his hand, or arm. (L, TA.) And Sw-b AlUinaMCa He inclined the vessel (Mgh, Mṣb) downwards, in order that what was in it might run [out]: (Mgh:) or he lowered, or depressed, the vessel; and in like manner, raOosa AlxaXabapi [the head of the piece of wood]. (T, TA.)
And Sw-b Uilayohi yaSarahu [He directed his sight towards him]. (Mṣb in art. lmH. [From AlS-awaAbu.]) And SaE-ada fiI-a Aln-aZara waSaw-abahu: see art. SEd.

And Saw-abotu qawolahu † I said that his saying was SawaAb [i. e. right; or I pronounced his saying to be right]. (Mṣb.) And Sw-b raOoyahu ‡ [He pronounced his opinion to be right]. (A.) And Sw-bhu † He said to him OaSabota [Thou hast hit the right thing; or said, or done, right]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, Uino OaxoTaOotu faxaT-iYoniI waUino OaSabotu faSaw-iboniI ‡ [If I do, or say, wrong, tell me that I have done so; and if I do, or say, right, tell me that I have done so]. (A, TA.)

[taSowiybN is also the contr. of taSoEiydN in an intrans. sense as well as in the trans. sense mentioned above:] one says, TaAla fiI AlOaroDi taSowiybiI wataSoEiydiI [Long have continued my descending, or going down, and my ascending, or going up, in the land]. (A in art. SEd.)

ASAb AlqiroTaAsa, [inf. n. as above,] said of an arrow, [It hit, or struck, the butt, or target; or went right thereto;] (Ṣ, TA;) and SaAbahu↓, (Ṣ, TA,) or SAb Alhadafa, (M,) aor. yaSiybuhu, (Ṣ, M,) inf. n. SayobN, (Ṣ, TA,) likewise said of an arrow, (Ṣ, M, TA,) signifies the same; (Ṣ, TA;) or SAb said of an arrow is intrans. (M.) And ASAb alone, [as though used elliptically,] (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. as above; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and SAb↓, aor. yaSuwbu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. SayobuwbapN, (Ṣ,) or SawobN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and SAb↓, aor. yaSiybu, inf. n. SayobN; (Mṣb;) likewise said of an arrow, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) It went right; did not deviate from the right course: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) or it reached [or hit] the object of aim. (Mṣb.) And SAb↓ naHowa Alr-imiy-api, (M, A, TA,) aor. yaSuwbu, (A, TA,) inf. n. SawobN and SayobuwbapN, (M, TA,) said of an arrow, (M, A, TA,) It went right towards the thing, or animal, shot at; (M, TA;) as also ASAb. (TA.)

Also ASAb AlqiroTaAsa, (Ṣ, TA,) and ASAb fiI AlqiroTaAsi, (TA,) [said of a man, as is indicated by the context in the Ṣ and TA, He hit the butt, or target;] he did not miss the butt, or target. (TA.) And ASAb alone is said of an archer or the like [as meaning He hit the object of his aim]: (Mṣb:) one says, ramaI faOaSaAba [He shot, or cast, and hit the object of his aim]. (A.)

[Hence, likening an event, &c., to an arrow,] one says also, ASAbhu OamorN, inf. n. as above, † [An event smote him, or befell him;] and SAbhu↓, aor. yaSuwbuhu, inf. n. SawobN, signifies the same. (Mṣb.) And OaSaAbatohu muSiybapN † [An affliction, or a calamity,, &c., smote him, or befell him]. (Ṣ.) And ASAbhu AlX-aIoCu † The thing reached him [so as to take effect upon him]: (Mgh,* Mṣb:) whence the saying, OaSaAbahu mino qawoli Aln-aAsi maA OaSaAbahu † [There reached him, &c., of the sayings of the people, what reached him, &c.]. (Mṣb.) [Thus tropically used, ASAbhu may generally be rendered It hit, struck, smote, wounded, hurt, affected, assailed, or befell, him. One says, ASAbhu maraDN, and wajaEN, and ASAbthu riyHN, &c., † A disease, and pain, and wind,, &c., smote, affected, or assailed, him.] And SaAbahu↓ AlmaTaru, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. yaSuwbuhu, inf. n. SawobN, (Mṣb,) † [The rain fell, or lighted, upon him, or it; wetted him, or it;] he, or it, was rained upon. (Ṣ.) And SaAbati↓ Als-amaMCu AlOaroDa i. e. † [The sky, or clouds, or rain,] watered the earth, or land, copiously: (Lth, M, TA:) or it means OaSaAbatohaA biSawobK [it smote it with rain; or sent rain upon it]. (M, L, TA.) In the following verse, cited by IAạr,
fakayofa turaj-iI AlEAcilaAtu tajal-udiI
waSaboriI UicaA maA Aln-afosu Siyba↓ HamiymuhaA
he explains Siyba as being like quSida, and says that it may be of the dial. of him who says SaAba Als-ahomu; but [ISd remarks,] I know not how this is, for SaAba Als-ahomu is not trans.; [though, as shown above, he has mentioned it as being trans.;] and in my opinion, [he says,] Syb here is from the phrase SaAbati Als-amaMCu AlOaroDa [expl. above; the meaning of the verse being, But how should the censuring women hope for my constraining myself to behave with hardiness, and for my being patient, when the beloved of the soul has been smitten by death, or by the decree of death; for ISd adds,] kaOan-a Almaniy-apa SaAbati AlHamiyma faOaSaAbatohu biSawobihaA. (M, TA.*)

[ASAb is also used in many phrases in which its agent is likened to an archer.] One says, ASAb AlS-awaAba ‡ [He hit the right thing or point, or the object, or aim, of his words or of his actions]: (A:) and ASAb Als-adaAda [which means the same]. (Ṣ in art. sd.) And ASAb alone [means thus likewise; or] † he said, or did, that which was right. (M, Ḳ.*) And ASAb fiI qawolihi wafiEolihi † He hit the right thing in his saying and his deed; (Mṣb;) and so fiI raOoyihi in his opinion; contr. of OaxoTaOa. (A.) And ASAb bigoyatahu † He attained, or obtained, the thing that he sought, or wanted: whence the saying, ASAb mino zawojatihi [and so app. OaSaAbahaA (see safaqa)] † He obtained his desired enjoyment of his wife: (Mṣb:) ASAb min-iI occurs in a trad., [as a euphemism,] said by the wife of Handhaleh, meaning † He compressed me: (Mgh:) and it is said in a trad., kaAna yuSiybu mino raOosi baEoDi nisaAYihi wahuwa SaAYimN, meaning † He used to kiss [the head of some one or more of his wives when he was fasting]. (TA: and the like is said in the Mgh.) And ASAb mina AlmaAli wagayorihi † He took, or took with his hand, of the property and other things. (TA.) And ASAb AlX-aIoCa ‡ [He hit upon, or lighted on, the thing;] he found the thing. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,* TA.) And ASAbhu [† He found it, met with it, or experienced it; namely, a good or an evil event. And † He found it out, or discovered it; namely, an enigma (see 8 in art. Hjw) or the like. And] † He found it to be right: and † he saw it, considered it, or held it, to be right. (TA. [See also 10.]) And † He aimed at it; (Aṣ, TA;) ‡ he desired, wished, willed, intended, or meant, it. (Aṣ, M, A, Mṣb, TA.) One says, OaSaAba fulaAnN AlS-awaAba faOaxoTaOa AljawaAba † Such a one aimed at, and desired, [to say] that which was right, (Aṣ, Mṣb,* TA,) and failed of giving rightly the reply. (Aṣ, TA.) And Oayona tuSiybaAni † [Whither do ye two desire to go?]; a saying of Ru-beh. (TA.) tajoriI biOamorihi ruxaMCF Hayovu OaSaAba, in the Ḳur [xxxviii. 35, referring to the wind], has been expl. as meaning † [Running by his command softly, or gently,] whithersoever He desireth. (M,* TA.) And ASAb Qll-ehu Al-aciI OaraAda, said in a trad., in reply to a question respecting the interpretation of a text, means † God desireth, or meaneth, [thereby,] what He desireth, or meaneth. (TA.) And ASAb Qll-ehu bika xayorFA means OaraAdahu ‡ [i. e. May God intend thee good]. (A.) And ASAb alone † He desired, or intended, or meant, that which was right. (M, Ḳ.*) One says also, ASAbhu bixayorK † [meaning He did good to him]. (El-Muärrij, TA in art. Asw.) [But] ASAbhu bikacaA, (M,) inf. n. UiSaAbapN, (Ḳ,) with which are syn. muSaAbN↓ [in accordance with a usage generally allowable] (Ṣ, TA)
and muSaAbapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) † [generally] means He afflicted him with, or by, such a thing; or gave pain to him thereby. (M, Ḳ:* in the latter, only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense; and so in other senses.) [Thus one says, ASAbhu biXar-K † He afflicted him with evil; or did evil to him: and ASAbhu bimakoruwhK † He afflicted him with, or did to him, an abominable, or an evil, thing or action: and ASAbhu biqawolK qabiyHK † He afflicted him with, or said to him, a foul saying: and ASAbhu bicaHolK † He punished him by blood-revenge: and ASAbhu bimaraDK † He, (i. e. God,) or it, (a thing,) affected him with disease; or rendered him diseased: and in many similar cases, the phrase may be well rendered with a verb derived from the noun; like phrases in which “affecit” (a Latin equivalent of ASAb) occurs; as in “honore affecit,” meaning “honoravit.”] El-Hárith Ibn-Khuld El-Makhzoomee says,
OaZulayomu Uin-a muSaAbakumo↓ rajulFA
OahodaI Als-alaAma taHiy-apF Zulomu
† [O Dhuleymeh, verily your afflicting a man who has given the salutation of peace, greeting, is tyranny]: IB says that this verse is not of El-'Arjee, as El-Ḥareeree imagined it to be: the correct reading is OaZulayomu, as above: Zlym is an apocopated from of Zulayomapu; which is the dim. of Zaluwm: some read OaZaluwmu: and some, Oasulayomu: [the verse is cited accord. to this last reading in the Ṣ:] rajulFA is governed in the accus. case by muSaAb [as an inf. n.]: and Zulomu is the enunciative of Uin-a. (L, TA.) OaSaAbahumu Ald-ahoru binufuwsihimo waOamowaAlihimo † means Time, or fate, afflicted them by destruction, or extirpation, among themselves and their cattle, or possessions. (M.) [In the Ḳ, AlUiSaAbpu is expl. as signifying AlAiHotiyaAju: but the right reading is evidently AlAijotiyaAHu, as IbrD has remarked in the margin of my copy of the TA; so that ASAb signifies † He destroyed, or extirpated; agreeably with an explanation in the sentence next preceding above, from the M.] mano yuridi Qll-ehu bihi xayorFA yuSibo minohu, † occurring in a trad., means Him whom God intendeth good He trieth with afflictions, that He may recompense him for them. (TA.) And one says, maA kunotu muSaAbFA walaqado OuSibotu † [app. meaning I was not affected with weakness of intellect, or madness, and I have become affected therewith: see muSaAbN, below]. (IAạr, TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tSw-b [quasi-pass. of 2]: see 1, in three places.
Also It was, or became, lowered, or depressed; syn. tasaf-ala. (A.)
[6. tSAwb, accord. to Freytag, signifies He, or it, was well directed: but for this he names no authority.]
7: see 1, first sentence.

10. AisotaSowabahu and AisotaSaAbahu signify the same, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) ‡ He saw it, considered it, or held it, to be right; (M, Mṣb, TA;) namely, his deed, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or his opinion, (M, TA,) or his saying: (A:) Th says, AisotaSabotuhu is the regular form; but the Arabs say, AisotaSowabotu raOoyaka. (M, TA. [See also 4, latter half.])

SaAbN A certain species of tree, from which, when it is pressed, there issues what resembles milk, a drop of which sometimes spirts into the eye, producing an effect like that of a flame of fire, and in some instances weakening the sight: (M, TA:) or a certain kind of bitter tree; (Aṣ, T, M, Ḳ, TA;) one of which is termed SaAbapN↓: (M, Ḳ:* [in the latter it is said that SaAbN is the pl. of SaAbapN; but properly speaking, the former is a coll. gen. n., and the latter is its n. un.:]) or the expressed juice of a kind of bitter tree: (Ṣ:) but accord. to the Ḳ, this is a mistake, though it is the saying of leading lexicologists: (TA:) or, as some say, the expressed juice of the Sabir [or aloes]. (M.)

hom.sense: SawobN an inf. n. used as a subst. (Mṣb) meaning Rain; (Lth, Mṣb;) and so Say-ibN↓, which is originally [SayowibN, i. e.] of the measure fayoEilN from AlS-awobu: (Bḍ in ii. 18:) or Say-ibN is an epithet applied to clouds (gayomN, Sh, O, or saHaAbN, Ṣ, Mṣb) meaning having rain, (O,) i. q. cuw SawobK: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or SawobN and Say-ibN↓ and Say-uwbN↓ [the last of which is written in the CK SayuwbN] all signify the same, (M, Ḳ,) as epithets applied to rain, meaning pouring forth: (M:) or Say-uwbN↓, which is originally of the measure fayoEuwlN, [being altered from SayowuwbN,] means rain pouring forth much, or abundantly: (IDrd, O:) [SaAYibN↓, also, is applied as an epithet to rain, like SawobN and Say-ibN; and] in the phrase SiybaAnu AlmaTari, accord. to Abu-l-ʼAlà, SiybaAn is pl. of SaAYib; or it may be an inf. n., like HiromaAn: and if one say SayobaAn↓, with fet-ḥ, the meaning is, what has poured forth of rain, notwithstanding the I in it, for similar to this are rayoHaAn from Alr-awoH and EayodaAn (meaning “tall” palm-trees) from AlEuwod. (Ḥam p. 796.)

Also Course, or tendency; syn. qaSodN: so in the saying, to one who is traversing a desert in uncertainty and has declined from the right way, Oaqimo Sawobaka [Rectify thy course]: and in the phrase fulaAnN musotaqiymu AlS-awobi [Such a one is pursuing the right course], said of a person when he is not declining from his way to the right or left. (TA. [See also another ex. voce OawobN.])

And A place, or point, of tendency or direction or bearing, syn. jihapN, (Mṣb, TA,) of a thing; (Mṣb;) and naAHiyapN [which means the same; and also a side; or a lateral, or an adjacent, part or tract of a thing; and in this sense SawobN is used in the present day]; and jaAnibN [which generally has the latter of these meanings]. (TA.)
See also SawaAbN, in three places.
SaAbapN: see muSiybapN.
Also Weakness, or feebleness, in the intellect; (M, A, Ḳ;) or a touch of insanity therein; (A;) or somewhat of insanity, or of madneess produced by diabolical possession. (Ṣ.)
See also SaAbN.

entry.sense: SuwbapN A collection, (jamaAEapN, M, or mujotamaEN, Ḳ,) or a collection, or heap, not measured nor weighed, (SuborapN, A) of wheat: (M, A, Ḳ:) a heap of wheat, and of dates, and of other things: (M:) a quantity collected together of dust or earth: (TA:) or anything collected together: (Kr, M, Ḳ:) a place in which dates are collected and dried is thus called by the people of El-Felj. (ISk, Ṣ.) One says, daxalotu EalaI fulaAnK faUicaA Ald-anaAniyru SuwbapN bayona yadayohi i. e. [I went in to such a one, and lo, the deenárs were] a heap poured out without measure before him: (Ṣ, M,* A:*) or, as some relate the saying, Ald-iynaAru, which is thus used as a gen. n. (M.)
SayobaAnN: see SawobN.

SawaAbN † A thing that is right, or what is said and of what is done; [like sadaAdN;] (Mṣb;) contr. of xaTaON; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also SawobN↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says, daEoniI waEalaI-a xaTaYiI waSawobiI↓ i. e. SawaAbiI [meaning † Leave thou me, and on me be the consequence of my wrong saying or deed, and my right]. (Ṣ.) [And hence the phrase, frequent in some of the lexicons, &c., AlS-awaAbu kacaA meaning † The right, or correct, word or wording or reading is thus: and SawaAbuhu kacaA † The right, or correct, writing or wording or reading of it is thus.]
And one says also qawolN SawobN↓ and SawaAbN [meaning † A right, or correct, saying: thus using each as an epithet]. (M.)
SawiybN: see SaAYibN, in two places.

hom.sense: SaAYibN: see SawobN.

Also, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) and muSiybN↓ (A) and SayuwbN↓ and SawiybN↓, (M, Ḳ,) An arrow going right, or hitting the mark: (Ṣ, M, A,* Ḳ,* TA:) ↓the last of these is the only epithet, known to IJ, of the measure faEiylN having the f and l sound and having w for its E, except TawiylN and qawiymN; for EawiySN is [held by him to be only] used as a subst.: SiyaAbN is pl. of SaAYibN, like SiyaAmN and qiyaAmN pls. of SaAYimN and qaAYimN; either from AlS-awaAbu fiI Alr-amoIi or from SaAba Als-ahomu Alhadafa having yaSiybu for its aor. (M.) [See also SayuwbN in art. Syb.] One says, Uin-ahu lasahomN SaAYibN Verily it is an arrow that goes right. (TA.) maEa AlxawaATiYi sahomN SaAYibN is a prov. [expl. in art. xTO]. (Ṣ.)
[Hence,] one says also raOoIN SaAYibN and muSiybN↓ ‡ [A right opinion]: (A, TA:) [Mṭr says,] raOoIN Say-ibN↓ meaning SaAYibN I have not found. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: Say-ibN: see SawobN, in two places: and SaAYibN.
Say-uwbN: see SawobN, in two places.

Suw-aAbapN The choice, or best, class of a people; (Fr, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also Suy-aAbapN↓ (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ) and Suy-aAbN↓. (Ḳ.) And qawomN Suy-aAbN↓ A choice, or an excellent, people. (Ṣ.) And Suy-aAbapN↓ signifies The choice, or best, of anything. (Ṣ.) [See also art. Syb.]
Also, Suw-aAbapN, The collective body of a people; (M;) and so Suy-aAbapN↓. (Kr, M in art. Syb.)

OaSowabu [More, and most, affected with weakness in the intellect, or insanity, or madness: see SaAbapN]. When a man says to another Oanota muSaAbN [meaning Thou art affected with weakness in the intellect,, &c.], the latter replies Oanota OaSowabu min-iI [Thou art more affected with weakness in the intellect,, &c., than I]. (IAạr, M, TA. [Thus these phrases are used in the present day.])

maSaAbN [A place of pouring forth: pl. maSaAwibu]. One says, huwa maSaAbu Alwadoqi [It is the place of the pouring of rain in the clouds]: and Ximotu maSaAwiba AlmaTari [I watched, or watched for, the places of the pouring of rain in the clouds]: and saqaAhumo maSaAwibu Als-amaMCa [The places of the pouring of the rain watered them; or may the places, &c. water them]. (A.)
