hom.sense: muSaAbN pass. part. n. of 4 [meaning Hit, struck, smitten, wounded, hurt, affected, assailed, afflicted,, &c.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)
Also Syn. with UiSaAbapN: (Ṣ, TA:) see 4, latter half, in two places.
And Syn. with muSiybapN, q. v. (A, Mṣb.)
Also The sugar-cane. (L, TA, and so in a copy of the Ṣ.)

entry.sense: maSuwbN pass. part. n. of SaAba [q. v.]. (Mṣb.)
miSowabN A ladle. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
muSiybN: see SaAYibN, in two places.
muSaAbapN Syn. with UiSaAbapN: (Ḳ, TA:) see 4, latter half.
See also muSiybapN.
tarakotu Aln-aAsa EalaI muSaAbaAtihimo is a saying mentioned by Ibn-Buzurj, as meaning [I left the people disposed, or placed,] according to their classes, or ranks. (TA.)
maSuwbapN: see the next paragraph.

muSiybapN, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said by Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà to be originally muSowibapN, (TA,) and maSuwbapN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and muSaAbapN↓ (M, Ḳ) and muSaAbN↓ (A, Mṣb) and SaAbapN↓, (M, Ḳ,) signify the same, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) An affliction, a calamity, a misfortune, a disaster, or an evil accident: (M, Mṣb, TA:) it is said in the Towsheeh that the primary signification of muSiybapN is a shot with an arrow: (TA:) the pl. is maSaAYibu, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb,) the form commonly obtaining, (Mṣb,) but irregular, (M,) the Arabs agreeing in pronouncing it with C, as though they likened the radical letter to the augmentative, (Ṣ,) or they imagined what is of the measure mufoEilapN to be of the measure faEiylapN without a radical I or w, (M,) and it is thought by Aṣ to be of the speech of the people of the cities, (Mṣb,) and maSaAwibu, (M,) which is the original form, (Ṣ,) or is said to be so, (Mṣb,) and is said by Zj to be the form preferred by the grammarians, (TA,) and muSiybaAtN. (Aṣ, A, Mṣb.)
qaT-N muSaw-abN A nibbing in which the exterior of the writing-reed is made to extend beyond the pith: opposed to qaAYimN. (TA in art. Hrf.)

SawobajN and SuwbajN, (Ḳ,) the latter the only word of its measure except suwsanN (AḤei, TA) and kuwsajN, (TA,) A thing with which bread is made; (Ḳ;) a wooden implement with which the makers of bread expand the cake of bread; (AḤei, TA;) the miHowar of the maker of bread, with which the dough, or bread, is expanded: (TA in art. lT:) an arabicized word, (Ḳ, TA,) form the Pers. JuwPaho [or Juwbaho]. (TA.) [See what is said in art. Srj respecting words in which both S and j occur.]

1. SaAta, aor. yaSuwtu (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) and yaSaAtu, (M, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. SawotN, (Ṣ, M,) said of a thing (Ṣ, O) [and of a man and of any animal]; and Sw-t↓, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taSowiytN, said of a man (Ṣ) [and of any animal, &c.]; and ASAb↓; (M, Ḳ;) It sounded; it, or he, made, produced, emitted, sent forth, or uttered, a sound, noise, voice, or cry; (PṢ and KL in explanation of the first, and MA and KL in explanation of the second;) he raised his voice, voiced, called or called out, cried or cried out, shouted, clamoured, exclaimed, or vociferated: (M, Ḳ:) SawotN signifies also the making lamentation: (KL:) and Sw-t↓ bihi, (M, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) he called, hailed, or summoned, him; called out, cried out, or shouted, to him. (M,* TA.) It is said in a trad., kaAnuwA yakorahuwna AlS-awota Einoda AlqitaAli [They used to dislike blustering on the occasion of combat, or fight]: meaning one's calling to another, or doing a deed to be mentioned in after times, and shouting, and making oneself known in a boasting and self-conceited manner. (TA.) [See also SawotN below.]

hom.sense: 2: see above, in two places {1}:
and see also 4, likewise in two places.
4: see 1.
ASAt signifies also He became possessed of Siyt [or fame,, &c.; i. e. he became famous]. (O.)

[It is also trans.; as in the phrase] ASAt Alqawosa He made the bow to sound [or twang]: (M, TA:) [and so is Sw-t↓; as in the phrase] Sw-t AlEiloka [He caused the kind of resin called Eilok to make a sound, or sounds]. (Ḳ voce OanoqaDa.)
[And it is trans. by means af bi; as in the phrase] ASAt biAlr-ajuli [and in like manner Sw-t↓ (see jar-asa)] He rendered the man notorious by a thing that he did not desire. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.)

entry.sense: 7. AnSAt bihi Alz-amaAnu [The age resounded with the mention of him; meaning] he became famous, or celebrated. (Ḳ.)
And AnSAt He answered, and came, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) being called: of the measure AinofaEala from AlS-awotu. (Ṣ, O.)
Also He went away hiding himself. (Ḳ.)
SaAtN: see SiytN:
and see also Say-itN, in two places.

SawotN [an inf. n. (see 1): and also a simple subst., signifying] A sound, (M, MA, TA, PṢ,) a noise, a voice, a cry, a shout, an exclamation, or a vociferation; (MA, PṢ;) of a human being and of other things: (ISk, TA:) conventionally, the sound of speech: (Mṣb:) [also a tone, considered with regard to the degree of elevation or depression of the voice:] and any sort of singing: (M, TA:) [and an air, or a song:] and it is used to signify a clamour, or confused noise, or mixture of sounds, (Ṣ,) and a cry for aid or succour: (Ṣ, M:) the pl. is OaSowaAtN: (M, Mṣb, TA:) it is masc.: (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, TA:) in the following verse, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) of Ruweyshid Ibn-Ketheer (Ṣ, M) Et-Tá-ee, (Ṣ,)
yaA Oay-uhaA Alr-aAkibu AlmuzojiI maTiy-atahu
saAyilo baniI OasadK maA hecihi AlS-awotu
[O thou, the rider urging on his beast, ask the sons of Asad what is this clamour?], (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) the poet has made AlSwt fem. because meaning thereby. AlD-awoDaMC and Aljalabap and AlAisotigaAvap, (Ṣ,) or he has made it fem. as meaning AlS-ayoHap, (M, Mṣb,) or AlAisotigaAvap: (M:) the like is often done by the Arabs, when two words, masc. and fem., are syn.: thus they say, Oaqobalati AlEiXaMCu, meaning AlEaXiy-apu; and hecaA AlEaXiy-apu, meaning AlEiXaMCu: (Mṣb:) but the making a masc. n. fem. for this reason is bad; though the reverse is held to be allowable. (M.) The Arabs say, OasomaEu SawotFA waOaraI fawotFA, meaning I hear a sound, or voice, but I see not a deed. (TA.) biSawotika in the Ḳur xvii. 66 is said to mean With the sounds of [thy] singing, and musical pipes. (M, TA.)

Aisomu SawotK is a term applied to A noun significant of a sound: nouns of this kind being of two classes; namely, nouns applied to the purpose of addressing irrational beings, or what are virtually in the predicament of irrational beings, as young infants; and onomatopœias, or nouns imitative of sounds: the former class consists of two descriptions of words; namely, ejaculations used for the purpose of chiding, as halaA (to horses) and Eadaso (to mules) and kixo kixo (to a young infant);
and ejaculations used for the purpose of calling, as jiIoC (to camels) and tuXaOo (to an ass): of the other class are gaAqi (imitative of the cry of the crow) and Taqo (imitative of the sound produced by the falling of stones) and qbo (imitative of the sound produced by the fall of a sword), &c.: nouns significant of sounds are generally indecl., because they resemble certain particles in neither governing nor being governed; but some of them are occasionally decl. [like other nouns]. (El-Ashmoonee's Expos. of the Alfeeyeh of Ibn-Málik, section AsmAC AlAfEAl wAlASwAt.)
See also the next paragraph, in four places.

hom.sense: SiytN (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SawotN↓ (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and SaAtN↓ (M, Ḳ) and SiytapN↓ (Ḳ) Fame, report, repute, or reputation, whether good or evil: (TA:) or good fame, good report, good repute or reputation, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) that spreads (Ṣ) among the people; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) so some say; (TA;) not evil: (Ṣ:) [they may often be well rendered renown:] SiytN is originally SiwotN; the w being changed into I on account of the kesreh preceding it: it seems as though they made it to be of the measure fiEolN to distinguish between the Sawot that is heard and the fame, &c. that is known: but sometimes they said, AinotaXara Sawotuhu↓ fiI Aln-aAsi in the sense of Siytuhu [i. e. His fame, &c., or good fame, &c., spread among the people]: (Ṣ, TA:) and lahu SawotN↓ fiI Aln-aAsi and SiytN [He has fame, &c., or good fame, &c., among the people]: and cahaba Siytuhu fiyhimo [His fame, &c., or good fame, &c., went among them]. (A.) It is said in a trad., maA mino EabodK Uil-aA lahu SiytN fiI Als-amaMCi, meaning [There is no servant of God, i. e. no man, but he has] a report by which he is known [in Heaven]; and it may be in respect of good and evil. (TA.) And in another trad., faSolu maA bayona AlHalaAli waAlHaraAmi AlS-awotu↓ waAld-afN [The distinction between the lawful (i. e. marriage) and the unlawful (i. e. fornication) is the report that is made in the case of the former, and the tambourine that is used in that case], meaning the publication of the marriage, and the going of the report thereof among the people. (TA.)
SiytN also signifies A blacksmith's hammer. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And An artificer, or a handicraftsman; syn. SaAniEN: (Ḳ accord. to the TA:) or a goldsmith; syn. SaAYigN. (So in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ.)

entry.sense: SiytapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SaAYitN [Sounding; making, producing, emitting, sending forth, or uttering, a sound, noise, voice, or cry; (see its verb, SAt;)] raising his voice, calling or calling out, crying or crying out, shouting, exclaiming, or vociferating; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) as also Say-itN↓; the two words being like maAYitN and may-itN; the latter originally SayowitN. (TA. [But see the next paragraph: and see also miSowaAtN.])

Say-itN, applied to a man, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and SaAtN↓, so applied, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and the latter likewise applied to an ass, (Ṣ,) both signify the same, (Ḳ,) Vehement, strong, or loud, of voice: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) rajulN SaAtN↓ is like rajulN maAlN “a man having much property,” and rajulN naAlN “a man who gives much,” and kaboXN SaAfN [“a ram having much wool”], &c., all of these epithets being originally of the measure faEilN: (Ṣ:) or SaAtN may be of the measure faAEilN from which the medial radical has gone; or it may be [originally SawitN,] of the measure faEilN. (M.) One says also SawotN Say-itN [A vehement, strong, or loud, voice]. (A.) See also SaAYitN.
Saw-aAtN: see miSowaAtN.
muSaw-itN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

miSowaAtN One who raises his voice, calls or calls out, cries or cries out, shouts, clamours, exclaims, or vociferates; i. q. muSaw-itN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) [or, as also Saw-aAtN↓, often occurring, who does so much, or is in the habit of doing so; each being of a measure denoting intensiveness of the signification.]
[Hence,] one says, maA biAld-aAri miSowaAtN, meaning There is not in the house any one (Ḳ, TA) that raises his voice,, &c.: in some copies of the Ḳ muSaw-itN↓, which has the same meaning. (TA.)
munoSaAtN Straight in stature. (Ṣ.)
Saw-ajaAnN: see SawolajaAnN, in art. Swlj.
1. SuHotuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [third pers. SaAHa, aor. yaSuwHu,] inf. n. SawoHN, (TḲ,) I clave, split, or slit, it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, a thing. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 2. Sw-Ht Albaqola, said of the wind, (Alr-iyHu, Ṣ, A,) and of the heat, (AlHar-u, A,) and of the sun, (AlX-amosu, TA,) inf. n. taSowiyHN, (Ḳ,) It dried up, or caused to dry up, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) the herbs, or leguminous plants, (Ṣ, A,) so that they became much split; (A;) and so AlxaXaba [the wood]; and the like of these: and Sy-Ht signifies the same. (TA.) And Sw-H AlX-aEara, said of dryness, It caused the hair to split much, and to fall off, and become scattered. (L.)
See also 5, in four places.

It is said in a trad., nahaI Eano bayoEi Aln-axoli qabola Oano yuSaw-iHa, meaning [He forbade the selling of palm-trees] before that the good thereof become distinguishable from the bad: related by some with r [i. e. yuSar-iHa]: (TA:) but El-Khat- tábee says that the right word is yuSaw-iH, with w. (TA in art. SrH.)

entry.sense: 5. tSw-H Albaqolu The herbs, or leguminous plants, became dried up; as also Saw-aHa↓: (IB, TA:) or became completely dried up; or became blighted and dried up; and Saw-aHa↓ signifies the same: (L:) or became dried up in the hot season, not by reason of a blight or the like: (T, TA:) or became dried up in the upper part, (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ,) yet retaining moisture: (AA, Ṣ:) or became dried up and split; (Aṣ, TA;) and Saw-aHa↓ signifies [the same, or] became dried up and much split: (A:) or (and so the verb tSw-H said of wood, and the like,) became much split, spontaneously, and parts thereof became scattered: and tSy-H signifies the same. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of ʼAlee, fabaAdiruwA AlEiloma qabola taSowiyHi↓ nabotihi † [Therefore hasten ye to obtain knowledge before the dryingup of its plants for want of mental vigour]. (TA.)

tSw-H also signifies It became much split; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) said of hair, &c.; (Ṣ;) as also AnSAH↓: (Ḳ: [but this latter is more correctly expl. below:]) [or] said of hair, it fell off and became scattered; as also tSy-H: (Ḳ:) or it became much split, (A, L,) of itself, (L,) [or by reason of dryness, (see 2,)] and fell off and became scattered. (L.)
7. AnSAH It clave, split, or slit; or became cloven, split, or slit. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also 5.
It (a mountain) became much cleft, or cracked, and dried, by reason of want of rain. (TA, from a trad.)
It (a garment) slit, or rent, of itself. (AO, Ṣ.)
‡ It (the moon, Ṣ, Ḳ, and the dawn, and lightning, TA) showed its light: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) originally, became cleft. (TA.) [See also 7 in art. SyH.]
SawoHN: see what next follows.

SuwHN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and SawoHN↓ (IAạr, Ḳ) The wall (HaAYiT) of a valley: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [app. meaning its perpendicular side; for] a valley has SuwHaAni, (Ṣ,) which means the two sides thereof, resembling two walls. (A.)

And The lower part of a mountain: (Ḳ:) or the face of a mountain that stands up (Ṣ, Ḳ) appearing (Ṣ) as though it were a wall. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., Oaloqawohu bayona AlS-uwHayoni Hat-aI Oakalatohu Als-ibaAEu, meaning [They cast him] between the two mountains [so that the beasts, or birds, of prey ate him]. (Ṣ.)
SaAHapN A plain, (A,) or land, (Ḳ,) that produces nothing (A, Ḳ) ever; (Ḳ;) i. e., in which is no good. (A.)
SuwHaAnN, with damm [to the S], Dry. (Ḳ.) And naxolapN SuwHaAnapN A palm-tree of which the branches with their leaves upon them have become dried up, rigid, and contracted. (Ḳ, TA.)
SuwaAHN Gypsum. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And † The sweat of horses: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) said to be likened to gypsum because of its whiteness. (T, L.)
And † Milk mixed with water, the latter being the more in quantity. (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ.)
Also An elevated piece, (najowap, so in the L and CK, and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) or such as is soft, or yielding, (rixowap, so in the TA as from the Ḳ,) of land. (L, Ḳ.)
And The spadix (TaloE) of the palm-tree, (AḤn, Ḳ,) when it dries up, and falls in pieces and becomes scattered. (AḤn.)

Suw-aAHapN, like rum-aAnapN, [but accord. to analogy it should be without teshdeed, like suqaATapN, &c., and so it is written in the L as relating to wool,] What has become much split, of hair, and what has fallen off and become scattered, thereof, (Ḳ,) and so of wool. (L, TA.)
munoSaAHN Flowing, or flowing copiously, running upon the surface of the ground; (Ḳ, TA;) applied to rain-water. (TA.)
And Herbage of which the blossoms have appeared. (TA.) [See a verse cited voce murotafiqN.]
4. ASAx lahu (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA) and Uilayohi, (A, TA,) inf. n. UiSaAxapN, (TA,) He listened to him, or it. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) [See a verse of Aboo-Du-ád (cited here as an ex. in the Ṣ and TA) voce naAXidN.]

And ASAx signifies also ‡ He was silent, or spake not, or ceased from speaking: so in the saying, OaSaAxa fulaAnN EalaI Haq-i fulaAnK, meaning ‡ Such a one was silent respecting the right, or due, of such a one, that he might take it away. (A, TA.) [And it is said that] it signifies thus in the prov., OaSaAxa UiSaAxapa Alminodahi liln-aAXidi, i. e. He was silent with the silence of the frequent chider of camels [or of him who drives and chides many camels] to one making known, or giving information of, a thing lost: applied to him who strives, or labours, in seeking [a thing] and then lacks ability, and desists. (Meyd. [But the verse cited voce naAXidN suggests another rendering, which I think preferable. In Freytag's “Arab. Prov.” i. 718, llnAXd is omitted.])
2. Sw-d AlS-aAda, inf. n. taSowiydN, He wrote the SAd [i. e. the letter S]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: SaAdN The name of one of the letters of the alphabet. (M, L. [See art. S.])

[It is also The title of a suwrap, the thirty-eighth chapter of the Ḳur-án.] If you make it a sign of the swrp, you write it as a single letter, and make it indeclinable with its last letter quiescent [in pronunciation]: if you make it a name for the swrp, you write it as [it is pronounced] in spelling; and say SaAdi, with kesr, because of the concurrence of two quiescent letters [in the former case]; and you may say SaAda, because this is easier of pronunciation: some make it imperfectly decl., considering it as fem. [and a proper name]: and some make it perfectly decl., considering it as masc.; and say, qaraOotu SaAdFA [I read, or recited, the chapter S]: and the like is done in the cases of q [the title of the fiftieth chapter] and n [the title of the sixtyeighth chapter]. (Mṣb.)
Accord. to ISd, its medial radical letter is originally w: (L:) accord. to IJ, it is I. (MF.)
See also art. Syd.

1. SaArahu, aor. yaSuwru, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. SaworN, (M, Ḳ,) He made it (a thing, M, Ḳ, or, as some say, specially the neck, M) to incline, or lean; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also SArhu, aor. yaSiyru; (Ṣ;) and ASArhu↓: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he demolished it threw it down, or pulled it down to the ground; as also ASArhu↓. (Ḳ.) One says, of a man, yaSuwro Eunuqahu UilaI AlX-aIoCi He inclines his neck to the thing. (Lth.) And Surotu UilaI-a AlX-aIoCa, and OaSarotuhu↓, I inclined, or bent, the thing to, or towards, me. (El-Aḥmar.) And Surotu AlguSona liOajotaniIa Alv-amara [I inclined, or bent, the branch, that I might pluck, or gather, the fruit]. (A.) And quluwbN laA taSuwruhaA AlOaroHaAmu † [Hearts which the ties of relationship do not incline]. (TA, from a trad.) faSurohun-a Uilayoka, in the Ḳur [ii. 262], means And turn them towards thee; and so faSirohun-a: (Akh, Ṣ, M:) but the former is the more common reading: this is the meaning commonly known, of each reading: though Lḥ says that the former means as above, and the latter means cut them, and divide them, in pieces; (M;) and some thus explain the former, making a transposition in the verse, as though the words were thus, faxuco Uilayoka OarobaEapF mina QlT--ayori faSurohun-a. (Ṣ.) One says also, Suro UilaI-a, and Suro wajohaka UilaI-a, Turn thou thy face towards me. (Akh, Ṣ.) And SaAra wajohahu, aor. yaSuwru, (M, Ḳ,) and yaSiyru, (Ḳ,) He turned his face towards a person or thing. (M, Ḳ.) And huwa yaSuwra maEoruwfahu UilaI Aln-aAsi ‡ [He turns his beneficence towards men]. (TA.)
[Agreeably with a statement cited above, it is said that] SaArahu, aor. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) signifies also He dissected it; or cut it, or divided it, in pieces. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
And hence, (TA,) SaAra AlHukoma † He (the judge, A, TA) decided the judgment. (Ṣ,* A, TA.)
[Freytag states, on the authority of the Kitáb el-Addád, that SAr, aor. as above, has two contr. significations: He separated, or dispersed:]
[and He collected.]
See also 2.
SaAra also signifies He (a man, M) uttered a cry, or sound. (M, Ḳ.)

Sawira, (M, A, Ḳ,) [aor. yaSowaru,] inf. n. SawarN, (Ṣ, M, A,) He, (Lth,) or it, (a thing, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, or a man's neck, M, A,*) inclined, or leaned; (Lth, Ṣ,* M, A, Ḳ;) as also AnSAr↓: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) it bent; or was, or became, crooked. (A.) One says, fiI Eunuqihi SawarN In his neck is an inclining; and a bending, or crookedness. (A.)
And SawarN as an attribute of a man signifies also ‡ An inclining, or inclination; (Ṣ;) a desiring, or desire. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

entry.sense:
2. Sw-r [inf. n. taSowiyrN,] He formed, fashioned, figured, shaped, sculptured, or pictured, him, or it; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and tSw-r↓ signifies the same; (Mṣb, and Bḍ in iii. 4;) and so does SAr↓, accord. to Aboo-'Alec, in the saying,
banaAhu waSal-aba fiyhi waSaAraA
[Which (referring to a church) he has built, and in which he has made a cross, or crosses, and has made sculptured, or painted, work]. (M.) One says, Saw-arahu Qll-ehu SuwrapF HasanapF [God formed him a goodly, or beautiful, form]. (Ṣ.)
See also 5, in two places.
4: see 1, in three places.

hom.sense: 5. tSw-r He, or it, was, or became, formed, fashioned, figured, shaped, sculptured, or pictured. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA.)
And [hence,] tSw-r liI [and Suw-ira↓ liI, like taxay-ala liI and xuy-ila liI,] It appeared to my mind, or imagination, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) as an image, or a picture. (Mṣb.)
See also 2.
Also He (being pierced with a spear or the like) inclined, to fall: (Ṣ:) or he (being struck) fell: (M, Ḳ:) or he, or it, fell, or alighted. (TA.)

entry.sense: 7. AinoSaAra: see Sawira.
Also It (a thing) became demolished, and cut, or divided, in pieces: (O:) it (a mountain) became demolished, and fell: (Ṣgh, TA:) it cracked, and split. (TA.)
8. ASTArhu He doubled it, or folded it; or he bent it; syn. vanaAhu. (O.)
SaArN: see Say-irN, below, in two places.

SaworN Small palm-trees: (M, Ḳ:) or a collection of small palm-trees: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) a word having no proper sing.: (Ṣ, M:) [but see SaworapN:] pl. SiyraAnN: (Sh, M, Ḳ:) and other trees: pl. as above. (Sh, TA.)
Also The root of a palmtree, (M, Ḳ,) or of a palm-trunk. (M.)
And The bank, or side, of a river or rivulet. (M, Ḳ.)
And The side of the neck. (O,* Ḳ,* TA. [In the CK, wAll-iyti is erroneously put for waAll-iytu.])

And The forelock: so in the saying of a rájiz,
kaOan-a EurofFA maAYilFA mino Saworihi
[As though a mane inclining from his forelock]. (Ṣ.)

SuwrN A horn: (Ṣ, M:) and a horn in which one blows: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) so in the Ḳur [vi. 73, &c.], yawoma yunofaxu fiI QlS-uwri [i. e. On the day when the horn shall be blown in]: El-Kelbee says, I know not what is AlSwr: and it is said to be pl. of SuwrapN, like as busorN is of busorapN; [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which SuwrapN is the n. un.;] i. e., [the phrase means] when the souls shall be blown into the forms of the dead: and El-Ḥasan read fiI AlS-uwari: (Ṣ, L, TA:) this is related on the authority of AO; but AHeyth asserts him to have said wrong. (L, TA.)
SawarN inf. n. of Sawira [q. v.]. (M, A.)
Also An itching (OukaAlN) in the head. (IAạr, TA.) [See also SaworapN.]

hom.sense: SaArapN The head, (O,) or the upper, or uppermost, part, (Ḳ,) of a mountain: (O, Ḳ:) and SuWayorapN [with C] has been heard from the Arabs as its dim. (TA.)
See also SiwaArN.

SaworapN ‡ An inclination, or a desire. (TA.) You say, OaraI laka Uilayohi SaworapF ‡ I see thee to have a loving inclination to him. (A.) And maA biI UilayohaA SaworapN ‡ I have not any inclination to, or desire for, her. (TA, from a trad.)
And An itching, or itch, (Hik-ap,) in the head: (A:) or an affection like Hik-ap in a man's head, occasioning a desire to be loused. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) [See also SawarN.]
And A palm-tree. (IAạr.) [See also SaworN.]

entry.sense: SuwrapN Form, fashion, figure, shape, or semblance; syn. XakolN, (M, Ḳ,) and mivaAlN; (Mṣb;) the external state of a thing; (IAth;) that whereby a thing is sensibly distinguished by men in general, and even by many other animate beings, from other things; as the Swrp of a man, and of a horse, and of an ass. (B.)

And An effigy; an image, or a statue; a picture; anything that is formed, fashioned, figured, or shaped, after the likeness of any of God's creatures, animate or inanimate: it is said that the maker of an effigy, or image, will be punished on the day of resurrection, and will be commanded to put life into it; and that the angels will not enter a house in which is a Swrp. (Mgh.) [See also taSaAwiyru.]
[Hence, A mental image; or a resemblance, of any object, formed, or conceived, by the mind; an idea: a meaning of frequent occurrence in philosophical works, &c.]
And Species; syn. nawoEN. (Ḳ.)

And The essence of a thing; that by being which a thing is what it is; or the property, or quality, or the aggregate of properties or qualities, whereby a thing is what it is; syn. HaqiyqapN: (IAth:) [specific character;] that whereby a thing is mentally distinguished by particular persons, not by the vulgar, from other things; as the Swrp by which a man is specially distinguished, consisting in reason and thought and other distinctive attributes: (B:) a quality, an attribute, a property; or a description, as meaning the aggregate of the qualities or attributes or properties, of a thing; or the state, condition, or case, of a thing; syn. SifapN: (IAth, Mṣb, Ḳ:) as when you say, Suwrapu AlOamori kacaA [The quality,, &c., of the thing is of such a kind]: (IAth, Mṣb:) and Suwrapu AlmasoOalapi kacaA [The description, statement, or form, of the question is of such a kind]: (Mṣb:) and so in the saying of the Prophet, OataAniI All-ayolapa rab-iI fiI OaHosani SuwrapK [My Lord came to me to-night in a most goodly state]; or Swrp may here refer to the Prophet, and may mean external state, or manner of being, or condition. (IAth.)
And The mode, or manner, of an action. (IAth.)
The pl. is SuwarN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SiwarN and SuwrN; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) the second of which is rare, and by some disallowed. (MF.)

The saying of the Prophet xalaqa Qll-ehu Mdama EalaI Suwratihi may mean that God created Adam in the Swrp [or form, &c.] that He, namely, God, originated and ordained; or in the Swrp proper to him, namely, Adam. (M.)

SuwrapN signifies also The face: so in a trad. cited voce muHar-amN; in which it is said that the Swrp is pronounced sacred, i. e. that it is not to be slapped: and in another, in which it is said that the Prophet disliked marking the Swrp with a hot iron. (TA.)
SuwaArN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

hom.sense: SiwaArN A herd of [wild] bulls or cows; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also SuwaArN↓ and SiyaArN↓ [the latter in the CK written Siy-Ar] and Suw-aArN↓ [in some copies of the Ḳ erroneously written SuwaAr, which, as observed in the TA, is a repetition]: (M, Ḳ, TA:) pl. of the first (Ṣ, M) and second and third (M) SiyraAnN. (Ṣ, M.)
Also A sweet odour; and so SuwaArN↓. (M, Ḳ.)

And A vesicle (wiEaMC) of musk; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also SuwaArN↓, (Mṣb,) and SiyaArN↓, (Ṣ,) and SaArapN↓ [also] signifies [the same, i. e.] a faArap or faOorap of musk: (O, Ḳ:) or SiwaArN and SuwaArN↓ signify a small quantity of musk: (M, Ḳ:) or a piece, or portion, thereof: (M:) and SiwaArN signifies also musk [itself]: (TA:) pl. OaSowirapN. (M, Ḳ.) [Said in the M to be Pers.]
AlS-iwaAraAni The two corners of the mouth; (O, Ḳ;) called by the vulgar AlS-aw-aArayon, (O, TA,) or AlS-awaArayon (O in art. Smg.)

entry.sense: SiyaArN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
SuWayorapN [with C] a dim. of SaArapN [q. v.]. (TA.)

Say-irN Goodly in Suwrap [i. e. form, &c.]; (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also SaArN↓. (TA in art. Xwr.) One says rajulN Say-irN Xay-irN (Fr, Ṣ) and SaArN↓ XaArN (TA ubi suprà) A man goodly in Swrp [or form, &c.] and in XaArap [i. e. appearance or apparel, &c.]. (Fr, Ṣ.) [See also Xay-irN in art. Xwr.]
Saw-aArN A sparrow (EuSofuwrN) that answers when called. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.*)
Suw-aArN: see SiwaArN, first sentence.

OaSowaru Inclining: (M, Ḳ:) pl. SuwrN. (M.) One says rajulN OaSowaru A man having an inclining, or a bending, or crooked, neck. (A.) And huwa OaSowaru UilaI kacaA He is inclining his neck and face towards such a thing. (A.)
[And hence,] † Having an inclination, or a desire, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) to, or for, (UilaI,) a friend, or an object of love. (M.)
taSaAwiyru [pl. of taSowiyrN and taSowiyrapN] Effigies, images, or statues; pictures; and the like. (Ṣ, Mgh.) [See also SuwrapN.]

muSaw-irN [A sculptor; and a painter, or limner, or the like]. AlmuSawiru as an epithet of God, The Former, or Fashioner, of all existing things, who hath established them, and given to every one of them a special form and a particular manner of being whereby it is distinguished, with their variety and multitude. (TA.)

1. SuEotuhu, (O, Ḳ,) [from SaAEahu,] aor. OaSuwEuhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. SawoEN, (TA,) I measured it with the SaAE [q. v.]. (O, Ḳ.) One says, hecaA TaEaAmN yuSaAEu i. e. [This is wheat] that is measured [with the SAE]. (O.)

And † [I collected it together, like as the measurer collects the corn, &c. in the measure: and the contr., i. e.] I dispersed it, or scattered it; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) in which sense it is [said to be] tropical; (TA;) and SiEotuhu, aor. OaSiyEuhu, (Ḳ in art. SyE,) inf. n. SayoEN, (TA in that art.,) signifies the same. (Ḳ in that art.) One says, SuEotu AlOaqoraAna, and gayorahumo, ‡ I came to the antagonists, and others, from their sides: (Ḳ, TA:) of a courageous man, or a courageous armed man, one says, yaSuwEu OaqoraAnahu ‡ He comes to his antagonists from their sides; (Ṣ, O, TA;) and the like is cited in the T from Lth; or as meaning he encompasses their sides; (TA;) or he collects together his antagonists (IḲṭṭ, Z, TA) from every side, (IḲṭṭ, TA,) like as the measurer collects together that which is measured: (Z, TA:) and of a man, (Ṣ, O,) or a pastor, (Lth, IḲṭṭ, Z,) yaSuwEu AlUibila, (Ṣ, O,) or maAXiyatahu, (Lth,) or Uibilahu, (IḲṭṭ, Z,) ‡ He comes [to the camels or] to his cattle [or to his camels] from their sides; or he encompasses their sides; (Lth, TA;) or he collects them together (IḲṭṭ, Z, TA) from every side, (IḲṭṭ, TA,) like as the measurer collects together that which is measured: (Z, TA:) but Az says that the foregoing explanations by Lth are wrong; that yaSuwEu OaqoraAnahu, said of a courageous man, or a courageous armed man, means he charges upon his antagonists and disperses them; and yaSuwEu Uibilahu, said of a pastor, he disperses his camels in the place of pasture; and yaSuwEu AlmaEaza, said of a hegoat, he disperses the [she-] goats; and SaAEa Alganama, aor. as above, and so the inf. n., he dispersed the sheep or goats; (TA;) and ASAE↓ Alganama, inf. n. UiSaAEapN, signifies thus likewise: (Lḥ, TA in art. SyE:) Lḥ also says that SuEotu Alganama, aor. OaSuwEuhaA, inf. n. SawoEN, and SiEotuhaA, aor. OaSiyEuhaA, inf. n. SayoEN, both signify I dispersed the sheep or goats: (O in art. SyE:) or, accord. to IḲṭṭ, SAE Uibilahu, said of a pastor, has two contr. meanings; he collected together his camels from every side; and also he dispersed his camels. (TA.)
Also I frightened him. (Ibn-ʼAbbád,* O,* Ḳ.)

And SuEotu Alqawoma, aor. OaSuwEuhumo, (Lḥ, O in art. SyE,) inf. n. SawoEN, (TA in that art.,) I urged, or incited, the people, or party; (Lḥ, O and TA in that art.;) and so SiEotu Alqawoma, (Lḥ, O and Ḳ in that art.,) aor. OaSiyEuhumo, (Lḥ, O ibid.,) inf. n. SayoEN. (TA ibid.)
[And SAE Alkurapa He propelled the ball with the SawolajaAn. (See SaAEN below, last sentence.)]
And SaAEati Aln-aHolu, (Ḳ,) [app. for SAEt AlnHl baEoDuhaA baEoDFA,] aor. taSuwEu, (O,) inf. n. SawoEN, (TA,) The bees followed [as though driving along] one another. (O, Ḳ.)
And SAE AlX-aIoCa, inf. n. SawoEN, He folded, or doubled, the thing; twisted it; or bent it. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

2. Saw-aEato mawoDiEFA, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taSowiyEN, (Ḳ,) She (a woman) prepared a place, such as is termed SaAEap, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and made it even, (TA,) for the separating and loosening of cotton. (O, Ḳ.)
Sw-Et Alr-iyHu Aln-abaAta The wind dried up, or caused to dry up, the plants, or herbage; (O, Ḳ;) as also Saw-aHatohu. (TA.)
Sw-E AlX-aIoCa He made the thing pointed in its head. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
And He rounded the thing in its sides. (O, Ḳ.)

S-wE, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (O,) said of an ass, [meaning a wild ass,] He drove his she asses to the right and left: (O, Ḳ:) so expl. by Ibn-ʼAbbád. (O.) And, said of a horse, He went at random, and resisted his owner [or rider]. (TA.)
Sw-E Uilayohi [said of a man, as is indicated in the O,] He turned about his head towards him: and he turned his face towards him. (O, TA.)
And Sw-E raOosahu, said of a bird, It moved, or moved about, its head. (TA.)
4. ASAE Alganama: see 1, latter half.
5. tSw-E It became dispersed, or scattered; as also AnSAE↓. (Ṣ.) You say, tSw-E Alqawomu The people, or party, became dispersed, or scattered, and remote, all of them, one from another. (O, Ḳ.)
Also, said of hair, It became contracted, and much split: [app. by reason of dryness: like tSw-H:] (Lth, O, Ḳ:) or it became dispersed, or scattered; (Lḥ, O, Ḳ;) and it fell off by degrees. (O, Ḳ.)
And, said of herbage, It became dried up; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) like tSw-H; (O;) as also tSy-E. (Ṣ; and O and Ḳ in art. SyE.)
7. AnSAE: see 5.

Also ‡ He turned away, or back, retreating, or returning, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and went (Ṣ, TA) quickly, or hastening: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) or you say, AnSAE Alqawomu ‡ The people, or party, went away quickly: and mudobirFA ‡ He went away [turning back] quickly. (TA.) [See an ex. voce SaAr-apN.]

And † It (a bird) ascended, or mounted, into the air, between the earth and sky, or into the middle of the sky. (TA in art. SyE, from the book entitled “Ghareeb el- Hamám” by El-Ḥasan Ibn-ʼAbd-Alláh El-Kátib El-Iṣbahánee.)

hom.sense: SaAEN (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SuwEN↓ and SawoEN↓ (O, Ḳ) and SuwaAEN↓ (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and SiwaAEN↓, (O, Ḳ,) thus accord. to five different readers of the Ḳur in xii. 72, (O, Ḳ,* TA,) A certain measure used for measuring corn [& c.], (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and upon which turn [or depend] the decisions of the Muslims [relating to measures of capacity]: (Ḳ:) or the SAE is different from the SuwaAE↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the latter being a certain vessel, in [or from] which one drinks [as will be expl. hereafter in this paragraph]: (Ṣ, TA:) the former is four OamodaAd [pl. of mud-N]; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e. (Mṣb) five OaroTaAl [or pints] and a third, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) by the measure of Baghdád; (Mṣb;) the mud- being a pint and a third: (Ḳ, TA:) so with the people of El-Ḥijáz, (Mgh, TA,) [i. e.] so with the people of the Harameyn, as was proved by a number of specimens of the SAE used in dealings with the Prophet, (Mṣb,) and so accord. to Esh-Sháfiʼee: (TA:) but with the people of El-'Irák it was eight pints, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) with whom agreed Aboo-Ḥaneefeh; the mud- with them being two pints; (Mṣb, TA;) but the addition was made by El-Hajjáj; and their SAE was the qafiyz Haj-aAjiI-, and was unknown to the people of El-Medeeneh, as is said by Az: (Mṣb:) accord. to Ed-Dáwoodee, its invariable measure is four times the quantity [of corn & c.] that fills the two hands, that are neither large nor small, of a man; for the SAE of the Prophet is not found in every place; and this (the author of the Ḳ says, TA) I have tried, and found to be correct: (Ḳ, TA:) the word is masc. and fem.: (Zj, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) accord. to Fr, the people of El-Ḥijáz make it fem.; and Benoo-Asad, except some of them, make it masc., as do the people of Nejd; and Zj says that the more chaste way is to make it masc.: (Mṣb:) the pl. (of pauc., used by those who make the sing. fem., O, Mṣb) is OaSowuEN, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) for which one may say OaSoWuEN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,*) changing the w into hemzeh, (Ṣ, O,) and accord. to AAF some say MSuEN, like MdurN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) a pl. of daArN, (Mgh,) but AḤát says that this is a vulgar mistake, (Mṣb,) and OaSowaAEN, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is used by those who make the sing. masc., (O, Mṣb,) and [of mult.] SuwEN, (Ḳ,) which is app. pl. of SiwaAEN↓, with kesr, (TA,) and SiyEaAnN, (Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is [likewise] a pl. of mult., (Mṣb,) or this last is pl. of SuwaAEN↓: and this sing. signifies a [vessel of the kind called] jaAm, [app. here used in the sense which this word commonly has in Pers., i. e. as meaning a cup,] in which, (Ḳ, TA,) or from which, (TA,) one drinks: (Ḳ, TA:) Saʼeed Ibn-Jubeyr says that the SwAE of the king [mentioned in the Ḳur xii. 72] was the Persian mak-uwk, of which the two extremities [are compressed so that they] meet together [app. in such a manner that the whole vessel resembles a small boat, the word mk-wk being expl. in several dictionaries as applied to a drinking-vessel of this form, probably from the Pers. mak-uwko signifying “a shuttle” and used in this sense in modern Arabic]: El-Ḥasan says that the SuwaAE and the siqaAyap are one thing, as Zj also says; and that the SwAE of the king is said to have been of wariq [meaning silver], and that they used to measure with it and sometimes they drank with it: Zj says that it is explained as an oblong vessel, resembling the mak-uwk, with which the king used to drink; and said by some to have been of mis- [which (as is said in the TA in art. ms) means copper, from the Pers. miso]. (TA.) [See also SawogN, with g.]
SaAEN signifies also † The place [or plot] in which a SAE [of seed] is sown: so in a trad. (TA.)

And ‡ A depressed piece of ground; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) as also SaAEapN↓; (O, Ḳ, TA;) like an excavation: or, as some say, a depressed place, sloping down from its surrounding borders: (TA:) or a narrow, depressed place. (TA in art. TO.)

And † A place that is swept and in which one then plays: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:) [see the verse cited in what follows:] and SaAEapN↓ is said to signify a piece of ground which a boy sweeps, removing its pebbles, and in which he plays with the ball: and a bare place, in which is nothing. (TA.)

And The place of the breast of the ostrich when she puts it upon the ground: (Ḳ:) or such a place is called SaAEu juWojuWi Aln-aEaAmi. (IF, O.) And one says, Darabahu fiI SaAEi juWujuWihi and fI SAEi Sadorihi meaning ‡ He struck him in the middle of his breast. (Z, TA.)

[And it is said that] SaAEN also signifies The [kind of goffstick called] SawolajaAn. (Ḳ.) In the following verse of El-Museiyab Ibn-'Alas, describing a she-camel,
mariHato yadaAhaA liln-ajaMCi kaOan-amaA
takoruw bikaf-aIo laAEibK fiI SaAEi
[the most obvious meaning of which is, Her fore legs moved briskly for the purpose of hastening, as though she were propelling a ball with the hands of a player in a piece of ground cleared for that exercise,] or, as some relate it, bikaf-aIo maAqiTK, meaning with the hands of a player with the ball, it is said by some that he means biSaAEK, [though it is not easy to see why, if so, he did not say biAlS-aAEi,] and that by the SAE he means the SawolajaAn, because it is bent (yuEoTafu [see 1, last sentence,]) for the purpose of striking with it, that the ball may be propelled (tuSaAEu) with it. (O.)

entry.sense: SawoEN and SuwEN: see SaAEN, first sentence.
The latter is also a pl., (Ḳ, TA,) app. of SiwaAEN, with kesr. (TA.)
SuwaEN Portions of herbage beginning to dry up. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
And of the flesh of a horse, Such as is scattered, or sparse; not collected together in one place. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)
SaAEapN: see SaAEN, latter half, in two places.

Also ‡ A place prepared by a woman for the separating and loosening of cotton: (Lth, O, Ḳ, TA:) and † a skin, like a niToE, which a woman sometimes makes, or prepares, for the separating and loosening of cotton and of wool upon it. (ISh, O, TA.)
And ‡ A place specially made, or prepared, for guests. (Z, TA.)
SuwaAEN and SiwaAEN: see SaAEN, former half, in five places.
OuSay-aAEN occurs as a dim. of SiyEaAnN [or rather of OaSowaAEN, pl. of SaAEN, regularly formed therefrom]. (IB, TA.)
munoSaAEN [part. n. of 7] Turning away or back, retreating,, &c. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. SaAgahu, (Ṣ, MA, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaSuwgu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) inf. n. SawogN (Ṣ, MA, O, Mṣb) and SuwaAgN (TA) and SiyaAgapN, (MA,) [or the last is a simple subst.,] He melted it, and poured it forth into a mould; (TA;) he cast it, molten, in a mould: (PṢ:) he made, formed, fashioned, or moulded, it, by the goldsmith's art; namely, an ornament [and the like]: (MA: [this last is the most usual meaning:]) or he prepared it, (Ḳ, TA,) and cast it, (TA,) namely, a thing, after the pattern of a right model. (Ḳ, TA.) One says of a man, SaAga Alc-ahaba Huliy-FA [He cast the gold so as to make of it ornaments; or he made, formed, fashioned, or moulded, the gold into ornaments]. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] SaAgahu Qll-ehu SiygapF HasanapF ‡ God created him (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) in a goodly mode, or manner, of creation. (O, TA.) And Siyga EalaI Siygatihi ‡ He was created after his [i. e. another's] mode, or manner, of creation. (TA.)
And SAg, or kalaAmFA, ‡ He composed, and adjusted, poetry, or speech, discourse, or language. (TA.)

And yaSuwguwna AlkalaAma ‡ They alter speech, [embellish it with lies,] and falsify it, or forge it. (TA.) And fulaAnN yaSuwgu Alkaciba, (Ṣ O, Mṣb,* TA,) inf. n. SawogN, (Mṣb,) ‡ Such a one forges, or fabricates, that which is false, or untrue: (O, Mṣb:*) a metaphorical phrase. (Ṣ.) And SAg fulaAnN zuwrFA and kacibFA ‡ Such a one forged, or fabricated, a lie, a falsehood, or an untruth. (TA.) And Sawogu All-isaAni means † The lying of the tongue. (Ḥar p. 605.)
SAg, aor. yaSuwgu, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. SawogN, (O,) also signifies It sank into the ground, said of water; and into the food, said of sauce, or seasoning: (O, Ḳ:) so says ISh. (TA.)
And SAg lahu AlX-araAbu The beverage, or wine, was easy and agreeable to him to swallow; i. q. sAg, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,) as a dial. var. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)

entry.sense: 5. tSw-g: see what next follows {7}.

7. AnSAg quasi-pass. of SaAgahu [in all its senses, proper and tropical: meaning It was, or became, melted, and poured forth into a mould;, &c.: and in like manner Freytag explains tSw-g↓ as used in the book entitled “Les oiseaux et les fleurs,” p. 7, meaning “formatus, fictus fuit;” but this is app. post classical]. (O, Ḳ.)
SawogN inf. n. of SaAgahu [q. v.]. (Ṣ, &c.)

[In the Ḳur xii. 72,] some read nafoqidu Sawoga Almaliki [meaning We miss, or see not, or find not, the King's molten vessel, or vessel made of melted metal]: in this instance, Sawog is an inf. n. (O, Ḳ, TA) used as a subst., (O, TA,) in the sense of AlmaSuwg↓, which means maASiyga [i. e. the thing that has been melted, and poured forth into a mould;, &c.]; like AlmuSaAgu↓ [a pass. part. n. of a verb which is not mentioned]: (TA:) it is like Darob in the phrase hecaA dirohamN Darobu AlOamiyri, (O, Ḳ,* TA,) meaning maDoruwbuhu: (O, TA:) and Er-Rághib says that it [i. e. the vessel thus termed] is held to have been made of molten gold: (TA:) some read [in the Ḳur xii. 72] SuwaAg↓, as though this also were [originally] an inf. n. (O, Ḳ, TA) from SaAga, (O, TA,) like buwaAlN and quwaAmN (O, Ḳ, TA) from baAla and qaAma. (O, TA.) [See also SaAEN, with the unpointed E.]

One says also, hecaA Sawogu hecaA This is of the measure of this; or is the like in measure of this: [as though of the make, form, fashion, mould, or cast, of this: (see also SiygapN:)] (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) and hecaA AlmaMCu Sawogu AlUinaMCi This water is of the measure of the vessel; or is the like in measure of the vessel: and everything that is the like in measure of another thing is said to be Sawoguhu. (O.)
And humaA SawogaAni They two are likes: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or they two are coëtaneans; syn. lidapN [which is properly a sing., though here used as a dual]. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.)

And huwa Sawogu Oaxiyhi (AA, O, Ḳ) He is he who was born immediately after his brother; and [in like manner, before him, for] he may be above him and he may be below him, (O,) like sawoguhu; as also Sawogapu↓ Oaxiyhi, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Auxotihi,]) like sawogapu Oaxiyhi: (TA:) and hiIa Ouxotuka Sawoguka and Sawogatuka↓ [She is thy sister who was born immediately after thee; or before thee]: (O, TA:) the pl. is OaSowaAgN. (TA voce sawogN.)
SawogapN: see the last sentence here preceding, in two places.

SiygapN is originally SiwogapN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) the w being changed into I because of the kesreh before it: (Ṣ O:) it is like qiymapN. (Mṣb.) [Its primary signification is A mode, or manner, of Sawog i. e. melting, and pouring forth into a mould;, &c.: and hence it signifies a make, form, fashion, mould, or cast:] and it is syn. with SiyaAgapN, q. v.: (TA:) and signifies the making [a thing]; and making according to a certain measure or proportion [and the like]. (Mṣb.) One says sihaAmN SiygapN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) Arrows [one in make;] uniform; (TA;) of the make of one man. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* TA.) And Siygapu Qll-ehi, meaning † The creation of God. (Mṣb.) And huwa Hasanu AlS-iygapi ‡ He is goodly in respect of make and of stature: or this means huwa Hasanu AlEamali [which may in this case be correctly rendered he is goodly in respect of make: and also he is good in respect of work]. (TA.) And huwa mino SiygapK kariymapK ‡ He is of a generous origin. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Z, O, Ḳ, TA.) And Siygapu Alqawoli kacaA ‡ The mode, manner, fashion, or form, of the saying is thus. (Mṣb.) And Siygapu AlOamori kacaA wakacaA † The shape of the affair, or case, is thus and thus. (TA.)
SayoguwgapN: see SiyaAgapN.
SuwaAgN: see SawogN, second sentence.

SiyaAgapN The craft, or art, (Ḳ, TA,) or work, or operation, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,* TA,) of the SaAYig [q. v.]; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) [generally meaning the craft or art, or the work or operation, of the goldsmith;] the act of melting [gold, &c.], and pouring [it] forth into a mould; [&c.; (see 1, first sentence;)] as also SiygapN↓ and SayoguwgapN↓, this last mentioned by Lḥ. (TA.)
Saw-aAgN: see the next paragraph, in five places.

SaAYigN and Saw-aAgN↓ (Ṣ, MA, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL) and Say-aAgN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, KL,) the last of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, (Ṣ, O,) originally SayowaAgN, (IJ, O, TA,) thus altered by some, from SayowaAgN to Say-aAgN, because of their disliking the double w, (IJ, TA,) One who practises, or performs, the craft, art, work, or operation, termed SiyaAgap [or melting gold, &c., and pouring it forth into a mould;, &c.; as expl. in the first sentence of this art.]; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) [generally meaning] a goldsmith, or worker in gold: (MA, KL:) the pl. of SaAYigN is SaAgapN [originally SawagapN] and Suw-aAgN and Suy-aAgN. (TA.) One says, huwa Saw-aAgu↓ AlHuliI-i [and SaAYiguhaA i. e. He is the moulder of ornaments, or of women's ornaments, of gold or of silver, &c.]. (TA.) [And hence miloHu AlS-aAgapi lit. Goldsmiths' salt; meaning chrysocolla, i. e. borax: thus termed in the language of the present day.] Aboo-Ráfi' the SaAYig is related to have said, kaAna Eumaru yumaAziHuniI yaquwlu Oakocabu Aln-aAsi AlS-aw-aAgu↓ yaquwlu Alyawoma wagadFA [ʼOmar used to jest with me, saying, The most lying of men is the goldsmith, who says, To-day, and Tomorrow]. (TA.) And kacibapN kacabahaA AlS-aw-aAguwna↓ [lit. A lie which the goldsmiths have told] is a saying (of Aboo-Hureyreh, O) occurring in a trad. (Ṣ, O.)

[Hence,] the pl. Suw-aAgN means ‡ Persons who alter speech, [embellish it with lies,] and falsify it, or forge it: and Saw-aAgN↓, ‡ one who moulds speech, and falsifies it, or embellishes it with lies: (TA:) and [in like manner] Say-igN↓, (O, Ḳ, TA,) originally SayowigN, (TA,) ‡ one who lies much, and embellishes his speech [with lies]: (Ḳ, O, TA:) the pl. of this last is SaAgapN, like saAdapN pl. of say-idN. (TA.) [See also Sab-aAgN.]
Say-igN, originally SayowigN: see the next preceding paragraph, last explanation.
Say-igapN i. q. variydapN [A mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth and piled up in the middle of a bowl]. (Fr, O, Ḳ.)
Say-aAgN, originally SayowaAgN: see SaAYigN.
OaSoyagu [as though originally OaSowagu, being mentioned in this art.,] Water such as is common (EaAm- [app. meaning to all who desire to take of it]), and much in quantity. (IAạr, TA,)
maSaAgN, [as a coll. gen. n.,] with fet-ḥ, Moulded ornaments or women's ornaments, of gold or the like; syn. HuliI-N maSuwgapN. (TA.)
muSaAgN: see SawogN, second sentence.
maSuwgN: see SawogN, second sentence.

hom.sense: 1. SaAfa, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. yaSuwfu, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. SawofN and SuWuwfN; and Sawifa, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. SawafN; (Ṣ;) He (a ram) had much Suwf [or wool], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) after having little thereof. (Ṣ, O.)

SAf Als-ahomu Eani Alhadafi, aor. yaSuwfu and yaSiyfu, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. SawofN and SayofN and SayofuwfapN, (O and Ḳ in art. Syf,) The arrow turned aside from the butt: (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) like DAf. (Ṣ and O in art. Dyf.) And SAf Ean-iI wajohuhu His face turned away from me. (Ḳ.) And SAf Ean-iI Xar-uhu, (Ṣ, M, O,) aor. yaSuwfu, inf. n. SawofN, (M,) His (a man's, Ṣ, O) evil, or mischief, turned away from me. (Ṣ,* M, O.*)

entry.sense: 2. Sw-f Alkaromu The grape-vine showed its fruitstalks [anew] after the cutting off of its fruit- (M,)
4. ASAf Qll-ehu Ean-iI Xar-ahu God turned away, or may God turn away, from me his evil, or mischief. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Mentioned also in art. Syf.]
5. tS-wf He became a SuwfiI-: (Mṣb:) he devoted himself to religious exercises; or applied himself to devotion: or he asserted himself to do so: (TA:) but it is post-classical. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: SaAfN (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) and SaAYifN↓ (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SaAfK↓, (M, O, Ḳ,) which last is formed by transposition [from the second], (M,) and SawifN↓ (M, O, Ḳ) and OaSowafu↓ (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SuwfaAnN↓ (AHeyth, TA) and SuwfiAniI-N↓, (M, O, Ḳ,) A ram having much Suwf [or wool]: (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) fem. with p {SaAfapN}, (Ḳ, [in which it seems to refer only to the last, i. e.]) the fem. epithet is SuwfaAniy-apN↓, (O,) or SuwfaAnapN↓, (AHeyth, and so in a copy of the M,) and SaAfapN also. (M.)
And lim-apN SaAfapN [A lock of hair hanging down below the lobe of the ear] of which the hair is like Suwf [i. e. wool]. (M.)
See also SuwfN.
And see art. Syf.

entry.sense: SaAfK: see the next preceding paragraph.

SuwfN [Wool;] an appertenance of sheep, (in the Ṣ lilX-aApi, in the M liloganami, and in the O and Mṣb [more definitely] lilD-aOoni,) which is to them like XaEarN to goats and wabarN to camels: (M:) [in the Ḳ only said to be well know:] n. un. SuwfapN, (M,) [i. e.] this latter has a more particular signification [meaning a portion, flock, tuft, or wisp, of wool]: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and sometimes SuwfN is used in the sense of the n. un., as mentioned by Sb: (M:) the pl. of SuwfN is OaSowaAfN [meaning sorts of wool]: (M:) and the dim. of the n. un. is SuwayofapN↓. (TA.) One says xaroqaMCu wajadato SuwfFA [An unskilful woman that has found wool]: (Aṣ, O, Ḳ:) a prov. (Aṣ, O) relating to property possessed by such as does not deserve to have it: (Aṣ, TA:) because the unskilful woman, when she lights upon wool, mars it, (O, Ḳ,) not spinning it well: (O:) applied to the stupid person who finds property and wastes it; (O, Ḳ;) or to him who finds that of which he knows not the value, and wastes it. (Z, TA.) And one says, fulaAnN yalobasu AlS-uwfa waAlquTona, meaning Such a one wears what is made of wool and of cotton. (A, TA.) In the saying of a poet,
HalobaAnapK rakobaAnapK Safuwfi
taxoliTu bayona wabarK waSuwfi
[Of one that is milked and ridden, that yields a row of bowls of her milk, (but see SafuwfN, of which other explanations have been given,) that mingles camels' fur and wool], the latter hemistich means, as Th says, accord. to IAạr, that is sold, and with the price whereof are purchased camels and sheep: or, accord. to Aṣ, that is quick in her pace; the drawing back of her fore legs being likened to [the motion of] the bow of the nad-aAf who mixes camels' fur and wool. (M.) One says also, Oaxacotu biSuwfi raqabatihi (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, but in the M Oaxaca,) and biSuwfatihaA (M, O) and biSaAfihaA↓, (M, Ḳ,) and biTuwfi raqabatihi and biTaAfihaA, and biZuwfi zaqabatihi and biZaAfihaA, and biquwfi raqabatihi and biqaAfihaA, (Ṣ, O,) meaning ‡ [I laid hold upon] the pendent hair in the hollow of the back of his neck: (IDrd, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) or the downy hairs upon the back of his neck: (M, O:) or the skin of his neck: (IAạr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or the back of his neck, altogether: (Fr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or I took him by force: (Abu-l-Ghowth, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or I followed him, thinking that I should not reach him, and overtook him; and this one says whether he lay hold upon his neck or not. (Abu-s-Semeyda', Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And OaEoTaAhu biSuwfi raqabatihi ‡ [He gave it altogether]; like OaEoTaAhu birum-atihi: or (as expl. by A' Obeyd, Ṣ, O) he gave it gratuitously; not taking a price. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

Suwfu AlbaHori [lit. The wool of the sea] is a thing [or substance] in the form of the animal Suwf [i. e., of wool; evidently meaning sea-weed resembling wool; such as is found in abundance thrown up on the beaches of the Red Sea: and that this is generally, if not in every instance, meant by the identical Hebrew word סוּף, as used in the Bible, has been most satisfactorily shown in art. “Red Sea” (by my deeply-lamented nephew Edward Stanley Poole) in Dr. William Smith's “Dictionary of the Bible”]: it is said in one of the Oabadiy-aAt, [see art. Abd,] laA Mtiyka maA bal-a baHorN SuwfapF [I will not come to thee as long as a sea wets a portion of Suwf], or, as Lḥ relates it, maA bal-a AlbaHoru Suwfahu [as long as the sea wets its Suwf; meaning, ever]. (M, TA.)
SawifN: see SaAfN.

hom.sense: SuwfapN n. un. of SuwfN [q. v.]. (M, &c.)
[Also applied by physicians to A pessary, or suppository, of wool, containing a medicament of some kind, to be inserted into the vagina or rectum.]

Also Any of those who had the management of aught of the work of the bayot [meaning the House of God, i. e. the Kaabeh], and who were called AlS-uwfaAnu↓: (M:) [accord. to the TA, it is said that AlS-uwfaAnu and AlS-uwfapu are both alike appel-lations applied to any of such persons:] J and others say that SuwfapN was the father of a tribe of Mudar, who used to serve the Kaabeh, and to return with the pilgrims from 'Arafát, in the Time of Ignorance; and it is implied in the Ṣ [that they were also called Mlu SuwfaAna, or] that Suwfap was also called SuwfaAn; and in a saying of Z, that AlS-uwfaAn and Mlu SuwfaAn were appellations of one and the same people: [hence, app., the applications of SuwfapN and SuwfaAnN to any servants of the Kaabeh:] but accord. to Ṣgh and the Ḳ, Mlu SuwfaAna is a mistake for Mlu SafowaAna. (TA.)
SuwfaAnN and its fem. with p {SuwfaAnapN}: see SaAfN:
and for the former see also SuwfapN.

Also [A species of agaric, i. e., of the kind of fungus thus called;] a certain thing [or substance] that comes forth from the heart of trees, flaccid and dry, in which fire is struck, and which is the best of things for the purpose of those who strike fire. (TA.)

entry.sense: SuwfaAnapN, applied to a ewe, is fem. of SuwfaAnN: see SaAfN. (AHeyth, TA.)

Also A certain herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolapN,) downy, (M, Ḳ,) and short, (Ḳ,) mentioned by Aboo-Naṣr as of the kind termed OaHoraAr [pl. of Hur-N], but not specifically described by him. (AḤn, M.)

SuwfiI-N, a post-classical word, A man of the people called the Suwfiy-ap: (Mṣb:) [formerly applied to any devotee: afterwards, particularly, to a mystic; one who seeks to raise himself to a high degree of spiritual excellence by contemplation of divine things so as to elicit the mysteries thereof:] the Suwfiy-ap may be so called [from the Greek σοφὸς: or] in relation to the people called Mlu SuwfaAn, [see SuwfapN,] as resembling them in the devotion of themselves to religious exercises: or in relation to those called Oaholu AlS-uf-api, wherefore they are also called AlS-uf-iy-apu: or in relation to AlS-uwf [i. e. wool], which is proper to devotees and recluses: this last is the derivation commonly received. (TA.)
SuwayofapN dim. of SuwfapN, n. un. of SuwfN, q. v. (TA.)
Saw-aAfN A manufacturer of Suwf [or wool, or of woollen garments, &c.]. (TA.)
SaAYifN: see SaAfN.
Say-ifapN, originally SayowifapN, A [garment of the kind called] jub-ap having much Suwf [or wool]. (TA.)
OaSowafu: see SaAfN.

1. SaAka bihi, (O, Ḳ,) aor. yaSuwku, (O,) inf. n. SawokN, (Ḳ,) It stuck, or clave, to him, or it: (O, Ḳ;) said of saffron, (Ḳ,) and of blood, and of other things: (TA:) and (O, Ḳ) so SAk bh, aor. yaSiyku, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, in art. Syk,) inf. n. SayokN; (Ḳ;) said of perfume. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) See also SaYika.
5. tSw-k fiI rajiyEihi, (Aṣ, O, Ḳ,) or, accord. to AZ, tDw-k, with D, (O,) or both, (Lḥ, TA in art. Sf,) [and tSwq,] He (a man, O) became defiled, or befouled, with [or in] his dung. (O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: SawokN The seminal fluid of a man. (Th, Kr, Ḳ.)

Also The first. (Ḳ.) One says, laqiytuhu Oaw-ala SawokK and buwokK I met him the first thing. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And in like manner, AifoEalohu Oaw-ala kul-i SawokK and bawokK [Do thou it the first of everything]. (TA.) And xuco hecaA Oaw-ala SawokK: see 1 in art. Sk. (O and TA in that art.)
Also Motion: so in the phrase maA bihi SawokN and bawokN [There is not in him, or it, any motion]. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: SaAYikN Sticking, or cleaving. (AA, TA.)
And [app. as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant] Sticking blood: or blood of the jawof [or belly,, &c.]. (TA.)
See also art. SOk.

hom.sense:
1. SaAla Ealayohi, [aor. yaSuwlu,] inf. n. SawolN and SawolapN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and SiyaAlN, (O,) He leaped, or sprang, upon him: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:)
and (Ḳ) SaAla Ealayohi, (M, Ḳ,) aor. yaSuwlu, (TA,) inf. n. SawolN and SiyaAlN and SuWuwlN and SawalaAnN and SaAlN and maSaAlapN, he sprang, or rushed, upon him; made an assault, or attack, upon him; namely, his adversary, or antagonist; syn. saTaA; (M, Ḳ, TA;) and Hamala: (TA:) [or he sprang upon him and seized him violently or laid violent hands upon him; for so saTaA is said to signify:] and SAl Ealayohi ‡ he overbore him, overpowered him, or subdued him; (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb,* TA; [a meaning also assigned to saTaA;]) namely, one man another nam. (TA.) [See also 1 in art. Syl.] One says, rub-a qawolK OaXad-u mino SawolK Many a saying is more severe than a leaping or springing [&c.]. (Ṣ, O.) And it is said in a trad. respecting prayer, bika OaSuwlu, meaning [By Thee may I] spring, or rush, or assault, and subdue. (TA.)

SAl, aor. as above, inf. n. SawolN, is also said of a stallion [camel], meaning He leaped, or sprang: or, accord. to AZ, SAl, inf. n. SawolN and SiyaAlN, said of a camel, means he leaped, or sprang, upon the [other] camels, and fought them: (Mṣb:) or one says of a stallion, SAl EalaI AlUibili, inf. n. SawolN, meaning he fought the [other] camels, (M, Ḳ,) and sent them on before: (M:) or, accord. to AZ, one says of a camel, (Ṣ,) or, accord. to Es-Sarakustee, some of the Arabs say of a camel, (Mṣb,) SaWula, (Ṣ, Mṣb, [in one of my copies of the Ṣ SAl, but the former is the right,]) like qaruba, (Mṣb,) with C, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. SaOlapN, meaning he betook himself to the killing of men, and springing, or rushing, upon them: (Ṣ) and without C in speaking of the act of one adversary, or antagonist, against another: (Mṣb:) Hamzeh El-Iṣbahánee says, in his “Proverbs,” that SAl Aljamalu means the camel bit; but he is alone in saying this. (TA.) One says also, SAl AlEayoru, meaning The he-ass attacked the she-ass: (Ṣ, O:) or SAl AlEayoru EalaI AlEaAnapi the heass drove away the she-ass, or the herd of wild she-asses, (M, Ḳ, TA,) and attacked her or them, biting her or them with the fore teeth, and kicking her or them with the hind leg or hind legs. (TA.)

SAl Albur-a, aor. as above, inf. n. SawolN, He swept away, or cleared, the wheat from the pieces of stick and of rubbish: and Saw-alonaA↓ AlHinoTapa we swept the wheat [well, and so cleared it from rubbish]: the teshdeed denotes intensiveness of meaning: (O:) Alt-aSowiylu↓ [or taSowiylu Albayodari] means the sweeping of the bayodar [or collected wheat or grain, or perhaps the place in which wheat or grain is trodden out], (O,) or of the sides thereof (nawaAHiI Albayodari [to clear it of rubbish]). (Ḳ.)
Siyla: see art. Syl.

entry.sense: 2. Sw-l, and its inf. n.: see 1, last sentence but one.

taSowiylN also signifies The extracting a thing by means of water: (Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, bAlmAli is erroneously put for biAlmaMCi:]) like the extracting a pebble from rice [by washing]. (TA.) [And app. The soaking a thing to extract the juice or bitterness, &c.: see miSowalN. See also an ex. in De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., vol. ii. p. 130 of the Ar. text; and see his remarks thereon in p. 335 of the transl. and notes.]

[Also The mixing, and stirring about, and beating, a thing.] One says, AljaraAdu yuSaw-alu fiI miXowaAhu [in the CK maXwAhu, which is a mistranscription,] The locusts are mixed, and stirred about, and beaten, in his miXowaI (O, Ḳ) i. e. frying-pan. (TḲ.)

3. muSaAwalapN and SiyaAlN and SiyaAlapN↓ [of which the first and second are inf. ns., the third being a quasi-inf. n.,] are syn. with muwaAvabapN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) SaAwalahu signifying waAvabahu [i. e. He leaped, or sprang, upon him; or he assaulted, or assailed, him: or he contended with him, each leaping, or springing, upon the other, or each assaulting, or assailing, the other]. (Ḳ.) [See also 6.]
6. AlfaHolaAni yataSaAwalaAni i. q. yatawaAvabaAni [i. e. The two stallion-camels leap, or spring, upon each other; or assault, or assail, each other]. (Ṣ.)

SawolapN is an inf. n.: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ: [see 1, first sentence:]) or it signifies A leap, or spring: (TA:) or a single act of a camel's leaping, or springing, upon [other] camels, and fighting them; as also SiyaAlapN↓: (Mṣb:) [but more commonly, impetuosity, of a man, and of a camel or the like.]
[Hence,] cuw SawolapK fiI Almizowadi One who springs upon the food, and devours it immoderately. (M, TA.*)
laqiytuhu Oaw-ala SawolapK means Oaw-ala waholapK [i. e. I met him the first thing, or the first thing that I saw]. (A, TA.)

SuwlapN mino HinoTapK and HinoTapN muSaw-alapN↓ [signify nearly the same, the former meaning A heap of wheat, and the latter wheat in general, cleared from rubbish by means of the implement called miSowalap or miSowal]: (O, Ḳ: [these significations are clearly indicated in the Ḳ, and more so in the O, by the context:]) the pl. of SuwlapN is SuwalN. (O.)
SiylapN, mentioned here in the Ḳ: see art. Syl.

SaWuwlN A camel that devours his pastor; that springs upon men, and devours them: (Lth, TA:) a camel that kills men, and springs, or rushes, upon them: (Ṣ:) or a camel that leaps, or springs, upon the [other] camels, and fights them: (Mṣb:) or a stallion that fights the [other] camels, (M, Ḳ,) and sends them on before. (M.) And † A man who beats others, and overbears, overpowers, or subdues, them. (TA.) Accord. to Az, it is originally without C, and is app. pronounced with C because the w is with damm. (TA.)
SiyaAlN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
[And also an inf. n. of 3, q. v.]
SiyaAlapN: see 3: and see also SawolapN.
OaSowalu mino jamalK [More impetuous than a camel; or more wont to spring upon others, or to assault, or assail, them, than a camel]. (TA.)
miSowalN A thing in which colocynths are soaked in order that their bitterness may depart. (AZ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And, accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, An implement with which the ears of corn are swept away, or cleared, from the pieces of stick and of rubbish. (O. [See also what next follows.])

miSowalapN A broom (mikonasapN, O, Ḳ) with which the sides of the bayodar [or collected wheat or grain, or perhaps the place in which wheat or grain is trodden out,] are swept [to clear it of rubbish]: (O, TA:) so says IAạr. (TA. [See also what next precedes.])
HinoTapN muSaw-alapN: see SuwlapN mino HinoTapK.
SawolajN and SawolajapN: see what here follows

SawolajaAnN (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) and SawolajaAnapN↓ (Sb, TA) and SawolajN↓ (T, TA) and SawolajapN↓, (TA,) as also Saw-ajaAnN, (L in art. Swj,) [A kind of goff-stick, or golf-stick, played with by men on horseback;] a stick with a curved, or crooked, end; syn. miHojanN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [or rather] a stick of which the end is curved [artificially] with which a ball is struck by men on horseback: a stick of which the end curves, or crooks, naturally, on its tree, is called miHojanN: (T, TA:) of Pers. origin, (Ṣ,) [i. e. from the Pers. JawoGaAno,] arabicized: (T, Ṣ:) pl. SawaAlijapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the p being added in the pl. because of the foreign origin, (Ṣ, M, TA,) as is mostly the case in broken pls. of words of foreign origin. (M, TA.)
SawolajaAnapN: see the next paragraph here preceding.

hom.sense: 1. SaAma, (Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. yaSuwmu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. SawomN, and SiyaAmN; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AiSoTaAma↓; (M, Ḳ;) He abstained, (Mṣb, TA,) in an absolute sense: (Mṣb:) this is the primary signification: (TA:) [or] this is said to be the signification in the proper language of the Arabs: (Mṣb:) and in the language of the law, (Mṣb, TA,) he observed a particular kind of abstinence; (Mṣb;) i. e. (TA) he abstained from food (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA) and drink (M, Ḳ, TA) and coïtus: (M, Ḳ:) and (Ṣ,* M, &c.) by a tropical application, (TA,) ‡ from speech: (Ṣ,* M, Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA:) or SawomN in the proper language of the Arabs signifies a man's abstaining from eating: and by a secondary application, a particular serving of God [by fasting]; (Mgh;) [i. e.] the abstaining from eating and drinking and coïtus from daybreak to sunset: (KT:) accord. to Kh, it signifies [properly] the standing without work. (Ṣ.) SAm AlX-ahora means SAm fiI AlX-ahori [He fasted during the month]: agreeably with what is said in the Ḳur ii. 181. (TA.) And it is said (Ṣ, M) by I’Ab (Ṣ) that the saying, in the Ḳur [xix. 27], (Ṣ, M,) Uin-iI nacarotu lilr-aHomeni SawomFA means † [Verily I have vowed unto the Compassionate] an abstaining from speech. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb.) One says also, SAm Alfarasu, inf. n. SawomN (Ṣ, M) and SiyaAmN, (M,) † The horse stood without eating of fodder; (Ṣ;) or abstained from the eating of fodder. (M, A, Mgh.) And SAm Eani Als-ayori ‡ He abstained from going along, or journeying. (TA.)
[Hence,] SAmt AlX-amosu † The sun became [apparently] stationary [in the mid-heaven]: (T, TA:) or attained its full height. (M, TA.)
And SAm Aln-ahaAru, (inf. n. SawomN, Ṣ,) ‡ The day reached its midpoint. (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ, TA.)
And SAmt Alr-iyHu, (M, TA,) inf. n. SawomN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ The wind became still, or calm. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA.)
And SAm AlmaMCu, [inf. n. SiyaAmN (see SulaAqapN) and probably SawomN also,] † The water became still, or motionless; syn. qaAma and daAma. (TA.)

And SAm Aln-aEaAmu, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. SawomN, (M,) ‡ The ostrich cast forth its dung; (M, Ḳ, TA;) and in the same sense the verb is used in relation to the domestic fowl; because each stands still in doing this, or because each becomes tranquil by reason of the passing forth of that which occasions annoyance: and accord. to [some one or more of the copies of] the M, SAm Aln-ahaAru, inf. n. SawomN, The nhAr, by which is here meant the young one of the karawaAn, [or rather of the bustard called HubaAraI,] cast forth what was in its belly. (TA.)
SAm maniy-atahu i. q. caAqahaA [He tasted, or experienced, his death]. (Ḳ.)
And SaAma He (a man) shaded himself by means of the tree called Sawom. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1, first sentence.

hom.sense: SawomN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, M, &c.)

[Hence,] AlS-awomu [app. for waqotu AlS-awomi] means also ‡ [The month of] Ramadán: (Ḳ, TA:) whence the saying of Aboo-Zeyd, Oaqamotu biAlbaSorapi Sawomayoni, meaning [I remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in El-Basrah] two Ramadáns. (TA.)

And [in like manner] SawomN also means † A Christian church; syn. biyEapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) as though for maHal-u AlS-awomi i. e. Alwaqofi [the place of station: for, as Hooker says, speaking of the ancient usage of the Church, “their manner was to stand at prayer, whereupon their meetings unto that purpose had the names of stations given them”]. (TA.)
See also SaAYimN.
Also † The dung of the ostrich. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

And, in the dial. of Hudheyl, (Ṣ,) Certain trees, (Ṣ, M,) or a certain tree, (Ḳ,) [but] the n. un. is with p {SawomapN}, of the form of the figure of a human being, (M,) ugly in appearance, (M, Ḳ,) very much so, the fruits of which are called ruWuwsu AlX-ayaATiyni, i. e. [the heads] of the serpents, [see XayoTaAnN and zaq-uwmN,] not having leaves: AḤn says that they have [what are termed] hadab [q. v.], their branches do not spread forth, they grow in the manner of the [species of tamarisk called] Oavol, but are not so tall, and mostly grow in the districts of Benoo-Shebábeh. (M.)

entry.sense: SaAmapN, for SawomapN, inf. n. of un. of SaAma: see a verse cited voce taAba, in art. twb.
SawomaAnu: see SaAYimN.
OaroDN SawaAmN Dry land or ground, in which is no water. (Ḳ.)

Saw-aAmN is like SaAYimN but having an intensive signification [i. e. meaning Abstaining, &c., much or often]. (Mṣb.) One says rajulN Saw-aAmN qaw-aAmN, meaning A man who fasts (yaSuwmu) [often] in the day, and who rises [often] in the night [to pray]. (TA.)

SaAYimN Abstaining, in an absolute sense: this is said to be the signification in the proper language of the Arabs: and in the language of the law, observing a particular kind of abstinence; (Mṣb;) [i. e.] abstaining from food (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and drink and coïtus: and, [by a tropical application, (see 1, first sentence,)] ‡ from speech: (M, Ḳ:) it is applied to a man: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) and SawomaAnu↓ signifies the same, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) so applied; (Ṣ;) as also SawomN↓, (M, Ḳ,) applied to a man, (M,) and to a woman, and to two men, (TA,) and to a pl. number; (M, Ḳ;) being an inf. n. used as an epithet; (TA;) or it is a pl., [or rather quasi-pl. n.,] like zaworN: (M voce DayofN:) or, in the proper language of the Arabs, SaAYimN signifies abstaining from eating: and by a secondary application, serving God in a particular manner [by fasting: see again 1, first sentence]: (Mgh:) accord. to AO, it signifies any creature abstaining from food, or † from speech, or † from going along or journeying: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. SiyaAmN and Suw-amN (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Suy-amN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Siy-amN and Suw-aAmN and Suy-aAmN and SayaAmaI, (M, Ḳ,) the last of which [written in the CK SuyaAmaI] is extr. (M.)

Applied to a horse, † Standing still (Ṣ, M, Mṣb) without eating of fodder (Ṣ, Mṣb) or without eating anything: (M:) or abstaining from the eating of fodder: (Mgh:) or standing upon his four legs. (Az in art. Swn, and TA.)
And bakorapN SaAYimapN † A sheave of a pulley that remains still, (Mgh, TA,) that will not revolve. (Ṣ, Mgh, TA.)
And maMCN SaAYimN † Water that is still, or motionless; syn. qaAYimN and daAYimN. (Mgh, TA.)

And maSaAmu Aln-ajomi † The [imaginary] place of suspension of the asterism [meaning the Pleiades]. (M.) Imra-el-Ḳeys says,
kaOan-a Alv-uray-aA Eul-qato fiI maSaAmihaA
biOamoraAsi kat-aAnK UilaI Sum-i janodali
[As though the Pleiades were hung, in their place of suspension, by means of ropes of flax, to hard and solid rocks: i. e. they seemed as though they were stationary: he means that the night was tedious to him]. (Ṣ. [See EM p. 36, where a reading of the former hemistich different from that above is given, with the same and another reading of the latter hemistich.])
One says also, jiYotuhu waAlX-amosu fiI maSaAmihaA, meaning † [I came to him when the sun was] in the middle of the sky. (TA.)
maSaAmapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1. SaAnahu, (M, Ḳ,) first pers. Sunotuhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. yaSuwnuhu, (TA,) inf. n. SawonN and SiyaAnN and SiyaAnapN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He preserved it, kept it, laid it up, took care of it, or reserved it, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) in its repository; (Mṣb;) and ADTAnhu↓ signifies the same: (M, Ḳ:) but one should not say ASAnhu, as the vulgar say. (TA.)

And [hence] one says, (M, Mṣb,) by way of comparison, (M,) SAn EiroDhu, (M, Mṣb,) inf. n. SiyaAnapN and SawonN, (M,) † [He preserved his honour, or reputation], Eani Ald-anasi [from pollution]. (Mṣb. [See also 6.]) And fulaAnN yaSuwnu diybaAjatayohi i. e. ‡ [Such a one preserves from disgrace] his cheeks; (A in art. dbj;) or diybaAjatahu his face. (Ḥar p. 15.)

And SAn Alfarasu Eadowahu (M, TA) and jaroyahu, (TA,) inf. n. SawonN, ‡ The horse reserved somewhat of his running for the time of need. (M, TA.) And farasN lahu SawonN wabacolN; and cuw SawonK waQboticaAlK: see 1 in art. bcl.

And SAn Alfarasu, aor. yaSuwnu, inf. n. SawonN, means Saf-a bayona rijolayohi [app. the same as Saf-a rijolayohi He set his hind legs evenly, side by side]: (M:) or he stood upon the extremity of his hoof, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) by reason of [attenuation, or abrasion, such as is termed] wajFI or HafFA. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And SAn, inf. n. SawonN, He (a horse) limped, or halted, much; (M;) or, as expl. by IB, slightly. (TA.) yaSun-a AlmaXoIa occurs in a verse (Ṣ, M, TA) of En-Nábighah, (M, TA,) [referring to horses,] and J says that Aṣ knew it not, but that others expl. it as meaning Reserving somewhat of the rate of going, (TA,) or as meaning suffering pain in the hoofs from attenuation, or abrasion: (Ṣ:) accord. to IB, it means limping, or halting, and suffering pain in the hoofs, from fatigue. (TA.)
5: see the next paragraph {6}.

6. taSaAwunN is the contr. of AiboticaAlN, (Mṣb,) or of tabac-ulN: (Ṣ and Mṣb in art. bcl:) one says, of a man, taSaAwana and taSaw-ana↓, the latter on the authority of IJ, (M, TA,) and mentioned also by Z, (TA,) † He preserved himself, or his honour, or reputation, (M, TA,) mina AlmaEaAyibi [from the things, or actions, for which he should be blamed], (TA. [See also 1, second sentence.])
8: see 1, first sentence.
SawonN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, M, &c.) See also SiynapN, below.
And see maSuwnN.
SawonapN [A receptacle for perfumes, &c., such as is commonly called] an Eatiydap. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

SiynapN [originally SawonapN] i. q. SawonN↓: one says, hecihi viyaAbu AlS-iynapi i. e. AlS-awoni [These are the garments of reservation for wear on extraordinary occasions]: (M, TA:) contr. of bicolapN. (TA.)

SiwaAnN and SuwaAnN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SawaAnN (Ḳ) and SiyaAnN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and SuyaAnN and SayaAnN, (Ḳ,) but the third and the last two are extr., (TA,) A thing, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or receptacle, (Ṣ,) [or chest or the like,] used as a repository (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) for a garment, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also maSaAnN↓, (Skr, cited by Reiske in Abulf. Ann. ii. 614,) [or for clothes,] or for a thing: (M, Mṣb:)
pl. OSownapN: (MA:) or maSaAnN↓ signifies any place in which one reposits a garment. (TA in art. Drs.)
SawaAniI-u pl. of SiyniI-N. (KL.) See art. Syn.

Saw-aAnN [Flint-stone; and flint-stones: thus in the present day:] a sort of stones, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) in which is hardness; (Mṣb;) hard stones, (M, Ḳ,) of a certain sort, (Ḳ,) with which fire is struck: or, as some say, certain black stones which are not hard: (M:) or a sort of hard stones, which, when fire smites it, crackles (yufaq-iEu) and cracks, and sometimes fire is struck with it, but it is not fit for [making] time, nor for heating for the purpose of roasting thereon: (Az, TA:) one thereof is called Saw-aAnapN↓. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: AlS-aw-aAnapu The dubur [meaning anus]: (Ḳ, TA:) so called because it keeps [from escape] much, or often, what would issue from it. (TA.)
See also Saw-aAnN.

entry.sense: Say-inN [thus app., like say-idN and jay-idN, written in my copy of the Mṣb Sayn] One who preserves his honour, or reputation. (Mṣb.)
maSaAnN: see SiwaAnN, in two places.
muSaAnN: see miSowaAnN.

maSuwnN and maSowuwnN↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like maduwfN and madowuwfN, (Ṣ and Mṣb in art. dwf, q. v.,) the latter of the dial. of Temeem, (M,) Preserved, kept, laid up, taken care of, or reserved; (Ṣ,* M,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied to a garment [&c.]; (Ṣ, M;) as also SawonN↓, which is an inf. n. used. as an epithet: (M:) one should not say muSaAnN, (Ṣ, TA,) nor munoSaAnN, as the vulgar say. (TA.)
miSowaAnN A bow-case; (Ḳ, TA;) as also muSaAnN↓. (TA.)
maSowuwnN: see maSuwnN.

1. Sawati Aln-axolapu, (Lth, Az, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. taSowiI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. SuwiI-N; (Lth, Az, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and Sawiyat, (Az, M, Ḳ,) which is the form preferred by Az, [aor. taSowaI,] inf. n. SawFI; (TA;) The palm-tree needed irrigation, and became slender: (Az, TA:) or became dry, or dried up; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also OaSowat↓, and Saw-at↓: (Ḳ:) and in like manner one says of other trees: and sometimes, of animals. (M.) And SawiIa AlD-aroEu The udder had no milk remaining in it. (Ḥam p. 661.)
[Hence,] Sawati AlX-aApu The ewe, or she-goat, became fat, (Ṣ, TA,) in consequence of her udder's having been made to dry up. (Ṣ.) And SawiIa He became strong. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 2. Sw-I, (M,) inf. n. taSowiyapN, (Ḳ,) primarily, (M,) is used in relation to females, meaning He abstained from milking her, in order that she might become fat, (M, Ḳ,) and not be weak. (M.) You say, Saw-ayotu Aln-aAqapa I abstained from milking the she-camel for some days in order that the milk might collect in her udder so that she might become fat: or I made her milk to dry up, that she might become fatter. (M.) And Saw-ayotu AlX-aApa, inf. n. as above, I made the udder of the ewe, or goat, to become dry, that she might become fatter: (Ṣ:) or Sw-yt Alganama I made the milk of the ewes, or goats, to dry up, purposely, that they might become fatter; like as one says in relation to camels: the subst. from the verb thus used is SawFI↓; and this is said to mean The leaving an animal and not milking her. (M.) Some say that taSowiyapN is like taSoriyapN; and hence the trad., Alt-aSowiyapu xilaAbapN [i. e. The causing the milk to collect in the udder of an animal by abstaining from milking her for some days, when one desires to sell her, is an endeavouring to deceive: but I think that the right reading in this instance is probably Alt-aSoriyapu, with r]. (TA.)

It is also used in relation to a stallion (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of the camels: (Ṣ:) thus it is used by El-Fak'asee. (M.) One says, Saw-ayotu AlfaHola, (M,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) I put no burden upon the stallion [camel], and did not bind him with a rope, in order that he might become more brisk in covering, and more strong; (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ;*) thus expl. by El-'Adebbes El-Kinánee: (Ṣ:) or I exempted him from work, and fed him, until his spirit returned to him, and he became fat. (M.) And Saw-ayotu liUibiliI faHolFA I chose for my camels a stallion, and fed and nourished him for the office of the stallion. (Ṣ.)
See also 1.
[And see art. Sw.]
4: see 1.
One says also ASwI Alqawomu, meaning The people's cattle became lean, or emaciated; like ADwI Alqwm. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)
[See also art. Sw.]

entry.sense: SawFI a subst. from 2, q. v. (M.)
SawK: see its fem., SawiyapN, voce SaAwK.
[Also, app., Empty sunobul (or ears of corn): accord. to the TA (on the authority of Az): the word in this sense, and thus applied, is there written with the article, AlSwI, without any syll. sign.]
Sawiy-apN: see the following paragraph.

SaAwK Dry, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) by reason of thirst, or want of irrigation, or by reason of leanness, or emaciation. (TA.) You say naxolapN SaAwiyapN, (M, Ḳ,) and SawiyapN↓, (M, TA,) [agreeably with rule, as part. n. of Sawiyat,] or Sawiy-apN↓, (so in copies of the Ḳ, [app. a mistranscription,]) A dry, or driedup, palm-tree: (M, Ḳ:) and in like manner one terms other trees: and sometimes, animals: thus the poet Sá'ideh applies the epithet SAwyp to wild cows or wild oxen (baqar waHoX). (M.)
And Strong. (TA.)

1. SaAba aor. yaSiybu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. SayobN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said of an arrow, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) i. q. OaSaAba [expl. in art. Swb]; (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) like SAb having for its aor. yaSuwbu. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb.)
SayobaAnN: see SawobN, in art. Swb.
SuyaAbN: see Suy-aAbapN.
SayuwbN An arrow going right, or hitting the mark: pl. SuyubN (M, Ḳ) and SiyaAbN, (MF, TA,) or the latter is pl. of SaAYibN, which signifies the same. (M, in art. Swb.)
SuyaAbapN: see Suy-aAbapN.
Say-ibN: see art. Swb.
Suy-aAbN: see Suy-aAbapN, in four places.
Say-uwbN: see art. Swb.

Sub-aAbapN and Suy-aAbN↓ (M, A, Ḳ) and SubaAbapN↓ and SuyaAbN↓ (A, Ḳ) The OaSol (M, A, Ḳ) [as meaning the original stock] of a people, (M,) or [as meaning the original, or the principal, or most essential, part,] of a thing: (A, Ḳ:) and the purest, or choice, or best, part or portion, (M,* A, Ḳ,) of a thing (M, Ḳ) of any kind, (M,) or of a people. (A.) One says, huwa fiI Suy-aAbapi qawomihi and Suy-aAbihimo↓ He is of the OaSol [or original stock] of his people: (Fr, TA:) and mino Suy-aAbapi qawomihi and Suw-aAbapi qwmh (TA) and mino Suy-aAbihimo↓ (A) of the purest in race of his people. (A,* TA.) And qawomN Suy-aAbN↓ A choice, or an excellent, people. (TA.)
Also the first, The collective body of a people; (Kr, M;) and so Suw-aAbapN. (M in art. Swb.)
And A lord, master, or chief. (M, Ḳ.)
SiytN and SiytapN: see art. Swt.
Say-itN: see art. Swt.

1. SaAHa, (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, &c.,) aor. yaSiyHu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) inf. n.
